'X' marks the spot when coding with ICD-10

One major difference between ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM is the addition of a seventh character. This seventh digit is used in certain ICD-10 codes to provide additional information about the encounter (e.g., initial encounter vs. subsequent encounter).

It's important to understand that when an ICD-10-CM code contains a seventh digit, you must always report the appropriate digit in the seventh character position. So when a code is shorter than seven characters but contains a digit in the seventh character position, coders must report the code with an appropriate seventh character value in order to be valid. In these cases, X will act as a placeholder.

This addition of placeholder “X” is used in certain codes to:

  • Allow for future expansion
  • Fill out empty characters when a code contains fewer than six characters and a seventh character applies

For example, when reporting "dislocation, jaw, subsequent encounter" in ICD-10-CM, you should report code S03.0xxD. Because the code is only four characters long and it requires a seventh character, it's important to report placeholder “X” in the fifth and sixth character positions.
ICD-10 puts a new twist on Excludes notes

Coders who are accustomed to the current ICD-9 Manual know to interpret the Includes and Excludes notes in the different diagnosis categories when they’re looking for the appropriate code. When the patient’s condition is listed in the Includes notes, that’s a good indication that you are in the right place. However, when you see the patient’s condition described in the Excludes notes, then you better keep looking because you’re in the wrong place.

The ICD-10 coding system, however, uses Excludes1 and Excludes2 notes. What’s the difference?

Excludes1 is referred to as a pure Excludes note. When a patient’s condition is described in an Excludes1 note, it means that you are definitely looking at the wrong category of codes. It means that the patient’s condition is “NOT CODED HERE!” Not only that, but your patient cannot have both the Excludes1 diagnosis at the same time as the condition described by that particular category of codes. They are mutually exclusive from one another (e.g. an acquired and a congenital form of the same disease).

An Excludes2 note indicates that a patient may very well have this condition as well as the condition in that particular category of codes. But if that’s the case, the condition in the Excludes 2 list is not coded in this section of codes, and you will have to look elsewhere in the ICD-10 Manual to code that specific condition.
Special report from the ICD-10 Summit: The perfect storm is brewing

The message was loud and clear. On April 12, during one of the kick-off sessions at the 2010 American Health Information Management Association (AHIMA) ICD-10 Summit in Washington, DC, speakers drove home the point that a perfect storm is brewing with four enormous initiatives:

  • ICD-10
  • HIPAA 5010
  • 2009 American Recovery and Reinvestment Act/Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act
  • 2010 Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act

Elaine Lips, RHIA, president and CEO of ELIPSe Inc., in Los Angeles and Deborah Kohn, MPH, RHIA, FACHE, CPHIMS, principal at Dak Systems Consulting in San Mateo, CA, explained how "strategic planning must begin yesterday for the convergence of these four enormous technology, process, and people iniatives."

These four initiatives are inter-related, so why plan separately? Both Lips and Kohn recommended the following enterprise impact assessment and road map:

  1. Develop a strategic process: This includes governance structure as well as project plans and communication plans.
  2. Perform an inventory: This is from both a technical and operational standpoint (e.g., vendors, health plans, business processes and workflows).
  3. Assess readiness/perform a gap analysis: Again, from both a technical and operational perspective.
  4. Plan education and training: Answer the questions who, what, where, when, and how as they relate to educating your staff members in the coding/HIM department as well as other departments.
  5. Analyze costs and prepare a budget: You need to allocate costs across several years and analyze staffing implications.
  6. Develop an implementation plan: Come up with a realistic timeline, go-live preparation requirements, a communication plan, detailed checklists for HIM and revenue cycle management, and an IT implementation process guide.

This is just the tip of the iceberg. Stay tuned for more buzz and insider tips from the ICD-10 Summit!
ICD-10 Summit speaker shares budget strategies

Budgeting for ICD-10 requires much more than just planning for the actual implementation. What happens to your business after the go-live date (October 1, 2013 in case you haven't heard!) once you've started submitting claims?

"You have to think about how to sustain your business far into the future after implementation," said Tori Sullivan, MHA, RHIA, PMP, healthcare sector manager at Capgemini in Herndon, VA, during a presentation on day two of the American Health Information Management Association (AHIMA) 2010 ICD-10 Summit in Washington, DC.

And if you need one more reason to convince you to start planning for implementation now, Sullivan made the point that there are dollars attached to all the necessary steps in your plan. So if you don't complete a particular step in the planned time period and you have to move that step to the next year, for example, you're moving all the costs associated with that step to the next year as well, Sullivan explained.

"So that's why if you start this year, you can spread costs out over multiple years," Sullivan said during the session.

When you form your budget, Sullivan said it's critical to consider the costs associated with the following:

  • Hardware
  • Software
  • Training
  • Communication
  • Contractor support
  • Loss of revenue/productivity

Stay tuned to ICD-10 Watch and JustCoding.com for more details from ICD-10 Summit sessions about coder education and training.

Did you attend the summit? What was the most interesting or surprising thing you learned? Post a comment or e-mail me at dbentley@hcpro.com.
AHIMA issues practice brief about GEMs

Still trying to understand how to use CMS' General Equivalancy Mappings (GEMs)? The American Health Information Management Association (AHIMA) issued a lengthy practice brief titled, "Putting the ICD-10-CM/PCS GEMs Into Practice" to shed some light on the topic.

In addition to explaining why the forward and backward mappings are not mirror images of each other (because all translation alternatives are based on the meaning and level of specificity of the code in the source system), the practice brief addresses:

  • How to apply GEMs for different purposes
  • How GEMs should not be used
  • How to select the GEM to use
  • Tips for developing applied mappings

To view this practice brief in its entirety, click here. Then click on “All current practice briefs in chronological order by publication date” and scroll down to the brief.

Many ICD-10 authorities agree that there are a number of myths and misconceptions floating around about the transition to this new coding system. So why not get information straight from the horse's mouth. Check out the following CMS FAQs related to ICD-10:

  1. The information in the introductions to the General Equivalence Mappings (GEM) points out that, in some cases, there is a clear one-to-one match between an International Classification of Diseases, 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) code and an International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition (ICD-10)-CM or ICD-10-Procedure Coding System (PCS) code. However, one ICD-9-CM code often translates to several ICD-10-CM or ICD-10-PCS codes because of the nature of going from the more general ICD-9-CM to the more specific ICD-10. Please describe the methodology that was used to create the GEMs.


  2. Why do the General Equivalency Mappings (GEM) go in both directions (from International Classification of Diseases, 9th Edition, Clinical Modification [ICD-9-CM] to International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition (ICD-10) and from ICD-10 back to ICD-9-CM)?


  3. For what period of time following International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition (ICD-10) implementation on October 1, 2013 will the General Equivalence Mappings (GEM) be updated?


  4. When do you anticipate that an International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition (ICD-10) version of the Medicare Severity Diagnosis Related Groups (MS-DRG) will be completed and posted on the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services website?


  5. Are there any instances when there is no translation between an International Classification of Diseases, 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) code and an International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition (ICD-10) code? How do the General Equivalency Mappings handle this situation?


  6. What methodology is being used in the Medicare Severity Diagnosis Related Groups (MS-DRG) International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition (ICD-10) conversion?


  7. We were told that validation of the General Equivalence Mappings (GEM) is occurring as part of the conversion of the current International Classification of Diseases, 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM)-based Medicare Severity Diagnosis Related Groups (MS-DRG) to International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition (ICD-10)-based MS-DRGs. How does this process identify any potential updates that might be needed to the GEMs? Will the GEMs be updated to correct any inaccuracies discovered in this process?


  8. How soon after a code has been added or deleted will the General Equivalence Mappings (GEM) be updated to reflect these changes?


  9. Were the General Equivalence Mappings (GEM) designed for use by all providers and payers or was the focus on use with Medicare data?


  10. What process was used to develop the General Equivalency Mappings (GEM)? Did the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) seek input from organizations such as the American Hospital Association (AHA) and the American Health Information Management Association (AHIMA) regarding the development of the GEMs? Did development of the GEMs involve both clinical and coding evaluations?


  11. Can ICD-9-CM procedure codes be reported on hospital outpatient claims? If I use HCPCS codes to report hospital outpatient services at the “required” service line level segment for a claim, may I use the ICD-9-CM procedure codes to report hospital outpatient services at the claim level “situational” segment?


  12. Does HIPAA permit the use of V codes? Is their use consistent with OASIS requirements?


  13. What are some of the key changes between Version 4010/4010A and Version 5010?


  14. Why is the Version 5010/D.0 (CMS-0009-F) final rule important at this time?


To stay abreast of recent updates, go to the CMS FAQ page, and type in "ICD-10" in the search field.
Don't let alphanumeric soup cause confusion

In a recent ICD-10 Watch post, we asked blog subscribers to see if they could stump their peers with their own ICD-10 quiz question. See if you can answer this question submitted by Asad Ali Rizvi of Quadax Inc:

Because ICD-10-CM is alphanumeric, what should you keep in mind about the code structure to avoid confusion between the letter "I" and the number "1", and the letter "O" versus the number "0" when they appear in ICD-10 codes?

Do you think you know the answer? Post a comment, and check back with ICD-10 Watch later this week to see the answer.
And the answer to our alphanumeric soup question is ...

Earlier this week, we posted the following ICD-10 pop quiz question submitted by Asad Ali Rizvi of Quadax Inc:

Because ICD-10-CM is alphanumeric, what should you keep in mind about the code structure to avoid confusion between the letter "I" and the number "1", and the letter "O" versus the number "0" when they appear in ICD-10 codes?

The answer is (drumroll please) ... the first character of an ICD-10-CM code can only be the letter "I" or "O." If it is not the first character, it can only be number "1" or "0."

The first character in ICD-10-CM codes is always an alpha character. Neither "I" nor "O" appear anywhere else in an ICD-10-CM code.

If you have an ICD-10 question that you think might stump fellow ICD-10 Watch subscribers, e-mail your question to dbentley@hcpro.com.
A code to remember: Suzy Buys Root Beer At Dairy Queen

ICD-10-PCS is drastically different from the ICD-9-CM Volume 3 procedure codes. Just looking at the physical appearance, you’ll see that the procedure codes in ICD-9-CM have a maximum of four digits (e.g., XX.XX). But ICD-10-PCS, which has no decimal points, has seven characters (e.g., XXXXXXX) that can be numbers or letters.

Not only do the ICD-10-PCS codes look different, but they also they provide a tremendous amount of specificity that is sorely lacking in the current ICD-9-CM procedure codes. Coders will likely get used to what each of the characters represent (with lots of practice), but it will definitely take some getting used to! For example, let’s see what each character represents in the medical/surgical sections:

  • 1st character – Section
  • 2nd character – Body system
  • 3rd character – Root operation
  • 4th character – Body part
  • 5th character – Approach
  • 6th character – Device
  • 7th character – Qualifier

When I was in grade school, I used to come up with a mnemonic to remember something that I would likely forget -- especially when it was something that needed to be in a particular order, such as this code structure for ICD-10-PCS. So I started trying to think of a catchy and easy way to remember what each character stands for in the medical/surgical sections. Albeit a first round try, I came up with “Suzy Buys Root Beer At Dairy Queen.” Although there are two Bs, hopefully I will remember that "body system" comes before "body part."

In addition to remembering the various characters, in ICD-10-PCS physicians may state anatomical sites in the documentation, but you must map these descriptions to a PCS definition. For example:

  • Teres minor muscle → Shoulder muscle, right
  • Teres minor muscle → Shoulder muscle, left

I don’t know about all of you out there reading this, but I think some coders may have trouble remembering where the teres minor muscle is in the body and will likely have to use anatomy illustrations and other such references for a good while. 

The medical surgical section provides specifics that exceed what we are used to in ICD-9-CM. For example, let’s say we were trying to code for an open diagnostic biopsy of the left teres minor muscle. In ICD-9-CM, the code (83.21) simply states "biopsy of soft tissue" and gives no specifics about the anatomical site involved. But in ICD-10-PCS, we’d have to know that the teres minor muscle is classified as a shoulder muscle to assign the correct body part for code assignment. To code for this, we would assign:

  • 0 – Medical and surgical (section)
  • K – Muscles (body system)
  • B – Excision (root operation)
  • 6 – Shoulder muscle, left (body part)
  • 0 – Open (approach)
  • Z – No device (device)
  • X – Diagnostic  (qualifier)

This may be very hard for coders to get used to without referencing a table or other reference. The vessels, nerves, muscles, and tendons seem to be the most challenging because in ICD-10-PCS, we will have to rely upon an Appendix or some other reference to assist in mapping anatomical terms to the correct PCS definition. I have a feeling we are all going to rely a lot on encoders and other such references to make sure we are assigning the correct body “part” code for procedures involving such anatomical sites.
Coding for services that straddle October 1 implementation

Aside from emphasizing that October 1, 2013, will be the date that everyone will begin to use ICD-10, Pat Brooks, senior technical advisor at CMS, explained the following during the March 23 ICD-10 National Provider Call:

If you were working in an ambulatory care center or a physician office and you see patients on October 1, 2013, on that date you must start coding your diagnoses in ICD-10. If you were in a hospital inpatient setting, for patients discharged on or after October 1, 2013, that will be the date that you must begin using ICD-10 codes. ... We do acknowledge that some of you may be coding bills that are a little after the fact, and say for August, maybe you do not submit bills until October or November. And we do know that payers will be receiving ICD-9 codes for over a period of time. But they will be ICD-9 codes for services prior to October 1, 2013.

On a related note, Brooks also clarified how claims for which providers are having issues (e.g., corrected claims) will be handled after October 1, 2013:

For claims for services that occur before October 1, 2013, you will always use ICD-9 codes. You will use that even if you send those bills in a couple of months late. So it’s not on the date you submit the claims, it’s on the date the service was provided that determines which coding system you would use. So those that you were still working on that happened in say September 2013, those will be ICD-9 codes.

Another caller posed the following question:

Providers tend to try to get prior authorizations from insurance companies in advance of providing the services. So I could see us trying to submit a prior authorization to cover a transaction in September for a service delivered in October that we will then bill sometime after October 1. Will a health plan be allowed to require the ICD-10 earlier for that purpose?

Pat Brooks provided the following response:

We are working on it internally, and I believe others are going to work on giving you specific instructions for how to handle these things that are within days of implementation. I don't know that we at CMS and others have a firm answer for you, but it’s one of the issues that we definitely are going to work on program instructions on. ... If you have a bill for services for DME or whatever that spans a date, then we are working on instructions on how we’ll handle those. But for those inpatient scenarios where patients are discharged after October 1, 2013, that’s really clear. We have really clear guidance--it’s the date of discharge, not the date they're admitted.

Access the presentation and transcript for this call on the CMS Web site.

A round-up of the latest ICD-10 resources

For example, the American Health Information Management Association's website has posted important tasks for the following HIM/coding professionals and the associated timelines for completing these tasks:

  • Inpatient coders
