Do you have an ICD-10 resource that you want to share with fellow ICD-10 Watch subscribers? Please post a comment, and include any appropriate links.

In ICD-9-CM, you can find the burn codes in the range of codes 940-949. If you were to try to find a code due to a corrosive burn, the Alphabetic index would direct you back to the main term "burn."

However, ICD-10-CM distinguishes between burns and corrosions. The burn codes are for thermal burns (except sunburns) that come from a heat source (e.g., fire, hot appliance). The burn codes are also for burns resulting from electricity and radiation. Corrosions are burns due to chemicals, and in ICD-10-CM they will have codes that are unique from the other burn codes. You will be able to distinguish between codes for burns and code for corrosions by looking at the first digit after the decimal point (Txx.x). If this digit is 0-3, the injury is due to a thermal burn. If this digit is 4 or higher, that indicates that the injury is due to a corrosion or chemical burn.
How will providers and payers apply the three-day rule?

At the recent American Health Information Management Association ICD-10 Summit in Washington, DC, several attendees were heard discussing the 3-day rule (sometimes called the 72-hour rule), specifically the question of how will providers and payers handle the transition on October 1, 2013, when ICD-10 takes effect.

Simply stated, under current Medicare regulations all diagnostic services, such as labs and x-rays, furnished within the three days immediately preceding and including the date of inpatient admission are included on the inpatient claim and not separately billable.

CMS has identified outpatient services that are to be considered diagnostic by the revenue code. All other services not on the revenue code list are considered “non-diagnostic” and are only billable on the inpatient claim when there is an exact match between the first-listed diagnosis code on the outpatient claim and the principal diagnosis code on the inpatient claim.

CMS has continued to reiterate that an exact diagnostic match must extend to the fifth code digit, and meeting the requirements has nothing to do with whether the outpatient service led to the inpatient admission.

With that said, as we flip the switch to ICD-10 for all services on October 1, 2013, what will happen with outpatient services that fall within the 3-day rule between September 28-30? The outpatient claims will reference ICD-9 codes and the inpatient claims will reference ICD-10, and we know that there won’t be an exact diagnostic match between the two.

So the question is will providers be required to “translate” those non-diagnostic outpatient services that qualify for consideration of the 3-day rule into ICD-10 to determine whether there is an exact diagnostic match? Or will CMS give the providers a “free pass” for those three days and not apply the rule because ICD-10 does not take effect until October 1. So to require translation would be a conflict with their own ruling.

Then again, CMS may completely change the 3-day rule between now and then, making this a non-issue. Something to think about as this is just one of the many questions that will arise as we approach 2013.
Time flies when we're having fun

Can you believe it has been about 18 months since the Department of Health and Human Services announced in the Federal Register that ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS would be implemented on October 1, 2013? It seems like just yesterday that we were all talking about how we would tackle this massive project, from converting our data to training our staff as well as ourselves about its effects on reimbursement and beyond.

Since that day in January 2009, so many other issues  have emerged that appear to have more of a current urgency than dealing with the “2013 pound gorilla” in the room. We can try to ignore it, we can walk around it or over it, we can even try to put it on the shelf or lock it in a closet, but the reality is that time always flies when we are having so much fun!

So where should we be in our planning? Among the many details, anyone who assigns codes or manages data should be becoming familiar with the General Equivalence Mappings (GEM). The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act that was signed into law this March requires that the GEM crosswalk between ICD-9 and ICD-10 be recognized as a HIPPA code set standard; however, keep in mind that the GEMS are not a substitute for understanding the ICD-10 codes themselves.

Also, data managers should be collaborating with their vendors and information technology departments to plan for key milestones for data conversion, testing, and software updates. Coders should also become familiar with the structure and organization of ICD-10. By this time, health plans should be developing their strategies for how to comply with the 5010 requirements so that testing can begin in 2011. And we all should be continuing to develop our budgets as new issues arise and future costs become more clear.

For those of you who may be waiting for a solution to find you, be cautious about waiting too long. Now is a good time to network with other facilities, professional organizations, hospital associations, vendors, and the like to pool expertise, share creative solutions, and resources. October 1, 2013 will be here sooner than you think.

As we continue our journey toward ICD-10 implementation, certified coders will need to show their proficiency in the new coding system. For holders of an American Academy of Professional Coders (AAPC) credential, all certified coders will have the opportunity to take the ICD-10 proficiency exam starting in October 2012 and must successfully complete the test by September 30, 2014. The 75-question test will be a timed, online proficiency exam. The AAPC hasn’t decided whether the exam will be multiple choice, but I am guessing that it will be. The test will be open book, and coders have the opportunity to take it twice for the $60 fee. AAPC will require its certified coders to pass this test to retain their certification.

For holders of a credential from the  American Health Information Management Association (AHIMA), continuing education hours with ICD-10-CM/PCS content will be required, as applicable and relevant to the specific AHIMA credential(s) held by the individual. AHIMA certified professionals are required to participate in a predetermined number of mandatory baseline educational experiences specific to ICD-10-CM/PCS. These specific CEUs will count as part of the total required CEUs, by credential, per CEU cycle. So for example, if you hold an RHIA credential with AHIMA, you are required to have at least 6 CEUs dedicated to ICD 10-CM/PCS; 12 for the CCS-P credential; 18 for the CCS credential, etc. Certificants who hold more than one AHIMA credential are required to report only the highest number of CEUs from among all credentials held. For example, if an individual has both an RHIA and CCS, he or she would normally report 50 CEUs per recertification cycle, and 18 of those CEUs will be required to cover ICD-10-CM/PCS. AHIMA certified professionals may begin earning ICD-10-specific CEUs after January 1, 2011.

Both organizations have promised to release more information about their ICD-10 proficiency requirements later this year.
CMS issues Special Edition MLN Matters article about ICD-10

On June 23, CMS issued MLN Matters Special Edition article #SE1019, which is intended to provide healthcare entities more information about the implementation of ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS.

In addition to outlining implementation compliance dates all providers should be aware of, the article also addresses the code structure of ICD-10-CM and the following new features of this code set:

  • Laterality
  • Combination codes for certain conditions and common associated symptoms and manifestations
  • Combination codes for poisonings and their associated external cause
  • Character 'x' is used as a fifth character placeholder in certain six character codes to allow for future expansion and to fill in other empty characters when a code that is less than six characters in length requires a seventh character
  • Two types of excludes notes
  • Inclusion of clinical concepts that do not exist in ICD-9-CM
  • A number of codes have been significantly expanded
  • Codes for postoperative complications have been expanded and a distinction made between intraoperative complications and postprocedural complications

You can also learn more about ICD-10-PCS and the use and structure of this code set by accessing MLN Matters Special Edition article #SE1019.
How will the DCA intensify financial impact when we switch to ICD-10?

I was reading a recent Medicare Payment Advisory Commission (MedPAC) letter to CMS commenting on the 2011 inpatient prospective payment system proposed (IPPS) rule, specifically their recommendations to recoup “overpayments” with interest and prevent the “unintended increases” in payments that have occurred since PPS hospitals moved from DRGs to MS-DRGs in 2008.

One of the goals of MS-DRGs was to make payments that took into consideration the differences in patients’ severities of illness while being budget neutral – basically paying a lesser MS-DRG for a patient with a less severe illness and paying a higher MS-DRG for a patient with a higher severity of illness. Unfortunately, the system did not work out exactly as planned. Hospitals understood that if they improved their documentation and ICD-9 code assignment, not only did they improve their statistical reporting, but they also improved their payments with very little change to the cost of the care that was provided to the patient.

In anticipation of this, one of the ways CMS is required by law to make adjustments to MS-DRG payments is by using the Documentation and Coding Adjustment (DCA). Remember, we did not have one in fiscal year 2011, so what will future DCA adjustments bring to the flawed MS-DRG system?

Between now and 2013 when ICD-10 is implemented, any adjustments made need to both recover the overpayments with interest since 2008 and prevent overpayments in the future. MedPAC has projected that the cumulative overpayments through 2012 will be more than $19 billion – wow! The DCA and other payment adjustments will not only affect those hospitals that have put a lot effort into improving their documentation to increase their payments, but also those hospitals that did not tackle their documentation issues and have actually seen a decrease in payments with the implementation of MS-DRGs.

So what happens on October 1, 2013 when we flip the switch to ICD-10? Even with the most diligent of efforts to get medical staff members and coders trained in ICD-10, we can probably expect a decrease in our case mix and therefore a decrease in our payments. If we are already paying back our debt for the MS-DRG overpayment snafu, how much more of a decrease will hospitals be able to absorb during this transition? Some food for thought as we move toward ICD-10.
ACDIS submits comment to CMS opposing code freeze

The Association of Clinical Documentation Improvement Specialists (ACDIS) recently submitted a comment to CMS explaining its position against the proposed code freeze. ACDIS' comment stated the following:

ACDIS strongly opposes the proposal to freeze changes to the ICD-9-CM coding system effective for fiscal year 2012. Accurate, specific code assignment is a prerequisite for accurate physician and hospital profiling and value-based purchasing. Since hospitals will have their risk-adjusted outcomes measured, and physicians will have their efficiency measured, CMS needs to work vigorously with the ICD-9 cooperating parties to encourage higher specificity of diagnoses.

ACDIS notes that the Institute of Medicine will soon publish its recommendations influencing how CMS will implement its hospital and physician value-based purchasing program. Click on this link to view Kathleen Sebelius’s letter announcing this report.

In a listening session regarding physician value-based purchasing sponsored by CMS last fall, ICD-10’s weakness in establishing an episodic grouping methodology was fully discussed. View a transcript of this discussion on the CMS website.

ACDIS notes that ICD-10-CM is an imperfect system and that refinements to ICD-9-CM should be carried over to ICD-10 prior to its implementation date of October 1, 2013. For example, ICD-10 has only one code for coronary artery disease and not separate codes for one, two, or three vessels. This harms the ability to predict risk-adjusted outcomes in patients with ischemic coronary artery disease. ICD-10 also does not account for uncontrolled diabetes or malignant hypertension, for example.

The best interest of the United States is a code set that allows providers to capture this and other critical data. ACDIS is on the ground working with coded data as it relates to quality, coding, case management, and compliance. Upgrades should therefore be made to both code sets simultaneously. A code freeze would deny that opportunity.

ACDIS urges CMS to continue to work on refining ICD-9 and mapping those changes to ICD-10. We encourage CMS to continue to be proactive in refining ICD-10 for the purpose of physician and hospital value-based purchasing.
Coding Clinic does not plan to convert previous guidance

If you've been wondering whether the American Hospital Association (AHA) plans to convert guidance it has published in Coding Clinic over the years to include ICD-10 codes, the answer is no.

"I am glad that the AHA has stated what their plans will be in regards to Coding Clinic," said Shannon E. McCall, RHIA, CCS, CCS-P, CPC-I, CCDS, director of coding and HIM at HCPro, Inc., in Marblehead, MA. "I am a bit surprised that they are not converting the past issues to ICD-10, but at the same time not surprised because we are talking about 26 years worth of information!"

In the Coding Clinic, second quarter, 2010 issue that the AHA just mailed out last week, there is an insert introducing the AHA Coding Clinic for ICD-10 Briefing Series. With each issue of AHA's Coding Clinic each quarter, this new briefing series will highlight different aspects of ICD-10.

Nelly Leon-Chisen, RHIA, director of coding and classification at the American Hospital Association, shared with me the insert, which states in part:

There are no plans to translate all previous issues of Coding Clinic for ICD-9-CM into ICD-10-CM/PCS since many of the questions published arose out of the need to provide clarification on the use of ICD-9-CM and would not be readily applicable to ICD-10-CM/PCS. As we get closer to the ICD-10 implementation date, we will announce when the AHA Central Office will begin to accept and process ICD-10-CM/PCS coding questions based on real medical records.

McCall says she thinks the AHA may use the past guidance as a starting point in these early issues of the new briefing series to start building the source authority over the next three years.

"I can see, for example, converting the major concepts like the coding of hypertension and chronic kidney disease to ICD-10 codes," McCall says. "The direct cause and effect relationship is a longstanding coding concept which would likely still be the case in ICD-10."

For more information about ICD-10 from the AHA, access the AHA website.
A word about external cause codes

Many of the changes to the 2010 ICD-9-CM codes were additions to the external causes of injury and poisoning E codes (E800–E999). Activity codes were added to give context as to what the person was doing when they sustained the injury. Another subcategory, the Activity Status codes, were also new additions.

With ICD-10, you would assign a code from category Y99 to indicate the work status of the person at the time the event occurred. The status code indicates whether the event occurred during military activity, whether a non-military person was at work, whether an individual including a student or volunteer was involved in a non-work activity at the time of the causal event. The external cause status codes are not applicable to poisonings, adverse effects, misadventures, or late effects.
Recognize the value and purpose of GEMs

The network of relationships between the ICD-9-CM and the ICD-10-CM code sets is named the General Equivalence Mappings (GEMs). It’s like trying to translate from one language to another. Sometimes there is an exact word match, and sometimes there isn’t. For example, the Eskimo has 52 names for snow. In English, we pretty much just have one word: snow! Similarly, a code set may not be able to seamlessly link the codes in one set to identical counterparts in the other code set.

There is no simple crosswalk from ICD-9 to ICD-10 in the GEM files. A mapping that forces a simple correspondence - each ICD-9 code mapped only once to a code in ICD-10 - defeats the purpose of upgrading to the new and improved ICD-10 coding system. Instead of a simple crosswalk, the GEM files attempt to organize differences in a meaningful way, by linking a code to all valid alternatives in the other code set from which choices can be made.
Have you started talking with your vendors?

October 1, 2013 is not the only deadline to be concerned with. If you submit electronic claims, you should complete internal testing with Version 5010 by January 1, 2011 so that you are prepared for external testing with payers, clearinghouses, billing services, and other business partners.

And by January 1, 2012, providers need to be fully compliant with Version 5010 standards if they conduct electronic transactions either directly or through a clearinghouse or billing service.

Having conversations with your vendors is a critical step to ensure that you can meet these deadlines. Check out CMS' fact sheet titled "Talking to Your Vendors About ICD-10 and Version 5010" for tips on what you need to discuss with your vendors.

Have you already started talking with your vendors? Post a comment and share your tips here.
On August 13, register for ICD-9 Coordination & Maintenance Meeting

Mark your calendars because on August 13, you'll have the opportunity to register for the September 15-16  ICD-9-CM Coordination & Maintenance Committee Meeting in Washington, DC.

As required by the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act and the Reconciliation Act of 2010, the Coordination & Maintenance Committee must convene before January 1, 2011, to receive stakeholder input regarding the crosswalk between the Ninth and Tenth Revisions of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-9 and ICD-10, respectively)  for the purpose of making appropriate revisions to the crosswalk.

According to the FY 2011 inpatient prospective payment system final rule that CMS issued July 30, a final decision on whether or not there will be a partial code freeze will be announced at this ICD-9-CM Coordination and Maintenance Committee. CMS will post an agenda for this meeting on its Web site by mid-August.

Registration is not required for those dialing in to the meeting by phone.

Access the complete Federal Register notice, or go to CMS' ICD-10 webpage and click on the ICD-9 Coordination & Maintenance Committee link page on the left to learn more.
My ICD-10-PCS Manual ... it's a page-turner!

OK, so maybe your ICD-10-PCS  (Draft) Manual doesn't rank up there with your most memorable reads, however, you can't deny that it's a page-turner! Sometimes, it may seem like you can't find the option you're looking for in terms of assigning the fourth character in an ICD-10-PCS code, for example, but the correct fourth character may be just on the next page.

Now that you will need to reference tables to assign the appropriate ICD-10-PCS codes, it's critical that you don't forget that sometimes these tables are not contained on a single page.  Check the next page for additional options when selecting the appropriate values for the different characters in ICD-10-PCS codes.

For example, consider ICD-10-PCS code 0CTS0ZZ, which involves the larynx. When I look at the table for code category 0CT in my 2010 (Draft) ICD-10-PCS Manual, I don't immediately see any fourth character option for a procedure that involved the larynx. However, when I turn the page, I see not only the character option for larynx, but I also see six additional fourth character options for other body parts.

So if you ever find yourself poring through your code options in your 2010 (Draft) ICD-10-PCS Manual and it starts to feel like you're in the middle of a cliffhanger with no resolution in sight, don't forget that the answer may be waiting for you on the next page.

Although I'm sure these great contributors to the field of medicine will live on in many other publications, ICD-10-PCS coding manuals will no longer include eponyms. So you not only need to be concerned with getting your physicians to document more details about the procedures they perform (e.g., the approach), but you also need to review their documentation habits. Make sure that you pass along word to your physicians and coders about this change, and also consider drafting a policy that outlines this important difference in assigning ICD-9 procedure codes vs. ICD-10-PCS codes so your staff members are aware going forward, not just during the transition to ICD-10.

Keep in mind that if your physicians are in the habit of using eponyms, chances are that your coders are also used to recognizing procedures by these alternative names. So make sure your coders brush up on their clinical understanding of procedures for which physicians usually use eponyms.

So, by now you know ICD-10-CM codes contain more specificity than many ICD-9-CM codes. After all, we’re going from 13,000 codes to 68,000 codes. So where will that increased specificity show up?

One place is stage of care. With ICD-10-CM, physician will have to document what stage of care he or she provides. For instance, the physician will have to document whether the encounter is an initial visit, a subsequent encounter, or sequela. Coders will need this information in order to select the appropriate seventh digit.

For more on the stages of care and other documentation challenges, check out “The top 10 documentation tips for ICD-10-CM: The devil is in the details” on JustCoding.com. This article is our free spotlight article until Sept. 1, then it will be available only to JustCoding.com members.
ICD-10 Watch takes planning to the next level with ICD-10 Trainer!

As 2011 approaches, it’s time to take planning for ICD-10 to the next level. Over the last few years, we've been watching as activity related to ICD-10 has started to ramp up. Perhaps some of you already have an organized task force and have started implementing various stages of your transition plan. We're striving to keep you abreast of not just what you should be planning for, but now what you need to start learning about the new coding system: the code structure, necessary documentation, the codes themselves, and so much more.

So in the spirit of this more intense phase of planning and implementation, ICD-10 Watch has undergone a name change to ICD-10 Trainer!

To make getting information more convenient for our readers, we are also launching a free, e-newsletter companion to this blog, which is also named ICD-10 Trainer. To learn more or to sign up for the new companion e-newsletter, visit HCPro's Healthcare Marketplace.
Codes will change, so will your contracts

The switch to ICD-10-CM will change more than just your code choices. It will also change how physician offices practice medicine.

All of your offices' policies will have to be revised to fit ICD-10-CM, says Rhonda Buckholtz, CPC, CPC-I, CGSC, COBGC, CEPDC, CENTC, vice president of business and member development for the American Academy of Professional Coders in Salt Lake City, UT.

You’ll also have to review all of your health plan contracts. If anything needs to be changed in those contracts, do it now, Buckholtz recommends. Don’t wait until September 2013 to look at those contracts or you could end up missing out on some reimbursement.
Fracture coding with ICD-10 requires knowledge of Gustilo-Anderson scale

When coding with ICD-10, there may be terms that neither your coders nor your physicians are used to using. Now is the time to pass on this knowledge to your medical staff so they can understand what details they'll need to document for coders to be able to accurately assign ICD-10 codes. Note the following excerpt from a July 21 JustCoding article:

Consider the Gustilo-Anderson classification of fractures. "I had never heard of this before," said Margaret Skurka, MS, RHIA, CCS, FAHIMA, professor and director of HIM programs at Indiana University Northwest in Gary, IN, who presented in April a session titled “The Road to an ICD-10 Proficient Coding Staff” at the American Health Information Management Association’s ICD-10 Summit in Washington, DC. "I asked my friend’s husband, who is an orthopedic surgeon, how often he had used the Gustilo-Anderson classification, and he said, 'Twice in 25 years.'"

This is a clear example of conversations that need to take place, not only with your coders, but also with your physicians, to make sure your organization has the best chance for a smooth transition in 2013.

Note the following Gustilo-Anderson classifications:

  • Type I: The wound is smaller than 1 cm, clean, and generally caused by a fracture fragment that pierces the skin (i.e., inside-out injury). This is a low-energy injury.
  • Type II: The wound is longer than 1 cm, not contaminated, and without major soft tissue damage or defect. This is also a low-energy injury.
  • Type III: The wound is longer than 1 cm, with significant soft tissue disruption. The mechanism often involves high-energy trauma, resulting in a severely unstable fracture with varying degrees of fragmentation.

So spread the word among both coders and physicians, and take advantage of this time before ICD-10 takes effect by working on potential documentation shortcomings. Do you know of other documentation details that are required to code with ICD-10? Post your comment here!
Coding to the highest degree of certainty

One of the things that is not changing between ICD-9 and ICD-10—which often takes hospital coders by surprise—is that coders of professional services cannot code diagnoses documented with the terms “probable,” “suspected,” “questionable,” “rule out,” “working diagnosis,” or other similar verbiage to indicate uncertainty. Instead, they can only code the condition(s) to the highest degree of certainty for that service, such as symptoms, signs, or abnormal test results.

Coders of professional services may also code all documented conditions that coexist at the time of the service and require or affect patient care, treatment, or management. Conditions that were previously treated and no longer exist should not be coded. However, history codes (categories Z80-Z87 for ICD-10) may be used as secondary codes when the historical condition or family history has an impact on current care or influences treatment. With ICD-9, coders are accustomed to using the V codes to indicate a history diagnosis.
There will be a partial code freeze prior to ICD-10 implementation

During the ICD-9-CM Coordination & Maintenance Committee Meeting on Sept. 15, CMS representative Pat Brooks, RHIA, announced that the committee had finalized the decision to implement a partial freeze for both ICD-9-CM codes and ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS codes prior to implementation of ICD-10 in October 2013. The partial freeze will be implemented as follows:

  • The last regular, annual updates to both ICD-9-CM and ICD-10 code sets will be made on October 1, 2011.
  • On October 1, 2012, there will be only limited code updates to both the ICD-9-CM and ICD-10 code sets to capture new technologies and diseases as required by section 503(a) of Pub. L. 108-173.
  • On October 1, 2013, there will be only limited code updates to ICD-10 code sets to capture new technologies and diagnoses as required by section 503(a) of Pub. L. 108-173. There will be no updates to ICD-9-CM, as it will no longer be used for reporting.
  • On October 1, 2014, regular updates to ICD-10 will begin.

To learn more, access p. 10 of the agenda for the ICD-9-CM Coordination & Maintenance Committee meeting, which is available on the CMS website.
Instructor surprised while teaching first ICD-10 Basics Boot Camp

I taught the first “official” two-day HCPro ICD-10 Basics Boot Camp™ a couple weeks ago. I was pleasantly surprised that all 50 participants felt the new coding system was easily learned. If I can ease the anxiety of just one group of coders at a time, I feel like I am making headway.

The one factor that did surprise me was that all along I kept thinking that the ICD-10-PCS part was going to be the difficult system to learn when in fact the attendees felt that ICD-10-CM was more difficult.

They easily picked up on the use of the PCS tables but found the amount of things to remember in ICD-10-CM (e.g., placeholders, excludes1 and 2 notes, use additional code notes, added specificity, and laterality) made it more difficult.

This was just a “basics” class so I think the viewpoint very well may change once they are given an operative report to code as opposed to just a stated procedure that can easily be converted to a seven character ICD-10-PCS code.

The whole experience as an instructor was so enjoyable because since this system is really new to everyone, most (if not all) the participants can’t necessarily bring in years worth of “but he/she told me to always code it this way” or “that’s not how we do it.” To learn a new system, it is refreshing and as a coder I think the key to remember is that right now we only have limited sources of information about correct ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS assignment.

We have the ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS coding guidelines as well as the very recently announced Coding Clinic for ICD-10 Briefings from the American Hospital Association. I will look forward to seeing more and more official guidance on proper code assignment as we near the implementation date.
Which side? Make sure physicians provide adequate documentation of laterality

One of the biggest changes in ICD-10-CM is the volume of codes that specify laterality. Providers will need to  document  which side, right or left, that the injury or diagnosis has occurred for approximately 5,000 codes.
For example:

•    D27.0 (benign neoplasm of right ovary)
•    D27.1 (benign neoplasm of left ovary)
•    D27.9 (benign neoplasm of ovary, unspecified side)

Coders should always assign the detailed codes, not the unspecified codes that are also available, but to do that, the clinician has to document it.

Other conditions that will require documentation of laterality include:
•    Joint pain
•    Joint effusion
•    Injury
•    Fractures
•    Sprains
•    Tears, meniscus, cruciate ligament
•    Dislocations
•    Arthritis
•    Cerebral infarction
•    Extremity atherosclerosis
•    Pressure ulcers
•    Cancers, neoplasms (breast, lung, bones, etc.)
•    Arthritis

Start working with your physicians now to get them in the habit of documenting laterality, so when you start using ICD-10-CM, you’ll have the documentation you need.
It's not always clear which root operation to assign

If you have taken a peek at a draft ICD-10-PCS Manual, you probably realize that you need to be come familiar with a number of root procedures, some of which you may not even be familiar with. But it's important to understand that it's not always clear which root operation to assign.

For example, when looking at procedures involving cutting or separation only, consider the following definitions:

  • Division : Cutting into a body part without draining fluids and/or gases from the body part in order to separate or transect a body part.

An example of this would be an osteotomy.

  • Release: Freeing a body part from an abnormal physical constraint.

An example of this would be an adhesiolysis.

But some coders may think that the root operation for an adhesiolysis is a destruction because "-lysis" means to cut away or destroy. This is just one example to illustrate that you'll want to really study the definitions of each root operation to be able to identify these potential gray areas.

Sometimes we get really excited about code changes, especially when they have such a huge impact on documentation issues. One such exciting change is in the ICD-10 coding guidelines for Chapter 6: Diseases of the Nervous System and Sense Organs. There is an addition to the guidelines regarding dominant/nondominant side.

Currently, when it comes to hemiplegia and monoplegia in ICD-9-CM coding, the physician must document dominant vs. non-dominant in order for us to code the specificity. If the documentation is lacking specificity, then code selection is for unspecified. In ICD-10, the new guideline states that when documentation is lacking and if the classification system does not indicate a default, the default should be dominant. It further goes on to address ambidextrous patients; the default should also be dominant.

I definitely think this is one that we can chalk up to the "win" column for coding and documentation issues.
Three subcategory codes required when using Glasgow Coma Scale

The Glasgow Coma Scale provides an objective way of recording the conscious state of a person, for initial as well as continuing assessment. A patient is assessed against the criteria of the scale, and the resulting points give a patient score between 3 (deep unconsciousness) and 15 (fully awake).

In ICD-10-CM, clinicians may use the Glasgow coma scale codes in conjunction with traumatic brain injury codes or sequelae of cerebrovascular accident codes. These codes are primarily used by trauma registries, but coders may report them for any setting.

At a minimum, you must report the initial score documented when the patient arrived at your facility. This may be a score from the emergency medicine technician (EMT) or in the ED. If the patient expires in the ED before being admitted to an inpatient unit, coders will report the case as an outpatient encounter.

You need one code from each of the three subcategories R40.21-, R40.22-, and R40.23- to complete the scale. So the clinician must document the patient’s visual, verbal, and motor status in the medical record.

When coding a patient’s visual status, look for documentation of how often the patient’s eye are open and select the appropriate code:

  • R40.211 (coma scale, eyes open, never)
  • R40.212 (coma scale, eyes open, to pain)
  • R40.213 (coma scale, eyes open, to sound)
  • R40.214 (coma scale, eyes open, spontaneous)

Then, do the same for the patient’s verbal and motor skills. Physicians will need to document the patient’s best verbal and best motor response for coders to select the most appropriate code.

The clinician must also document when the coma scale is recorded in order to assign the appropriate seventh character as:

  • 0,unspecified time
  • 1, in the field (EMT or ambulance)
  • 2, at arrival to ED
  • 3, at hospital admission
  • 4, 24 hours or more after hospital admission
What impact will ICD-10 have on MS-DRG payments?

I often wondered how the ICD-9-CM code set would translate to ICD-10-CM/PCS in regards to MS-DRGs. I couldn’t fathom that along with the costly transition to a new code set, CMS would “double whammy” us by implementing this system, and it would result in a severe adjustment in our MS-DRGs (i.e., reimbursement). I am glad that my hunch was correct that the intended impact of mapping of MS-DRGs from ICD-9 to ICD-10 should be (note I say should be) minimal for hospitals. Per the ICD-9-CM Coordination and Maintenance committee meeting:

Abstract: On October 1, 2013, the reporting of diagnoses and procedures in the US will transition from the clinical modification of the ninth revision of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-9-CM) to the tenth revision (ICD-10). The impact of conversion to ICD-10 on Medicare MS-DRG payments to hospitals was estimated using 2009 Medicare data. A minimal hospital payment increase of 0.05 percent was found using the ICD-10 version of MS-DRGs. In contrast, a modest hospital payment decrease of 0.38 percent was found when ICD-10 data was mapped backed to ICD-9-CM and the ICD-9-CM version of MS-DRGs was used. —3M Health Information Systems, Wallingford, Connecticut

They found that only about a little over 1% of the almost 11 million discharges studied resulted in an MS-DRG change. The abstract continues:

The results of the payment impact analysis show that the conversion to a native ICD-10 version of MS-DRGs will have a minimal impact on aggregate payments to hospitals and the distribution of payments across hospitals. The objective of the ICD-10 MS-DRG conversion project was to produce an ICD-10 version of MS-DRGs that replicated the ICD-9-CM version. Thus, for data coded in ICD-10, the ICD-10 MS-DRGs would assign “the same MS-DRG had the same case been coded using ICD-9-CM codes” (CMS, 2010, D). The development of a complete native ICD-10 version of the MS-DRGs allowed ICD-10 codes to be evaluated on an individual basis to determine the most appropriate MS-DRG assignment. As a result, there is a high degree of consistency between the ICD-9-CM and ICD-10 version of the MS-DRGs.

Please note that this analysis due to its sample size were mapped by not utilizing the additional specificity in ICD-10 but rather if an ICD-9 code had added specificity in ICD-10, it was not considered. To me, this means that they did not take into consideration (and understandably so) how obtaining added specificity for a code series MAY impact the overall MS-DRG if there are certain codes within that series that are labeled as CC/MCC.

In addition to other considerations, and not just focusing on the intention but rather reality, is that DRG shifts could occur due to improper training of the coding staff. An example could be if the coder selects the improper root operation for a code (e.g, excision versus resection). This incorrect code assignment could also potentially cause changes within the MS-DRGs resulting in payment increases or decreases.
CMS posts 2011 ICD-10-PCS files to website

CMS posted this week the following ICD-10-PCS files for 2011 to its website:

  • Official ICD-10-PCS Coding Guidelines
  • 2011 Version: What's New
  • Code Tables and Index
  • Code Descriptions
  • ICD-10-PCS Reference Manual and Slides

Although CMS posted these in addition to several other files, updates to ICD-10 going forward will be minimal due to a recent announcement that a partial code freeze would be implemented. Access a recent ICD-10 Trainer blog post to learn more about the partial code freeze.
I'm looking forward to ICD-10-PCS coding!

Looking forward to it? Did I really just say that? Yep – I sure did!

In July, I attended a preview of HCPro’s ICD-10 Basics Boot Camp™. I was actually a little surprised that the ICD-10-CM codes, guidelines, and assignment process will not be that much different from ICD-9-CM. I am not sure what I was expecting, but I thought it would be much more complicated.

Granted, I do not code on a daily basis so my perspective is a little skewed, but personally I think we will have a harder time getting our physicians and other care providers to document well enough to be able to code specific enough so as not to impact reimbursement and quality patient care. The coders, with proper, timely training, are going to do just fine.

With that said, what I really enjoyed was the ICD-10-PCS training. What a difference—and that is a good thing. We will finally have a unique, well-defined code for every procedure, with the expansion for new procedures being relatively painless. No more generic three to four digit ICD-9 procedure codes!

Each of the seven characters of an ICD-10 procedure code has a meaningful definition, but we will have to take the time to learn the definitions inside and out (no pun intended).

We will also need to “bone up” on our anatomy and physiology (A&P) because of the specificity of the codes. It might be a good idea to start to become familiar with the new PCS procedure definitions. Look for economical ways to get an A&P refresher, which can be useful for ICD-9 coding, too. Look ahead, and don’t wait and try to cram all the necessary education into the last year or it really will seem like an overwhelming task.

Sure there will be a learning curve for coders as with anything so fundamentally different, but I am actually excited to code with ICD-10-PCS ... and use a book to do it! Speaking as a former HIM Director, I am no longer intimidated—we can do it! Hmmm ... I wonder whether there will be employment opportunities for just PCS coders?

By now everyone knows that coders will need more documentation and specificity to assign the correct ICD-10 codes. And everyone knows that increased documentation has to come from the providers—the physicians, nurses, and nonphysician practitioners who are providing the care.

So have you started talking to your providers about improving their documentation? Do they even know what will be required? If not, now is the time to start. If the providers don’t know what the coders need, they can’t make sure they’re documenting it. Get physicians involved in the planning for ICD-10, particularly explaining to physicians by specialty the effect the new coding system will have on their practices.

Gauge training needs by conducting assessments of staff members (e.g., coders, admissions, precertification, and registration) to better determine their knowledge of ICD-10. Although it’s too early to train coders about the new codes, now is a good time to provide overview education about ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS to help foster comfort with the transition and dispel any myths and misconceptions about the new coding system.
CMS special forum may underscore potential pitfall of partial code freeze

CMS will hold a Special Forum to receive input on the development and implementation of its hospital value-based purchasing program, as required by Section 3001 of the Affordable Care Act. The primary audience for this call includes hospitals, medical providers, beneficiaries, public citizens, professional associations and other interested stakeholders.

In an upcoming JustCoding article that will be published next week, James S. Kennedy, MD, CCS, managing director at FTI Healthcare in Atlanta, emphasizes that if code sets don’t reflect the various stages of illness severity, physicians will be profiled inaccurately in Medicare’s physician value-based purchasing, medical home, and accountable care organization risk-adjustment programs.

The following excerpt from CMS outlining questions they will address during this forum, Kennedy says, highlights reasons why some in the provider community do not support the recently finalized decision to implement a partial code freeze of ICD-9 and ICD-10:

  • The legislation requires the inclusion of a Medicare Spending per Beneficiary efficiency measure, adjusted for age, sex, race, severity of illness and other factors? How should this be measured and how should risk adjustment be applied?
  • The legislation calls for the Secretary to use the Hospital Compare website to include information that is useful to consumers and providers. What information should be included on the website? What performance data will be most useful to consumers and providers? What improvements should be made to the website?

CMS is using coded data to profile hospitals and physicians, but one has to question how effective this can be when the code set does not translate the patient’s severity of illness, Kennedy says. To read more about this topic, don't miss next week's issue of JustCoding News: Inpatient.

To participate in "CMS Hospital Value-Based Purchasing Program Special Forum," on Tuesday, Oct. 26, 1-3pm EST:

  • Toll-Free Dial-In #: 866-501-5502
  • Conference ID #: 18696295
Understand rules 12 and 13 of the ICD-10 coding guidelines

Rule 12 of the 2010 ICD-10-CM Official Guidelines for Coding and Reporting reads:

Reporting same diagnosis code more than once

Each unique ICD-10-CM diagnosis code may be reported only once for an encounter. This applies to bilateral conditions when there are no distinct codes identifying laterality or two different conditions classified to the same ICD-10-CM diagnosis code.

Rule 13 reads:

Laterality

For bilateral sites, the final character of the codes in the ICD-10-CM indicates laterality. An unspecified side code is also provided should the side not be identified in the medical record. If no bilateral code is provided and the condition is bilateral, assign separate codes for both the left and right side.

At first blush after reading these rules, you might think they conflict with one another. But they don’t. Looking at a couple of examples helps to make the rules clearer.

For example, let’s say a patient has suffered a traumatic fracture on the proximal phalanx on both the left and the right thumbs. There is not a single code to indicate the fracture occurred on both thumbs. Therefore, you would report code S62.511 for the displaced fracture on the right thumb and code S62.512 for the displaced fracture on the left thumb. So this illustrates rules 12 and 13 in action. The fracture occurred on both the left and the right sides, and because there is not a single diagnosis code to indicate both fractures, report two distinct codes to indicate the laterality.

On the other hand, let’s say a patient has been diagnosed with age-related nuclear cataracts in both eyes. In this case, a single code exists (H25.13) to indicate the cataracts exist in both eyes, so you report only one code. If only the right eye had the nuclear cataract, use code H25.11; if only the left eye was involved, use code H25.12. If the  medical record did not specify which eye was involved, you would report code H25.10. But I hope your physicians are documenting better than that!
Look at medical procedures in a completely new way

In ICD-10-PCS, every procedure falls into one of 31 root operations, which define the objective of the procedure. Although some root operations seem self-explanatory (e.g., transplantation or reattachment), others are not so straightforward. Consider the following excerpt from an article, "Learn the nuances of root operations to help ensure accurate ICD-10-PCS code assignment" from the most recent issue of JustCoding News Inpatient:

Procedure documentation may often include the term “removal,” but according to PCS definitions, the physician actually performed an extraction or even an extirpation. Do not code directly what the physician lists as the procedure; rather, you should always read the operative report to determine what the physician actually did and which definition the procedure meets.

Take into account the following potential documentation problems:

Procedure: Nonexcisional debridement of skin of back. There is no lead term in ICD-10-PCS for “debridement,” so based on definitions, the coder must review the body of the operative report to see what the physician actually performed. In this case, code the debridement as an extraction because it fits the definition (i.e., being pulled off a portion of the body part by use of force). In this case, skin is the body part.

To learn more about root operations and coding with ICD-10-PCS, join HCPro for a two-hour live audio conference, ICD-10-PCS Surgery Coding: Understand and Apply Five Medical Surgical Root Operations on November 18, at 1 p.m. (Eastern). Our expert speakers will give you a close look at what it will take to change years of coding habits and make the leap to ICD-10-PCS. Following a basic introduction to the ICD-10-PCS system, they will discuss five specific root operations using operative reports to show you how to assign the appropriate ICD-10-PCS code.
Keep an eye on LCDs, NCDs

ICD-10 will change more than just the code sets and will impact more than just your coders. The clinical area will face many changes because so many health plan policies are going to change, says Rhonda Buckholtz, CPC, CPMA, CPC-I, CGSC, COBGC, CPEDC, CENTC, vice president of business and member development for the American Academy of Professional Coders in Salt Lake City.

CMS’ national coverage determinations (NCD) and MACs’ and FIs’ local coverage determinations (LCD), as well as individual payer policies, will also change. Anything tied to a diagnosis or medical necessity is going to have to change.

Your practice or facility will need to create its own policies for dealing with those changes and may even have to examine how they handle advance beneficiary notices of noncoverage (ABN), because the diagnostic coding will change.
Will the super bill be a thing of the past?

So, once we start using ICD-10 codes, will you still be able to use a super bill?  A super bill is a cheat sheet that many facilities and practices develop, on which they list their top diagnostic codes and then circle the appropriate condition(s). In ICD-10-CM, such a document may not be practical. The American Academy of Family Medicine’s super bill went from two pages under ICD-9-CM to six pages under ICD-10-CM, says Rhonda Buckholtz, CPC, CPMA, CPC-I, CGSC, COBGC, CPEDC, CENTC, vice president of business and member development for the American Academy of Professional Coders in Salt Lake City.


“So you can imagine sending a patient a seven-page super bill,” says Buckholtz. “You’d have to be planting a tree constantly to make up for it.”


If a practice or facility can’t switch to electronic medical records, it will have to really revise the super bill by removing the diagnosis codes and asking the physicians to write them in by hand, says Buckholtz. That, in turn, can lead to documentation problems.
What sets HCPro ICD-10 boot camp apart?

Over the past few weeks through e-mail, at conferences, and during class many people have asked myself and my colleagues what makes the HCPro ICD-10 Basics Boot Camp™ different from the other programs currently available. First and foremost, the focus of HCPro’s boot camps has always been on providing high-quality education in an intensive learning environment that allows students to practice what they learn as they go along. With ICD-10, our focus remains the same. We use materials that I created based on the actual ICD-10 coding systems and their associated guidelines. I designed the course specifically for the intensive boot camp learning format. Some other organizations’ training programs also include education on the implementation process itself or are designed with trainers in mind. HCPro’s course is focused exclusively on training students on the new coding system, using expert educators with years of experience teaching coding.

Some have also asked me what the right time is for ICD-10 training. And, of course, that answer depends on each organization’s unique circumstances. Most say it’s too soon for intense training for the entire coding staff, and I agree. That’s why for 2011 and early 2012 we’re starting by offering an introductory course with one-day and two-day options—one-day for ICD-10-CM only, and two days for ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS. This level of education will provide students a familiarity with the new system, a comfort-level that they can handle the transition, and a first step toward getting their organizations ready. It won’t be until mid-2012 that we release our intensive five-day course. But 2011 is a great time for introductory training, particularly for those taking a lead role in getting their facility ready for ICD-10 as well as those who have concerns and fears about the transition.

Here is how one of the students in my first on-site ICD-10 boot camp class put it: “This was an excellent introduction to ICD-10 coding. I no longer dread the change and actually believe it is much needed.”
Not everything will change in ICD-10-CM

Coders and other HIM professionals generally focus on the ways ICD-10-CM is different from ICD-9-CM—the number of codes, the length of the codes, the look of the codes, the level of specificity, and the increased documentation requirements.

Seems like a lot, right? Well, it is, but not everything is changing. For example, the index will be structured the same as in ICD-9-CM, with the alphabetic index of diseases and injuries, alphabetic index of external causes, table of neoplasms, and table of drugs and chemicals. The index will still be divided into two parts:

  • Index to diseases and injuries
  • Index to external causes

The tabular index will retain the same hierarchical structure and the chapters are structured similarly to ICD-9-CM, with minor exceptions. For example, the sense organs (eye and ear) will move from the nervous system chapter to their own chapters.

In addition, many conventions (e.g., abbreviations, punctuation, symbols) will mean the same thing. And even though ICD-10-CM generally provides more detail, nonspecific codes (“unspecified” or “not otherwise specified”) are available to use when the provider doesn’t include enough detail in the documentation to support more specific code.

Maybe more importantly—or at least more comfortingly—you will still look up codes the same way:

  • Look up diagnostic terms in Alphabetic Index
  • Then verify code number in Tabular List
Major change to the coding guidelines regarding anemia secondary to malignancy

While attending an American Health Information Management Association ICD-10 course, I was surprised to learn that there is a huge change to the coding guidelines regarding neoplasms. Currently in ICD-9-CM, if a patient is admitted for complications due to the malignancy, the complication is the principal diagnosis. We even have a code that specifically addresses anemia in neoplastic disease, and now we have one that addresses anemia associated with chemotherapy. Assignment for both follow the same guideline—that the complication (i.e., the anemia) is the principal diagnosis.

However, this rule appears to have changed in ICD-10-CM.

If a patient is admitted for anemia associated with malignancy and the treatment is only for the anemia, the appropriate code for the malignancy is sequenced as the principal or first-listed diagnosis followed by code D63.0 (anemia in neoplastic disease). This is a huge change that we will have to get used to when transitioning from ICD-9 to ICD-10.

Even more interesting is the fact that the rule regarding anemia associated with chemotherapy, immunotherapy, and radiation therapy will follow the guidelines associated with “adverse effects.” Therefore, the appropriate adverse effect code should be sequenced first, followed by the appropriate code for the anemia and neoplasm.

Coders should keep this in mind and begin working with their physicians now so that they can identify the appropriate guideline to apply when coding for anemia.  To ensure coders assign the appropriate code, it will be important that physician documentation identifies whether the anemia is associated with the neoplasm or an adverse effect of the treatment associated with the malignancy.

The Commission on Certification for Health Informatics and Information Management (CCHIIM) recently announced ICD-10 recertification requirements for individuals certified by the American Health Information Management Association (AHIMA).

In the document, "ICD-10 CE Requirements for AHIMA Certified Professionals & FAQs," the CCHIIM commission states the following:

AHIMA Certified Professionals are required by CCHIIM to participate in a predetermined number of mandatory baseline educational experiences specific to ICD-10-CM/PCS. These ICD-10-CM/PCS specific CEUs will count as part of all AHIMA certificants’ total CEU requirements for the purpose of recertification. Stated differently, the following CEU requirements will be included as part of each certificants’ total, required CEUs, by credential, per CEU Cycle.

The total number of ICD-10-CM/PCS continuing education units (CEUs) required, by AHIMA credential, is as follows:

  • CHPS – 1CEU
  • CHDA – 6 CEUs
  • RHIT – 6 CEUs
  • RHIA – 6 CEUs
  • CCS-P – 12 CEUs
  • CCS – 18 CEUs
  • CCA – 18 CEUs

*6 CEUs = 1 day of training (Please see the explanation under FAQs)

Certificants who hold more than one AHIMA credential will only report the highest number of CEUs from among all credentials held. For example, if a certificant has both an RHIA and CCS, the certificant would normally report 40 (30 CEUs for RHIA and an additional 10 CEUs for CCS) CEUs per recertification cycle, and 18 of these CEUs will be required to cover ICD-10-CM/PCS.

AHIMA certified professionals can begin earning ICD-10-CM/PCS specific CEUs during the period of January 1, 2011 thru December 31, 2013. NOTE: All AHIMA Certified Professionals who complete AHIMA’s Academy for ICD-10 prior to January 1, 2011 will be allowed to use those CEU hours to fulfill the ICD -10-CM/PCS CE requirement.
ICD-10 codes with the character 'X' may require some decoding

What does "x" represent in ICD-10? What seemed like a fairly straightforward question and answer in a recent HCPro ICD-10 Basics Boot Camp™ class I was teaching actually evolved into more of a tricky topic than I initially thought. And it caused me to ponder the following question: Why did the coding authorities decide to use the letter “x” as a placeholder, and as a category of codes, as well as a character in ICD-10-PCS codes? In other words, how is one to determine what the “x” means? Consider the following variety of meanings an “x” can have in an ICD-10 code:

  • For ICD-10-CM code T48.5x1A, the “x” is a placeholder.
  • For code category X78.0, the X is the category of codes (X00–X99) and identifies intention of an injury, exposure, etc.
  • For ICD-10-PCS code 0HB0XZX, the first “X” identifies that the approach was external and the second “X” identifies the procedure was diagnostic.

The positioning of the “x” as well as the code set (CM or PCS) involved determines what it indicates in each circumstance, but this can be confusing for those learning the system. Certainly, learning a new code set will prove a challenge to coders, and having multiple meanings for a letter makes it even harder.

To read the entire answer I provided for this Ask the Expert Q&A, access this recent JustCoding article.
A bare bones look at anatomy and physiology education

I have heard and read many discussions that coders will need to get in-depth education on anatomy and physiology (A&P) and pathophysiology before we flip the switch to ICD-10. The more I thought about it, the more questions I had. What will be changing so much with ICD-10 that we need to get “re-educated,” when certified coders and HIM professionals already have a basic to advanced understanding in these areas? Was I missing the gist of the discussions because I didn’t understand what we are referring to? So I “googled” the terms, and here are the definitions:

Human physiology is the science of the mechanical, physical, and biochemical functions of humans in good health, their organs, and the cells of which they are composed. The principal level of focus of physiology is at the level of organs and systems within systems. Physiology is closely related to anatomy; anatomy is the study of form, and physiology is the study of function. Due to the frequent connection between form and function, physiology and anatomy are intrinsically linked and are studied in tandem as part of a medical curriculum.

Pathophysiology is the study of the changes of normal mechanical, physical, and biochemical functions, either caused by a disease, or resulting from an abnormal syndrome. More formally, it is the branch of medicine which deals with any disturbances of body functions, caused by disease or prodromal symptoms. The study of pathology and the study of pathophysiology often involves substantial overlap in diseases and processes, but pathology emphasizes direct observations, while pathophysiology emphasizes quantifiable measurements. Pathophysiology looks at the specific malfunctioning that comes from or - alternately - causes disease.

With that said, this triggered even more questions. Regarding anatomy, the T-4 vertebrae has not moved or morphed in some way. For physiology, the endocrine system continues to function the same as it always has.

But what about pathophysiology? Is this our weak link when it comes to training for ICD-10? Is ICD-9 so inferior to ICD-10 that we really haven’t understood how the body works or doesn’t work for all of these years? Are we behind the 8-ball not only for learning a new classification system but at the same time having to learn what normal and abnormal body functions are? For those of us who will have to use ICD-10-PCS, hasn’t CPT already prepared us for a greater degree of specificity? Won’t the Body Part Key in PCS help us out when we get stuck?

I am an advocate for a variety of continuing education in HIM, which includes all of these areas that are defined above. I will take a leap of faith and assume that most of us have kept current on developing diseases and technology, that we have done research on the web, and that we have asked our medical staff these types of questions all along. I guess my point is that we probably don’t need to invest in college level courses. We do know the body, its parts and its functions – let’s give ourselves some credit. But between now and that magical day on October 1, 2013, we need to gain confidence in what we do know and be aware of what we don’t know and get specific education to fill the gap. Personally, I don’t think continuing education in these modalities has to be as monumental of a task as it is being made out to be.
Billing office will see changes with ICD-10-CM

The billing department will see plenty of payer ¬policy changes as a result of ICD-10-CM. Billers must know how the new policies affect what can be billed and how they must submit the bills under the new policies. Billers will also have to differentiate between policies for the ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM codes when facilities and practices run dual systems for a time after the switch to ICD-10-CM.

Health plans are currently revising all payment policies that are tied to ICD-9-CM. Expect those revisions to continue as the ICD-10 implementation date draws closer. Billers need to stay on top of changes after the switch to ICD-10-CM takes place to make sure they have the most current information available.

Billers will also need to be trained on the new code sets. In particular, they must understand how the ICD-10-CM codes relate to the less-specific ICD-9-CM codes.
A look at how to code neoplasms in ICD-10

Neoplasms are a form of new, abnormal growth in organs and tissues. The cells do not develop as an organized part of the site where they form, and they may spread to other parts of the body in a process called metastasis.

Looking up Neoplasms in ICD-10 is quite similar to looking up Neoplasms in ICD-9. The biggest difference is the location of the Neoplasm table. In ICD-9, you find the table within the Alphabetical Index to diseases under Neoplasm. In ICD-10, the Neoplasm table follows the Alphabetic index to diseases.

So first find “Zymotic” in the Alphabetic index to diseases and the next page will begin the first page of your Neoplasm table. Neoplasms in both ICD-9 and ICD-10 are classified according to the site affected and the way they behave, which can be malignant, benign, in-situ, or uncertain/unknown. Benign polyps are excluded from the neoplasm table because they are coded to the chapter of the body system in which they are found.

As I mentioned, the neoplasm code blocks are organized according to behavior, with the block for primary malignant neoplasms, (C00–C96), being the largest. This is subdivided according to site. Guidelines indicate that a malignant neoplasm is coded to this block if the documentation clearly states that it is a primary site. If the documentation does not state whether a malignant neoplasm is primary or not, the neoplasm must be assumed to be primary.

After the malignant neoplasm blocks come those for in-situ and benign neoplasms, followed by a block for neoplasms of uncertain or unknown behavior.
Use appropriate seventh character for fracture coding

The meanings of the seventh character for ICD-10-CM codes vary across chapters and categories. Fracture codes include additional information that can be provided by the extension.

When coding for a fracture, be sure you add the appropriate seventh character to each code:

  • A, initial encounter for fracture
  • D, subsequent encounter for fracture with routine healing
  • G, subsequent encounter for fracture with delayed healing
  • K, subsequent encounter for fracture with nonunion
  • P, subsequent encounter for fracture with malunion
  • S, sequela

Use extensions for initial encounter (A and B) while the patient is receiving active treatment for the injury, including:

  • Surgical treatment
  • Emergency department encounter
  • Evaluation and treatment by a new physician

Extensions for subsequent encounter (i.e., D, G K, and P) indicate encounters after the patient has received active treatment of the injury and is receiving routine care for the injury during the healing or recovery phase. These types of encounters include:

  • Cast change or removal
  • Removal of external or internal fixation device
  • Medication adjustment
  • Other aftercare and follow-up visits

Note: Do not use the ICD-10-CM aftercare Z codes for aftercare for injuries. For aftercare of an injury, assign the acute injury code with the appropriate seventh character for subsequent encounter.
Coding changes for adverse effects and poisonings

One of the challenges in ICD-9 is teaching the difference between coding for adverse effects and poisonings. You have to understand the difference between the two, and you have to also understand the coding differences. I often tell my students to make sure they write the definitions of adverse effects and poisonings right near the table of drugs and chemicals in their ICD-9 Manuals, as well as the coding guidelines for each of them so that the information is right where they need it. For ICD-10, the table of drugs and chemicals as well as the guidelines will undergo revisions, so we will have to adjust our thinking as well.

When coding for adverse effects in ICD-9, you must code first the “reaction” followed by the E code (external causes) identifying the substance that caused the adverse reaction. This E code comes from the therapeutic column. This is different from coding a poisoning, for which we first report the poisoning code followed by the reaction and then the E code, which identifies the substance as well as how the patient was poisoned (e.g., accident, suicide, assault, or undetermined).

In the ICD-10 draft manual, the columns have changed. Now the “therapeutic column” has been deleted from the table, and a new column for "adverse effect" has been added. The poisoning column no longer exists but has been replaced by several columns that read: “poisoning accidental (unintentional)”, “poisoning Intentional/self-inflicted”, “poisoning assault”, and “poisoning undetermined.” There has also been a new column added to identify “underdosing,” which seems to be an increasing problem. Because the table of drugs and chemicals looks different, what does this mean for the coding of these two types of conditions?

For adverse effects, ICD-10 guidelines state, “Codes in categories T36-T65 are combination codes that include the substances related to the adverse effects, poisonings, toxic effects and underdosing, as well as the external cause. No additional external cause code is required for poisonings, toxic effects, adverse effects and underdosing codes.” According to the guidelines, the T36-T65 code would be the first listed code. You would also report the code(s) that specify the “reaction” or as ICD-10 calls it “the nature of the adverse effect, poisoning, or toxic effect."

There are further guidelines:

  • Do not code directly from the table; always refer back to the tabular list.
  • Use as many codes as necessary to completely describe all drugs, medicinal, or biological substances.
  • If the same code would describe the causative agent for more than one adverse effect, poisoning, toxic effect, or underdosing, assign the code only once.
  • If two or more drugs, medicinal or biological substances are reported, code each individually unless the combination code is listed in the table of drugs and chemicals.

It will take a little bit of adjustment, but all this is pretty mild as coding guideline changes go. I personally feel that it is about time that the adverse effect codes identify the condition. In ICD-9 there was a fine line between poisonings and adverse effect coding. It came down to the fact that poisonings had the 900 poisoning code first and the E code identified how they were poisoned, requiring at least three codes to code it correctly versus the possibility of only two codes for adverse effects. Now the coding will look more alike. Regarding specificity, I think ICD-10 is more appropriate, and I am looking forward to the changes.
AHIMA highlights coding basics for physician practices

At the annual American Health Information Management Association's (AHIMA) convention in September, AHIMA practice resources managers Kathy DeVault, RHIA, CCS, CCS-P, and Ann Zeisset, RHIT, CCS, CCS-P, gave a presentation on the basics of ICD-10-CM for physician practices. They addressed key differences between ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM and also reviewed new features and the formatting of the codes.

The presentation also included coding examples that involved diabetes, obstetrics, and fractures. For example, how would you code type I diabetes mellitus with diabetic nephropathy in ICD-10?

To see their step-by-step advice for assigning the appropriate code and to learn more about other presentation highlights, including popular ICD-10 facts vs. myths, access the AHIMA presentation.
