This resource is a diamond in the rough

It may come as a surprise, but CMS has an excellent website to help with the transitions to 5010 and ICD-10. This site is actually easy to use and fairly comprehensive compared to some of their others that leave us chasing our tails and feeling like we have entered into some sort of vortex.

On this site, there are a variety of resources for providers, vendors, and payers, as well as information to help providers educate staff. The CMS website serves as the “official” site to help answer many of your questions.

Don’t get me wrong—there are many other organizations out there doing an excellent job to help us understand and convert to ICD-10. But just be cautious and confirm that what you have is the gospel! I have seen and heard many rumors that are being passed around, and I am concerned that people are relying on hearsay and will find themselves lagging behind.

To dispel just one rumor,  CMS has been very clear about the implementation date. There has been no change to that date or a “stay of execution” issued for anyone in the healthcare industry. Yes, the ICD-10 implementation date is still October 1, 2013, and you can verify this on CMS' website, where you will find a very clear timetable.

While you are there, sign up for official e-mail updates if you haven’t already done so, and take a look at their other resources. CMS has even created an official ICD-10 logo to help you distinguish fact from fiction.

Here is the link - check it out!
CMS posts updated 2011 GEMs for ICD-10-CM/PCS

CMS has released the 2011 versions of the ICD-10-CM/PCS crosswalks, also known as the General Equivalence Mappings (GEM) on its ICD-10 website.

In addition, CMS also posted a document titled “ICD-10 GEMs 2011 Version Update: Update Summary,” which outlines the number of comments CMS received, the type of changes recommended, the types of changes made based on the comments, as well as the types of comments not accepted and reasons why.

The document states:

Of the 5,200 comments submitted, roughly one third of the recommended changes were either implemented for this update or had been previously implemented in the September update, based on public comment received during the past year. Approximately 850 recommended changes, or 16% of all comments received, were new changes implemented for the 2011 GEMs, and approximately 900 additional recommended changes, or 17% of all comments received, supported previous changes in the most recent updated GEMs files (posted on the CMS website in September, 2010).

One example of a change that CMS incorporated in this update as a result of public comment is the ICD-10-CM to ICD-9-CM GEM entry for pneumococcal arthritis.

In 2010, ICD-10-CM code M00.111 (pneumococcal arthritis, right shoulder) mapped to ICD-9-CM code 711.01 (pyogenic arthritis, shoulder region). A public comment CMS received stated that the ICD-9 code mappings CMS selected did not totally represent the description of the ICD-10 code, noting however, that the selections were not clinically incorrect.

The updated 2011 entry states that ICD-10-CM code M00.111 maps to ICD-9-CM code 711.01 and ICD-9-CM code 041.2 (pneumococcus infection in conditions classified elsewhere and of unspecified site).

CMS explained that the code specifying the infection as pneumococcus was added to create a translation cluster, to capture the complete meaning of the ICD-10-CM code, and in accordance with ICD-9-CM instructional notes for code 711.0-.
Consider new and recurring costs for ICD-10 switch

Expert predictions for industry costs for the upcoming move to ICD-10-CM/PCS vary from $6 billion to $14 billion (Robert E. Nolan Company), to $1.15 billion (RAND Corporation). Regardless of where the overall figure ends up, you’re probably more worried about what your facility or practice will end up paying. The estimates consider the cost of necessary training, productivity loss during the transition, and returned claims due to errors or confusion.

In order to better manage the costs of the transition, begin planning for it now. “If they begin to transition to ICD-10 now and start looking at the areas that are going to be impacted, they can cut their costs significantly,” says Rhonda Buckholtz, CPC, CPMA, CPC I, CGSC, COBGC, CPEDC, CENTC, vice president of business and member development for the American Academy of Professional Coders in Salt Lake City. Estimate the costs of the coming switch to ICD-10 by considering  one-time and recurring costs.

Your one-time costs will include:

  • ICD-10 training for all of your coders – inpatient, outpatient, and physician services
  • Clinical documentation training for clinicians
  • Possible productivity losses resulting from coder training and productivity decreases during the early days of using  ICD-10
  • Improving your information systems, including modifications and upgrades to current systems
  • Purchasing new hardware or software to handle ICD-10 codes

Your organization will face recurring costs from:

  • Salaries for staff who are devoted to ICD-10 implementation and/or ongoing compliance
  • Consulting and contract coders

As the New Year starts, where are you at in terms of your ICD-10 implementation plans? This might be a good time to sit down and identify any gaps in your preparation to ensure a smooth transition to ICD-10. According to the American Health Information Management Association, here are some ideas that you might want to consider:

  • Inpatient and outpatient coders should be reviewing the code structure, coding guidelines, and coding conventions for ICD-10-CM. By now, coders should also be familiarizing themselves with the differences and similarities between ICD-9 and ICD-10. Coders also need to identify any knowledge deficits in terms of anatomy and physiology and make plans to “bone up” in those areas.
  • Inpatient coders should also be learning and memorizing the definitions for procedure approaches and root operations for ICD-10-PCS. They should understand how these new definitions will greatly impact the accuracy of their procedure code assignment.
  • Data managers should be working closely with the information technology department in the planning to modify the data from ICD-9 to ICD-10. They should also be involved in decisions to create dual systems and determine how long this will be necessary. They also need to engage in ongoing system testing in preparation for implementing plans in 2012.
  • Department managers should be reviewing their budgets to see whether they are on-target for what they projected. Department managers need to also determine whether they need to request additional funding for unforeseen costs and increased education in areas such as anatomy and physiology.

This is just a brief summary for some key members of the ICD-10 implementation team. For more information, visit the AHIMA ICD-10 webpage. Remember, it was only a few days ago when we were commenting “where did the year go?”
Last day to register for CMS' ICD-10 implementation teleconference!

CMS will host a national provider teleconference January 12 at 1 p.m. that will focus on ICD-10 implementation in 2011. CMS representatives will discuss implementation strategies for this year.

Registration will close at 1 p.m. on Tuesday, January 11, or when available space has been filled.

Among the agenda items, CMS will address the following:

  • Planning for transition to ICD-10 –A call to action
  • ICD-10 implementation for services provided on and after October 1, 2013—No grace periods or delays
  • Date of service implementation requirements
  • Tools for converting codes – 2011 General Equivalence Mappings (GEMs)
  • Partial freeze of ICD-9-CM and ICD-10 code updates, except for new technologies and diseases
  • Use of unspecified codes in both ICD-9-CM and ICD-10
  • Updating payment and coverage policies for ICD-10
  • Differences between ICD-9-CM and ICD-10
  • Internal planning groups and organizational strategies
  • Awareness, educational strategies and assessing training needs
  • Implementation plan development and impact assessment
  • Determining vendor readiness
  • Coding gap analysis—What needs to be done for your coding staff
  • Assessing quality of medical record documentation
  • Developing an ICD-10 budget
  • Consequences of poor preparation
Look WHO has a free ICD-10 training tool

Can’t wait to learn more about ICD-10? Want to get some basic training and experience in using ICD-10? Not enough money in the budget to go get training? Take a look at the World Health Organization’s website. They have designed a self-study course, which you can work on at your own pace. You can even pick which customization that suits you best:

  • How to apply ICD codes and rules, have a medical background
  • How to apply ICD codes and rules, have little or no medical background
  • Have to fill in death certificates
  • Want to know more about ICD, but will probably never have to assign codes

On November 23, 2010, the North Carolina Healthcare Information & Communications Alliance (NCHICA) and the Workgroup for Electronic Data Interchange (WEDI) published what they call an "alternative" ICD-10 implementation timeline, reflecting the fact that many in the healthcare industry have delayed much of their ICD-10 implementation work.

When the groups created their original timeline, they did so based on the assumption that all entities would begin significant work on their ICD-10 implementation in January 2009. However based on recent surveys, the groups revised the timeline using August 1, 2010, as the new start date while keeping the October 1, 2013 go-live date.

The press release announcing the updated timeline states:

As a result, several steps had to be combined and durations shortened for each group. For vendors, product requirement analysis and reengineering were combined, with duration for those steps shortened from 14 to 8 months. Health plan strategy development was reduced from 6 to 4 months, and system design and development work was reduced from 18 to 12 months. Internal testing time was reduced from 9 to 6 months, external testing from 10 to 8 months. For providers, internal system design and development was reduced from 14 to 6 months, internal testing from 12 to 8 months, and external testing from 10 to 8 months.

This alternative timeline thus gives us a picture of the results of delaying this critically important project, and the increased risks for failure in entities which have delayed their work. For those entities that have delayed work later than the August 2010 date, critical steps are even more drastically impacted. Individual entities should look at both the original timeline and the alternative timeline to determine which timeline best reflects their situation and use that as the starting point for their project plan.
ICD-10-CM codes can tell a different side of the diagnosis story

As many may be aware, laterality has been added in ICD-10-CM to increase specificity. Codes assigned for conditions such as fractures, burns, and pressure ulcers will indicate right side versus left side. Don’t panic—there are still codes available for unspecified “sides.”

For example, consider the following ICD-10-CM categories:

  • L89.60 (pressure ulcer, unspecified heel)
  • L89.61 (pressure ulcer, right heel)
  • L89.62 (pressure ulcer, left heel)

Note that this series of codes also requires a sixth digit to identify the stage of the pressure ulcer (i.e., stage I-IV or unstageable).

Another example illustrating laterality is the ICD-10-CM code for a fracture of the shaft of the radius (ICD-10-CM category S52.3)

The fourth digit identifies the type of fracture (e.g., greenstick or transverse), and the fifth and sixth digits identify right versus left and in some cases whether the fracture was considered displaced or nondisplaced. The final character identifies if it was initial, subsequent, or sequela.

The fracture example brings to mind something for which I am not sure I have seen the answer. Because ICD-10-CM codes will be used for professional and outpatient services and yet the HCPCS codes (CPT and HCPCS II) will still be used to report the procedures, will it still be necessary to report the –RT or –LT modifiers?

I would presume so because identifying whether a physician performed a procedure on the right or left is important. But would it be redundant, like putting a -50 modifier (bilateral procedure) on a procedure code that states bilateral in the description?

It could possibly cause issues if the diagnosis is somehow coded as a fracture of the right shaft of the radius, but for some reason the CPT procedure is assigned with modifier-LT. I could envision the potential of medical necessity denials that we do not encounter using ICD-9-CM diagnosis codes.

For example, we currently have ICD-9-CM diagnosis codes that indicate bilateral hernias. Yet the CPT Manual still instructs coders to utilize modifier-50 when hernias are repaired bilaterally. This reference leads me to believe that even though ICD-10-CM codes will have the added specificity of laterality, coders will still use modifiers –RT, -LT and -50 (for that matter) as they currently do.
‘X’ marks the spot, but for what?

When coders are looking at scenarios in ICD-10-CM/PCS, where the X is located within the code matters.

When X is in the fifth and/or sixth character, X is a placeholder. ICD-10-CM codes can be up to seven characters long. However, not every code that requires a seventh character is actually seven characters long. So some codes do not have an applicable fifth digit. Some lack a fifth and a sixth character. In those cases, such as poisonings or injuries, coders will need to add a placeholder so the seventh character ends up in the correct position. Otherwise, the code will be invalid.

For example, a patient presents with an accidental poisoning by other anti-common-cold drugs. For the initial encounter, coders would report T48.5x1A. In this case the x is merely a placeholder so the sixth and seventh characters are in the correct position. If a coder inadvertently omits the placeholder, code T48.51A is not a valid code.

When X is at the beginning of the code, it indicates the chapter (i.e., codes X00–X99). For code category X78.0, the X is the category of codes and identifies intention of an injury, exposure, etc. The X series of codes is part of Chapter 20: External causes of morbidity.

The character X can be even more confusing to coders who work with both inpatient and outpatient records. In ICD-10-PCS, X can be used in multiple places, each with a different meaning. For example, in ICD-10-PCS code 0HB0XZX, the first X identifies that the approach was external and the second X identifies the procedure was diagnostic.
Will ICD-10 updates occur annually each October 1 as they do for ICD-9?

You can expect ICD-10 updates to follow the same timeline that you are already accustomed to for ICD-9—almost.

An ICD-9-CM Coordination and Maintenance Committee Meeting was held September 15-16, 2010, when it was announced that during this transitional time, the updates for these code sets will follow this schedule:

  • 10/1/11: Last regular ICD-9-CM and ICD-10 updates
  • 10/1/12: Limited updates to both ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM/PCS
  • 10/1/13: Limited updates to ICD-10-CM/PCS (no ICD-9-CM updates)
  • 10/1/14: Regular updates to ICD-10-CM/PCS will resume

To learn more about this decision to partially freeze codes, JustCoding members can access an October 26, 2010 article, "Partial code freeze prompts concern about lingering problematic codes."

A little ICD-10 factoid that might surprise you

We should all be in the middle of our plans to transition from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS. From planning and budgeting to training and auditing to process and technology changes, the details sometimes seem overwhelming and our to-do lists just keep getting longer.

I was doing some research on implementation, and I ran across something that made me pause and say, “Hmmmm…I didn’t know that.” So I wanted to take a moment to share a “factoid” with you. Maybe one day it will come in handy during one of those trivia games.

We have been using ICD-9-CM for many years, and we should know that the ICD stands for international classification of diseases and the CM stands for clinical modification. When we move to ICD-10-CM, both of those definitions will remain the same. However, there is a “pure” version of ICD-10 used internationally by more than 100 countries for cause of death reporting and statistics. On the other hand, more than 25 countries have made modifications to ICD to better capture health information for reimbursement and resource allocation. Here are just a few:

  • Sweden has been using a modification since 1997 and some international codes are omitted from use
  • Australia introduced their version in 1998 called ICD-10-AM
  • Canada implemented their version in 2000 called ICD-10-CA
  • France introduced their version in 2005
  • Germany has a modification called ICD-10-GM
  • A Thailand version has been in use since 2007
  • Korea has been using their modification since 2008

And not to be outdone (although a few years behind), the United States will introduce their version on October 1, 2013.

Keep in mind that the language versions should not be confused with clinical versions because ICD has also been translated into 42 languages in addition to the modifications.

So now you know!

Physicians who are part of a practice do go to the hospital to deliver babies, provide consults, and perform surgeries. So does that mean coders in a physician’s office will need to learn ICD-10-PCS?

The answer is: Coders will not use ICD-10-PCS on physician claims, even for those inpatient visits. The only people using ICD-10-PCS will be hospital personnel who are coding hospital claims.

ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes will be used by all providers in every healthcare setting. So if you're using ICD-9-CM diagnosis codes, then you will replace those codes with ICD-10-CM codes after October 1, 2013.

ICD-10-PCS is the procedure part of ICD-10, and it will only be used for hospital claims for inpatient hospital procedures only. It will not be used by hospitals for their outpatient claims.

The switch to ICD-10-CM/PCS will not impact CPT or HCPCS, so everywhere coders report CPT or HCPCS now, they will continue doing that, even after ICD-10 is implemented

So you still think you have plenty of time before the switch to ICD-10-CM/PCS happens, right? After all it’s still too early to start learning the codes. But what have you done to prepare? According to the AHIMA, outpatient coders should have completed these tasks by the middle of 2011:

  • Understand the ICD-10 final rule and its implications to your coding position.
  • Learn about the structure, organization, and unique features of ICD-10-CM.
  • Use assessment tools to identify areas of strength/weakness in the biomedical sciences (e.g. anatomy and pathophysiology).
  • Review and refresh knowledge of biomedical concepts as needed based on the assessment results.
  • Begin learning about the general equivalence mappings (GEMs) between ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM.

Inpatient coders also need to learn begin studying ICD-10-PCS definitions (root operations and approaches).

Once you have checked those items off your list, start planning for the second half of the year and these recommended tasks:

  • Review code structure and coding conventions for ICD-10-CM.
  • Learn the fundamentals of the ICD-10-CM system.
  • Analyze and practice applying the ICD-10-CM coding guidelines.
  • Continue to review and refresh knowledge of anatomy and physiology concepts.
CMS releases tentative agenda for ICD-9 Coordination and Maintenance Committee meeting

CMS included nine topics related to ICD-10-CM/PCS on its tentative agenda for the ICD-9-CM Coordination and Maintenance Committee meeting March 9-10. This is the final meeting to address ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM/PCS code updates before the partial code freeze is implemented.

CMS will cover procedure topics on the first day of the meeting, with the second day devoted to diagnosis topics. The two-day meeting will be held in the CMS auditorium in Baltimore.

These general ICD-10-CM/PCS topics are included on the tentative agenda:

•    ICD-10-PCS updates

The following specific requests for ICD-10-PCS are also on the tentative agenda:

•    Interspinous process internal fixation - dynamic stabilization vs. static distraction
•    Mesh (biological) in PCS

Anyone who wants to attend one or more session in person must preregister on CMS’ Website. You can also find the complete tentative agenda.
Examine coding for uncontrolled diabetes in ICD-10-CM

In previous versions of the ICD-10-CM Draft Manual, we were all under the impression that certain conditions, such as malignant versus benign hypertension and uncontrolled versus not stated as uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, would be something of the past (i.e. ICD-9-CM). But we know better when it comes to coding!

Coding hypertension in ICD-10-CM will still not identify malignant versus benign, but we found out that uncontrolled diabetes will be identified just in a slightly different way.

At the ICD-9-CM Coordination and Maintenance Committee meeting held September 15-16, 2010, the lack of reference in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic index to terms commonly used to identify the uncontrolled nature of diabetes, such as out of control, was addressed. Luckily, the result was that an instruction was added to identify that the term diabetes that is considered inadequately controlled, out of control, or poorly controlled will be assigned based off the type of diabetes (e.g., type 1, type 2, drug-induced, or due to underlying condition) with hyperglycemia. Consider the following excerpt from the agenda handouts:

Internal review: ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM GEM entries for “uncontrolled diabetes” codes

2010 entry

Example 1

250.02 Diabetes mellitus without mention of complication, type II or unspecified type, uncontrolled

To E11.9 Type 2 diabetes mellitus without complications

Example 2 250.43 Diabetes with renal manifestations, type I [juvenile type], uncontrolled

To E10.21 Type I diabetes mellitus with diabetic nephropathy

Updated 2010 entry

Example 1

250.02 Diabetes mellitus without mention of complication, type II or unspecified type, uncontrolled

To E11.65 Type 2 diabetes mellitus with hyperglycemia

Example 2 250.43 Diabetes with renal manifestations, type I [juvenile type], uncontrolled

To E10.21 Type I diabetes mellitus with diabetic nephropathy AND E10.65 Type I diabetes mellitus with hyperglycemia

Comment

The ICD-10-CM index gives the following instruction under the main term and the three sub-terms below:

Diabetes

- inadequately controlled - code to Diabetes, by type, with hyperglycemia

-out of control - code to Diabetes, by type, with hyperglycemia

-poorly controlled - code to Diabetes, by type, with hyperglycemia

The interesting thing to note is that currently in ICD-9-CM, the term “poorly controlled” does not default to a fifth digit identifying “uncontrolled,” however "inadequately" and "out of control" do default to uncontrolled.
Two sides to every story: A physician and a coder discuss ICD-10's impact

I was talking with a friend of mine recently about the transition to ICD-10. He is a very good doctor who prefers to leave the “administrative details” to his capable office manager. Although he recognizes that the transition from ICD-9 to ICD-10 is significant, he feels that on the surface, the change won't really impact him as a doctor all that much.

He knows it will entail updating his encounter forms to accommodate the new diagnosis codes from their current three- to five-digit configuration to three to seven digits. For the most part though, he feels it is basically a billing issue and something that mainly concerns the statisticians.

After all, he points out, look who benefits from the implementation of the new system. The 3M Corporation will be a big winner with its contracts and software products related to the system changes as well as the coding organizations. But, I pointed out, changing to ICD-10 will have a far more outreaching effect. It will affect the quality, costs, and documentation needs of our health care system.

I expounded the benefits that ICD-10 will be more accurate and precise in both reporting from the physicians and reimbursement levels from payers and how training for the new system will not be such a stretch for those already familiar with ICD-9. In addition, America will finally be able to communicate in the same language as the rest of the world already using ICD-10.

But my friend questioned these benefits, saying that the additional detail in documentation won’t truly benefit practitioners. And, he argued, there will be confusion of 1 vs. I and O vs. 0. A-ha! So he had been doing some homework! He voiced grave concerns about the politicians vowing to help improve the health care system.

But I persisted. Surely, the benefits outweigh the costs. Again, he questioned my assertion. He feels that whenever Washington hands down an “improvement,” somehow physicians are more often than not burdened with the short end of the stick. He agrees there is much to be said for implementing ICD-10, but he is not convinced the benefits outweigh the costs or that all the costs have been thoroughly considered.

He feels that I’m on the “Trust me. This is a good thing.” bandwagon without seriously entertaining the cons involved. I acknowledged that with change comes pain, but also gain.

What do you think? Hit the comments button.
Should I pursue training now or later or both?

A common question I have been asked lately is whether coders should receive ICD-10 training now, or should they wait until much closer to the implementation date of October 1, 2013? Comments by some nationally known organizations such as the American Academy of Professional Coders (AAPC) and CMS have many wondering what they should do?

In a recent issue of Coding Edge, the AAPC advised coders to wait to obtain training on the specifics of the ICD-10 codes due to the fact that the code sets are currently in their draft format. However, during the January 12 CMS teleconference, a CMS representative specifically stated that during Phase I (i.e., the timeframe of 1st quarter 2009–2nd quarter 2011), coders should learn about the differences between ICD-9 and ICD-10 and the value of the new code sets.

I tend to lean a little more toward the CMS thought process, but also understand the hesitance on the AAPC’s viewpoint. It is true that the code sets are in a draft format currently, but they may likely remain that way until the last revision to the ICD-10 code sets. Consider the following schedule for the remaining planned updates:

  • The last regular annual update to both ICD-9-CM and ICD-10 will be made on October 1, 2011.
  • On October 1, 2012, there will be only limited code updates to both ICD-9-CM and ICD-10 code sets to capture new technology and new diseases.
  • On October 1, 2013, there will be only limited code updates to ICD-10 code sets to capture new technology and new diseases.

It's important to note that changes can be made up until the implementation date. I do not think that we should decide not to pursue training based on the fact that the code sets are still a “draft version.” I think this is the perfect time for coders and other health information professionals associated with the coding process to at least get very basic training on the structural differences as well as documentation differences that the new code set will require. Why wait to start requesting physicians to increase the specificity in their documentation? The longer this information has been ingrained, the more prepared and less traumatic the transition will be in my opinion.

I do feel that really extensive training may be futile because we still have a few years before implementation. Coders can maybe hold off for a year or so and then pursue this type of training. It may be difficult to keep both code sets fresh in our minds and not overload ourselves. I just think knowing what is coming is much better than procrastinating for fear of “changes” in the system. The system's overall structure will not change prior to implementation, however there can be revisions to the code sets themselves. But as coders, we are used to that aspect. Every year we easily adjust to revised codes and accommodate new codes. I don’t think we ought to see ICD-10 all that differently.

In terms of when you personally decide to obtain some training on ICD-10 is an individual decision, however, as a fellow coder I would encourage all of you to at least learn the basics of the code sets so that you can prepare yourself for what is to come.
