ICD-10 Transition Planning: Evaluating Your Organization’s Mindset

This series of entries will not follow a random bi-weekly topic but will focus on the chronological transition to ICD-10 readiness. My intent is to dispel myths and compare real-world experience in the ICD-10 planning space with the commonly disseminated wisdom of the healthcare industry’s coding, compliance and payor advisory bodies. Let’s first discuss how to evaluate your organization’s mindset.

Most conventional wisdom on the topic of ICD-10 planning dives directly into the process of determining impact and creating a current state assessment for use in assembling a complete roadmap toward compliance. Although basically valid, this approach skips a few crucial steps. Without knowing how your organization sees this behemoth of a transition, you cannot hope to formulate a transition strategy or mitigate any of your risk. This logic applies to both the small group practice as well as the large multi-hospital health system.

I have observed on various occasions that despite industry pamphlets, project plans, and seminars, many organizations still pigeonhole ICD-10 into the revenue cycle, IT, or coding space and isolate the majority of their efforts and governance inside that limited mindset.

This is a terminal mistake and will cause drastic repercussions ultimately making well-meaning efforts ineffective. Those directors, physicians or executives that control the multi-year budgeting process must be made aware upfront that the ramification of limiting this process to a single business unit puts the organization’s long term survival in jeopardy. Logically, the case for setting a high priority is easy. Politically or socially this can be one of the hardest steps in getting a project moving forward.

The best way to emphasize the importance of the project and gain supporters is to let manager level employees think about the change ramifications that directly affect their areas of responsibility. Effects on people, processes, and systems will be drastic in some cases. The objective here is not to cause fear, it is to garner support and inspire action—action you will provide as part of a proactive approach to an impending risk.

The pigeonhole mindset is usually the result of the stakeholder or decision maker not seeing the personal ramifications of this transition. Like in sales, if there is no problem to solve combined with a ramification of inaction, you will have no priority. Once the concern is firmly understood and personalized by the decision maker, your team can move on to define the scope of the issue.

ICD codes are deeply rooting in almost every major business process inside a healthcare entity. They support clinical care, allow for billing, justify adjudication, and can be the backbone of compliance. This makes ICD-10 a strategic concern worthy of both human and capital resources. Change programs of this magnitude require process, systematic, and training investments that will directly compete with electronic health record dollars in the present and accountable care organization and meaningful use determination in the future. ICD-10 must take its place beside those strategic issues as a large initiative worthy of high priority. Your team will need to instill this mindset in stakeholders like a mantra so that when mundane tasks once again consume their workday you can be assured that this mindset of priority will plant the seed of action.

Your stakeholders must not only understand the scope of the risk, but also the scope of the solution.

  • Can a revenue cycle project upgrade systems or provide awareness training to several thousand front office or inpatient staff?
  • Can an IT project change coding processes to maintain coded-per-hour metrics?
  • Can a coding or audit project maintain your standards for days in accounts receivable?

When we ask ourselves and our stakeholders these types of questions, we begin to realize that an enterprise problem demands an enterprise solution. As we move toward the formation of the ICD-10 steering committee we will see that the planning and implementation stages will require cross-functional interviews, budgets, and governance that are simply not possible within a small departmental framework.

The mindset variable can be a decisive one. At the beginning of an initiative like this, be sure to focus on stakeholder understanding and support with a clear picture toward future action. If you as the ICD-10 champion can establish personalized stakeholder priority, enterprise risk awareness and enterprise solution support, you have created a strong foundation for the governing structure that is to come.
CMS indentifies error in 5010 FISS logic

As many of you know, before we switch to ICD-10-CM/PCS, we first will be transitioning to HIPAA Version 5010. In fact, that date is less than one year away. By January 1, 2012, providers need to be fully compliant with Version 5010 standards if they conduct electronic transactions either directly or through a clearinghouse or billing service.

Well, providers aren’t the only ones running into trouble during the transition. On January 28, CMS issued Transmittal 851 to instruct contractors regarding the present-on-admission (POA) indicator and version 5010 claim submission. This transmittal modifies FISS logic to auto-populate POA indicator "Z" for IPPS hospitals using 5010.

CMS found that the FISS was not correctly applying the hospital-acquired condition logic correctly and was dropping the POA indicator Z from inpatient claims. CMS determined that because providers would be unable to report the ‘Z’ (End of POA) indicator under 5010, the grouper would not apply hospital-acquired condition logic correctly, resulting in payment implications for providers.

Before you can think about implementing ICD-10, you need to be sure your numerous Hospital Information Systems (HIS) and Practice Management Systems (PMS) are upgraded for the change. It can be a potentially overwhelming process, and it has to start now.

During our 90-minute live intermediate-level audio conference, “ICD-10 Vendor Readiness: Build Your Game Plan Now,” our expert speakers will give you strategies and hands-on advice to streamline the upgrading process. You’ll learn how to work with your vendors to ensure their systems are ready for this very significant change in the way you’ll be doing business in the future.

You’ll walk away with a list of questions to ask your vendors to ensure your transition to ICD-10 is a success.

For more information and for an audio clip preview of the show, visit HCPro's marketplace page.
Check out ICD-10 related FAQs on CMS website

CMS has posted two new frequently asked questions (FAQs) about ICD-10 national provider teleconferences and the partial code freeze. To access these FAQs, please visit the CMS ICD-10 webpage, click on the Medicare Fee-for-Service Provider Resources link on the left, scroll down the page to the “Related Links Inside CMS” section, and select “ICD-10 FAQs.”

This FAQ section addresses the following questions:

  • Will there be a code freeze for ICD-10?
  • Will ICD-10 have an impact on CPT and HCPCS codes?
  • Will ICD-10 codes be used in all health care provider type settings such as hospitals, physician offices, home health visits, skilled nursing facilities, etc?
  • Will overly detailed medical record documentation be required for ICD-10?

The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) posted the new 2011 guidelines for ICD-10-CM on its website. You won’t find many significant changes to conventions, general coding guidelines, and chapter specific guidelines, but the changes are easy to spot.

In the actual guidelines, the CDC uses bold text for narrative changes and underlines items that have moved within the guidelines since 2010. Heading changes are in italics.

Here are some of the changes:

Some of the most significant additional information appears in Chapter 5: Mental and Behavioral Disorders (F01–F99). The guidelines include new narrative information about mental and behavioral disorders due to psychoactive substance use, including a new heading.

The guidelines for Chapter 6, Diseases of Nervous System and Sense Organs (G00-G99), includes this information under “Dominant/nondominant” side:

Should the affected side be documented, but not specified as dominant or nondominant, and the classification system does not indicate a default, code selection is as follows:
• For ambidextrous patients, the default should be dominant.
• If the left side is affected, the default is non-dominant.
• If the right side is affected, the default is dominant.

In Chapter 15: Pregnancy, Childbirth, and the Puerperium, under the “final character for trimester”, the guidelines now state that coders may use the provider’s documentation of the number of weeks to assign the appropriate code identifying the trimester.

For fetal extensions, coders should assign a seventh character where applicable, to identify the fetus for which the complication code applies. Those categories include O31, O32, O33.3–O33.6, O35, O36, O40, O41, O60.1, O60.2, O64, and O69. The guidelines further clarify when coders should assign a seventh character of “0”.

In Chapter 19: Injury, Poisoning, and Certain Other Consequences of External Causes (S00–T88), the guidelines also include new instructions on the appropriate seventh character for delayed treatment. Specifically, coders should assign the appropriate seventh character for initial encounter for a patient who delayed seeking treatment for the fracture or nonunion.

In Chapter 20, External Causes of Morbidity, the guidelines for activity code now include the following:

A code from category Y93 is appropriate for use with external cause and intent codes if identifying the activity provides additional information about the event.

In the same chapter, under “External cause status”, you’ll find this instruction:

An external cause status code is used only once, at the initial encounter for treatment. Only one code from Y99 should be recorded on a medical record.


These are only some of the changes in the first section of the guidelines. Even though the transition is still more than a year away, it’s a good idea to at least become familiar with the guidelines now.
Should we learn ICD-10 codes now or later?

As a regulatory specialist, I find myself asking my students, fellow coders, and other colleagues (e.g., clinical documentation improvement specialists) where they are in terms of preparation for ICD-10 implementation. Have they taken the time to familiarize themselves with the codes? Often, the answer is "No, we don’t have time." Others raise the concern that ICD-10 is simply in a draft version and that they are waiting for the finalized version.

I can’t say that it is much of a surprise. However, if you haven’t started working toward ICD-10 implementation, then your organization may find itself in trouble when ICD-10 takes effect on October 1, 2013.

As a fellow coder, I can understand being busy and not having the time to focus on something that doesn’t impact us for a couple of years down the road. We are often too busy just trying to keep up with the ICD-9-CM changes every year.

And since the recovery audit contractor program began, we are also busy worrying about documentation improvement and ensuring that we are reporting appropriately based on current guidelines and Coding Clinics—many are simply struggling with all of the different audits.

However, as a certified coder, one of my responsibilities is to keep up the certification by earning continuing education credits. So why not put some of those credits that you have to earn toward familiarizing yourself with the ICD-10 system? Both the American Health Information Management Association (AHIMA) and the American Academy of Professional Coders have laid out their plans for ICD-10 certification requirements. The earlier I start, the more time I will have to prepare myself.

Speaking to the concern that ICD-10 is in a draft format and that you may be waiting for the finalized version, keep in mind that ICD-10 will remain in draft format until closer to the implementation deadline. However, every year a version of the ICD-10-CM/PCS Manuals are printed so that you can get an idea of what the codes look like and what the coding guidelines are going to be when it is finalized. Since the first draft version, changes have been made, but the system itself has not changed. Right now, the codes resemble what they are going to look like when we get to our implementation deadline with revisions, additions, and possibly even some deletions.

The coding guidelines for the most part look a lot like what we currently have for ICD-9-CM, but there are some significant changes that I think as an AHIMA certified ICD-10 trainer could be big issues for coders. For example, there is a difference when it comes to principal diagnosis selection. Unless they make big changes to the ICD-9-CM Guidelines for Coding and Reporting, then those changes are going to impact us in a matter of a minute—on September 30, 2013 we are going to code it one way, and then on October 1, 2013 it will change.

I, for one, believe it is extremely important that I start asking myself, “How is this going to look in ICD-10?” We are creatures of habit, and we get used to the idea that “it has always been coded this way.” At least if I can keep in mind that it is that way for now, but won’t be when ICD-10 comes into effect, then I believe it will be easier for me to make the transition to ICD-10.

I panicked when the American Hospital Association said previous Coding Clinics were not going to be "translated" to account for ICD-10 codes. But now as I familiarize myself with some of the ICD-10 code changes, I find it easier to understand that it may not be necessary to reference many of the Coding Clinics when assigning ICD-10 codes. This is because with the new coding system, there may be one code with the extensions that will address what we now require two or more codes to do in ICD-9. Therefore, sequencing may not be an issue.

I have also started to look at medical records to determine whether there is enough documentation in the record to code accurately with the ICD-10 system, in hopes that I can work with physicians and clinical documentation improvement specialists to ensure that we are clearing up those potential documentation nightmares before October 1, 2013.

The biggest issue I see is with ICD-10-PCS, which is very different from ICD-9 volume 3 procedure codes. ICD-10-PCS codes are much more specific, and I know that physicians often don't provide enough information for coders to assign all the characters. So if we can fix those potential documentation nightmares now, we won’t have a backlog of charts that we cannot code due to insufficient information. And we all know how much physicians love to answer queries. If I can begin to educate them a little at a time over the next two years about those issues, then it shouldn’t be such a difficult process.

So, should you be waiting to closer to ICD-10 implementation date to start learning the system or do you think that you should get started now to ensure a successful transition for you and your organization?

As we work toward the implementation of ICD-10 in 2013, strategic opportunities for change abound. Remember all those items that have remained static on your operational wish list? Perhaps you can integrate some of those items into the ICD-10 implementation project that is underway at your organization.

Start now by exploring and identifying potential strategic advantages that can be further developed as you travel down the road of your planning process. Some of these opportunities may include modified partnerships or revisions in revenue growth models; or maybe even a new role in your own career!
ICD-10-CM/PCS guidelines now include present on admission reporting guidelines

ICD-10-CM/PCS now has guidelines for reporting conditions that are present on admission (POA). As part of the 2011 guidelines updates, CMS and the National Center for Health Statistics added Appendix I to cover reporting POA.

The POA guidelines are a supplement to the ICD-10-CM Official Guidelines for Coding and Reporting and are designed to facilitate the assignment of the POA indicator for each diagnosis and external cause of injury code reported on claim forms. These guidelines do not replace information in the official guidelines. Don’t look to these guidelines to tell you which conditions should be coded as POA, either. They are designed only to explain how to append the POA indicator.

Some general items to note in the guidelines:

•    Coders may use medical record documentation from any provider involved in the care and treatment of the patient to support the determination of whether a condition was present on admission or not. For these guidelines, a “provider” is a physician or any qualified healthcare practitioner who is legally accountable for establishing the patient’s diagnosis.

•    POA means the condition was present at the time the order for inpatient admission occurs. Conditions that develop during an outpatient encounter, including emergency department, observation, or outpatient surgery, are considered present on admission.

•    Coders should assign POAs indicators to principal and secondary diagnoses and the external cause of injury codes.

•    Providers do not have to document a condition as POA within any specified time frame.

For more on the specifics on how to assign POA indicators, review Appendix I of the guidelines. The appendix begins on page 101.
AHIMA top 10 list outlines critical tasks for Phase I

The American Health Information Management Association (AHIMA) recently posted on its ICD-10 webpage a Top 10 List: Phase One. In early 2011, Phase I (first quarter 2009–second quarter 2011) of the ICD-10-CM/PCS Organizational Impact Assessment will be coming to a close, the AHIMA notes.

The AHIMA outlines 10 tasks in a condensed format to help facilitate ICD-10-CM/PCS implementation plan development and impact assessment. For example, to execute the step "Perform impact assessment," the AHIMA recommends that organizations:

  • Identify range of impact on every department
  • Analyze impact on operational processes
  • Assess impact on documentation processes and work flow
  • Identify impacted internal and external reporting
  • Assess the detail in clinical documentation to determine whether it is adequate to support ICD-10-CM/PCS

The list also states that HIM managers and coding professionals should become familiar with the format, basic structure, and fundamentals of ICD-10-CM/PCS. If your organization is currently tackling this task of education, learn more about HCPro's ICD-10 Basics Boot Camp™ and ICD-10 Basics Boot Camp Online™.

To access the AHIMA Top 10 list in its entirety, click here.

HCPro is conducting research into how organizations are assessing their ICD-10 readiness. Click the link below to participate.

http://www.zoomerang.com/Survey/WEB22C5AE44S33/
To switch or not to switch…

I saw a question posted recently regarding the inclusion or exclusion of Workers Comp, property, casualty, and auto under the CMS mandate to implement ICD-10. My first reaction was why wouldn’t they be part of the mandate so that we don’t have to maintain two coding systems. My next reaction was do I have any proof to back up my first reaction. Unfortunately that answer was no - so I went in search of an official response.

I found a document on the CMS website - www.cms.gov/ICD10 - called ICD-10-CM/PCS: Myths and Facts that was published in April 2010. CMS states that noncovered entities which are not covered by HIPAA, such as Workers’ Compensation and auto insurance companies that use ICD-9-CM may choose not to implement ICD-10-CM/PCS.

I gasped – they can’t be serious? I guess I never really thought about the “noncovered” entities not be being required to transition to ICD-10. Apparently I have been living under a rock and I have been under the assumption that if you report, accept, or use ICD-9 codes, you would be switching to ICD-10.

CMS goes on to say that it is in the noncovered entities’ best interest to use the new coding system because the detailed level of coding would add value to their roles in their healthcare industry. CMS also says it will work with noncovered entities to encourage their use of ICD-10-CM/PCS. Ah-ohhhhhh!

I am not a purveyor of doom and gloom, but this could throw a really big wrench in our implementation plans. It might be a good idea to identify the noncovered entities that you share data with and inquire if they will be switching to ICD-10 and if they will be ready on October 1, 2013. If not, you may need to start thinking of Plan B, if you haven’t already. Does anyone have a Plan B?
Check out changes to ICD-10-CM guidelines for neoplasms

The 2011 ICD-10-CM Official Guidelines include several changes relating to the correct coding for neoplasms. Chapter 2 of the ICD-10-CM contains the codes for most benign and all malignant neoplasms. Coders for certain benign neoplasms, such as prostatic adenomas, appear in the specific body system chapters.

Under the Coding and sequencing of complications section, ICD-10-CM guidelines now state that when the admission or encounter is for the management of an anemia associated with an adverse effect of radiotherapy, coders should sequence the anemia code first, followed by the appropriate neoplasm code. In addition, coders should report code Y84.2 (radiological procedure and radiotherapy as the cause of abnormal reaction of the patient, or of later complication, without mention of misadventure at the time of the procedure)

Under Admissions/Encounters involving chemotherapy, immunotherapy and radiation therapy, the guidelines now instruct coders to report the code for the neoplasm as principal or first-listed diagnosis when an episode of care involves the surgical removal of a neoplasm, followed by adjunct chemotherapy or radiation treatment during the same episode of care.

Don’t forget these general reminders about coding for neoplasms in ICD-10-CM:
To properly code a neoplasm, determine from the record if the neoplasm is benign, in-situ, malignant, or of uncertain histologic behavior.

For malignant neoplasms, determine any secondary (metastatic) sites.

In general, reference the neoplasm table in the Alphabetic Index first when looking for the code(s).
If the provider documents the histological term, reference that term first, rather than going immediately to the Neoplasm Table, in order to determine which column in the Neoplasm Table is appropriate.

To read up on all of the ICD-10-CM guidelines for 2011, download the official guidelines from the CDC.
Lack of unspecified options for seventh characters—a root cause for documentation issues??

One of the things I have always liked about ICD-9-CM is that no matter how poor the documentation, if a code requires a fourth and/or fifth digit the manual always gives what I call the “out” by having an option of “unspecified”.

It sometimes can appear as its own fifth digit such as in category 550 for an inguinal hernia. The fifth digit provides as an option a “0” to identify either a unilateral (not specified as recurrent) or unspecified. This option can be a lifesaver in some circumstances where the documentation is solely “inguinal hernia”. We have an option for a fifth digit without querying the provider for clarification.

Don’t get me wrong, it’s best to make sure we have clear and complete information in our documentation. However in instances holding up a record to query is not feasible nor would it yield a different outcome from a payment perspective.  

Now in ICD-10-CM, we’ll find some situations where these options are still available to us. Based on the example above, we will continue to have unspecified options as you can see below. Even though it does not state “unspecified” in the code title it does include inguinal hernia, NOS.  

K40.90 Unilateral inguinal hernia, without obstruction or gangrene, not specified as recurrent

Inguinal hernia NOS
Unilateral inguinal hernia NOS

So, if it looks the same why do I bring it up? Well, in ICD-10-CM some code categories include brand new concepts that are not reflected in the ICD-9-CM code set such as the identification of initial versus subsequent versus sequela as part of the code title.  

Coding for an open wound of the elbow is assigned 881.01 (open wound of elbow, forearm and/or wrist, without mention of complication) for the initial encounter and would likely be assigned an aftercare code (V58.43) for any subsequent encounters and late effects codes (906.1) to identify a related sequela from a previous injury.

In ICD-10-CM, the identification of which encounter provides the detail necessary without needing different categories of codes. For example:

S51.001 Unspecified open wound of right elbow
S51.002 Unspecified open wound of left elbow
S51.009 Unspecified open wound of unspecified elbow
Open wound of elbow NOS

This category requires a seventh character extension. The options are:

The appropriate 7th character is to be added to each code from category S51

A, initial encounter
D, subsequent encounter
S, sequela


Is the provider going to be required to document initial, subsequent, or sequela because no unspecified option exists for the seventh character? If ICD-10-CM ends up being fashioned as ICD-9-CM then the options should be:

The appropriate 7th character is to be added to each code from category S51

A, initial encounter or unspecified
D, subsequent encounter
S, sequela

Applying the definition of a default I would presume the most common occurrence would be to assign this code category as an initial encounter which is why I suggested “A” as a default seventh character. But, until that addition is in the book or further clarification is made in the guidelines, it appears the documentation will need to clearly state this information in order to support selection of a seventh character.
Do I need to learn ICD-10-PCS?

Coders are discussing whether they need to be trained in ICD-10-CM only or should they also receive training in ICD-10-PCS. Well, the answer may depend on what setting you are currently employed in, what position you current hold, and your career path for the future.

In general, if you are in any of the following “documentation dependent” positions, you will need PCS training, but the degree of training may vary depending on your role:

  • HIM directors working in a hospital setting
  • Coders who code only inpatient hospital discharges
  • Coders who code both inpatient discharges and outpatient visits in a hospital setting
  • Clinical documentation specialists who work in an inpatient hospital setting


If you are in either of the following positions, PCS training may be optional:

  • HIM directors working in clinic settings
  • Coders who code only outpatient visits in a hospital setting
  • Coders who code only professional procedure codes (i.e. CPT, HCPCS Level II) in a physician’s office or other clinic setting


Keep in mind that I use “optional” training loosely. Coders who will only ever use CPT procedure coding may not need PCS training. However, you may want to consider where your career path might be going in the future.

Let’s take a look at the two main organizations that are recognized for their coding credentials. According to AHIMA, the CCS credential “demonstrates a practitioner's tested data quality and integrity skills, and mastery of coding proficiency” which applies to coding both inpatient and outpatient records. However, the training checklist on AHIMA’s website indicates outpatient coders need only learn ICD-10-CM.

On the other hand, AAPC states that its credential CPC-H is for identifying “proficiency in assigning accurate medical codes for diagnoses, procedures and services performed in the hospital or clinical outpatient setting.” In addition, the AAPC training section identifies PCS for inpatient coding.

So with that said, if you are not currently in a setting that would use ICD-10-PCS and you never plan to be in that setting, PCS training may be optional. Coders who currently code or are considering coding in the hospital setting, regardless if they code inpatient only or outpatient only coding tasks, may be better served by obtaining PCS training now to be considered a well-rounded coding expert.

My point of view is that if you are possibly looking at a career change that may be affected by ICD-10-PCS, you should consider training now so you don’t have to play catch up later. Currently, I am not working in a hospital setting, but you never know when opportunity may knock!
How are you doing with your transition to 5010?

The current versions of the X12 Version 4010/4010A1 transaction standards  lack certain functionality that are pertinent to the healthcare industry. By now, health plans, healthcare clearinghouses, and healthcare providers should be heavily involved in working to achieve  Level I compliance (required as of January 1, 2011) with HIPAA 5010 standards. It is important for physician practices to be working with vendors on the transition to 5010. To bring it down to the most basic level, transactions are electronic exchanges involving the transfer of healthcare information between two parties for specific purposes (e.g., a provider submitting a claim to a health plan for payment). The 5010 version replaces the X12 version that designated entities must use when conducting electronic transactions, including:

  • Claims and encounter information
  • Payment and remittance advice
  • Claims status
  • Eligibility
  • Enrollment and disenrollment
  • Referrals and authorizations

Level I compliance means that covered entities can create and receive compliant transactions. Level II compliance, which is required by January 1, 2012 means that entities have completed testing with each of their trading partners and are able to operate in production mode with the new versions of the standards.

One of the things that 5010 will do is increase the diagnostic field size to accommodate ICD-10-CM/PCS codes. Other changes include the ability to distinguish between ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM/PCS codes, which will be necessary during the transition period after ICD-10-CM/PCS is implemented in 2013, when providers may be using both code sets. Communicate with your vendors to understand what their plans are for testing and helping you to migrate to 5010.

Read this American Health Information Management Association article to learn more about preparing for 5010.
One size does NOT fit all for ICD-10 training

When it comes to training staff members for the upcoming transition to ICD-10-CM/PCS, not everyone has the same needs or characteristics. They don’t even belong to the same group of shareholders.

Everyone on your staff, with the possible exception of the janitorial crew and the cafeteria staff, will need some ICD-10 training so you need to have a game plan to address the different needs, says Omar Rosario, PMP, lead associate at Booz Allen Hamilton in Washington.

Everyone needs to understand their roles within the organization and what expectations they will have to meet during and after the transition to ICD-10.

When preparing to train the different groups of stakeholders, look at their motivations, Rosario says. What’s in it for them? How does this transition and the education that goes with it make their jobs easier?

Don’t forget about the collective motivation as well, the idea that this change is good for the healthcare system and your facility as a whole. You can’t get to one type of motivation without the other.
Where does ICD-10 transition fit in?

As most people in the healthcare industry know, the conversion to ICD-10-CM/PCS isn’t the only initiative organizations are trying to implement. So where does the ICD-10 conversion fit within your organization’s priority list?

That was one of the questions an expert panel answered during the ICD-10 as an enabling strategy session at the American Health Information Management Association’s ICD-10 Summit in Baltimore April 11-12.

Consider what they had to say and how it compares to your facility’s priorities.

Gloryanne Bryant, RHIA, RHIT, CCS, CCDS, regional managing director of HIM Revenue Cycle at Kaiser Permanente in Oakland, CA, sees the ICD-10 transition as one of priorities for those in health information management. She believes it is a bigger priority this year because the implementation deadline is coming closer.

Bryant sees computer-assisted coding and moving to a completely electronic medical record as other high-focus areas.

Todd Craghead, vice president of Intermountain Healthcare in Salt Lake City, said it’s obvious that things will be influenced by the transition to ICD-10. However, certain key initiatives are always at the forefront at Intermountain, including working to capture the level of detail that is necessary to influence care.

Stuart Erdman, senior director of finance for Johns Hopkins Health System in Baltimore, said the hospital system is very involved in the transition to ICD-10, but it is not the highest priority in the short term. Like many other facilities, Johns Hopkins is struggling to deal with state and federal budget cuts and how that revenue reduction translates to the health system’s budget.

Coding productivity will decrease at least initially with the switch to ICD-10-CM/PCS. But do you know how productive your coders are now? If the answer is no, consider following  the example of Mary A. Roberts, CCS,  regional coding manager for BayCare Health System in Tampa Bay. BayCare employs approximately 80 coders for its 12 hospitals and 20 outpatient ambulatory care centers.

“We felt that if ICD-10 was going to impact productivity, then we needed a baseline,” Roberts said during the AHIMA ICD-10 Summit in Baltimore April 11-12. So Roberts and BayCare worked with Karen Youmans, MPA, RHIA, CCS, President of YES Consulting in Largo, FL, to find out.

Different coders code at very different rates, depending on their experience and knowledge level. In addition, they also spend differing amounts of time on coding and other tasks, such as querying physicians and waiting for reports.

The team also looked for trends. For example, less experienced coders queried more, Roberts said. As a result, Roberts teamed up coders with different experience levels so the more experienced coders could serve as mentors. Before the coder writes a query, he or she can ask the mentor if that person has time to review the file.

Roberts and her team plan to use the ongoing assessments to help map out where they need to provide education going forward. But at least they have a place to start. Do you?
Determine best approach for training clinicians

Getting clinicians onboard and trained for the transition to ICD-10-CM/PCS will be one of the biggest challenges for most facilities, according to Patricia A.C. Hildebrand, MSN, RN, AHIMA-approved ICD-10 trainer, CCS-P, CPHQ, FACHE-designate, and executive director of Hildebrand Healthcare Consulting in  Midland, TX.

Clinicians fall into two separate groups, which require different approaches to training for ICD-10-CM/PCS, said Hildebrand during the AHIMA ICD-10 Summit in Baltimore April 11.

Independent providers are not facility or practice employees, which means you can’t dictate to them. For these providers, Hildebrand recommended keeping training to a minimum. One-page lists of FAQs work well, she said. Use bold type and color to catch their eye. Since clinicians are trained not to take anything at face value, include a citation or where they can find more information.

Be careful when asking for a time commitment from these clinicians because their business is treating patients and time is money, Hildebrand said. Consider approaching the youngest partner in the group or the loudest complainer and asking for his or her help.

You can take a different approach when dealing with clinicians who are employed by the practice or facility. Those clinicians are motivated by different things, Hildebrand said.
When you provide them with more detailed ICD-10-CM/PCS information, do it as part of their continuing education. Look to your state licensing board for some education as well.

Tap into their sense of competitiveness, Hildebrand advised. For this, contests work well, she added.

It’s hard to get people to work on a team. Create cross-functional teams where members sit down and deal with whatever they need to change to ensure a smooth, successful transition to ICD-10-CM/PCS. Those challenges will vary by facility and practice, so look at how things are done where you work.
Payers and providers need to work together

Many of the speakers at the AHIMA’s ICD-10 Summit April 11-12 in Baltimore stressed the importance of working together. Physicians, coders, and information technology folks all need to work together for a successful implementation, but you need to extend that cooperation outside the organization as well.

Those in the healthcare industry need to do a lot more sharing—with colleagues, those above and below them in the organization, and their peers, said Gloryanne Bryant, RHIA, RHIT, CCS, CCDS, regional managing director of HIM Revenue Cycle at Kaiser Permanente in Oakland, CA.

“It’s important that on day one, things don’t go bump in the night,” said Dennis Winkler, director of technical program management for Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Michigan (BCBS). Winkler said BCBS wants to partner with key facilities so that when they test their ICD-10-CM/PCS systems, they are testing with real data.

“It’s kind of a shame that we need this type of initiative to get all of the parties to sit down and discuss what is best for the industry,” Winkler added.

The need to share information will go beyond the 2013 implementation date before the process of reporting ICD-10-CM/PCS codes is really seamless, Bryant said.
Struggling to sort out sprains and strains

When teaching ICD-9-CM coding, I often use a little ditty, “sprains and strains are the same,” to remind myself that when a physician documents “strain,” I need to start with the main term of “sprain” in the ICD-9-CM Manual. If you go to the main term of strain in the ICD-9-CM alphabetic index, it directs you to the term “sprain.” Therefore, in ICD-9-CM there is no difference between a sprain vs. a strain.

However, if you refer to the main term "strain" in the ICD-10-CM alphabetic index, you will see modifying terms for certain types of strains. For example, if we use the modifying term “cervical,” the manual references ICD-10-CM code S16.1. If you then go to the main term "sprain" and use the modifying term “cervical,” the manual references ICD-10-CM code S13.4—a completely different code. Other modifying terms under strain might suggest the coder cross-reference other main terms (e.g., injury, muscle, by site, and strain), but there are no cross-references to the main term “sprain.” That is until you reach the site under injury, and then it might cross-reference the coder to “see sprain.”

This brings to mind a few questions. Are sprains and strains actually not the same? And if they aren’t, then why have we never made the distinction before? Also why there are only a handful of modifying terms under the main term “strain?” Is it because in some areas strains are different, whereas in other areas sprains and strains really are the same? And how is a coder to know?

This may be another potential documentation concern when it comes to ICD-10-CM, and we should discuss this possible coding challenge with our physicians to make them aware of the different codes based on the documentation of the word strain vs. sprain with certain anatomical modifying terms. This is just one of the many reasons why it is important to start working with the ICD-10 code sets now in order to help identify potential documentation and coding nightmares before the implementation October 1, 2013 date.
CMS to host call focusing on ICD-10 conversion activities

CMS will host a national provider teleconference, "CMS ICD-10 Conversion Activities," on May 18, 1 - 2:30 p.m. EST.  Presenters will discuss the ICD-10 conversion process currently taking place within CMS, including a case study from the CMS Coverage and Analysis Group on their transition to ICD-10 for the lab national coverage determinations (NCDs). A question and answer session will follow the presentations.

This teleconference will be geared toward medical coders, physician office staff, provider billing staff, health records staff, vendors, educators, system maintainers, and all Medicare fee-for-service providers.

CMS representatives will address the following topics:

  • ICD-10 overview
  • Lab NCDs conversion process from ICD-9-CM to 1CD-10-CM
  • Home health conversion
  • OASIS and procedure code reporting
  • Update on claims spanning the implementation date
  • National ICD-10 implementation issues


To register for the call participants need to go to: http://www.eventsvc.com/palmettogba/051811

Registration will close at 1 p.m. on May 17, or when available space has been filled.

To learn more, access the CMS website.


Upgrading to 5010

5010.  That’s the cool way of saying Version 5010 of the Accredited Standards Committee (ASC) X12.  It is the next version of the HIPAA electronic transaction standards that providers and all HIPAA covered entities must comply w

Upgrading to 5010

5010. That’s the cool way of saying Version 5010 of the Accredited Standards Committee (ASC) X12. It is the next version of the HIPAA electronic transaction standards that providers and all HIPAA covered entities must comply with by January 1, 2012. If you are prepared to send and receive 5010 transactions and your clearinghouses or payers are ready as well, you can begin to use the 5010 transactions prior to January 1, 2012 if you mutually agree to this. Using the transactions early gives you the peace of mind that everything is working smoothly and your claims will continue to be processed. If you do identify any issues, you can resolve them prior to the compliance date when all the procrastinators will just be finding out that they have a problem. You will need version 5010 of the HIPAA transactions in order to report your ICD-10 codes. The compliance date for using ICD-10 codes is October 1, 2013.



ith by January 1, 2012.  If you are prepared to send and receive 5010 transactions and your clearinghouses or payers are ready as well, you can begin to use the 5010 transactions prior to January 1, 2012 if you mutually agree to this.  Using the transactions early gives you the peace of mind that everything is working smoothly and your claims will continue to be processed.  If you do identify any issues, you can resolve them prior to the compliance date when all the procrastinators will just be finding out that they have a problem.  You will need version 5010 of the HIPAA transactions in order to report your ICD-10 codes.  The compliance date for using ICD-10 codes is October 1, 2013.

I have been doing this workout program called P90X. It’s a challenge, and I’m not nearly as faithful to it as I should be. There is one segment called “Ab Ripper X,” during which our fearless leader is having us do a series of 11 different exercises to firm up those flabby abdominal muscles. Each exercise had 25 repetitions. Once I’m about a third of the way into the fifth exercise, my mind starts to wonder if I really need to finish this routine. Then Tony Horton cheerfully calls out, “Imagine you have to do a 100 of them! 25 is not so bad!” and so I keep going.

Well by the same token, we are all so wrapped up in our transition to ICD-10-CM/PCS, but guess what? Some people are talking about a transition from CPT®-4 to CPT®-5!

CPT-5 is supposed to enhance the structure of CPT to reflect the coding demands of our dynamic healthcare system. Among many of the objectives, CPT-5 will strive to make improvements that addresses the needs of hospitals, managed care organizations, long-term care facilities, ambulatory care centers, and healthcare researchers.

When can we expect CPT-5? I have no clue. The silence about CPT-5 is deafening. Imagine if you had to transition to ICD-10-CM/PCS and CPT-5 at the same time! Now ICD-10 doesn’t seem so bad, right?!
Pool resources among small facilities for ICD-10 conversion

Small rural facilities that haven’t yet started planning  for ICD-10-CM/PCS shouldn’t panic yet, but they also shouldn’t delay much longer, says Jeff Wieters, RHIA, senior technical advisory consultant at QuadraMed and an AHIMA-approved ICD-10-CM/PCS trainer. “If they start today, they could still be okay.”

Approximately half of the hospitals in the U.S. are considered rural and approximately half of those are critical access hospitals. Rural hospitals have very small budgets and often need grants or subsidies to remain open. These facilities will spend quite a bit of money on the conversion relative to their budgets, Wieters says.

Staff at small facilities don’t need to feel overwhelmed and alone, Wieter says. “There are plenty of people out there to help them.”

Look for ways to pool your resources with other small facilities. Some state agencies and organizations are designed to help small hospitals by providing power in numbers to negotiate with vendors and payers. If your state doesn’t have such an organization, consider contacting other small facilities on your own.

Just when I thought that ICD-10 would resolve those annoying coding guideline and definition inconsistencies, I have discovered that some will still exist in ICD-10, too. Oh no—say it ain’t so!

The ICD-10-CM diagnosis code structure will be alphanumeric consisting of three to seven characters. The ICD-10-PCS codes for reporting hospital inpatient procedures will also be alphanumeric with seven characters. What I didn’t realize is that certain alpha characters will be “off limits” in the design of the diagnosis or procedure codes.

According to the ICD-10-PCS coding guidelines:

  • One of 34 possible values can be assigned to each axis of classification in the seven-character code, which includes numbers 0 through 9 and the alphabet (except the letters “I” and “O” because they are easily confused with the numbers “1” and “0”).
  • “U” is a potential third character describing a root operation called supplement (i.e., putting in/on biological or synthetic material that physically enforces and/or augments the function of a portion of a body part).

According to the ICD-10-CM code descriptions:

  • “I” is used to assign diagnosis codes in Chapter 9, Diseases of the Circulatory System (I00–I99)
  • “O” is used to assign diagnosis codes in Chapter 15, Pregnancy, Childbirth and the Puerperium (O00–O9a)
  • “U” is not being used at this time and is reserved for future diagnosis code expansion

So in summary, use I, O, and U (in the future) to describe diagnosis codes, but never use I and O with procedure codes—use 1, 2, and U instead. Sounds like a jingle just waiting to be written, "I.O.U. and 1.2.U..."
Do I need to select a training vendor based on my current credentials?

Certification in this day and age has become a vital part of obtaining and proving proficiency in coding and other related fields. Many years ago, coders did not have to be certified to secure employment. However, times have definitely changed. Now it seems like it is discouraging for those without a credential such as a CCS or CPC to even complete a job application for a coding position.

As a coding educator, I am thrilled to still have the opportunity to work with new coders, those who are re-entering the workforce, and even those just wanting structured training versus “OJT”  or on-the-job training. I am a true advocate of obtaining coding certification and coding training in general for those who work in coding because it's not only a boost for their self-esteem but it also earns them professional credibility. It truly is an accomplishment to be able to put CCS, CPC, or other such designations in your signature line!

With that said, because there are so many organizations that certify coders, some coders wonder whether they have to get ICD-10-CM/PCS code-set education only from the organization that supports their credentials? If you are a CPC, do you have to get trained by the American Academy of Professional Coders (AAPC) because they issued your credential? Or if you have the CCS, do you have to get trained by the American Health Information Management Association (AHIMA) because they are the organization that supports that credential? The short answer is technically—no.

If you are seeking training outside your organization through outside vendors, there are a few things I would look for to target a vendor out of the many that currently exist:

  • Seek training from those who you know are skilled and effective at being educators and presenters. Lots of people know how to code, but how many can actually teach what they know to others?
  • Make sure the entity providing the training is approved for continuing education from the organization through which you hold your credentials. For example, if you are a CCS, make sure AHIMA CE credits are offered; and similarly for a CPC, ensure that AAPC CE credits are available.
  • Don’t hesitate to request a summary of evaluation scores from past attendees. If a vendor has pre-approval for CE credits, they generally are required to collect evaluation data. Who better to judge than those who have already participated in the training?
  • Ensure that the course is taught at the appropriate level for you. Because ICD-10 is new to everyone, I recommend starting with something very fundamental. This includes even those who may have many years of ICD-9-CM experience; it will be somewhat like learning a different system. Expand to more complex and comprehensive training in the 12-18 months prior to the implementation date. Remember, take baby steps so that the transition isn’t so overwhelming!
  • Focus training based on your needs. If you are a professional services coder (e.g., CPC) you only need to learn ICD-10-CM unless you plan on also being an inpatient facility coder.
  • Explore training mediums and options that best fit your needs. Some may learn best in a live class, while others may fare better via a webinar, online course, or possibly even a book.

There are many things to consider as we move closer to October 1, 2013 and continue to tackle the items on your ICD-10-CM/PCS training checklist. The key points I highlighted above list is certainly not an all inclusive-list. A fair number of people have asked me lately whether there is only one place to learn ICD-10-CM/PCS, and I wanted everyone to know you have alternatives just like you do now for education on CPT/HCPCS II and ICD-9-CM.
A great enhancement to the Volume II Alphabetical Index to Diseases

One of the things that I like about the ICD-10-CM manual is use of the vertical gray bars in the Volume II “Alphabetical Listing for Diseases.” This greatly enhances the ability to see how far the modifying term is indented from the main term.

In the ICD-9-CM manual, it is sometimes easy to lose track in the alpha index how far in the indentation occurs from the main term. Remember if the modifying term is indented one time, it is giving modifying information of the main term. A second indentation (indented further in) is a modification of the modifying information. A third indentation is modifying that…and so on.

When you get into multiple indentations, it is sometimes difficult to see how far the indentation is unless you’re sitting there with a ruler and especially when the modifying terms span into different pages and different columns. Using the two gray vertical bars is such a simple solution. Why didn’t we think of that sooner?!
Will transition result in fewer returned claims?

Right now only one in five hospital claims is fully paid without a payer request for more information, according to a RAND Corporation report. With the upcoming transition to ICD-10-CM/PCS, providers hope to see that number improve.

ICD-10-CM/PCS accommodates new procedures and new diagnoses that are unaccounted for in the current ICD-9 code set. The increased number of codes allows greater specificity and exactness in describing a patient's diagnosis and in classifying inpatient procedures. ICD-10 will accommodate newly developed diagnoses and procedures, innovations, technology and treatment, and performance-based payment systems, and should result in more accurate billing.

Using the more robust ICD-10 concept will cut down on the number of questions payers have about claims, Denise Buenning, Director of the Administrative Simplification Group at CMS’ Office of E-Health Standards and Services in Baltimore, said during the AAPC-CMS ICD-10 Code-a-thon April 26. In addition, we will have better data to improve the management of patient care to better describe the diseases.
GEMS only part of the solution

General Equivalency Mappings (GEMs) are crosswalks between ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM codes. They are a helpful way to start looking for a code when you move from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM. But GEMs are not a substitute for learning how to code in ICD-10-CM/PCS.

CMS created GEMs to go from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM and vice versa. In some cases, you’ll find a one-to-one match. However, just as you find multiple definitions for words in a dictionary, you'll find multiple possible matches in the GEMS.  That means you’ll actually have to read the record, find the correct information, and match it to the most appropriate code.

If you're going to use a crosswalk, the Affordable Care Act tells you that you should use the version posted to the CMS website, and that’s really important, said Denise Buenning, Director of the Administrative Simplification Group at CMS’ Office of E-Health Standards and Services in Baltimore, during the AAPC-CMS ICD-10 Code-a-thon April 26. Having a standardized crosswalk will make things easier and more consistent across the healthcare industry.

You can access the current CMS GEMs on the CMS website.
ICD-10 is more specific, with a few exceptions

As I look at the ICD-10-CM codes and take into consideration some of the possible documentation issues we might face, one of the questions that comes to mind is are we actually taking a step backward with the codes for some conditions in ICD-10-CM?

Over the years, ICD-9-CM has improved in terms of specificity for many diagnoses codes. For example, we have been working with our physicians to identify “malignant” hypertension. Looking ahead to ICD-10-CM, however, some of these strides we have made toward greater specificity in ICD-9-CM no longer apply with the ICD-10-CM code set.

For example, the term "urosepsis" has plagued coders and physicians for years. Coding Clinics have tackled the subject, and we have spent countless hours clarifying documentation of the term urosepsis with physicians. In ICD-9-CM, we have come to learn that without further clarification from the physician, the term urosepsis simply means a urinary tract infection (UTI). We also know that many physicians use the term urosepsis to mean UTI with sepsis, but coders cannot deduce that from the term alone. Coders have to either query the physician for the specificity of UTI with sepsis, or they have to go by ICD-9-CM coding conventions and code urosepsis to ICD-9-CM code 599.0 (UTI). However, the index in the ICD-10-CM Manual includes an instructional note to "code to condition," meaning a query would be necessary to determine appropriate code assignment. So we need to explain to coders and physicians that we will no longer be able to code the condition urosepsis in ICD-10-CM.  That way physicians can discontinue the use of the word or understand that it may lead to even more queries .

A few years ago we were also given many combination codes in ICD-9-CM to identify conditions that MRSA caused. However, this is no longer the case in ICD-10-CM. A code no longer exist for the combination of MRSA and pneumonia. Instead, we will have to code the pneumonia and the causative organism separately.

I think it is very important that we make the Cooperating Parties that govern ICD-10-CM/PCS aware  of our concerns. Look at your most commonly coded diagnoses now to identify any potential issues. It's clear that the Cooperating Parties didn’t convert all ICD-9-CM codes over to ICD-10-CM and to better understand the ICD-10-CM system, I think they should provide for us the rationales as to why some conditions either no longer appear in the index or why some of the greater specificity we have gained in ICD-9-CM (e.g.,  malignant hypertension vs. benign hypertension) no longer matters.
Get ready to hit the ground running at AHIMA ICD-10 Academy

I attended the live portion of the American Health Information Management Association ICD-10-CM training in Baltimore last week. It is definitely not for the faint-hearted! It was a good overview summary of ICD-10-CM, with a few exercises thrown in at a very fast pace. I found the pace to be lightning speed. You definitely won’t have a chance to be bored! There was very little time to spend on exercises.

Personally, I would have liked to have had more time to apply my knowledge via the exercises just to make sure I understood all the concepts. But it's nice that there are plenty of exercises to practice with once the academy is over, and you can work at your own pace.

Although I haven’t had an opportunity to spend time with the course materials since the Academy, I think that the course content is strong. And yes, I enjoyed the live part of the Academy much more than the first part, which was all online.
What kind of transition team does your organization need?

The complexity and costs of the switch to IDC-10-CM/PCS will vary by the size of the organization. A large, multi-facility health system needs to review more areas and plan more changes than a five-person physician office.

Not everyone needs a large ICD-10-CM/PCS transition team. Look at the size of your organization. Do you need a large transition committee or can you hold a staff meeting instead? Or do you fall somewhere in between?

Regardless of your organization’s size, everyone needs to understand his or her role in the transition. Make a list of the tasks you need to accomplish and assign someone within the organization to complete each task. Give them a deadline and don’t be afraid to ask for help. You can find plenty of information and resources now.
Post-acute care: Have you created your implementation plan?

With 2013 seemingly so far away, many post-acute care organizations, including long-term care facilities, homecare agencies, and hospices, have not started their ICD-10 coding training. Many want to make sure the codes are in final form before training and others feel as though they don’t have the time to begin training, but it is important to start planning how you will tackle this daunting new change.

In a recent survey of our homecare and long-term care customers, we asked them where they were in the process of creating an ICD-10 implementation plan for their agency or facility. The numbers show:

•    Long-term care:

o    Out of 153 responses, only 7% have completed a framework for an implementation plan, while 16% are in the process of developing their plan.
o    The remaining 77% of those surveyed either don’t know if they have developed a plan or have not created one at this time.

•    Homecare:

o    Out of 254 responses, only 3% have completed a framework for an implementation plan, while 17% are in the process of developing their plan.
o    The remaining 80% of those surveyed either don’t know if they have developed a plan or have not created one at this time.

As 2013 approaches slowly but steadily, it is important to begin your work on this implementation plan. Although it may feel far away, it will be here before you know it and understanding what your agency or facility will have to do to prepare, even if it is sometime in the future, is crucial.

So tell us: Where does your agency or facility fall? Have you created an implementation plan? Do you plan on developing your plan soon? Let us know and share your thoughts in the comments section!
Start learning PCS root operations now

You’ve probably heard that it’s too early to start learning ICD-10-CM/PCS codes. After all, the codes are still in draft format. However, it’s not too early to start learning the root operations for ICD-10-PCS. You’ll need to understand what those terms mean before you can find the correct codes.

One of the root operations is extirpation. That’s a pretty new term for everyone. In fact, you won’t find it in the ICD-9-CM index.

ICD-10-PCS defines extirpation as the taking or cutting out solid matter from a body part. The solid matter may be an abnormal byproduct of a biological function or a foreign body. It is embedded in a body part or is in the lumen of a tubular body part. The solid matter may have been previously broken into pieces. With extirpation, the physician takes out no appreciable amount of the body part. Think thrombectomy, foreign body excision, or removal of a kidney stone.

Extirpation is root operation C in ICD-10-PCS, which means your third character will be C. For example, a physician performs an embolectomy throughout the upper right arm on the arterial side. In this case, you would code 05CD0ZZ.

Remember that physicians may not use the exact term ICD-10-PCS uses, so you need to read the record and match the procedure to the correct root operation.
CMS posts 2012 ICD-10-PCS codes and guidelines

CMS recently posted the 2012 ICD-10-PCS codes and coding guidelines. A summary of the major changes for 2012 states that there are 1,182 new codes, 381 revised titles, and 1,345 deleted codes.

In response to public input, note the following changes:

  • In the Medical and Surgical section, there is a new qualifier "Vertical" in the Medical and Surgical section for the stomach body part to specify vertical sleeve gastrectomy
  • In the Medical and Surgical section, there is a new qualifier "Left Atrial Appendage" for the left atrium body part to specify procedures performed on the left atrial appendage
  • In the Introduction section, there is a new qualifier "Anti-Infective Envelope" to specify placing an antimicrobial envelope around device (e.g. pacemaker generator) inserted in the subcutaneous tissue

Based on an internal review for clarity and ease of use, CMS decided to:

  • Revise device values as needed to adhere to new device value maintenance standard
  • Add respiratory, breast and prostate body part values for laser interstitial thermal therapy (LITT), to be consistent with body parts specified in ICD-9-CM includes notes and index entries

The ICD-10-PCS General Equivalence Mappings (GEM) and reimbursement mappings are coming soon:

  • 2012 ICD-10-PCS GEM Mappings will be posted in October 2011
  • 2012 ICD-10-PCS Reimbursement Mappings will be posted in December 2011

Well, CMS apparently wants to make sure everyone tests the HIPAA Version 5010 transaction sets. CMS previously announced two national testing days, and is adding 5010 testing week.

CMS scheduled 5010 testing week for August 22-26 as an opportunity for trading partners to come together and test compliance efforts that are already underway with the added benefit of real-time help desk support and direct and immediate access to Medicare administrative contractors (MAC).

CMS recommends all trading partners participate in the National 5010 Testing Week. However, you don’t need to wait until August to start testing. CMS encourages you to begin working with your MAC now to ensure timely compliance.

Note that successful testing is required before a trading partner may be placed into production.

For more information about the testing week, contact your local MAC.
ICD-10-PCS root operations sound similar, but mean different things

ICD-10-PCS codes include one digit for the root operation that the provider performs. The root operation is always the third character is the seven-character code. The definitions of these root operations are consistent across other sections of ICD-10-PCS, although they may be represented by different characters in different sections.

Some root operations sound similar but actually indicate slightly different procedures, such as excision, resection, and detachment.  An excision involves cutting out a portion of a body part, but a resection involves cutting out all of a body part. Detachment is the cutting off of all or a portion of the upper or lower extremities.

Because a provider may use the word “excision” when he or she actually performs a resection, coders will need to carefully read the operative note to determine what was actually performed.

Start by reviewing the definitions of the various root operations. If you learn the root operations early, you’ll have a head start on learning how to code in ICD-10-PCS.
ICD-10-CM/PCS training: Go back to basics

So the transition to ICD-10-CM/PCS is still more than two years away, and it’s too early to start learning actual codes. But you can start reviewing some of the major concepts of ICD-10-CM/PCS with coders and physicians.  The codes might change, but the concepts won’t.

Consider going back to basic concepts like specificity. Tell the physicians what additional detail coders will need after the switch to ICD-10-CM/PCS. Consistently query them for this information now. If you start requesting the information now, with any luck, physicians will document it as a matter of course when the switch to ICD-10-CM/PCS rolls around.

You also need to ask for the information every time. Consider laterality, for example. Coders need to know the specific site of an injury or procedure in order to select the most appropriate ICD-10-CM/PCS code.

Start asking physicians for that location now, but ask for every type of diagnosis or procedure. You can’t tell them you need it for a fracture and not for an ear ache. The physicians will be confused about what coders need and when. As a result, they may not document it at all instead of trying to figure out where they need to and where they don’t.

Oh, and one more thing, don’t tell the physicians that ICD-10-CM/PCS still includes unspecified codes. Reporting an unspecified diagnosis on a non-specific site—think unspecified otitis media in an unspecified ear—defeats the purpose of the switch and may lead insurance companies to question the integrity of a claim.

Note: Please only participate in the survey if you are an HIM professional. If you are not an HIM Director or Manager or do not hold a closely-related position, please forward the survey to one of your HIM colleagues.

The survey should take less than 5 minutes to complete. We appreciate your time!
