Thank you for your time and assistance.
CMS posts new podcasts based on national provider calls

CMS created the following four podcasts based on the January 12 national provider call, “Preparing for ICD-10 Implementation in 2011:”

  • Welcome and ICD-10 Overview
  • Implementation Strategies for 2011
  • Question and Answer Session, Part 1
  • Question and Answer Session, Part 2

You may also access the following four podcasts based on the May 18 national provider call, "CMS ICD-10 Conversion Activities National Provider Teleconference - Including a Lab Case Study:"

  • Welcome and ICD-10 Overview
  • Case Study on Translating the Lab NCDs
  • ICD-10 Updates from CMS Subject Matter Experts
  • Question and Answer Session
Looking in the rear view mirror?

As a kid, do you remember playing the game where you sat round in a circle and one person whispered a phrase in the ear of the person sitting next to them, and that person passed it along until everyone in the circle had heard the phrase? Then the last person repeats what the first person said, and it is usually not even close to the original phrase, producing a big laugh.

I think that has been happening with the rumor that CMS is going to delay the ICD-10 implementation. Some providers may believe it possibly based on what a member of Congress may have whispered in their ear.

Well, the rumor has been consistently dispelled by CMS representatives during national provider calls. If you listened to CMS' ICD-10 Conversion Activities National Provider Teleconference on May 18, you probably heard Denise Buenning, director of Administrative Simplification Group Office of E-Health Standards and Services, state that CMS is moving ahead with the transition plans for its contractors, and the date is not going to change.

Although CMS reports that is in different phases of transition, it certainly appears that they are moving on down the road and starting to convert its policies. You can download the May 18 presentation on CMS' website.

If you are moving ahead in first gear hoping that the rumor is true and that a delay will come, you need to stop looking in the rearview mirror. ICD-10 implementation is on course with no sign of it running into the ditch. That first day of October 2013 is on the horizon. Have you ever looked at that phrase on your car mirror and wondered what it meant? Yes—objects in the mirror are closer than they appear!
Is your system ready for ICD-10-CM/PCS?

If you haven’t already done so, now is a good time to look at your system capabilities and see what you need to update or upgrade before the transitions to HIPAA Version 5010 and ICD-10-CM/PCS.

Start by identifying and analyzing software. For example, some software may require updates for 5010. Also look at your needs for system storage. The larger number of ICD-10-CM/PCS codes may mean you need more storage space.

Analyze your system’s software interoperability. Assess access points, work flow, and business and accounting systems. Don't forget to account for the separate business and accounting systems that your outlying facilities or outpatient clinics may have.

Finally, capture your vendors' information. Make sure you have the appropriate contacts for 5010 and ICD-10-CM/PCS. This is also a good time to establish communication protocols with each of your vendors, identify the preparations needed to update your software, and establish timelines for receiving updates.

Update your mainframe first, then your secondary and tertiary systems. Make sure you test each update. If you don’t and you have a problem, you might not be able to identify where the problem is.
Combination codes aid in specificity of disease process with certain complications/manifestations

One of the things that has concerned me about ICD-10-CM is the lack of guidance regarding sequencing. Since the American Hospital Association announced that it would not be converting Coding Clinic for ICD-9-CM and that we would start with new Coding Clinics for ICD-10-CM, I have been a little freaked out about the amount of confusion this may cause when it comes to sequencing and principal diagnosis selection. However the more I work with ICD-10-CM, I can see that many of the Coding Clinics that we rely on for ICD-9-CM will no longer be necessary due to the make-up of the ICD-10-CM codes.

For example, let's take a look at coronary artery disease (CAD) and angina. Many Coding Clinics address the sequencing of angina as an additional (subsequent) diagnosis when it is related to CAD.  You would list firsICD-9-CM diagnosis code 414.0x (principal), followed by the angina code (either ICD-9-CM code 413.9 or 411.1). However, in ICD-10-CM these Coding Clinics are no longer necessary because we will have a combination code that will identify the disease process (CAD) and the manifestation (angina) all in one code.

Consider ICD-10-CM code I25.110 (Atherosclerotic heart disease of native coronary artery with unstable angina pectoris). The ICD-10-CM code seems to be consistent with the advice that we have in ICD-9-CM, however, without the need for a Coding Clinic to address sequencing. Expect to see more of such code combinations with disease processes and their manifestations in ICD-10. Take, for example, ICD-10-CM code K50.013 (Crohn’s disease of small intestine with fistula) or ICD-10-CM code K71.51 (Toxic liver disease with chronic active hepatitis with ascites).

ICD-10-CM codes have the ability to represent complete disease processes and their manifestations in one complete code, which helps alleviate confusion regarding sequencing disease processes and their manifestations, a sometimes common problem in ICD-9-CM. Where we often require more than one code in ICD-9-CM, we may now be able to use a combination code in ICD-10-CM that will represent the disease process and the complication/manifestation.

Procedural complications further illustrate this. In ICD-9-CM, we have one code that identifies foreign body accidentally left in during surgery (998.4). However, there are 50 ICD-10-CM codes (T81.5x) that identify the specificity for a foreign body accidentally left in during surgery and the “reaction” due to the complication (e.g., adhesions, obstruction, and perforation).

With ICD-10-PCS, coders will have 31 root operations to choose from and not all of them are clear cut. Start learning the root operations now to prepare you for the switch to ICD-10-PCS.

The ICD-10-PCS root operation destruction refers to the physical eradication of all or a portion of a body part using energy, force, or a destructive agent.

With destruction, the physician is not physically removing any of the body part. You may have fragments or elements that are available for pathological review, but not a whole body part.

Fulguration of a polyp and cauterization of a skin lesion are two examples of destruction.

Consider this example: A patient is diagnosed with bilateral chronic turbinate hypertrophy. The physician uses the coblation generator and the intramural coblation of turbinate probe to treat the inferior turbinates at three levels.

In ICD-9-CM, you would report code 21.69 x 2 (other turbinectomy). In ICD-10-PCS, you would report codes 095L7ZZ (medical-surgical, ear, nose, sinus, destruction of the nasal turbinate via a natural or artificial opening) and 095L7ZZ.
Use documentation assessment to find gaps now

Will physician documentation be specific enough so coders can select the most appropriate code in ICD-10-CM/PCS or will coders be defaulting to unspecified codes?

For starters, don't dwell on details. When educating physicians about ICD-10-CM/PCS, explain that the transition will not be as burdensome as they might think. In some cases, ICD-10-CM will allow greater specificity in reporting illnesses such as asthma and trauma. ICD-10-CM/PCS will also be better able to expand and accommodate new codes to capture new diagnoses and procedures.

Consider conducting a documentation assessment. This will help physicians and coders better understand where gaps may exist. Coders with ICD-10-CM/PCS training should code their practice’s or  hospital’s top 20 procedures and top 20 diagnoses with the new coding system using current documentation.

After completing a documentation assessment, you should be able to quickly determine whether the documentation includes enough specificity for ICD-10-CM/PCS.

Once you know where physician documentation is lacking, coding managers and CDI specialists should provide simple, succinct presentations about ICD-10-CM/PCS during staff meetings to inform physicians about changes specific to their specialties. Begin asking physicians to document this more specific information approximately six months before implementation.

If an excision involves cutting out a portion of a body part, and a resection involves cutting out all of a body part, what then is an extraction?

According to the ICD-10-PCS guidelines, an extraction is “pulling or stripping out or off all or a portion of a body part by the use of force.” Ouch.

Dilation and curettage and vein stripping are two extraction procedures. As a note, bone marrow and endometrial biopsies are not coded to the root operation excision. They are coded to extraction, with the qualifier diagnostic.
As with all ICD-10-PCS codes, identify the method the physician employs to reach the procedure site in the “approach” value of the code.

So let’s look at a practice case. A physician documents the following:

After induction of general anesthesia the patient was placed in the dorsal lithotomy position and appropriately prepped and draped. Successive dilators were placed until the cervix was adequate for insertion of the suction cannula. Suction cannula was placed and suction curettage performed with no residual endometrial lining. The tissue was sent to pathology to rule out endometrial cancer.

In this case, you would report ICD-10-PCS code 0UDB7ZX, extraction of endometrium, via natural or artificial opening, diagnostic.
5010 is a vital stepping stone to transition to ICD-10

When we think of all of the steps we have to take to get ready for ICD-10 implementation, missing one step in the planning process could cause chaos in your facility. Don’t forget about 5010! Your transition to the UB-04 /837 I electronic claims format 5010 standard must be ready to go on January 1, 2012. This is a requirement for all HIPAA-covered entities and their business associates in preparation for the conversion to ICD-10. Keep in mind that 5010 implementation will not be as easy as IT just flipping a switch. It will require changes to software, systems, and procedures that you use for billing Medicare and other payers.

If you fail to test and complete the necessary HIPAA 5010 transaction upgrade, you risk not being paid for your services. CMS has been very clear that beginning on January 1, 2012, they will not pay claims for any providers who are not using the new format. Many payers have also taken that stance; however, a few state Medicaid agencies will be lagging a little behind. But that doesn’t mean that you get any additional time to convert.

One of the many reasons for changing to the 5010 format is that providers will be able to report more ICD-9-CM codes (and eventually ICD-10-CM codes) on the UB-04. Currently, providers can report up to 17 secondary diagnosis codes; however, Medicare contractors only process eight of them when paying an inpatient claim.

In the new format, providers will be able to report up to 24 secondary diagnosis codes, and Medicare contractors will be required to process all of them when paying the claim. This is good news for facilities.

Looking at procedure codes, only five secondary codes can be reported using the current format; however under the new 5010 transaction standard, providers can report up to 24 secondary procedure codes. I don’t know if I have ever seen a case where 25 total procedures were coded for an inpatient, but now we will have the ability to report if it does occur. (I would hate to be the coder who got that chart—yikes!)

One of the other coding changes will be that the current three fields available for reporting E codes, although not required for Medicare claims, will expand to 12 fields.

So where are you at in this first step of the conversion trail? Has your facility begun internal and external testing of this claims format for your vendors, clearinghouses and payers? Don’t assume that someone else is taking care of this step. If you are looking for some good resources to understand what 5010 is all about, check out these links:

  • www.cms.gov/Versions5010andD0
  • www.getready5010.org
Teaching an old dog new tricks

I’m not really crazy about the title of this blog post, but that’s how the adage goes. Once you get used to something, like ICD-9-CM for example, change is met with resistance.

I don’t want to think of myself as an “old dog.” Instead of “old,” how about experienced or possibly mature.

At any rate, for folks who are accustomed to ICD-9-CM and can even rattle off code numbers from memory, there is a certain amount of understandable fear in converting to ICD-10-CM/PCS. Fear not! I think you will find that much of your knowledge will transition over to ICD-10 very readily.

The biggest change between the two coding systems that you will probably notice right off the bat relates to the Excludes Notes. In ICD-9-CM, you simply have the Excludes Notes. In ICD-10-CM, you have the more user-friendly Excludes 1 and Excludes 2 Notes.

The next biggest change is in the organization of the Volume II alphabetical index. In ICD-9-CM, the alphabetical list of diseases, which included the neoplasm and hypertension tables, was followed by the Table of Drugs, and then the alphabetical list of External Causes. In ICD-10-CM, Volume II begins with the alphabetical list of diseases. Instead of being in the alphabetical listing of diseases under the main term "Neoplasm,"  the Neoplasm table now follows the alphabetical listing of diseases. The placement of the neoplasm table was a bit odd for me, but I’m getting used to it.

Kudos to the ICD-10 Table of Drugs and Chemicals over the ICD-9 Table of Drugs. I find it easier to code poisonings and adverse effects of drugs in ICD-10-CM. I do have to remind myself in ICD-10-CM, however, that if the intent for the poisoning is not documented, that we are to code to an accidental poisioning. In ICD-9-CM, that would be coded to the “undetermined” intent code.

The last two observations that I will mention involve the alphabetical listing of external causes. In ICD-9-CM, to find a code to report the place of occurrence, I headed for the main term "Accident" and then to “occurring at.” But in ICD-10-CM, you simply go to the main term "Place of Occurrence."

Finally, if I’m looking for the status of the patient in ICD-9-CM as far as whether they are a civilian, volunteer, military person, etc., I go to the main term "Activity Status." That won’t work with ICD-10-CM. Instead, you have to go either to "External Cause Status" or "Status of External Cause." So I did have to change a few of my old habits, but the good news is—I’m getting it!
YouTube: Pet tricks, daring stunts, and ... CMS!

When I hear "YouTube," I think of video clips of babbling babies, stupid pet tricks, and “don’t try this at home” stunts. But did you know that CMS is now on YouTube? Who’d a thunk it! They even have their own channel to which you can subscribe. It looks like CMS has passed me by for technology advances—I bet they even Facebook and Twitter—what is this world coming to?

If you missed the May 18 ICD-10 presentation, you can now listen to it on YouTube as well as view and download the slides. (Simply click on this link and scroll down to "Video Slideshow Presentation.") You can even get CEUs from the American Academy of Professional Coders and the American Health Information Management Association for listening—that is just way too easy! I did watch most of the presentation, and it was not bad for a government issue. As another option, you can listen to it via four podcasts while you are commuting to and from work. Why listen to music when you can listen to CMS instead!

You can also subscribe to CMS' YouTube channel to be notified of newly posted videos.
Take a step-by-step approach to learning ICD-10-PCS

A step-by-step approach to code assignment is helpful when trying to understand the complexity of ICD-10-PCS.

Step one: Determine the first character, which denotes the general category of the procedure.   

Step two: Determine the second character, which denotes the specific body system to which the procedure applies.

Step three: Determine the third character, which denotes the root procedure. The medical and surgical section of codes includes 31 potential root operations, each of which is based on the objective of the procedure. These 31 root operations are organized into nine groups.

Step four: Determine the fourth character, which denotes body part (the specific anatomical site where the procedure is performed).

Step five: Determine the fifth character, which denotes the approach (the technique used to reach the site of the procedure).

Step six: Determine the sixth character, which denotes the device (any devices that remain after the procedure is completed). This does not include materials incidental to a procedure, such as clips and sutures. It also doesn’t include instruments that facilitate a procedure (e.g., instruments for visualization, such as a cystoscope).

Step seven: Determine the seventh character, which denotes the qualifier (additional attributes of the procedure performed, when applicable). Examples include the type of transplant (allogenic, syngenic, or zooplastic) or a second site for a bypass.

Note that the specific options for root operation, body part, approach, device, and qualifier will vary depending on the applicable section of ICD-10-PCS.
Preparing for implementation: Who should agencies and facilities educate about ICD-10-CM/PCS?

Given the many differences between the ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM/PCS system and the thousands of new codes that will be used, all skilled-nursing facility (SNF) and homecare agency staff members involved in coding should begin preparing for implementation, if they haven’t already. But coders are not the only people who should be involved in training. So who should be trained on ICD-10-CM/PCS coding?

It is important to provide enough training to all staff members who are affected by coding to ensure they have at least a basic understanding of ICD-10-CM/PCS coding and its impact on care.

For long-term care, staff members in these positions should be trained:
•    MDS coordinators
•    Clinicians
•    Therapists
•    Social service employees
•    Physicians
•    Billers
•    Management staff

For homecare, staff members in these positions should be trained:
•    Clinicians
•    OASIS coordinators
•    Therapists
•    Social service employees
•    Physicians
•    Billers
•    Management staff

Many agencies and SNFs may be hoping they only have  to educate coders, but it is wise to include many different departments. Understanding this huge change will unite the organization and provide clarity for others about the changes. The bottom line is that switching to the ICD-10-CM/PCS is a big initiative and all agency and facility departments must work together to ensure a smooth transition.

Now tell us: Who do you plan on educating? Will it be an agency or facility-wide training or kept to separate departments? Have you even thought about it yet?
ICD-10-CM includes more info on asthma

The CDC updated the terminology used to describe asthma in ICD-10-CM to reflect the current clinical classification of asthma. In ICD-9-CM, asthma is described as extrinsic or intrinsic. In ICD-10-CM, it is classified as mild intermittent, mild persistent, moderate persistent, and severe persistent.

Asthma is classified to category J45 with the fourth character classifying the type of asthma and the fifth character classifying the asthma as with status asthmaticus (2) or with acute exacerbation (1). Physicians will need to provide specific documentation for this diagnosis in ICD-10-CM.

Category J45 includes several use additional code notes to identify the following:

  • Exposure to environmental tobacco smoke (Z77.22)
  • Exposure to tobacco smoke in the perinatal period (P96.81)
  • History of tobacco use (Z87.891)
  • Occupational exposure to environmental tobacco smoke (Z57.31)
  • Tobacco dependence (F17.-)
  • Tobacco use (Z72.0)

Some of the removal root operations can easily be confused with other root operations that involve taking out solids, fluids, or gases from a body part (e.g., drainage, extirpation, and fragmentation).

Take, for example, drainage. A patient undergoes suction curettage and needle aspiration. You may think  these procedures fall under the drainage category for root operations, but they don’t.

Drainage is a procedure that involves only a catheter and indicates the removal of gases or liquids, not specific body parts. The use or insertion of a catheter distinguishes drainage from other similar procedures.

Coders should use the root operation drainage for both diagnostic and therapeutic drainage procedures.

Examples of drainage codes include:

  • 0W9B3ZZ, thoracentesis of left pleural effusion
  • 059F3ZZ, phlebotomy of left median cubital vein for polycythemia vera
  • 0W9930Z, percutaneous chest tube placement for right pneumothorax
  • 099V4ZZ, endoscopic drainage of left ethmoid sinus
Y2K scare pales in comparison to ICD-10's impact

Do you remember the Y2K scare? Vendors and information technology staff were entranced with making upgrades to computers and information systems months in advance to make sure that the internal clocks would continue to function and the world, as we knew it, would not crash.

When many people were out celebrating the New Year, I remember that I was with a group sitting in our hospital waiting for something dreadful to happen—but keeping our fingers crossed that it wouldn’t. We watched TV as the New Year rolled across the rest of the world, waiting for it to hit the East coast and wondering would the lights go out and the computer systems collapse. Well, Y2K turned out to be just a blip. In fact it was so insignificant, I don’t even remember any problems when the year 2000 arrived.

Some are comparing the transition to ICD-10 to that point in history. Although I see some similarities, October 1, 2013 will certainly have a much larger impact on health care than Y2K ever did. Although Y2K affected everything from our watches to our power grid, ICD-10 is unfortunately hitting us where we can least afford it. Most of us have been preparing for this change at some level for a few years, and the intensity of the process will crank up over the next two years. This all takes time and money—the former being marginal for most anyone in health care these days and the latter playing a disappearing act with each regulatory change.

Once January 1, 2000, 12:01 a.m. had passed, life went on without much interruption or thought given to that conversion. We won’t be that lucky with ICD-10. We will see the impact on our revenues, stress levels, employment, and relationships well into 2014 and beyond. So in retrospect, I don’t think we can even compare the two events. If there is anyone out there who is not deep in preparation by this time and thinks that I might be like that storybook character Henny Penny crying “the sky is falling, the sky is falling,” let me know how things are going for you when the clock hits 12:01 a.m. on October 1, 2013.
AHIMA provides role-based model for physician practices

These days it seems like a new ICD-10 tool is waiting for you around every corner. Be sure to periodically check different organization's websites, as many of them are constantly updating information. For example the American Health Information Management Association (AHIMA) presents a role-based model for ICD-10 implementation on its website, which includes a new section geared toward physician practices.

AHIMA describes its tool, stating:

This model identifies key tasks or milestones that must be completed within specific timeframes by specific organizations and in some cases specific roles within organizations. It is organized first by healthcare entity, then by roles, enabling you to focus on your setting and role and then identify the important milestones and action items to help inform your planning. The model identifies not only what you need to do and by when, but also links to suggested resources to help you accomplish these steps.

When should a coder report multiple procedures performed during a single operative session in ICD-10-PCS? Look to the official guidelines for information.

According to the guidelines, coders should not separately code components of a procedure specified in the root operation definition and explanation. They should also not separately code procedural steps necessary to reach the operative site and close the operative site.

For example, the resection of a joint as part of a joint replacement procedure is included in the root operation definition of replacement and is not coded separately. A laparotomy performed to reach the site of an open liver biopsy is not coded separately.

However, in certain circumstances, coders should report codes for both procedures. According to the guidelines, during the same operative episode, multiple procedures are coded if:

  • The same root operation is performed on different body parts as defined by distinct values of the body part character. For example,  separately code a diagnostic excision of the liver and pancreas.
  • The same root operation is repeated at different body sites that are included in the same body part value. For example, an excision of the sartorius muscle and excision of the gracilis muscle are both included in the upper leg muscle body part value, and coders should report multiple procedures.
  • Multiple root operations with distinct objectives are performed on the same body part. For example, coders should code destruction of sigmoid lesion and bypass of sigmoid colon separately.
  • The intended root operation is attempted using one approach, but is converted to a different approach. For example, the physician coverts a laparoscopic cholecystectomy to an open cholecystectomy. In this case, code a percutaneous endoscopic inspection and open resection.

Coders must make sure the documentation fully supports reporting both procedures. If the documentation is incomplete or you are unclear about what the physician did, query the physician for more information.

Another new term coders will need to know for ICD-10-PCS root operations is fragmentation. Fragmentation is breaking solid matter in the body into pieces.

Note that in a fragmentation procedure, the solid matter is not removed from the body, it is simply broken apart.  The pieces of the solid matter are either eliminated or absorbed through normal biological functions.

Examples of fragmentation procedures and the corresponding ICD-10-PCS code(s) include:

  • Code 0FF98ZZ,  endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with lithotripsy of common bile duct stone
  • Code 02FN0ZZ, thoracotomy with crushing of pericardial calcifications
  • Code 0TFB8ZZ, transurethral cystoscopy with fragmentation of bladder calculus
  • Code 0UF68ZZ, hysteroscopy with intraluminal lithotripsy of left fallopian tube calcification,

The fragmented solid material may be either an abnormal byproduct of a biological function or a foreign body.

During a fragmentation procedure, the physician applies physical force (e.g., ultrasonic, manual) directly or indirectly through intervening body parts to break the solid matter into pieces. Coders should report both direct and extracorporeal fragmentation procedures using this root operation.

Over the summer, I was in the process of going through the American Health Information Management Association Academy for ICD-10-CM for trainers. I had completed the online, self-paced part of the class. The next phase, which I completed in June, was the live classroom portion.

I was looking forward to the live part of the class. Online training has its place, and there is much to be gained from it. But honestly, I’ll take the “in-the-flesh” interactive experience over the online version any day. I know we all learn in different ways, and I have had the privilege to be an instructor both in the classroom and online. And while I do not have any statistics to cite off the top of my head, my gut instinct is that my students in the classroom retain a lot more information than the students who get the exact same information via an online delivery system. The good thing about online training is that it saves travel money, and you don’t have to leave home (or work) to do it.

However, the classroom naturally lends itself to multiple exposures to key concepts. The instructor presents the key concept, you work through exercises, you receive the correct answer, you hear other students’ questions. The key concepts are restated and clarified in different ways. Your exposure tends to be more limited with an online experience. You read the material and then you take a test. It’s just not as exciting. We learn by repetition, therefore, give me the classroom!
ICD-10-CM chapter 13 codes require site, laterality

Coders will find they need more information to select the appropriate code in chapter 13 (Diseases of the Musculoskeletal System and Connective Tissue [M00–M99]) of the ICD-10-CM Manual.

Most of the codes in chapter 13 will include site and laterality designations. The site represents either the bone, muscle, or joint involved.

Coders can choose an option for multiple sites when a diagnosis involes more than one bone, muscle, or joint (e.g., code M08.89 [other juvenile arthritis, multiple sites]). When more than one bone, joint, or muscle is involved and no multiple site option or code exitts, coders must use multiple codes to indicate the sites involved.

For example, report the following codes for osteomyelitis of cervical and lumbar vertebra:

  • M46.22(osteomyelitis of vertebra, cervical region)
  • M46.26 (osteomyelitis of vertebra, lumbar region)

All codes that include laterality requirements require coders to identify whether the disease, injury, or diagnoses is located on the right or left region. For example, if a physician diagnosis an abscess of bursa of the right shoulder, report code M71.011 (abscess of bursa, right shoulder). In ICD-9-CM, coders would report this condition with code 727.89 (disorder of synovium/tendon/bursa), which lacks site and laterality specificity.
Get a jumpstart on 5010 for peace of mind

5010. That’s the cool way of saying Version 5010 of the Accredited Standards Committee (ASC) X12. It is the next version of the HIPAA electronic transaction standards that providers and all HIPAA covered entities must comply with by January 1, 2012. You will need version 5010 of the HIPAA transactions in order to report your ICD-10 codes.

If you are prepared to send and receive 5010 transactions and your clearinghouses or payers are ready as well, you can begin to use the 5010 transactions prior to January 1, 2012 if you mutually agree to this.

Using the transactions early gives you the opportunity to have peace of mind that everything is working smoothly and your claims will continue to be processed once ICD-10 takes effect on October 1, 2013. If you do identify any issues, you can resolve them prior to the compliance date when all the procrastinators will just be finding out that they have a problem.
Review documentation, ICD-10 codes for chest pain

Coders should focus on chest pain, among other areas, as part of a larger review of ICD-9-CM codes and in preparing for ICD-10-CM.

Coding chest pain in ICD-9-CM requires the physician to document the specific type and location of the pain, and ICD-10-CM is really no different. The following are ICD-10-CM codes for chest pain:

•    R07.1, Chest pain on breathing

o    Painful respiration

•    R07.2, Precordial pain
•    R07.8, Other chest pain
•    R07.81, Pleurodynia

o    Pleurodynia not otherwise specified (NOS)
o    Excludes1: epidemic pleurodynia (B33.0)

•    R07.82 Intercostal pain
•    R07.89, Other chest pain

o    Anterior chest-wall pain not otherwise specified (NOS)

•    R07.9, Chest pain, unspecified

Patients are frequently admitted to the hospital with "rule-out myocardial infarction (MI)," and then the physician never explicitly says whether the MI is actually ruled outThat makes it tough for the coder.

If the physician ultimately diagnoses a patient who presents with chest pain as having had an MI, the physician must explicitly document the MI. To accurately assign an ICD-10-CM code for an MI, coders will need to know both the wall—as required by ICD-9-CM—and the artery involved in the MI.
Coding Clinic conversion unlikely, but some areas require clarification

As an AHIMA ICD-10 certified trainer, I have been doing a lot of work on various ICD-10 projects. When it comes to working with the new coding system, I find myself wondering whether the first ICD-10 Coding Clinics are going to address some of the key issues for which  we currently have ICD-9 Coding Clinics.

I identified various areas for which many of the Coding Clinics we have now will no longer be necessary in ICD-10 due to the specificity of the codes and the fact that in some instances when we currently have to report multiple ICD-9 codes, we will  be able to apply only one ICD-10 code, which clears up sequencing issues. However, there are some areas that the new ICD-10 codes don’t address. And because we won’t be able to apply the ICD-9 Coding Clinics, I think we need to start looking at them from the perspective of our current common coding scenarios by applying the ICD-10 codes and identifying areas for which we will need clarification. Otherwise we run the risk of leaving it up to the powers that be to identify these key areas in time for implementation on October 1, 2013.

For example, there is an ICD-10-PCS code under the "Extracorporeal Assistance and Performance" section with a root operation Restoration. One of the examples of procedures that would be coded to this root operation is attempted cardiac defibrillation, unsuccessful. But what happens if they attempt the procedure multiple times? Do we report the procedure more than once?

Another area for which I have questions relates to ventilation management. Currently in ICD-9, we have guidance regarding postoperative ventilation management. However, as ICD-9 Coding Clinics are not being converted for ICD-10, this question comes up once again about when it would be appropriate to report postoperative ventilation management. If there is no guidance when ICD-10 takes effect, many coders may apply the rules that we already have in place with the ICD-9 system while others may not, causing variations in coding and reimbursement across the board.

I also have a question related to the ICD-10-PCS system regarding the qualifier “diagnostic.” I have not seen any advice as to when we would use this qualifier, therefore it has been left up to interpretation. When the question came up in a training class, the instructor who was teaching stated that if the physician said “excisional biopsy” for a lumpectomy, for example, the qualifier would be X for Diagnostic. If the physician simply said “excision,” then the qualifier would be Z to indicate No Qualifier. However, I have not found any guidance on the subject in writing as to whether we can use the word “biopsy” as an assumption to code the qualifier X for Diagnostic. Currently there are no guidelines for assigning character 7, which means that we will need to look to Coding Clinic to clarify its use.

These are just a few that I could think of off the top of my head. I am sure the more I work with the system, the more questions I will come across. This is just one of the reasons why it is important that we have coders working with the system now so that we can start to question and hopefully get answers before the implementation of ICD-10. I would feel a little better if we at least knew that these were being addressed.
