During this live 90–minute audio conference, our expert speakers will walk you through two different plans to tackle education at your facility. One case study features a 750-bed acute care hospital that will roll out its education initiatives in 2012-mid 2013. The second highlights a specialty cardiac hospital in Long Island that has been conducting education for coders and CDI staff since early 2011. You will also learn strategies to budget and conduct organization-wide staff training.

Join HCPro and expert speakers Adelaide M. La Rosa, RN, BSN, CCDS, and Deborah Beezley, RHIT, at 1 p.m. (Eastern) Tuesday, November 8 for this live audio conference. Use coupon code BE2011 to receive $50 off the price when you order online at HCMarketplace or by calling HCPro Customer Service at 800-650-6787.

Coders will use the root operation division when the physician plans to cut into, transect, or otherwise separate all or a portion of a body part. Do not use division if the physician plans to cut or separate the area around a body part, the attachments to a body part, or between subdivisions of a body part that are causing abnormal constraint.

An anal sphincterotomy is one example of a division procedure. Consider this example:
Manual examination of the rectum and anus was done, and examination showed that the patient has an anterior anal fissure. For that reason, lateral sphincterotomy was done at the 3 o’clock position using the closed approach, dividing only the internal sphincter using the #11 blade.

In ICD-10-PCS coders would report code 0D8R3ZZ. Note that the fifth character represents a percutaneous approach because the physician documented using a closed approach and dividing only the internal sphincter.

Other division procedures include:

  • 0L8V3ZZ, division of right foot tendon, percutaneous
  • 02883ZZ, left heart catheterization with division of bundle of HIS,
  • 0P8N0ZZ, open osteotomy of capitate, left hand (The capitate is a carpal bone)
  • 0D878ZZ, EGD with sphincterotomy of pylorus
  • 018R3ZZ, sacral rhizotomy for pain control, percutaneous
What ancillary procedures will we report with ICD-10-PCS codes? Inquiring minds want to know!

As I continue to learn more and work with ICD-10-PCS codes, I find myself questioning the ancillary service codes in ICD-10-PCS.

In my experience as an inpatient facility coder, I know that there are a handful of procedures that will be considered ancillary services in ICD-10-PCS when the new coding system takes effect in 2013. Things like ventilation management, insertion of nasogastric tubes, peripherally inserted central catheter and central lines, and some radiology services that relate mostly to cardiology procedures (e.g., angiography and angiocardiography in relationship to cardiac catheterizations). I know that some providers actually assign ICD-9-CM volume 3 procedure codes now for things like transfusions of blood products and vaccines.

With the development of the ICD-10 coding system, some of these procedures will actually be covered in the medical/surgical section of ICD-10-PCS, while others are found in the following sections:

  • Placement (immobilization)
  • Administration (transfusions)
  • Measurement and monitoring
  • Extracorporeal assistance and performance (ventilation management)
  • Extracorporeal therapies (decompression)
  • Imaging (computed tomgraphy/magnetic resonance imaging)
  • Substance Abuse Treatment (detox)

All of which make me wonder, do we focus on the medical/surgical and obstetrics sections, from which come the majority of procedures that impact payment? And how much time and effort do we need to focus on the other sections such as those listed above?

In my experience working with various hospitals, not all providers code the same when it comes to those procedures that do not impact the MS-DRG system (e.g., transfusions). Some hospitals that I worked for wanted us to capture the ICD-9-CM volume 3 code 99.04 (transfusion of packed cells), whereas other hospitals that I worked for didn’t want us to pick it up, stating that it is a chargemaster issue.  Therefore, it would be picked up with the CPT code on the floor/unit where the procedure occurred. As a coder, I never got into the “why’s.” I just simply followed the process set in place at the various hospitals. I often had a list that said “pick these up” or “don’t pick these up” for each hospital, and I would code accordingly.

As I work with the ICD-10-PCS system now, I wish I had a copy of those lists so that I would be able to look back on them as an educator and determine where I should focus my attention.

The inpatient coder in me says to look at what impacts reimbursement and worry about those others down the road as we get advice on whether facilities will actually be capturing data with the ICD-10-PCS code. The educator in me says that I need to know what facilities plan to do. If they are currently capturing those procedures with an ICD-9-CM volume 3 code, are they planning on continuing the process with the ICD-10-PCS code? Or will they adopt the attitude that other facilities have that if it doesn’t impact reimbursement and it is being captured with the chargemaster system, then they will not be picking it up with an ICD-10-PCS code.
CMS to hold ICD-10 implementation strategies and planning call

Representatives from the American Hospital Association (AHA), the American Health Information Management Association, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will discuss ICD-10 implementation strategies and planning during a national provider call November 17 from 1:30-3 p.m.

CMS experts will also discuss recent guidance for claims that span the implementation date.

The agenda for the call is:

  • General ICD-10 requirements and CMS implementation planning
  • General implementation planning and strategies
  • Coding Clinic for ICD-10, AHA's implementation plans
  • National Committee on Vital and Health Statistics meeting on provider and vendor
  • Public health reporting issues
  • Medicare FFS Claims Processing Guidance for Implementing ICD-10

Registration for the call closes at noon November 17 or when available space has been filled. For more details, including instructions on registering, visit the CMS website.
Initial vs. subsequent. New vs. established. Will it be an issue?

Will the new ICD-10-CM concept of using seventh character code extensions to identify initial encounters vs. subsequent encounters cause additional confusion in relation to professional services, for which concepts of new visits vs. established visits are already at times a conundrum?

Many times providers select their own diagnosis and procedure codes for the billing staff. In this day and age, providers commonly employ electronic tools to assist in selecting codes, so will requiring information such as whether a patient is new or established for selection of evaluation and management (E/M) codes and then identifying whether a condition applies for an initial vs. subsequent encounter for the diagnosis codes possibly leave room for error?

Let’s look at the definitions for the seventh character extensions in ICD-10-CM. Per the ICD-10-CM Official Guidelines for Coding and Reporting in reference to Chapter 19: Injury, Poisoning and Certain Other Consequences of External Causes:

  • A: Initial encounter. Use this when the physician actively treats the condition during the initial encounter (e.g., surgical treatment, ED encounter, evaluation by new physician).
  • D: Subsequent encounter. Use this for encounters after the physician performs the initial treatment, but the patient continues to receive care during the healing or recovery phase (e.g., cast change/removal, removal of fixation, medication adjustment).

Now let's review the definitions for "new" versus "established" in CPT®.

Per the American Medical Association’s 2011 CPT Manual, a new patient is “one who has not received any professional services (face-to-face) from the physician or another physician of the same specialty who belongs to the same group practice in the past three years.” An established patient is one who has received services with the same criteria within the past three years.

Consider an example to see whether it could cause some confusion.

A physician evaluates a new patient for a fractured left index finger. No surgical intervention is required therefore the provider reports only an E/M service (CPT codes 99201–99204; new patient office visit). We’ll assume it wasn’t a consult. The ICD-10-CM diagnosis code for the fracture would be S62.601A because the physician did not document the exact location on the phalanx. The provider assigns a seventh character of “A” to identify it is an initial encounter because this was an initial assessment by this physician.

Fast-forward two years and the same patient comes to see the same physician for a fractured proximal phalanx of the right great toe. Again, the physician only provides medical management and reports for just an office visit and the diagnosis code for the fracture. Would the E/M service be new or established? Established (CPT 99211–99215)! We’ll assume again (to keep it easy) that it wasn’t a consult. The physician has seen this patient within the past two years. But, should we assign the fracture code with a seventh character of an A for "initial"? Or should we assign a seventh character of D for subsequent because the patient saw this physician two years ago?

It would be appropriate to assign ICD-10-CM diagnosis code S92.411A for an initial encounter because although the patient may be established to the physician, this is the physician's initial evaluation of this condition.

This is just one more thing for physicians to keep straight (but maybe us coders can serve as a resource?). Please keep in mind that code assignment for the diagnoses that require seventh character extensions should be based on whether the condition is new to the physician—not necessarily whether the patient is considered new to the physician.
Break through the silos and assemble all the team players

I had the opportunity to attend the American Health Information Management Association convention this year in Salt Lake City, and I helped work in HCPro's exhibitor booth. As a former HIM director and compliance officer, I was curious to learn about the progress the attendees have made in their transition to ICD-10-CM/PCS and where they might be going with their ICD-10 training. Here are a few of the trends that I picked up on.

  • Coders are still interested in receiving education on ICD-9-CM and are looking ahead to possibly obtaining anatomy and physiology education. It seems that current coding staff are focusing on the here and now—ICD-9-CM—and that it is still too early to begin ICD-10 training, unless the education focuses on body parts and functions instead of the actual classification system.
  • HIM managers and directors are starting to incorporate more intensive ICD-10 training into their 2012 budget, and they're planning for more courses in anatomy and physiology for their coding staff. The take-away I got from that was that many of the HIM directors and managers seem to agree with the coders’ point of view on the timing of ICD-10 education, but are taking the lead for ramping it up within their own areas beginning next year.
  • Clinical documentation specialists and physicians I talked to felt a little removed from the urgency right now. This concerned me because these people will be absolutely integral to the success of the transition and should be part of current discussions about ICD-10 education.
  • Many vendors and a few payers seemed to be ahead of the providers in terms of ICD-10 readiness. It gave me peace of mind to know that they were ahead of the curve because providers will be so dependent on each of these entities; however, if the providers are not as prepared or even more so than these players, they could be creating their own nightmare.
  • I thought it was very interesting that a CFO was looking for any education on ICD-10-CM/PCS, not only for herself but “just for the coders” in her healthcare system. Although she has been a CFO for many years, I was not sure if they had done some training and she was not part of that or if she had just realized that ICD-10 was going to greatly impact her facilities and they needed to start to plan ahead. Yikes!

I think the common thread that I saw was there seems to be a lack of communication and/or understanding between the major and minor players in our transition to ICD-10-CM/PCS. For some reason, there is a continuing silo effect going on when I was hoping we would have moved beyond this by now. Granted my research was in no way scientific, but as 2012 approaches, it might be a good time to make a resolution to get everyone at the table—not just your immediate staff— to create a transparent plan and begin moving ahead swiftly. If your efforts have gone unnoticed or unanswered, you may want to try a different approach or take it up the company chain.
Educate physicians to make transition easier

Coders are sharpening their knowledge of anatomy and physiology and honing their ICD-10-CM/PCS skills. The HIM department is getting ready for the transition, but did you remember to explain it to your physicians?

HIM directors and coders are already worrying about whether physicians will document well enough for coders to assign the most appropriate code without ended up with an unspecified code.
Tailor education to physicians can ensure that when coders are ready to assign ICD-10-CM/PCS codes, the documentation won't be a barrier to their success.

Here are tips to consider when educating physicians:

Don't dwell on details. When educating physicians about ICD-10-CM/PCS, explain that the transition will not be as burdensome as some might anticipate. ICD-10-CM will allow greater specificity in reporting illnesses and will be better able to add new codes to capture new diagnoses and procedures.

Remind physicians that ICD-10-CM is simply an extension of ICD-9-CM with added specificity for laterality and several other relevant clinical details.

Discuss the financial implications. Money talks, right? And everyone--from a physician office to a major hospital system--is worried about revenue. Use it to your advantage when educating physicians. ICD-10-CM/PCS will allow improved data to measuring physician performance and complexity of care, which factor into medical necessity determinations. These determinations are an important part of reimbursement.
Don’t stop implementation plans because AMA opposes ICD-10-CM/PCS

The American Medical Association (AMA) House of Delegates voted to “work vigorously to stop implementation of ICD-10” during the closing session of its semi-annual policy-making meeting November 15.

The AMA cites the number of competing healthcare initiatives and the costs involved in the transition as reasons it opposed the switch. It’s a little late in the game to be figuring that out.

Providers should not put their implementation plans on hold. Many (hopefully most) providers and payers are already planning for the ICD-10-CM/PCS transition. Some have even started updating systems, forms, and processes. CMS representatives have repeatedly said the deadline isn’t changing. And really, too many good reasons exist for the switch.

Consider these factors:

The United States is the last industrial country to implement ICD-10-CM/PCS. We’re 10 years behind Canada and even farther behind Europe. Beyond how embarrassing it is to be so far behind the rest of the developed world, we can’t share data with other countries because we’re using a different code system. We can’t compare disease or mortality rates because it’s an apples to apricots comparison. And by the time we implement ICD-10-CM/PCS, most of the rest of the world will be looking at ICD-11.

ICD-9-CM is out of room. Every year, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention add more and more out of sequence codes, which creates confusion for coders because the code isn’t where it should logically be. ICD-10-CM contains thousands more codes already and has plenty of room to expand in the future.

Increased specificity is a good thing. Many ICD-9-CM codes lack detail, especially ICD-9-CM Volume 3 procedure codes. How can you justify your patient is really, really sick if you can’t explain why? In ICD-9-CM Volume 3, you can’t even distinguish between a central venous catheter insertion and a peripherally inserted central catheter. They both map to the same code (38.93). In ICD-10-PCS, coders can report percutaneous placement of venous central line in right internal jugular (05HM33Z) for example. Of course, the physician has to document enough information for the coder to select the correct code.

Documentation is going to continue to be a big problem. We all know that.. ICD-10-CM/PCS requires more information and in some cases different information than ICD-9-CM. But generally it’s information the physician already knows and he or she just isn’t writing it down. For example, if a physician sets a broken arm or removes a foreign object, he or she should be able to say which arm the patient broke or where the foreign body was.

The documentation will also help with quality of care indicators and outcome assessments. If a very ill patient makes a tremendous recovery because of a provider’s excellent care, the provider will be able to show just how sick the patient was and how well he or she recovered.

Change is never easy. The transition to ICD-10-CM/PCS won’t happen overnight and it won’t be easy. But it will benefit the healthcare profession all around from coders to HIM to physicians and (ultimately) patients. Instead of digging in its heels at this late date, the AMA should be looking for ways to make the transition better and easier.

CMS’ Office of E-Health Standards and Services (OESS) won’t enforce compliance with the HIPAA 5010 transaction set until March 31, 2012, the agency announced November 17. The 90-day delay will not affect the implementation date for the ICD-10-CM/PCS coding systems, CMS said. That date remains October 1, 2013.

CMS did not change the actual implementation date of HIPAA 5010. Providers must still comply with the 5010 transaction standards by January 1, 2012. Small health plans have until January 1, 2013. OESS simply decided it will not take any enforcement actions until March 31, 2012.

OESS decided to delay enforcement because most covered entities would not be ready to comply by January 1, 2012. Many covered entities are still waiting for software updates, according to OESS.

However, OESS will still accept complaints related to compliance between January 1 and March 30, 2012. Covered entities will have to provide evidence that they are complying or are making a good faith effort to comply with the new HIPAA standards during the 90-day period if asked by OESS.

All HIPAA-covered entities and their business associates are required to switch to HIPAA 5010 in preparation for the conversion to ICD-10-CM/PCS. Failure to comply with the HIPAA 5010 requirement means covered entities might not be paid for their services.
Note disconnect between late effect terminology in guidelines vs. indices

Late effects are considered to be the residual effects after the acute phase of an illness, disease, or injury. Typically, late effects are considered chronic conditions and can result from the treatment for an illness, disease, or injury. There is no time limit as to when a late effect can manifest itself. It can occur directly after the disease or even years after the illness or injury has passed.

ICD-9-CM coding for late effects varies depending on whether combination codes exist, such as with cerebrovascular accidents (CVA), for which a combination code identifies the residual condition and that it is a late effect of a CVA. Or late effects can require multiple codes to identify the condition, such as with accidents or injuries for which you need separate codes to identify the:

  • Current (residual) problem
  • Condition as a late effect of an injury
  • External cause (E code) to identify the cause of the injury that resulted in the late effect

When we move to ICD-10-CM, late effects are termed sequela (singular) or sequelae (plural). If you look up the term "late effect" in the alphabetic index of the draft ICD-10-CM Manual, an instructional note states "see Sequelae." This includes looking up the additional external cause status codes. The alphabetic index references you to "see Sequelae." So we are going to have to get used to the change in terminology. As a coding instructor, I already identify this change in terminology with my students so that they can get used to the verbiage.

It gets confusing, however, when you look at the ICD-10-CM Official Coding Guidelines for Coding and Reporting. For example, if you look at the chapter-specific guidelines for Chapter 19: Injury, Poisoning, and Certain Other Consequences of External Causes, the guidelines make several references to coding for "late effects." In Chapter 20: External Causes of Morbidity, the guidelines also reference coding for late effects. So it raises the question, why the disconnect between the coding guidelines and how we actually address the codes in the alphabetic index and tabular index? Was this in error and should the official coding guidelines reflect the change in terminology, or did they intend to have such a lack of consistency?
PT/OT, oh where did you go?

For those who work in environments where codes from category V57 (care involving use of rehabilitation procedures) are a staple, you be surprised to learn that when it comes to ICD-10-CM, all V57 codes map to the same ICD-10-CM code (Z51.89). In ICD-9-CM, the codes within category V57 help to identify a variety of therapies that providers administer to patients:

  • V57.0 (breathing exercises)
  • V57.1 (other physical therapy [except breathing exercises])
  • V57.2x (encounters for occupational or vocational therapy)
  • V57.3 (speech-language therapy)
  • V57.4 (orthoptic training)
  • V57.8x (orthotic and other training or therapy)
  • V57.9 (unspecified rehabilitation procedure)

An instructional note corresponding to category V57 codes states that coders should assign an additional code for the underlying condition or reason for such rehab procedures (e.g., late effect of cerebrovascular accident with aphasia, hemiplegia, or aftercare of a fracture).

When referencing the ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM general equivalency mappings (affectionately called “GEMs”), all of these codes (that by the way have some specificity in ICD-9-CM) map only to one ICD-10-CM code Z51.89 (encounter for other specified aftercare). There is an instructional note in ICD-10-CM that states to “code also condition requiring care,” but does this diagnosis really identify whether the therapy provided was physical therapy, occupational therapy, or vocational therapy? Not so much.

This concept is important because the American Hospital Association's (AHA) Coding Clinic, Third Quarter, 2006, instructed inpatient rehab hospitals to use a V57 code as the principal diagnosis. We know that the AHA is not going to translate the ICD-9-CM Coding Clinics to ICD-10-CM, but for the sake of rehab hospitals I do hope that some guidance is provided sooner than later if they are not to assign the encounter for rehab code as the principal diagnosis. Maybe the thought is that ICD-10-CM code Z51.89 identifies with as much detail as is necessary for reporting for inpatient rehab? If we still are to assign additional codes for the conditions requiring care then it should be ok, right?

Clearly we found a reason to have specific codes in ICD-9-CM, so maybe we ought to stay tuned for more specificity to filter over into the ICD-10-CM codes for inpatient admissions for rehab.

Get ready to say goodbye to Coding Clinic for ICD-9, and hello to Coding Clinic for ICD-10.

The AHA will cease publication of its ICD-9 guidance, but is already planning for an ICD-10-CM/PCS replacement, according to Nelly Leon-Chisen, RHIA, Director of Coding and Classification for the AHA.

“We have no plans to translate [previous Coding Clinic volumes] because many of those [issues] came about as [ICD-9-CM] codes needed qualifications [and clarifications],” Leon-Chisen said during CMS’ “ICD-10 Implementation Strategies and Planning National Provider Call” November 17.

The AHA will begin to publish its new Coding Clinic for ICD-10 in the fourth quarter of 2012. It will provide practical information and coding advice approved by the cooperating parties and AHA editorial advisory board. The new Coding Clinic for ICD-10 will follow the same format as Coding Clinic for ICD-9 and the AHA will still accept questions.

Anyone with questions about the ICD-10 guidelines or codes can submit them to the AHA now, but anyone who submits a question needs to have working knowledge of the new code sets and questions must pertain to the application of the codes and the interpretation of the medical record.

Looking for the 2012 ICD-10-CM code updates? Want to see what's included in the final regular update before implementation? Check the CMS’ ICD-10-CM and GEMS website. CMS posted the 2012 ICD-10-CM:

  • Index and tabular
  • Code titles
  • Addendum
  • General Equivalence Mappings (GEMs
  • Reimbursement mappings files

GEMs demonstrates how a code in one set (i.e., the source system) translates to the other (i.e., the target system), with conversions based on code book instructions, index entries, and Coding Clinic advice.

CMS posted the ICD-10-PCS files in June on the ICD-10-PCS and GEMs webpage.
ICD-9-CM vs. ICD-10-CM: Can a code possibly mean two different things?

CMS recently posted a file that identified duplicate codes within the ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM systems.

The list isn’t terribly extensive, but in this atmosphere of transitioning from one system to the next, wouldn’t it have been best to avoid any codes that could possibly be duplicated depending on which system it is defined within?

I think this could be confusing not only for the transition but also for data mining, research, and analysis of codes for years prior to and after the transition in October 2013. This could also be a factor for payers who are not planning to update to the ICD-10 system but rather are planning to map backwards to ICD-9-CM for claims processing purposes. This concept isn’t new considering many payers utilize different versions of the ICD-9-CM code set but have "patches" (for lack of an official term) to map the codes correctly within the system.

For example, a number of years ago ICD-9-CM code 787.2 was the correct four-digit code for dysphagia. However, when a fifth digit was added to this code to identify the phase (787.20–787.29), code 787.2 was no longer valid. Some payers dealt with this change by internally mapping this code backwards to 787.2, if necessary.

This can be an issue though if the codes can mean two different things depending on whether you're using ICD-9-CM or ICD-10-CM. System administrators should be aware of this possibility as you are setting up all information systems to accept the new codes and if your organization is utilizing any mapping features. I am sure a “techie” can make this easy for us as to differentiate. I can honestly say I am not tech-savvy at all, so I’d leave it to the pros to come up with a solution.

Luckily the culprits lie solely in the ICD-9-CM E codes (external causes) as they are defined in the ICD-10-CM E code series (Chapter 4: Endocrine , nutritional, and metabolic disorders, E00–E89).

Consider the following example:

  • ICD-9-CM code E841.9 (accident to powered aircraft, other and unspecified, injuring other person)
  • ICD-10-CM code E84.19 (cystic fibrosis with other intestinal manifestations)

ICD-9-CM code E841.9 would never be used as a principal or first-listed code, however notice that ICD-10-CM code E84.19 will be a specific diagnosis of cystic fibrosis with other intestinal manifestations. Maybe we ought to start requiring the decimal points? Notice in ICD-9-CM, the decimal—if used—would come after the fourth digit, whereas in ICD-10-CM it would come after the third digit. This would differentiate the two codes, but decimals aren’t always used.

I think as coders we’ll already face the challenge of remembering that “E codes” are no longer external cause codes in ICD-10-CM and we can see codes from this series (depending on the specific code of course) in ICD-10-CM as a principal diagnosis.

I found it interesting that there were no ICD-9-CM V codes on this list so I checked. The reason why is that V codes in ICD-9-CM have either three, four, or five digits. When I looked at all the V codes in ICD-10-CM (V00–V99), they require seven characters so there will not be any duplication within this series. (Just a side note, but the V00–V99 codes in ICD-10-CM represent transport accidents, which are some of the very same ones we were discussing above as being duplicates.)

Also, consider the following:

  • ICD-9-CM code E841.9 (accident to powered aircraft, other and unspecified, injuring other person)
  • ICD-10-CM code V95.39xA (other specified air transport accidents, other person on ground due to air traffic accident)

Coding always keeps life interesting—changing the codes we are familiar with to mean two different things depending on which system we are using, as well as mapping some of our “E codes” to “V codes.” What will they think of next to make this an even bigger challenge? Regardless, I have faith that we’ll be able to tackle it.
ICD-10-PCS surgery: It’s all in the approach

In the medical and surgical section of ICD-10-PCS, character 5 refers to the approach or method used to reach or expose a body part during a procedure. As a result, coders will need to look for physician documentation of how he or she performed the procedure.

The seven approaches include:

  • Open (0). With this approach, the surgeon cuts through skin or mucous membrane and other body layers necessary to expose procedure site.
  • Percutaneous (3). When using this approach, the surgeon effects entry, by puncture or minor incision, of instrumentation through the skin or mucous membrane and any other body layers necessary to reach the site of the procedure. The surgeon uses nonvisualization instrumentation such as needles or catheters to reach the operative site.
  • Percutaneous endoscopic (4). This approach is similar to the previous approach except  the surgeon use visualization instrumentation to reach the operative site.
  • Via natural or artificial opening (7). When using this approach, a surgeon introduces instrumentation through natural or artificial external opening to reach procedure site.
  • Via natural or artificial opening endoscopic (8)—Entry of instrumentation through natural or artificial external opening to reach and visualize procedure site
  • Open with percutaneous endoscopic assistance (F). With this approach, a surgeon cuts through skin or mucous membrane and other body layers necessary to expose procedure site. The surgeon then introduces and instrumentation, by puncture or minor incision, through skin or mucous membrane and other body layers necessary to aid in performance of the procedure.
  • External (X). With this approach, the surgeon performs a procedure directly on the skin or mucous membrane using indirectly applied external force through skin or mucous membrane.

For example, a patient undergoes a laparotomy with removal of the common bile duct (0FT9- ). The ICD-10-PCS chart lists four different possible approaches for this procedure—open, percutaneous, via natural or artificial opening, or via natural or artificial opening endoscopic.

If the surgeons are not documenting the approach now, start querying them for this information. While it won’t change how you code now, it should get them in the habit of documenting this information by the time we switch to ICD-10-PCS.
ICD-10-PCS root operations: Bypass is more than just CABG

In ICD-10-PCS, coders assign the root operation bypass (third character 1) when the surgeon’s objective in the procedure is to reroute the contents of a tubular body part. Bypass procedures includes normal routes such as those made in coronary artery bypass procedures, and abnormal routes such as those made in colostomy formation procedures.
A bypass includes one or more concurrent anastomoses with or without the use of a device such as autografts, tissue substitutes, and synthetic substitutes.
A coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) is just one example of a bypass procedure. ICD-9-CM contains a total of nine codes (36.10-36.19) to describe different versions of the CABG procedure. These codes specify the version based on one aspect of the procedure; however the aspect defined is not consistent for all nine codes. Four of the codes specify the number of coronary arteries bypassed, four specify the source of the new blood flow, and one is an “unspecified” choice.
By contrast, ICD-10-PCS components can be combined to produce 34 unique codes (021-) defining all significantly different versions of the comparable CABG procedure. All 34 codes specify the same four aspects of the procedure: the number of coronary artery sites bypassed, the approach to the procedure site, the type of graft if used, and the origin of the bypass (source of the new blood flow).
Physicians can also perform bypass procedures on various other body parts, such as cerebral ventricles (0016-) the spinal canal (001U-), lower arteries (041-), the cystic duct (0F18-), or the esophagus (0D1-).
Manual of edits in MCE can be a helpful tool for coders and billers

The Medicare Code Editor (MCE) is software that detects and reports errors in the coding on claims that are submitted for payment. All Part A inpatient discharges and transfers pass through the MCE prior to grouping for that inpatient claim to the appropriate MS-DRG. There are currently 20 edits that claims are reviewed for (e.g., checking for valid ICD-9-CM diagnosis and procedure codes, using an E code used as a principal diagnosis code, and checking for a potential age or sex conflict).

When we transition to ICD-10-CM/PCS, the MCE will continue to be used to review Part A claims prior to assigning the codes to the appropriate MS-DRG. The reason I bring this up is that if you go to CMS' ICD-10 website, you can download the MCE manual, which contains each edit and its code lists for October 1, 2010–September 30, 2011. I thought it provided an extensive and interesting list of the ICD-10 diagnosis codes that run through the current version of the MCE. Although this will be updated as we approach October 1, 2013, this reference can help familiarize both coders and billers with the way the codes will look in the very near future.

This is just one of the many tools that CMS has posted to its website. Click here to access the ICD-10 version of the MCE.

When a physician frees a body part from an abnormal physical constraint by cutting or by use of force, coders will use the root operation release (N) in ICD-10-PCS.

Keep in mind, though, that you select the code based on the body part the physician is freeing, not the tissue the physician manipulates or cuts to free the body part. Physicians can perform a release procedure:

  • On the area around a body part
  • On the attachments to a body part
  • Between subdivisions of a body part that are causing the abnormal constraint

Examples of release procedures include:

  • 0TN60ZZ, laparotomy with exploration and adhesiolysis of right ureter
  • 0CN7XZZ, frenulotomy for treatment of tongue-tie syndrome
  • 0RNJXZZ, manual rupture of right shoulder joint adhesions under general anesthesia
ICD-10-PCS root operations: Removal isn't what you think

Removal sounds like it should be an easy root operation in ICD-10-PCS. Removal means taking something out, right? Physicians remove things all the time—your appendix, a cyst, the toy your son stuck up his nose.

However, in ICD-10-PCS, removal has a different definition. Coders use the root operation removal when a physician takes out or off a device from a body part.

When a physician removes a device, coders will code the procedure to removal if it is not an integral part of another root operation, regardless of the approach or the original root operation by which the device was put in.

Examples of removal procedures include:

  • 02PYX2Z, non-incisional removal of Swan-Ganz catheter from right pulmonary artery
  • 0PPJX5Z , removal of external fixator, left radial fracture
  • 0FP000Z, open removal of a drainage device from the liver
  • 0JPT3XZ, percutaneous removal of a vascular access device of the subcutaneous tissue and fascia of the trunk
Don't miss JustCoding's ICD-10 Virtual Summit!

Get three days of ICD-10 training without the travel. This online event, February 29-March 2, 2012, will feature two tracks: One for HIM Directors and Coding Supervisors and another for Inpatient and Outpatient Coders. This one-of-a-kind virtual summit will offer practical, hands-on guidance for the challenges of ICD-10 preparation and implementation. You won't have to budget for travel or brave uncertain weather to hear presentations from faculty and dialogue with these experts as well as your peers. You'll be able to access presentations, question and answer sessions, and networking opportunities from any computer or conference room without having to leave the office. This event offers attendees continuing education credits to maintain their credentials, access to JustCoding editors and your peers in networking forums, and a virtual exhibit hall. Following the live event, all attendees will have ongoing on-demand access to all of the Summit sessions and content. Click here to learn more about this upcoming Virtual Summit, including the agenda, speakers, and pricing.
Note ICD-10-CM guideline changes for neoplasms

The 2012 ICD-10-CM updates include significant narrative changes for primary malignant neoplasms overlapping site boundaries and malignant neoplasm of ectopic tissue, as well as smaller narrative changes to coding and sequencing of complications.
ICD-10-CM instructs coders to classify a primary malignant neoplasm that overlaps two or more contiguous (next to each other) sites to the subcategory/code .8 ('overlapping lesion'), unless the combination is specifically indexed elsewhere. For multiple neoplasms of the same site that are not contiguous, such as tumors in different quadrants of the same breast, coders should assign a code for each site.
For malignant neoplasm of ectopic tissue, code the malignant neoplasm to the site mentioned. For example, code an ectopic pancreatic malignant neoplasm to pancreas, unspecified (C25.9).
When a patient is admitted or sees a provider for management of an anemia associated with the malignancy, and receives treatment only for anemia, report the code for the malignancy as the principal or first-listed diagnosis followed by the appropriate code for the anemia.
When a patient is admitted or sees a provider for management of an anemia associated with an adverse effect of the administration of chemotherapy or immunotherapy and receives treatment only for the anemia, sequenced the anemia code first followed by the appropriate codes for the neoplasm and the adverse effect.
Some ICD-10-PCS guidelines differ from today's, but also vary from CPT

While working on various projects related to ICD-10-PCS, I have discovered many areas where I think coders are going to struggle because the rules either go against the way we code now in ICD-9-CM volume 3 or differ from the way we code in our outpatient CPT® world. I was excited to learn that for the first time we were going to actually have coding guidelines when it came to the inpatient procedural coding system. Currently, we have very limited guidance when it comes to procedural coding using ICD-9-CM volume 3 codes, and most of that guidance comes from the American Hospital Association's (AHA) Coding Clinics, which we have to remember are going away once ICD-10-CM/PCS takes effect in 2013. The AHA will issue new Coding Clinics as question arise. One area that caught my attention is one that we all have memorized as coders. Currently in ICD-9 or in our outpatient world, if we begin a procedure laparoscopic and convert to open, we only code the open procedure. They even developed code V64.41 (laparoscopic surgical procedure converted to open procedure) to identify this and to use as an additional diagnosis because we only report the open procedure code. However, when we move to ICD-10-PCS, there is a multiple procedure guideline that states we should code multiple procedures when the intended root operation is attempted using one approach but is converted to a different approach. For example, consider a laparoscopic cholecystectomy that is converted to an open cholecystectomy. You would report this as both a percutaneous endoscopic inspection and an open resection. However, the CPT rule still applies for the physician’s coding, so there will be a disconnect between what the facility reports and what the surgeon reports. Another area where we see this is when it comes to coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) procedures. Currently, harvesting the saphenous vein is included in the procedure for the CABG and is not reported separately. When we move to ICD-10-PCS, we have a coding guideline that states if a physician obtains an autograft from a different body part to complete the objective of the procedures, a separate procedure is coded. The example they use is a CABG with an excision of the saphenous vein to use as the graft. You would report separately the excision of the saphenous vein along with the CABG procedure. However, our physician world will still follow CPT guidelines, which state that the excision to obtain the graft is included and therefore not reported separately. So I'm wondering why is there such a disconnect between how we code now with ICD-9-CM volume 3 codes? And why is there going to be a disconnect between how physicians will report a particular procedure vs. how facilities will report that same procedure in ICD-10-PCS? The only explanation I can offer is that facilities and physicians don’t actually have the same work ‘value’ when a procedure is performed. While the physician’s revenue is tied to his or her actual work, the facility has equipment and staffing, for example,that is involved when those procedures are performed, and that may be the rationale for the changes in the guidelines. But without actually hearing it from the powers that make these decisions, we can only speculate about the reasons behind the changes. It sure would be nice if when they change a particular code or guideline, they would also give us the rationale behind the changes like we get from the American Medical Association when there is a change to CPT—don’t you agree?
Will payers be ready for ICD-10 come October 1, 2013?

Have you heard that not all payers will be ready for the ICD-10-CM/PCS coding system on October 1, 2013? What a headache, huh? All payers were required to be ANSI X12 Version 5010 compliant by January 1, 2012, which is a separate issue from having to have their claims processing systems ready for ICD-10-CM/PCS coding by the October 1, 2013, implementation date. Hopefully most payers will be on board, but the possibility remains that some payers may not implement ICD-10-CM/PCS until after October 1, 2013. For starters, you might want to check in with your state Medicaid program to see what their plans are. Some have suggested that payers may choose to delay implementation of ICD-10 as a strategy for saving reprogramming costs of their claims processing system. That seems shortsighted. After all, it would just be a delay, not a total savings. Others have suggested that while all payers have to accept ICD-10 codes on October 1, 2013, there will be different degrees of readiness on some payers’ parts. For example, a state Medicaid plan may have to “patch” their own system in order to accept the ICD-10 code from the provider and then translate it to an ICD-9 code that their system can still understand. The intent is that it should be transparent to the provider. Sounds like trouble to me though! And because it is always best and most efficient to pay the claim correctly the first time, wouldn’t a delay be more expensive in the long run? Payers and providers would have to deal with additional costs of data translation, inappropriate denials, reviews, appeals, resubmissions, etc. That equates to more administrative expenses rather than any type of savings. Hopefully all payers will be on board at the drop dead date and will not have to MacGyver their system so that they can translate ICD-10 codes back to ICD-9. Doing so, even for a transitional period, is bound to create havoc.

When you hear the word 'transplant', what do you think of first? Many people probably think of organ transplants. If you’re one of those people, you’re all set for the ICD-10-PCS root operation transplantation. Coders will use transplantation when a physician puts all or part of a living body part taken from another individual or animal to physically take the place and/or function of all or a portion of a similar body part. For example, a surgeon places a donor kidney in a patient’s body. For transplantation codes, report the third character Y. Examples of transplantation procedures include:
  • 02YA0Z2, orthotopic heart transplant using porcine heart (The donor heart comes from an animal (pig), so report zooplastic as the qualifier value)
  • 0BYF0Z1, transplantation of right lower lung lobe, from an identical twin
  • 0DYE0Z0, transplantation of large intestine, using organ donor matched intestine, open approach
One reminder: bone marrow transplants are not coded in the surgery section. For a bone marrow transplant, look in section 3 (administration) and the root operation 2 (transfusion). Take a voyage into the unknown with the ICD-10-PCS Overview presented by Jennifer Avery, CCS, CPC-H, CPC, CPC-I, Senior Regulatory Specialist with HCPro, Inc. during   The JustCoding Virtual Summit: ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS, February 29-March 2. This one-of-a-kind virtual summit offers practical, hands-on guidance for the challenges of ICD-10 preparation and implementation. You won't have to budget for travel or brave uncertain weather to hear presentations from faculty and dialogue with these experts as well as your peers.
When do you code a device in ICD-10-PCS?

Physicians use devices all the time during procedures. For example, they may place a temporary catheter in a patient, insert a drug-eluting stent, or insert a central line. So when do you report a device for the sixth character of an ICD-10-PCS code?
The quick answer? Only when the device remains in the patient after the procedure. This means coders should use a sixth code for pins, rods, plates, prosthesis, and the like. It does not include a temporary catheter. If it’s removed, it’s not considered a device in terms of ICD-10-PCS.
Report the device with the appropriate sixth character. For the external replacement of the right breast using an autologous tissue substitute, report code 0HRTX7Z. If the physician used a synthetic substitute, the sixth character changes to J, making the code 0HRTXJZ. For a nonautologous skin substitute, report K as the sixth character (0HRTXKZ).
Materials such as sutures, ligatures, radiological markers, and temporary post-operative wound drains are integral to a procedure, so don’t code those as devices either.
Some codes will not even offer a device option. For others, the coder may need to determine whether the physician is leaving the device in the patient. For example, if a physician performs a dilation of the left pulmonary vein using a percutaneous approach, coders will need to chose between two codes (027T3DZ and 027T3ZZ) based on whether the physician left the interluminal device in the patient. In some cases, you may have to query the physician to be sure.

The only thing we have to fear is fear itself, according to Franklin D. Roosevelt. We certainly shouldn’t fear the transition to ICD-10-CM/PCS. Unfortunately, however, it seems to be a common reaction to the coming transition. The problem is coders will be going from a system they know well to one with which they’re not familiar, says Robert S. Gold, MD, CEO and cofounder of DCBA, Inc., an Atlanta-based consulting company. It’s a lot like the worry that preceded Y2K, he adds. But the rest of the world has already moved to ICD-10-CM/PCS, so health information management and coding staff members should look to the problems other countries encountered during their transitions. Instead of being fearful, gather as much information as you can to reduce the fear, suggests Sandy Nicholson, MA, RHIA, vice president of Health Information Services for DCBA, Inc. Nicholson and Gold will provide some of that information during the “Combine Clinical and ICD-10-CM Coding for the Musculoskeletal System” session of JustCoding Virtual Summit: ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS February 29-March 2. “We don’t have all of the answers, but we will help you reduce the fear.”

You can attend from the comfort of your home or office. You can even come in your pajamas! We hope to see you there!

When the American Medical Association (AMA) made it clear back in November that it wanted to delay the transition to ICD-10-CM/PCS, the first thing that came to mind was ... are you kidding me? According to the AMA, who cited a 2008 report, “ICD-10 will create significant burdens on the practice of medicine with no direct benefit to individual patients' care." But it's important to note that we are one of the last countries to implement ICD-10, and therefore our disease management data cannot be compared to other countries who are comparable to the U.S. in medical advances. If we cannot compare apples to apples when managing diseases and treatments, how will we improve patient care as well as compete with the world? As it stands, we are out of ICD-9 codes and can no longer accurately report patients’ diagnoses as well as treatments and emerging technologies. Without accurate diagnosis and procedure codes, our payment systems are restricted and cannot be designed to pay providers appropriately. From the standpoint of creating significant burdens, physician practices have to implement ICD-10-CM, not ICD-10-PCS like many hospitals across the country. Hospitals that are paid under the prospective payment system will be directly impacted by changing to ICD-10-PCS, but physicians will not—they will continue to be paid under the Medicare Physician Fee Schedule with ICD-10-CM, potentially only impacting coverage determinations because CPT-4 is the basis of their reimbursement structure. DRG payments to hospitals will certainly shift—mostly likely in a negative direction—until coding competence using ICD-10-CM/PCS increases. The risk and burden are much greater to hospitals than they are to physician practices when you consider the volume and costs for inpatient care. I was very pleased to see that the American Health Information Management Association stepped up and responded to the AMA's position with published disappointment. We are less than two years away from flipping the switch to ICD-10-CM/PCS, and both providers and payers have spent hundreds of millions (if not billions) of dollars since 2009 to prepare for this conversion. I read the AHIMA members’ reactions on the Communities of Practice, and I was relieved to see that the overwhelming majority of members were equally disappointed and brought forward some excellent counterpoints and insight.

The summit features two tracks, one for HIM directors and coding supervisors and one for inpatient and outpatient coders. Each track offers six sessions, but participants have on demand access to all of the sessions for six months. That means you can earn a total of 12 AHIMA CEs and gain practical, hands-on guidance for the challenges of ICD-10 preparation and implementation. We plan to have other credits available for the summit, so stay tuned for more credit information in the near future. The summit is less than three weeks away, so sign up today!
Combination codes aren’t new to outpatient coders

Outpatient coders are getting very familiar with combination codes when it comes to procedure coding, thanks to the AMA. Coders have been seeing more and more combined procedures in recent years in the CPT® Manual. For example, in 2011, AMA combined CT of the abdomen and CT of the pelvis into a single code. So the thought of combination codes for diagnoses shouldn’t be that scary. Some of the combinations will make life easier. In ICD-10-CM, coders will only need one code to report type 2 diabetes mellitus with mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy with macular edema instead of three in ICD-9-CM. The single ICD-10-CM code includes the type of diabetes mellitus, the body system affected, and the specific complications affecting that body system. Some of the combinations may come as a surprise, though. Codes in categories T36–T65 are combination codes that include substances related to adverse effects, poisonings, toxic effects and underdosing, and external causes (e.g., T39.011A, poisoning by aspirin, accidental [unintentional], initial encounter). Combination external cause codes identify sequential events that result in an injury, such as a fall that results in striking an object (e.g., W01.111A, fall on same level from slipping, tripping, and stumbling with subsequent striking against power tool or machine, initial encounter). Start now by reviewing some of the categories with combination codes: diabetes, coronary artery disease, pressure ulcers, and poisonings and adverse effects. Review the documentation you currently have and try coding the record in both ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM. That will help you determine what’s missing, then share that information with physicians. You can even start querying them for the additional information now. Hopefully, they will be in the habit of documenting the additional information by the time October 1, 2013 rolls around.
JustCoding Virtual Summit offers AAPC credits

As promised, more news about continuing education credits for the JustCoding Virtual Summit: ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS. We are now offering up to 12 AAPC credits for attendees. The summit features two tracks, one for HIM directors and coding supervisors and one for inpatient and outpatient coders. Each track offers six sessions, but participants have on demand access to all of the sessions for six months. That means you can earn a total of 12 AAPC CEs and gain practical, hands-on guidance for the challenges of ICD-10 preparation and implementation. And those are in addition to the 12 AHIMA credits we announced earlier. You can earn both AAPC and AHIMA for attending each session, it’s not an either/or deal. So you can rack up a total of 24 credits while getting ready for the switch to ICD-10. What are you waiting for? Sign up now!
JustCoding Virtual Summit now offering even more credits

In addition to AAPC and AHIMA continuing education credits, attendees to the JustCoding Virtual Summit: ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS can also earn up to 12 credits from the Association of Clinical Documentation Specialists (ACDIS). Clinical documentation improvement (CDI) specialists can pick up credits while learning about the new coding conventions and guidelines as well as how to obtain the appropriate level of documentation from physicians. CDI specialists can also pick up tips about how to work with physicians now to improve documentation before ICD-10-CM/PCS goes live. Don’t miss your chance to get a jump on improving documentation early to make the transition smoother. Sign up today!
Say so long to eponyms in ICD-10-PCS

What’s in a name? That which we call a rose by any other name would smell as sweet. At least Shakespeare says so.
And that has what to do with coding in ICD-10-PCS you might ask. Well, you won’t find eponyms—words derived from the name of a real, fictional, mythical, or spurious character or person—in ICD-10-PCS. So you’ll need to know what that physician is actually doing.
For example, when a physician documents he or she performed a Whipple procedure (and the physicians will still use that term), you will need to know the physician performed a pancreaticoduodenectomy. (Yeah, Whipple procedure is much easier to remember and say.)
Similarly, an Abbott-Fisher-Lucas procedure is a two-stage technique for hip fusion in absence of femoral head, failed femoral prosthesis, or infected trochanteric mold arthroplasty. If you work for an OB/GYN, you’ve probably also seen documentation of Smead-Jones technique, a running closure technique used to approximate abdominal fascia, rectus muscles, and anterior peritoneum.
Physicians will not be required to change their terminology for documenting procedures in ICD-10-PCS (lucky for them, but not so much for us). So how do you know what the physician means by Gatellier-Chastang approach? The best way to know is to ask now.
Look at your documentation and see what eponyms your physicians currently use. Make a list, then make an appointment to sit down with the physicians and have them explain exactly what they are doing for each procedure. You’ll gain a better understanding of what your physicians are actually doing and you’ll get a leg up on coding in ICD-10-PCS.
Not as many NOS codes in ICD-10-PCS

Inpatient coders currently can default to “not otherwise specified” (NOS) codes in ICD-9-CM Volume 3, but they won’t have that option as frequently in ICD-10-PCS.
Coders report NOS codes when the physician did not document enough information for the coder to select a more specific code. For example, in ICD-9-CM, if a physician documents osteoplasty of the facial bone without specifying which facial bone, coders can report 76.69 (other facial bone repair).
However, in ICD-10-PCS, the coder will need to know the actual bone or bones the physician repaired in order to select the appropriate code. A repair of the facial bone codes to 0NQ, but the fourth character, body part, offers 29 possible choices. In addition to the specific bone, coders will also need to know which side of the face is involved. The code for an open repair of the left temporal bone (0NQ60ZZ) differs from the code for an open repair of the right temporal bone (0NQ50ZZ).
That can sound a little daunting at first, but remember that most of this information is already somewhere in the medical record. Physicians know which bone or bones they repaired, but you might need to search for the documentation.
Reach out to your physicians now to get them in the habit of documenting this information in a certain place. You might have more luck asking them where they usually document it so you’ll know where to look. And if it’s already in the documentation, that’s one less thing you will need to ask about later.
CMS hints at delay in ICD-10 implementation deadline

Big news regarding the ICD-10-CM/PCS implementation timeline came out this morning during the American Medical Association (AMA) National Advocacy Conference in Washington, DC. Per CMS acting administrator Marilyn Tavenner, CMS plans to revisit the current implementation deadline of October 1, 2013. Tavenner said CMS wants to reexamine the pace of implementing ICD-10 and reduce physicians’ administrative burden, according to an AMA tweet from this morning. Tavenner also indicated that the timeline will be revisited through the rulemaking process, according to Modern Healthcare, which CMS has since confirmed to HCPro.   Read more on HCPro.com.
AHIMA urges providers not to stop implementation plans because of possible date change

CMS is looking at the timeline for ICD-10 implementation, acting administrator Marilyn Tavenner told attendees at the American Medical Association (AMA) National Advocacy Conference in Washington, DC, February 14.
But that doesn’t mean CMS will change the implementation date, so organizations should not stop their implementation plans. “This is a promise from CMS to examine the timeline, not to change it,” Dan Rode, MBA, CHPS, FHFMA, vice president for advocacy and policy at American Health Information Management Association said in a statement. “But government officials are sending mixed signals that many in the healthcare community will interpret as a reason for delay.”
If organizations and practices delay their implementation plans, they could end up spending more money, Rode said. Delays could also diminish the value of other programs, such as meaningful use. AHIMA CEO Lynne Thomas Gordon, MBA, RHIA, FACHE, urged healthcare providers to continue their implementation plans, emphasizing the advantages of the move to ICD-10-CM/PCS.
CMS has still not released any official statement detailing its plans for reviewing the timeline or any potential new implementation dates, so stay tuned for more information.
The blessings of laterality for fractures

A patient comes in with displaced fracture of base of second metacarpal bone of his right hand. The physician treats the patient and sends him home. The coder would report ICD-10-CM code S62.310A for the initial visit.
Our patient comes back a month later for a follow-up visit and the physician documents routine healing of the fracture. The coder reports S62.310D for the follow-up visit. Remember, for follow up visits for fractures, you report the code for the original fracture with a seventh character D for routine healing.
The next day, our patient comes in with a displaced fracture of base of second metacarpal bone of his left hand and a displaced fracture of base of third metacarpal bone, left hand. The coder reports S62.311A (second digit) and S62.313A (third digit) for the initial visit to treat these fractures.
Our patient is pretty unlucky when it comes to breaking his fingers. The added specificity of ICD-10-CM means we should have an easier time getting paid for his treatment. Because the codes break down the specific hand and finger broken, the payer knows that the patient actually broke three different fingers and we aren’t trying to scam them for extra payment.
Laterality can also be important if a patient has delayed healing of a fracture. Suppose when our unlucky patient came back a month after his first fracture on his right hand, the physician documented delayed healing. The coder would report S62.310G (notice the new seventh character). Then he comes back in with the new fractures of his left fingers the following day.
Because we can show a different hand was involved, we can clearly demonstrate he did not come back in for treatment of the fracture with delayed healing.
All of this paints a clearer picture of our patient not only for our payers, but also for his treating physicians going forward. In the end, that should benefit the patient as well.
HHS confirms possible delay to ICD-10 implementation

After years of repeatedly saying the implementation date for ICD-10-CM/PCS wasn’t changing, the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and CMS are rethinking their stance. HHS Secretary Kathleen G. Sebelius confirmed late Wednesday that HHS will look at postponing the implementation date by which certain healthcare entities must comply with ICD-10-CM/PCS. HHS plans to review the October 1, 2013 compliance date through the rule making process, but as of now, has not released any addition information, such as a possible new implementation date. The American Medical Association (AMA) pushed strongly and publicly for the change. Its House of Delegates voted to “work vigorously to stop implementation of ICD-10” during the closing session of its semi-annual policy-making meeting November 15. All of the lobbying apparently paid off. On February 14, CMS acting administrator Marilyn Tavenner told attendees at the AMA's National Advocacy Conference in Washington, DC, that CMS would reexamine the pace of ICD-10-CM/PCS implementation.
HHS confirms ICD-10 delay: What does it mean for your hospital?

It’s no longer a mere possibility; HHS has confirmed its intent to delay the ICD-10 compliance deadline, according to its latest press release. “We have heard from many in the provider community who have concerns about the administrative burdens they face in the years ahead,” HHS Secretary Kathleen Sebelius said in the press release. “We are committing to work with the provider community to reexamine the pace at which HHS and the nation implement these important improvements to our healthcare system.” It is “premature” to speculate on the rulemaking process or the eventual ICD-10 implementation deadline, a CMS spokesman told HCPro earlier today. Read more on HCPro.com.
To delay training or not to delay training, what should you do?

The transition to ICD-10-CM/PCS has not been cancelled, just delayed. And we’re not even sure for how long. Some industry experts offer their thoughts on what organizations should do while we wait for more information from CMS. You can learn more about ICD-10-CM, ICD-10-PCS, and preparing for the transition regardless of the date during the JustCoding Virtual Summit: ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS February 28-March 2. “We should not cease preparation for the transition, but use this extra time wisely by spreading out the training dollar over the time extension rather than trying to train everyone over a shorter period of time.  Many of the topics in the virtual seminar address what changes are needed, and the delay of I-10 now gives people the opportunity to implement process and policy changes within their organizations so that they will be absolutely ready when ICD-10 IS implemented.” – Lynne Spryszak, RN, CCDS, CPC-A, AHIMA-approved ICD-10 CM/PCS Trainer , CDI education director for HCPro, Inc., who will be discussing, The road to ICD-10 for HIM and CDI during the summit. “Most larger hospitals or chains have their timeline set up already and have plans going.  This should give your smaller hospitals an opportunity, if there is a delay, to get resources identified and planning organized so that they don't get left behind whenever the shoe drops.” – Robert S. Gold, MD, CEO of DCBA, Inc., in Atlanta, who will discuss strategies for physician education  as well as clinical and ICD-10 coding for the musculoskeletal system March 2 during the conference. “Since we really don’t know how long the delay might be, I think it’s important to continuing to learn about and to prepare for the eventual implementation.  And if anyone was behind, now is their chance to catch up.” – Ann Zeisset, RHIT, CCS, CCS-P, AHIMA-Approved ICD-10-CM/PCS Trainer, president of Ann Zeisset Consulting, who will examine ICD-10-PCS clinical circumstances from  a CDI perspective during the summit March 1. Don’t let this opportunity pass you by. Join Lynne, Ann, Dr. Gold, and our other expert speakers for the JustCoding Virtual Summit: ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS February 28-March 2 and make sure you’re ready when ICD-10-CM/PCS goes live!
Will CDI staff take on larger role in querying physicians?

Physician queries are considered communications between coding (or coding-related) professionals and physicians to clarify or increase specificity in the documentation to ensure good clinical documentation as well as to support code assignment for the billing process. Queries are technically not limited just to inpatient coding and in some cases can also be done for outpatient or professional services. For the moment, I’d like to focus more on the previous than the latter. Currently, queries can be performed concurrently or retrospectively to the inpatient admission/discharge. Concurrent queries, which are generally preferred, are posed while the patient is still “in-house” and the physician is readily available to provide clarification while the information is new in his or her mind. Verbal queries are generally included with the concurrent queries. Retrospective queries are performed after the patient is discharged, typically prior to the billing or post-billing. The query responsibility is generally shared by the coding staff as well as clinical documentation improvement (CDI) staff members. Now on to why I am bringing this up. Queries performed by CDI specialists traditionally have been mostly limited to diagnoses (and in many cases ones that affect the overall reimbursement), such as complications/comorbidities (CCs and MCCs). But some of these queries have no financial bearing on the case and are simply posed to obtain added specificity to reflect true severity of illness. We know that with all the added details in the ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes, there very well may be many more opportunities for queries to be posed. But, my cause for concern is that the ICD-10-PCS codes will require a very thorough understanding of how physicians actually perform the procedures and the anatomy involved, which may go beyond the clinical knowledge of coder. So, will CDI specialists become more involved in the query process as it relates to procedure coding? Procedures can certainly have an impact on the overall MS-DRG assigned, and incorrect assignment can lead to improper overpayments (or underpayments). If a question arises regarding a procedure, would it make more sense for the coder or the CDI specialist to pose it to the surgeon? CDIs are in many cases spread very thin (as coders are as well) and may even find it hard to even touch all the cases more than once or twice from a diagnosis standpoint. So will it present problems in the future if we add to their workload additional clarifications needed for operative reports? All seven characters must be assigned to qualify as a complete ICD-10-PCS code, so there is no way out by using a vague code with digits/characters identifying “unspecified.”
Being prepared is paramount for ICD-10 implementation

So CMS may or may not change  the October 1, 2013 implementation date for ICD-10-CM/PCS. We’re still waiting to hear more from CMS and the Department of Health and Human Services. While we’re waiting, we need to continue to work on implementation and be diligent, says Gloryanne Bryant, RHIA, CCS, CCDS, AHIMA-certified ICD-10-CM/PCS Trainer and Regional Managing Director HIM (NCAL Revenue Cycle) for Kaiser Foundation Health Plan Inc & Hospitals in Oakland, CA. “With the volume of work to be done with ICD-10 readiness, whether there is a one-year extension or not or more than one year; it requires us all to make sure all aspects and areas are covered with our readiness planning,” she adds. “Being well prepared is paramount. Attending ongoing educational opportunities can help to verify and validate the direction that one’s practice or organization is on or has taken with their implementation.” Gloryanne will be one of the featured speakers during the JustCoding Virtual Summit: ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS February 28-March 2. She will explain how to conduct documentation and coding assessments in preparation for ICD-10.
An instructor’s perspective on the proposed ICD-10 delay and the need to continue training

Even though this kink (the possible implementation delay) has been presented to everyone, I think we need to remember that the likelihood of continuing status quo for a lengthy amount of time using ICD-9-CM (which is not really functional any longer) is very slim. A decision to move forward with some type of updated system must be made. At this point we don’t know if the delay is a few months after October 1, 2013 (e.g. January, 1, 2014) or a year or more. But if we continue to hold off on learning about ICD-10 until we know, that just puts us in the same boat by not taking advantage of the additional time given to us to learn and master this system.  I believe the more exposure the community has to ICD-10, the more voices will be cheering on its implementation.  When the decision is made about a new date, CMS accepts comments during the comment period in the rulemaking process. Hear more from Shannon during the JustCoding Virtual Summit: ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS February 28-March 2.
Keep moving forward with ICD-10-CM/PCS implementation plans

Don’t let rumor steer you away from the goal of being ready for ICD-10-CM/PCS implementation. By now, everyone has heard that CMS plans to issue a proposed rule with a new ICD-10-CM/PCS implementation date. That doesn’t mean everyone—or even anyone—will get an extension, according to James S. Kennedy MD, CCS, director in the FTI Healthcare group of FTI's corporate finance practice in Brentwood, TN.  He and Ann Zeisset RHIT, CCS, CCS-P, will also be addressing ICD-10-CM/PCS from a clinical perspective during the JustCoding Virtual Summit: ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS. “All CMS has said is that is it going to initiate rulemaking,” Kennedy says. “They have not said that they are going to delay [ICD-10 implementation].” Just because CMS proposes a rule doesn’t mean the agency will implement it, Kennedy cautioned. Four years ago, CMS proposed a rule to have Medicare use DRGs, but because of the negative comments CMS received, it scrapped the proposal. In the 2012 OPPS final rule, CMS decided not to finalize a proposal to cap payments for outpatient cardiac resynchronization therapy defibrillator procedures based on an MS-DRG. Do you want to take a chance on being late? “Procrastination is not the answer,” Kennedy says. Organizations should continue to move forward with their ICD-10-CM/PCS implementation plans and not let this lull them into thinking they should quit preparations, Kennedy adds. “Don’t let this [possible delay] distract you or make you think ICD-10 is going away,” he says. “It’s not. Are you willing to take a chance on not being prepared?”

I love the National Public Radio (NPR) program, "Wait, Wait, Don't Tell me" (WWDTM), a fun look a the news. The program features a panel of amusing well-knowns who answer questions and try to win a prize for an audience member (the voice of one of the program's personalities on the winner's home answering machine). The other thing I love about WWDTM is that I can listen to past shows online. I clicked in recently and hit on the September 17, 2011 program. One of the segments was titled "Name That Horrifying Injury" and was based on a Wall Street Journal story from earlier in the week about ICD-10 codes and how they are used to indicate specific injuries for insurance purposes. The joke was that ICD-10 includes codes for some pretty bizarre incidents—bizarre to the Journal—and therefore amusing as heck to the WWDTM panel and in-studio audience. The panelists were each asked a question about the codes and given three possible answers: #1: There are no fewer than nine ways to be injured by what?
  1. Medieval jousting lances
  2. Turtles
  3. Fellow audience members at a GOP presidential debate
(You can see where this is going…) The answer is "B", and among the nine are 'bitten by’ and 'struck by'. The host added that ICD-10 includes codes dealing with incidents involving macaws, cows, chickens, and three codes to report being bitten by a dolphin. #2: Which urban menace can cause three different kinds of injury?
  1. People not looking up from their Blackberries
  2. Lamp posts
  3. Falling pianos
The answer is "B", with codes that include "walk into lamp post, initial encounter" and "walk into lamp post, subsequent encounter". #3 Two of the following are names of musical bands and one is an injury that needs to be coded. Name the injury.
  1. Unspecified balloon accident
  2. String cheese incident
  3. Nickleback
The answer is "A". Yes, there really is a band called "String Cheese Incident". Access the WSJ article here. There's a quote from a physician who questions the need for such level of detail. "Really? Bathroom versus bedroom?" the Ohio doc is quoted as saying. "What difference does it make?" Click here to listen to the NPR broadcast. Click on that NPR link and treat yourself to 3 minutes and 45 seconds of silly fun. You'll understand why they're laugh at what you all work so hard to do so well. They should  be happy you're on top of things, particularly if someone out there is burned because their water skis catch fire.
Oh, the ICD-10-CM codes you’ll find

In honor of Dr. Seuss' birthday, we present: Oh, the ICD-10-CM codes you’ll find Hit by a truck? Bit by a duck? There’s an ICD-10-CM code for that.   Liver contused? Wrong substance infused? There’s an ICD-10-CM code for that.   Infected with tapeworm? Or maybe it’s ringworm. How about a screw worm? Yes, there’s an ICD-10 code for that.   You’re awake from insomnia. So what’s the reason? Caffeine abuse? Amphetamine use? Or maybe the season? You’ll find an ICD-10-CM code for that.   Congenital deformity of the hip Non-thermal abrasion of the lip A fracture caused by a slip There’s an ICD-10-CM code for that.   Are you the victim of mudslide of cataclysmic nature? Then you might be in for aftercare of a healing fracture. Oh, no, you have malignant neoplasm of the hepatic flexure. Never fear--There’s an ICD-10-CM code for that.
ICD-10-PCS guideline A11 puts onus on coders

Some of the ICD-10-PCS root operations are very similar—think excision (cutting out or off, without replacement, a portion of a body part) and resection (cutting out or off, without replacement, all of a body part). So how is a coder supposed to choose? Physicians will tell us by which root operation they document, right? Unfortunately, wrong. According to the Official Guidelines for ICD-10-PCS (A11), the physician does not have to document a specific root operation. Many of the terms used to construct PCS codes are defined within the system. Physicians are not expected to use the terms used in ICD-10-PCS code descriptions and coders don’t need to query the physician when the documentation clearly matches the defined PCS terms. The coder is responsible to determine what the documentation in the medical record equates to in the PCS definitions. Even so, ICD-10-PCS relies solely upon written provider description of the procedure. If the physician documents left upper lung lobectomy, coders would report a resection of upper lung lobe, left, not an excision. Raise your hand if you have even seen a physician document extirpation. Anyone? Well, we know physicians take or cut out solid matter from a body part. They just don’t say they extirpated the kidney stone. They might document removal or extraction. Coders will have to read the operative report to see what the physician actually performed in order to choose the correct root operation. Start looking at the most common procedures physicians perform at your facility, then compare the documentation to the root operations and see if you can pick the correct one. Not sure about a procedure? Ask a physician to explain exactly what’s going on. Not every coder can just walk up to a physician and ask questions. (Wouldn’t life be easier if they could?) If you are in that situation, talk to your manager or supervisor. Ask if they would set up short training sessions where different physicians explain procedures within their area of expertise. The meetings don’t have to be long, but could benefit everyone in the end.
‘As God as my witness’ there’s a query opportunity here

Can you begin to imagine how complex a piece of great literature would be if we had to include complete documentation of each medical incident? Or have to stop every time we have to develop physician queries?
