When we look up laceration, forehead in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index, we are directed to S01.81, laceration without foreign body of other part of head. When we go to the Tabular Index, we see that we need a seventh character to denote the encounter type, so our final code would be S01.81XA. That brings us to Matt’s final injury, the fork to the foot. Matt removed the fork before coming to Fix ‘Em Up, and fortunately, nothing stayed behind in the punctures. Again, we need to know which foot (right), with or without foreign body (without), foot itself or toes (foot itself), and encounter type (initial). All of that brings us to: S91.331A (puncture wound without foreign body, right foot, initial encounter). And with that, Dr. Toe is done with Matt and we are done with his diagnostic record. So it’s time to head home and fire up the grill. I will not be adding any cherry tomatoes though.
Another physician group comes out against ICD-10 implementation

The American Osteopathic Association (AOA) House of Delegates has joined the American Medical Association’s (AMA) crusade to crush ICD-10 implementation.
Back in November 2011, the AMA’s House of Delegates voted to “work vigorously to stop implementation of ICD-10” during the closing session of its semi-annual policy-making meeting.
The AOA isn’t going quite that far, but the House of Delegates did vote to oppose full implementation of ICD-10 during its 2012 annual meeting in Chicago. And the AOA may not be as dedicated to stopping ICD-10 as the AMA: only 51% of delegates voted in favor of the AOA voicing its disapproval.
In response to the AMA’s declaration, the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) decided to investigate delaying ICD-10 implementation and eventually proposed a one-year delay. We still have no final word on whether HHS is actually changing the date and if so, what the new compliance date will be.
Wile E. is back for follow up treatment

Why hello there, Mr. Coyote. Long time, no see. Are you still chasing that roadrunner? You are? Well, you are certainly persistent, I’ll give you that. So what brings you into the Acme Clinic today? You’re here to see Dr. Frankenbean for a follow up? Certainly, have a seat and we’ll be right with you. Poor Wile E. I got the whole story from his medical record when I was coding his chart. Apparently, he ordered a do-it-yourself tornado kit (designed to seed clouds) from a less-than reputable dealer. Unfortunately, the seeds got wet before Wile E. could disperse them properly and they created a massive tornado. Of course instead of scooping up that evil bird, the tornado took Wile E. on a ride to an abandoned mine field, then dropped him. Our poor coyote friend suffered multiple injuries that Dr. Frankebean treated at the Acme ED three weeks ago and now he’s back for a progress check. According to Dr. Frankenbean’s notes, Wile E. suffered a:
  • Subluxation of the cervical vertebrae (that explains the neck brace)
  • Primary blast injury to the lung (caused by the mines exploding)
  • Traumatic rupture of ear drum due to blast injury (also caused by the mines exploding)
  • Singed fur
Luckily for Wile E., he is healing well, according to the chart. So how do we code all of Wile E.’s various injuries? One thing we need to know for most of the codes is the encounter type. We know this is not an initial visit. Wile E. saw the same physician for the same injuries three weeks ago. That leaves us with subsequent (D) or sequela (S). How do we know whether to use a D or an S as our seventh character? In Dr. Frankenbean’s notes, he documented a follow up visit, but does not mention any late effects of the injuries. That means we’re coding for a subsequent visit. Let’s start with the subluxation of the cervical vertebrae. We know it’s a subluxation, not a fracture, in the cervical area, and a subsequent visit. What else do we need to know? How about the specific vertebrae involved? ICD-10-CM does include a code for unspecified vertebra, but we want to avoid reporting that code if we can. So let’s see if the information is in Wile E.’s medical record. And it is. Dr. Frankenbean notes, “CT scan shows improvement in subluxation at C2/3 and 3/4.” So we would report:
  • S13.130D, subluxation of C2/C3 cervical vertebrae, subsequent visit
  • S13.140D, subluxation of C3/C4 cervical vertebrae, subsequent visit
Make sure you check the notes at the top of the S13 (dislocation and sprain of joints and ligaments at neck level) series of codes. We have includes, code also, and Excludes2 notes to follow. None of those notes apply for our case, but you should always check them to be sure. By looking back to the beginning of the series, we also find the notation to report the appropriate seventh character. If you just look at the specific codes for subluxation of the cervical vertebrae, you might miss the seventh character and then your code’s not valid and you don’t get paid. Bad stuff. Speaking of bad stuff, let’s move on to Wile E.’s blast injury. We know which organ was affected (lung) and we know subsequent visit. What we don’t see at first is the laterality. And the laterality here is a little different from the laterality of other codes. Here we just need to know unilateral, bilateral, or unspecified. We don’t need to know right or left. So back to the documentation where we find Wile E. suffered a blast injury of the right lung. That means unilateral, which leads to code:
  • S27.311D, primary blast injury of lung, unilateral, subsequent visit
For the traumatic blast injury to the ear, again we need to know whether it’s unilateral, bilateral, or unspecified. In the record, we see that Dr. Frankenbean called in an audiologist, Dr. Ringer, to see Wile E. during the visit. In her note, she states that the blast ruptured both of Wile E.’s ear drums, which means bilateral. She also notes that she also consulted during Wile E.’s initial visit. So we are still coding a subsequent encounter. The seventh character A is for use as long as the patient is receiving active treatment for the fracture, according to the ICD-10-CM Official Guidelines. Active treatment includes:
  • Surgical treatment
  • Emergency department encounter
  • Evaluation and treatment by a new physician
According to the guidelines, we use the seventh character D for encounters after the patient has completed active treatment. So, same physician, follow up, no sequela, bilateral ears leads us to:
  • S09.313D, primary blast injury of ear, bilateral, subsequent visit
ICD-10-CM does not include a code for singed fur (not surprising since most people don’t have fur). However, it does include an extensive list of burn codes. Could the singed fur actually be a burn? It’s possible, but according to Dr. Frankenbean’s original notes, “fur burned off of face, but no burns to the tissue.” So no burn code for Wile E. And as a friend of Wile E’s would say, “That’s all, folks!”
ICD-10-CM coding for a bachelor party mishaps

What happens in Vegas might stay in Vegas, but when things go wrong in Atlantic City, people end up at Fix ‘Em Up Clinic. Today, we have several bachelor party victims who made the clinic their first stop after arriving home from a weekend on the boardwalk. Dr. Bender’s first patient is Jimmy, who apparently decided to send his bachelorhood off in style with a few too many adult beverages. We’re not sure exactly what Jimmy drank, largely because Jimmy’s not sure. What we do know is Jimmy is suffering from acute alcohol intoxication without complications. Dr. Bender has ruled out alcohol poisoning, a very serious condition, and instead determined that Jimmy’s symptoms are the result of alcohol intoxication. When we look up alcohol related disorders, we find a variety of potential codes:
  • F10.1, alcohol abuse
  • F10.2, alcohol dependence
  • F10.9, alcohol use, unspecified
How do we determine which code series to use? By reading the documentation of course. Here’s what Dr. Bender has to say about Jimmy’s alcohol use:

Patient reports history of occasional social drinking, rarely drinks to excess. Was out celebrating upcoming wedding, had too much to drink. No finding of chronic abuse or dependence.

No abuse or dependence means we’ll use the unspecified code. Even knowing that, we still have plenty of codes to choose from, including:
  • F10.92, alcohol use, unspecified with intoxication
  • F10.94, alcohol use, unspecified with alcohol-induced mood disorder
  • F10.95, alcohol use, unspecified with alcohol-induced psychotic disorder
  • F10.96, alcohol use, unspecified with alcohol-induced persisting amnestic disorder
  • F10.97, alcohol use, unspecified with alcohol-induced persisting dementia
  • F10.98, alcohol use, unspecified with other alcohol-induced disorders
  • F10.99, alcohol use, unspecified with unspecified alcohol-induced disorder
If we go back to the documentation, we see a notation of “without complications” so we’ll report:
  • F10.920, alcohol use, unspecified with intoxication, uncomplicated
Jimmy got off pretty lucky (until his fiancée finds out what he was doing in Atlantic City), but some of his friends ended up with more than just a hangover. Chris not only overindulged in alcohol, but ended up walking into a lamppost while walking on Baltic Avenue. That collision left him with a concussion, broken nose, and two black eyes. Fortunately, the effects of the alcohol had not worn off, so he didn’t feel a thing. We can report Chris’ overindulgence with F10.920 because Dr. Bender noted only impaired coordination and slurred speech as problems related to the alcohol. Those are really more consequences of too many beers and not complications. In order to code Chris’ concussion, we need to know if he lost consciousness. His friends report a brief loss of consciousness. When pressed for a more specific time frame, Jimmy says, five or 10 minutes. That leads us to S06.0X1, concussion with loss of consciousness of 30 minutes or less, but we’re not done yet. Codes in the S06 series require a seventh character to denote the encounter type. Dr. Bender documented an initial encounter for all of Chris’ injuries, so the final code is
  • S06.0X1A, concussion with loss of consciousness of 30 minutes or less, initial visit
Chris’ broken nose is easy to code because he only has one nose (no laterality) and we already know the encounter type (initial). That leads to code:
  • S02.2xxA, fracture of nasal bones, initial visit
Note that you do need to add two “x” placeholders to make sure the seventh character ends up in the seventh place. S02.2A is not a valid code. That leaves Chris’ two black eyes. Since Chris managed to get two black eyes, we need to report two codes, again adding the seventh character for the encounter:
  • S00.11xA, contusion of right eyelid and periocular area, initial visit
  • S00.12xA, contusion of left eyelid and periocular area, initial visit
We can also add codes to explain how Chris suffered his injuries:
  • W22.02xA, walked into lamppost, initial visit
  • Y92.480, sidewalk as the place of occurrence of the external cause
And that brings us to Dan, the final member of the party. Dan was having so much fun at the bar that he didn’t want to leave. When the bouncers tried to escort him out, Dan put up a fight. Dr. Bender noted the following: Patient seen for initial visit following drunken unarmed altercation in restaurant bar. No complications from alcohol. Patient sustained laceration to left cheekbone, abrasions to right knuckles, multiple broken ribs left side, and abdominal contusions. No internal injuries. No foreign bodies in any of the wounds. Kind of makes you wonder how the other guys look. But since we don’t have to code their injuries, let’s focus on Dan. Dan also gets F10.920 for his overindulgence. One down, many codes to go. Next is his lacerated cheekbone. We know which side (left), which encounter type (initial), and no foreign bodies. That takes us to code:
  • S01.412A, laceration without foreign body of left cheek and temporomandibular area, initial visit
Moving on to the abrasions on his right knuckles, we run into a problem. ICD-10-CM contains a separate code for abrasion of each finger. And Dr. Bender didn’t specify. He gave us which hand, but not which fingers. So we’ll have to query. Dr. Bender adds the following information in response to our query: Abrasions of right index, middle, ring fingers, no fractures. Three fingers means three codes:
  • S60.410A, abrasion of right index finger, initial visit
  • S60.412A, abrasion of right middle finger, initial visit
  • S60.414A, abrasion of right ring finger
Next up, broken ribs. I hope we don’t have to know which ones! And it turns out, we don’t, we just need to know that more than one is broken and which side (left). That gives us:
  • S22.42xA, multiple fractures of ribs, left side, initial visit
The code for abdominal contusions is even less specific: S30.1xxA (contusion of abdominal wall, initial visit). We can also add:
  • Y04.0xxA, assault by unarmed brawl or fight, initial encounter
  • Y92.511, restaurant or café as the place of occurrence of the external cause
Well, let’s hope things go more smoothly for Jimmy and his friends in the fut

Patience may be a virtue, but knowledge is power. Okay, enough clichés. The bottom line is we’re still waiting for a new ICD-10 implementation date. HHS published the proposed rule, moving implementation to October 1, 2014, in the Federal Register April 17. Comments were due within 30 days of publication. That was more than two months ago. And we’re still waiting. In the meantime, continue with your ICD-10 preparations. Don’t use HHS’ drawn out process as an excuse to stop preparing. CMS released a checklist to use in preparing for ICD-10. The steps include:
  • Educate staff and leadership about ICD-10
  • Perform an impact assessment
  • Plan a realistic and comprehensive budget
  • Coordinate with external partners
  • Get ready for testing
Most facilities and practices should have already completed at least the first three steps. After all, until April, we were expecting ICD-10 implementation to be in 2013. Who knows, it could still be 2013. Just because HHS proposed delaying implementation doesn’t mean it’s going to finalize that plan. One thing that CMS didn’t include on its list is coordinating with internal partners. ICD-10 implementation is going to affect pretty much every part of your organization except housekeeping and maybe the physical plant. Don’t fall into the trap of thinking ICD-10 is only an HIM problem. If you haven’t already created an implementation team, there’s no time like the present. If you have a team in place, make sure it includes the correct members. According to CMS, project teams should consist of representatives from key areas of your organization, including:
  • Senior Management
  • Health Information Management/Coding
  • Billing/Finance
  • Compliance
  • Revenue Cycle Management
  • Information Systems and Technology
Make sure you appoint a project or team leader and communicate regular with each other, the staff, and senior management. And keep an eye out for a compliance date.

When a physician places a device that takes the place of all or some of a body part, assign a code from ICD-10-PCS root operation replacement (third character R). Think of a total knee replacement or a skin graft. The physician may remove or replace a body part, physically eradicate the body part, or render ir nonfunctional during the replacement procedure. Remember to code a removal procedure if the physician also takes out a previous replacement device. Examples of replacement procedures include:
  • 0QR70KZ, excision of necrosed left femoral head with bone bank bone graft to fill the defect, open
  • 08R83KZ, penetrating keratoplasty of right cornea with donor matched cornea, percutaneous approach
  • 0HRV0JZ, bilateral mastectomy with concomitant saline breast implants, open
  • 04R00JZ, excision of abdominal aorta with goretex graft replacement, open
  • 0LRS0KZ, tenonectomy with graft to right ankle using cadaver graft, open
ICD-10-CM coding goes to the dogs

The dogs days of summer have arrived so the residents of Anytown descended on the dog park with their furry friends today. Sadly, not all of the puppies (and people) play well together and some of the ended up at the Fix ‘Em Clinic to see Dr. Huck Hound. Ilene thought it would be a good idea to take Howie, her Bichon Frisé, to the park so he could frolick to his heart’s content. Unfortunately, as soon as they hit the park, Howie spotted a bunny near the woods and took off in hot pursuit—while Ilene still had a firm grip on his leash. Howie succeeded in wrenching her arm but the bunny made a clean getaway. Dr. Hound sees Ilene for an initial visit and diagnoses a dislocated right shoulder. That gives us the laterality and the encounter (for our seventh character). What else do we need to know? Let’s start with the specific type of dislocation. Is it a dislocation of the acromioclavicular joint, the humerus, or the scapula? Also, is this a recurrent dislocation? Maybe Howie chases bunnies often. When we scan through Dr. Hound’s notes, we see he documented subluxation of the humerus. Great, so we’re all set. Or maybe not. When we look up the code, we find out that we need to know whether the subluxation is anterior or posterior. Time to query. Dr. Hound informs us that the injury is a posterior subluxation and it not recurrent. That leads us to code:
  • S43.024A, posterior dislocation of right humerus, initial visit
Since we know where Ilene was when she was injured, we could also report:
  • Y92.830, public park as the place of occurrence of the external cause
Because she was walking Howie at the time of the incident, we could also add:
  • Y93.K1, activities involving walking an animal
Keep in mind, though, that not all payers want to see external causes codes (think ICD-9 E codes) on the claim. Make sure you know your payer’s preference before you submit the claim. Shannon also visited the dog park today with her 9-year-old pit bull Damian. Poor Damian, in addition to being an older dog also suffers from lupus. He is content to mainly bask in the sun on a warm patch of grass. That’s great for Shannon until it’s time to go home and Damian doesn’t want to budge. Rather than fight with her dog, Shannon picked him up – and pulled the muscles in her back. Damian apparently packed on the pounds recently. Dr. Hound documents an initial visit for a lower back strain. That’s pretty easy to code as it turns out:
  • S39.012A, strain of muscle, fascia and tendon of lower back, initial visit
Again, if your payer wants the external causes codes, report Y92.830 for the park. You scould also report:
  • Y93.K9, overexertion related to animal care
What if Shannon was the patient with lupus instead of Damian? How would we code that condition? Turns out we would need a lot of information. First of all, we need to narrow down the type of lupus:
  • Anticoagulent
  • Discoid
  • Erythematosus
  • Exedens
  • Hydralazine
  • Nephritis
  • Nontuberculous, not disseminated
  • Panniculitis
  • Pernio (Besnier)
  • Tuberculous
So if the physician just documents lupus, that won’t cut it in ICD-10-CM. Let’s say Dr. Hound documents systemic lupus erythematosus. Is that enough to get us to the correct code? Unfortunately not, but you knew I was going to say that, didn’t you? Codes for systemic lupus erythematosus fall under the M32 category in ICD-10-CM. Our choices include:
  • M32.0, drug-induced systemic lupus erythematosus
  • M32.1, systemic lupus erythematosus with organ or system involvement (with multiple subcategories to indicate specific organ or system involvement)
  • M32.8, other forms of systemic lupus erythematosus
  • M32.9, systemic lupus erythematosus, unspecified
If you see a lot of lupus patients in your facility or practice, start getting your physicians used to documenting these additional details now so it will be an habit by the time we start using ICD-10-CM. Our final visitor from the dog park is Sally, who had a close encounter with Damian while he was napping. Sally, who’s 5, didn’t see Damian, tripped over him, and went sprawling in the dirt. Damian woke up, looked around, concluded nothing interesting was going on, and promptly went back to sleep. Sally’s mom took her home thinking Sally suffered no serious injuries, but found out Sally cut her hand on a rock when she fell and part of the rock remained embedded in her hand. So Mom brought Sally in to see Dr. Hound. Dr. Hound documents an initial visit for a laceration of the right palm with rock fragments still inside. I think he’s getting the hang of this detailed documenting. That tells us everything we need to know. Just as a side note, ICD-10-CM does not include a code for a laceration specifically of the palm. When you look up laceration, palm, in the Alphabetic Index, it directs you to laceration, hand. Our codes for Sally would be:
  • S61.421A, laceration with foreign body of right hand, initial visit
  • Y92.830, public park as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • W54.8XXA, other contact with dog, initial encounter
ICD-10-CM includes codes for bitten by and struck by a dog, everything else falls under other contact with dog. Since Sally tripped over Damian, who was napping and minding his own business, we would go with other contact with dog. That’s all for today’s outing to the dog park. The next time you take your puppy for out, make sure you watch where you’re going so you don’t trip over a dog or step in something worse.
New ICD-10 compliance date coming soon (we hope)

We’re one step closer to knowing whether the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) will actually delay ICD-10 implementation and if so, by how long. The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) is currently reviewing the proposed rule, “Administrative Simplification: Standard Unique Identifier for Health Plans and ICD-10 Compliance Date Delay.” The OMB’s review is the final step before release of the rule. However, the review can take up to 60 days. HHS originally proposed a one-year delay (from October 1, 2013, to October 1, 2014) for ICD-10 implementation April 9. The proposed rule was published in the Federal Register April 17. HHS received a large number of comments on the proposed delay. That could be one reason it’s taken so long for the rule to make its way to the OMB. So we’re still waiting to hear what the final compliance date is, but at least we’re getting closer to knowing what that date will be.

Diseases of the ear and mastoid process are moving up in the ICD-10-CM world. They’re getting their own chapter. In ICD-9-CM, eyes and ears shared a section. You’ll find diseases of the ear in Chapter 8 (H60-H95) in ICD-10-CM. Not surprisingly, that’s right after diseases of the eye and adnexa, which live in Chapter 7. ICD-10-CM divides the diseases of the ear into externa, media, and interna, just like ICD-9-CM. ICD-10-CM diseases of the ear generally require that you know which ear is involved or if both ears are affected. For example, if a physician documents an abscess of the external ear, coders have four choices:
  • H60.00, abscess of external ear, unspecified ear
  • H60.01, abscess of right external ear
  • H60.02, abscess of left external ear
  • H60.03, abscess of external ear, bilateral
Avoid the unspecified ear code as much as possible. The whole point of going to ICD-10-CM is to gather better, more complete data, so unspecified ear doesn’t really cut it. And the physician should know which ear he or she treated and many physicians are already documenting that information. You may just have to locate it. For some conditions, ICD-10-CM contains more codes, but the only addition is really the laterality. Take a look at otosclerosis. In ICD-9-CM, you have five codes to choose from:
  • 387.0, otosclerosis involving oval window, nonobliterative
  • 387.1, otosclerosis involving oval window, obliterative
  • 387.2, cochlear otosclerosis
  • 387.8, other otosclerosis
  • 387.9, otosclerosis, unspecified
ICD-10-CM contains 20 codes for otosclerosis. However, ICD-10-CM still uses the same five subcategories as ICD-9-CM. The additional codes just provide the detail of where the otosclerosis is located:
  • Right ear
  • Left ear
  • Bilateral
  • Unspecified
So you’ll see a lot more codes, but really only need one additional piece of information. Another common feature of the ear disease codes is “other specified” as a code choice. Just as in ICD-9-CM, other specified means we have detailed information, but we don’t have a code that fits. That’s different from “unspecified,” which means we have the code choices, but not the information. In some cases, coders will see both “other specified” and “unspecified” as choices in the same subcategory. Consider disorders of the acoustic nerve. The subcategory includes the following codes:
  • H93.8X1, other specified disorders of right ear
  • H93.8X2, other specified disorders of left ear
  • H93.8X3, other specified disorders of ear, bilateral
  • H93.8X9, other specified disorders of ear, unspecified ear
  • H93.90, unspecified disorder of ear, unspecified ear
  • H93.91, unspecified disorder of right ear
  • H93.92, unspecified disorder of left ear
  • H93.93, unspecified disorder of ear, bilateral
If you find yourself report H93.90, you need to stop and query the physician.  Payers may reimburse you for an unspecified disorder of an unspecified ear immediately after the transition to ICD-10-CM (or they may not). However, as time goes on, you’ll probably have a harder time collecting reimbursement for such a vague diagnosis.
Fastballs, flying bats, and ICD-10-CM coding

We’ve hit the middle of August and Anytown’s summer adult baseball league is winding down its season. Just like the pros, though, our players haven’t escaped injury free. Randy, the league’s top southpaw pitcher, is back to see Dr. Selig for a follow up visit for a rotator cuff injury he suffered earlier in the season after throwing one too many super special fastballs. Dr. Selig documents the following:

Routine follow up visit for a partial tear of the left supraspinatus tendon caused by overuse. Injury occurred on baseball field during summer league baseball game. Patient is healing well. Will see again in two weeks.

When we look up supraspinatus tendon in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index, it directs us to M75.10-. Because of that dash at the end of the code in the index, we know we need additional characters to complete our code. When we look up that code in the Tabular List, we notice ICD-10-CM includes three types of rotator cuff tears:
  • M75.10, unspecified rotator cuff tear or rupture, not specified as traumatic
  • M75.11, incomplete rotator cuff tear or rupture not specified as traumatic
  • M75.12, complete rotator cuff tear or rupture not specified as traumatic
Each category includes three choices that specify laterality (right, left, unspecified) and each requires a seventh character for the encounter type. Based on Dr. Selig’s documentation, we will report a code in the M75.11- series because we know  Randy suffered an incomplete tear. And because this is a follow up visit, we would report:
  • M75.112D, incomplete rotator cuff tear or rupture of left shoulder, not specified as traumatic, subsequent visit
Notice that the code itself does not specify which tendon the patient injured. However, if we look under  M75.1, rotator cuff tear or rupture, not specified as traumatic, we find these codes include:
  • Rotator cuff syndrome
  • Supraspinatus tear or rupture, not specified as traumatic
  • Supraspinatus syndrome
We also find an Excludes1 note for a tear of rotator cuff, traumatic (S46.01-). Dr. Selig documented a non-traumatic injury so we would stay with the M75.112D. Tommy came in to see Dr. Selig after today’s game with pain on the inside of his elbow, numbness in the small finger and ring finger, and a decreased ability to throw a baseball. After examining Tommy, Dr. Selig documents:

 Initial visit for patient with torn ulnar collateral ligament, right elbow. Tear caused by slow deterioration of ligament due to pitching motion.

So we know this is not a traumatic injury because it involves deterioration over time. Since Dr. Selig documented a tear, we’ll start by looking up tear in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index. Under tear, torn, we do not find ulnar collateral ligament, so let’s check just ligament. The entry for ligament directs us to see sprain. Under sprain, we do find ulnar collateral ligament, but the entry directs us to see Rupture, traumatic, ligament, ulnar collateral. Hmm, that doesn’t seem correct. Dr. Selig documented the cause as slow deterioration, not a traumatic injury.   If we look under Sprain, elbow, we also find ulnar collateral ligament listed with code S53.44-. This looks better. In the Tabular List, S53.44 denotes ulnar collateral ligament sprain. Since we know this is the first visit for a right ulnar collateral ligament sprain, we would report:
  • S53.441A, ulnar collateral ligament sprain of right elbow, initial visit
Our final diamond casualty, Earl, arrives with a slightly different type of injury. Earl was in the dugout managing the Cardinals when he was hit by a flying bat. Apparently Reggie let go on the follow through. Sadly for Reggie’s team the Cubs, the only thing Reggie hit today was Earl. And he gave Earl a concussion and a nice big contusion to remember him by. Earl’s players badgered him into coming into the Fix ‘Em Up Clinic even though he didn’t lose consciousness. At least that’s what Earl claims. His players disagree and say he was out for two or three minutes, four minutes at most. Dr. Selig documents the following in Earl’s chart: Patient seen for initial visit. Suffered concussion after being hit in head by flying baseball bat during game. Suffered mild concussion with LOC less than 5 minutes. Contusion of forehead, no laceration, no foreign body, no underlying fracture. No other injuries noted. Let’s start with Earl’s concussion. It doesn’t matter if Earl was out for three minutes or four. The first ICD-10-CM code for a concussion indicates loss of consciousness 30 minutes or fewer. He definitely wasn’t out longer than that, so we would report:
  • S06.0X1A, concussion with loss of consciousness of 30 minutes or less, initial visit
For Earl’s contusion, we don’t have a code that specifies forehead, so we would report:
  • S00.83XA, contusion of other part of head, initial visit
Note that for this code, we know which part of the head is involved, we just don’t have a code for it. This is not the same as reporting an unspecified code if we don’t know the specific area. And because we know what Earl was doing when the injuries occurred, we can also report:
  • Y92.320, baseball field as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y93.64, activity, baseball
  • W21.11XA, struck by baseball bat, initial visit
With that it’s time to head out to the field to catch the late game. Play ball!

Penny came into the Fix ‘Em Up emergency department Friday, complaining of tingling and numbness in her face and arm. She was also somewhat unsteady on her feet. Her husband Dave also reported Penny had trouble speaking and one side of her face was drooping.  By the time she arrived at the ED, her symptoms had resolved. Still, it turns out it was a good thing she came in. Dr.  Morang saw Penny, listened to Dave, and after running some preliminary tests, diagnosed Penny with a transient ischemic attack (TIA). For the non-vascular and non-neurologic coders among us, a TIA is when blood flow to a part of the brain stops for a brief period of time. A person will have stroke-like symptoms for up to 24 hours, but in most cases symptoms only last for 1-2 hours. In ICD-10-CM, we have the following choices for coding a TIA:
  • G45.0, vertebro-basilar artery syndrome
  • G45.1, carotid artery syndrome (hemispheric)
  • G45.2, multiple and bilateral precerebral artery syndromes
  • G45.3, amaurosis fugax
  • G45.4, transient global amnesia
  • G45.8, other transient cerebral ischemic attacks and related syndromes
  • G45.9, transient cerebral ischemic attack, unspecified
So we need more information from Dr. Morang. So let’s send him a query. He responds that Penny suffered from carotid artery syndrome, so we report G45.1. Dr. Morang ordered some additional tests (including an MRI and carotid artery duplex scan) and planned to see Penny (and Dave) in his office Tuesday after the test results are in. The MRI revealed that Penny did not suffer a TIA, she suffered a stroke. Now we have a new series of codes. When we look up stroke in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index, we find the following qualifiers all leading to the same code (I63.9):
  • Apoplectic
  • Brain
  • Embolic
  • Ischemic
  • Paralytic
  • Thrombotic
Turns out, I63.9 is the code for cerebral infarction unspecified. That’s not a good code to use. We might get away with an unspecified code when we first start using ICD-10-CM, but I have a feeling payers won’t cover those diagnoses codes for long. Instead of settling for unspecified, let’ see if we can’t get to a more specific code. Cerebral infarctions fall under category I63. When you look it up in the Tabular Index, you’ll notice two notes:
  • Includes occlusion and stenosis of cerebral and precerebral arteries, resulting in cerebral infarction
  • Use additional code, if applicable, to identify status post administration of tPA (rtPA) in a different facility within the last 24 hours prior to admission to current facility (Z92.82)
We don’t have to worry about an addition code in this case because Penny did not receive tPA. We’re just looking for a stroke code. In order to narrow down the possibilities, we need to know what caused Penny’s stroke. Our broad choices include:
  • I63.0, cerebral infarction due to thrombosis of precerebral arteries
  • I63.1, cerebral infarction due to embolism of precerebral arteries
  • I63.2, cerebral infarction due to unspecified occlusion or stenosis of precerebral arteries
  • I63.3, cerebral infarction due to thrombosis of cerebral arteries
  • I63.4, cerebral infarction due to embolism of cerebral arteries
  • I63.5, cerebral infarction due to unspecified occlusion or stenosis of cerebral arteries
  • I63.6, cerebral infarction due to cerebral venous thrombosis, nonpyogenic
  • I63.8, other cerebral infarction
  • I63.9, cerebral infarction, unspecified
Oh, Dr. Morang, we have another question. Can you tell us, please, what kind of stroke Penny had? And which vessels were involved? And which side the vessels are on? Okay, that’s three questions, but querying coders really want to know. Dr. Morang replies that Penny suffered a cerebral infarction due to occlusion of the right carotid arteries. That leads us to I63.231 (cerebral infarction due to unspecified occlusion or stenosis of right carotid arteries). Penny fortunately is expected to make a complete recovery. She’s going under the knife in a few weeks for what Dr. Morang calls “roto rootering of the arteries” (for the more medically minded, that’s a carotid endarterectomy). But that is another visit. For now, we’ll wish Penny well and send Dr. Morang a quick thank you.

HHS will delay implementation of ICD-10 by one year, from October 1, 2013 to October 1, 2014. HHS announced the delay August 24 as part of the Administrative Simplification: Adoption of a Standard for a Unique Health Plan Identifier; Addition to the National Provider Identifier Requirements; and a Change to the Compliance Date for the International Classification of Diseases, 10thEdition (ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS) Medical Data Code Sets final rule. “I am thrilled it was not postponed past October 1, 2014,” says Shannon McCall, RHIA, CCS, CCS-P, CPC, CPC-I, CEMC, CCDS, Director of HIM and Coding for HCPro, Inc, in Danvers, Mass. “I think the sooner we can adopt this more robust classification system the closer we will be to enhancing the data capture of coded information in the U.S.   I am cautiously optimistic that there will be not be further debate over this revised implementation date.  I hope organizations did not lose momentum in the recent period of limbo but if anyone did we just got the green light to surge onward and upward! “ HHS originally proposed a one-year delay (from October 1, 2013, to October 1, 2014) for ICD-10 implementation April 9. The proposed rule was published in the Federal Register April 17. HHS received a large number of comments on the proposed delay. A display copy of the final rule is available. It is scheduled to be published in the Federal Register September 5.

We’ve all heard of deranged killers, but have you ever heard of a deranged knee? Better yet, can you code for it? Coding for a derangement isn’t new. We have derangement codes in ICD-9-CM. For example, code series 717 contains codes for various internal derangements of the knee, including:
  • 717.0, old bucket handle tear of medial meniscus
  • 717.1, derangement of anterior horn of medial meniscus
  • 717.2, derangement of posterior horn of medial meniscus
  • 717.3, other and unspecified derangement of medial meniscus
In most cases, the codes are fairly general. In fact, you don’t need any additional specification until you hit
  • 717.4, derangement of lateral meniscus
  • 717.8, other internal derangement of knee
These two categories require a fifth digit that supplies additional detail. In ICD-10-CM, internal derangements of the knee fall under M23.- and that category includes a lot more codes. You’ll also find a Excludes1 note (meaning not coded here) for the following conditions:
  • Ankylosis (M24.66)
  • Current injury - see injury of knee and lower leg (S80-S89)
  • Deformity of knee (M21.-)
  • Osteochondritis dissecans (M93.2)
  • Recurrent dislocation or subluxation of joints (M24.4)
  • Recurrent dislocation or subluxation of patella (M22.0-M22.1)
Almost all of the codes under category M23.- require a six-digit code, but none require a seventh character. When we look at the possibilities for types of knee derangement, we find the following general subcategories:
  • M23.0, cystic meniscus
  • M23.2, derangement of meniscus due to old tear or injury
  • M23.3, other meniscus derangements
  • M23.4, loose body in knee
  • M23.5, chronic instability of knee
  • M23.6, other spontaneous disruption of ligament(s) of knee
  • M23.8, other internal derangements of knee
All of the codes include a character to indicate laterality:
  • 0 or 9 for unspecified, depending on the code series
  • 1 for right
  • 2 for left
For codes under M23.4 and M23.5, that information occupies the fifth character position. For the remaining codes, that information is noted in the sixth character. So for example, if a patient suffers a spontaneous disruption of medial collateral ligament, you would choose one of these codes:
  • M23.631, other spontaneous disruption of medial collateral ligament of right knee
  • M23.632, other spontaneous disruption of medial collateral ligament of left knee
  • M23.639, other spontaneous disruption of medial collateral ligament of unspecified knee
Be sure to look for documentation of the specific ligament, as well as laterality. ICD-10-CM also contains code series for:
  • M23.60, other spontaneous disruption of unspecified ligament of knee
  • M23.62, other spontaneous disruption of posterior cruciate ligament of knee
  • M23.64, other spontaneous disruption of lateral collateral ligament of knee
  • M23.67, other spontaneous disruption of capsular ligament of knee
Also remember that other spontaneous disruption does not mean unspecified spontaneous disruption. Other means we have the information, but no code. Unspecified means we don’t know because our provider didn’t tell us. Speaking of unspecified, category M23.- includes three unspecified codes:
  • M23.90, unspecified internal derangement of unspecified knee
  • M23.91, unspecified internal derangement of right knee
  • M23.92, unspecified internal derangement of left knee
Notice that M23.90 denotes an unspecified derangement of an unspecified knee. If you are reporting that code, you need to have a chat with your provider about basic documentation. Really, the provider should know (and note) which knee he or she examined.
Build a better procedure code with ICD-10-PCS

Welcome to Stitch ‘Em Hospital, where we’re preparing for ICD-10-PCS by actually coding some of our procedures using the new system. We want to make sure we’re ready to go on October 1, 2014, and practice makes perfect. Unfortunately our encoder decided to take the day off, so we’ll need to use the ICD-10-PCS coding manual and the actual tables to code today’s case. Today’s patient, Penny, was initially seen at our sister facility, Fix ‘Em Up Clinic. Penny suffered a stroke as the result of a blockage in her right carotid artery. Her ICD-10-CM diagnosis is:
  • I63.231, cerebral infarction due to unspecified occlusion or stenosis of right carotid arteries
Penny is in today for a right carotid endarterectomy to clean out the artery and reduce her changes for a future stroke. Dr. Ted will be performing her surgery. So how do we code the right carotid endarterectomy? Let’s look at each of the seventh characters to see what our options are and build the actual code. The first character denotes the section of the ICD-10-PCS manual. We’re looking up a surgery, so we would go to the Medical and Surgical section. That gives us a first character of 0 (zero). Note that ICD-10-PCS does not use letters I and O, because they can be confused with numbers 1 and 0. The second character is the body system, where is the procedure being done. In Penny’s case, the surgeon is operating on her carotid artery, so we would use Upper Arteries as our body system. That gives us a second character of 3. Our next step is to determine the root operation of the procedure. Things can get a little tricky here because some of the root operations have very similar definitions. In this case, you will find six different root operations that you might consider:
  • Drainage, taking or letting out fluids and/or gases from a body part
  • Excision, cutting out or off a portion of a body part using a sharp instrument
  • Extirpation, taking or cutting out solid matter from a body part
  • Extraction, pulling or stripping out or off all or a portion of a body part by the use of force
  • Fragmentation, breaking solid matter in a body part into pieces
  • Resection, cutting out or off, without replacement, all of a body part
When determining the root operation, you need to know the intent of the procedure and what the physician is actually doing. We can eliminate a couple of the potential root operations fairly quickly if we know what a carotid endarterectomy actually is. During a carotid endarterectomy, the surgeon removes plaque or other material that has built up on the lining of the artery wall. It is carried out by separating the plaque from the arterial wall. So Dr. Ted is not cutting out or off all of a body part, so we can eliminate resection. He is also not taking or letting out fluids or gases, he’s removing plaque. So cross off drainage. He will not be removing a body part, the plaque is a foreign substance, so that eliminates excision. And since Dr. Ted is not removing a portion of a body part, we know we won’t be coding an extraction. That leaves us with two choices:
  • Extirpation
  • Fragmentation
Dr. Ted will be removing the plaque, not simply breaking it up. So for this case, our root operation is Extirpation, making our third character C. So far, we have 03C as the beginning of our code. That will help us find the correct table in the ICD-10-PCS manual to fill in the remaining four characters. When we go to the table for 03C, we find 29 choices for a body part. That doesn’t mean 29 different arteries though. Almost all of choices include laterality, so for the vertebral artery, we have two choices (right or left) with their own body part character. We know Dr. Ted is operating on Penny’s right carotid artery, so we should be able to quickly find the body part. Not so fast. It turns out ICD-10-PCS includes body part characters for three different right carotid arteries:
  • H, common carotid artery, right
  • K, internal carotid artery, right
  • M, external carotid artery, right
Here’s where we really need Dr. Ted to document well. If he doesn’t state which artery he operated on, we’ll need to query. Let’s check his documentation first and see if the information is there. Keep in mind that for ICD-9-CM procedure coding, you don’t need this level of specificity, so your physicians may not be documenting it. (I would hope they are just from a medical record/patient care perspective.) If physicians are not currently documenting this level of detail, start working with them to include it now so when we get to ICD-10-PCS, they’ll be in the habit of including the details you need to code. Dr. Ted is apparently well trained (or we’ve just queried him to death about this already) because he documented the right common carotid. Our fourth character therefore is H. The fifth character represents the approach. In the table for 03C, we only have three possible choices for a fifth character:

0 Open

3 Percutaneous

4 Percutaneous endoscopic

 Dr. Ted documented an open approach, so we would use 0 as our fifth character. That leaves characters six and seven, which will be a breeze for this procedure. Character six presents a device character and character seven is used for qualifiers. The table lists only on possibility character for both: Z. So we would report Z as character six and seven, making our final code:
  • 03CH0ZZ, extirpation of matter from right common carotid artery, open approach
Dr. Ted reports the operation is a success and Penny is expected to make a full recovery. Now if only we could get the encoder back up and running!
End of summer injuries at Fix ‘Em Up Clinic

Labor Day might mark the unofficial end of summer, but we have plenty of summer-related injuries today at the Fix ‘Em Up Clinic. Our first guest of the day, James, went rock climbing for the first (and he vows the last) time over the weekend. Instead of reaching the summit and enjoying a spectacular view, James lost his grip and ended up looking up at the summit from his back. Fortunately, James did not suffer any life-threatening injuries.  Dr. Hoffa documented the following:

Patient James seen for initial encounter of wrist and hand fractures suffered during fall while rock climbing at state park. James also suffered abrasions to left forearm, wrist, and hand. No head trauma or internal injuries noted.

Off to our trusty ICD-10-CM coding manual to begin coding James’ case. Almost immediately, we realize we have a problem. Well, it’s really a lack of information. Dr. Hoffa documented hand and wrist fractures. When we look up a wrist fracture, we are directed to S62 (fracture at wrist and hand level) and four pages of possible codes. Yikes. Before we send Dr. Hoffa a query, let’s make sure we know everything we don’t know so he can fill in the blanks all at once.
  • Is the fracture displaced or non-displaced?
  • Which specific bone is broken?
  • Is the fracture open or closed?
  • Which wrist is involved—left or right?
A note under S62 tells us to code a fracture as displaced if it is not specified. Further we are instructed to code the fracture as closed if that information is not provided. Since we need other information from Dr. Hoffa, we’ll clear those two points up as well. Dr. Hoffa sends back the following response:
  • Patient suffered closed, displaced fractures of navicular , pisiform, and cuneiform bones of right wrist.
Great. Now we should be all set. Or not. Turns out ICD-10-CM includes three sets of codes for fractures of the navicular:
  • Distal pole
  • Middle third
  • Proximal third
Looks like we’ll have to ask Dr. Hoffa for more info. When we receive his response to our follow up query, we learn that James fractured both the middle and proximal third of the navicular. Because we know this is an initial visit, we can code the wrist fractures as follows:
  • S62.021A, displaced fracture of middle third of navicular [scaphoid] bone of right wrist, initial visit
  • S62.031A, displaced fracture of proximal third of navicular [scaphoid] bone of right wrist, initial visit
  • S62.111A, displaced fracture of triquetrum [cuneiform] bone, right wrist
  • S62.161A, displaced fracture of pisiform, right wrist, initial visit
That takes care of James’ multiple wrist fractures. On to the hand fractures. In the Alphabetic Index, under traumatic fracture, hand, we find these possibilities:
  • carpal —see Fracture, carpal bone
  • finger (except thumb) —see Fracture, finger
  • metacarpal —see Fracture, metacarpal
  • navicular (scaphoid) (hand) —see Fracture, carpal bone, navicular
  • thumb —see Fracture, thumb
Oh, Dr. Hoffa, we need more information! Dr. Hoffa responds that James suffered displaced fractures of the second, third, and fourth metacarpal bones, but did not fracture any fingers. Okay, but we still need to know which part of the bones he fractured (yes, ICD-10-CM is that specific):
  • Base
  • Shaft
  • Neck
Turns out all of the fractures were to the base of the metacarpals. That leads us to:
  • S62.310A, displaced fracture of base of second metacarpal bone, right hand, initial visit
  • S62.312A, displaced fracture of base of third metacarpal bone, right hand, initial visit
  • S62.314A, displaced fracture of base of fourth metacarpal bone, right hand, initial visit
Now on to the abrasions. Dr. Hoffa only documented abrasions to the hand, but we should probably query to make sure none of the fingers are involved, because they have their own codes. And we find out no fingers involved, just the left hand. So we would code:
  • S60.512A, abrasion of left hand, initial visit
  • S50.812A, abrasion of left forearm, initial visit
  • S60.812A, abrasion of left wrist, initial visit
We can also add some external cause codes as well, if our payer wants them. (Think E codes in ICD-9-CM). For James, we know what he was doing (rock climbing), where (state park), and what happened (fall ). Our codes would be:
  • W15.XXXA, fall from cliff, initial encounter
  • Y92.830, public park as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y93.31, activity, mountain climbing, rock climbing and wall climbing
Choosing a code for the fall is a little problematic because we have a lot of choices for a fall. We know it was accidental. We know he fell from a height to the ground. Since he was rock climbing, I would call that a cliff. You could argue for using the unspecified code (W19.XXXA, unspecified fall , initial encounter). But that’s generally used only if you don’t have specific information. You could also make an argument for W17.89XA (other fall from one level to another, initial encounter) because he fell from a height. Even though we haven’t firmly resolved that question, we’re going to move on to our next patient, Karin. Karin went mountain biking over the weekend in a forest and encountered an unhappy black racer snake. Fortunately for Karin, black racers are non-venomous snakes. She ended up with a nasty puncture wound on her left leg. Karin knows how to treat a snake bite so the wound did not become infected, but she wanted to have someone take a look just to be sure. This is Karin’s first visit to Fix ‘Em Up. When we look up bite, reptile, nonvenomous, the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index directs us to see bite, by site. So we’re coding for the location of the injury, not the animal that bit Karin. That leads us to:
  • S81.852A, open bite, left lower leg, initial visit
To add further details to Karin’s record, we could also code:
  • W59.11, bitten by nonvenomous snake
  • Y92.821, forest as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y93.55, activity, bike riding
That’s all for today’s wounded at Fix ‘Em Up Clinic. Hopefully, fall will be a slower season, but I’m not counting on it!
ICD-10-PCS: Are you in the correct row?

If you have looked at the ICD-10-PCS Manual, you know that the codes are arranged in tables based on the first three characters of the code. The table contains all of the possible choices for characters four through seven for that particular three-character starting point. For instance, the surgeon is performing an insertion into the subcutaneous tissue of fascia. Your first three characters would be:
  • 0 for Medical and Surgical section
  • J (subcutaneous tissue and fascia) for the body system
  • H for the root operation Insertion
The table then gives you the following choices for a body part:
  • S, subcutaneous tissue and fascia, head and neck
  • T, subcutaneous tissue and fascia, trunk
  • V, subcutaneous tissue and fascia, upper extremity
  • W, subcutaneous tissue and fascia, lower extremity
However, T is off in its own row even though all four body parts have the same options for approach and qualifier. Fourth character T, however, has one additional device that is not an option for the other three body parts. You need to pay attention to those distinctions because ICD-10-PCS guidelines state: valid codes include all combinations of choices in characters 4 through 7 contained in the same row of the table. So even though all four body parts are in one table, they are in separate rows. As a result, 0JHT0VZ (insertion of infusion pump into trunk subcutaneous tissue and fascia, open approach) is a valid code, 0JHS0VZ is not.
Know the body part guidelines for ICD-10-PCS

By now, you probably know that ICD-10-PCS codes contain seven alpha-numeric characters. Each character represents a specific piece of information and those meanings can vary by section.
In the Medical and Surgical section of ICD-10-PCS, the fourth character represents the body part. That sounds pretty simple and straightforward, right? You pick the body part that represents the site of the procedure.
It is—and it isn’t—that simple. Some of the body parts are very specific, such as right cephalic vein. Others are more general, such as subcutaneous tissue and fascia, abdomen.
Here are some things to keep in mind when choosing the fourth character for your ICD-10-PCS code:
If the provider performs a procedure on a portion of a body part that does not have a separate body part value, code the body part value corresponding to the whole body part. For example, when the provider performs a procedure on the alveolar process of the mandible, you would use the mandible body part.
Where a specific branch of a body part does not have its own body part value, use the closest proximal branch that has a specific body part value. For example, the surgeon destroys part of the trifacial nerve. ICD-10-PCS does not include a specific fourth character for that nerve, so you would code it to the trigeminal nerve.
Some body parts have a fourth character for procedures performed bilaterally. If the provider performs the exact same procedure on both body parts, for example the fallopian tubes, assign the fourth character for fallopian tubes bilateral. If the body part does not have a bilateral choice, code each procedure separately. For example, a patient undergoes bilateral knee replacement. You would report two procedure codes—one with the fourth character for the right knee, the other with the fourth character for the left knee.
Not sure what ICD-10-PCS includes in a body part? No problem. ICD-10-PCS includes a body part key to help.
If you look up zygomatic process of frontal bone, the key directs you to code the procedure to either frontal bone, right, or frontal bone, left.

Today we are taking a peek into OR 3 at the Stitch ‘Em Up Hospital to watch Dr. Cap I. Larry work on some blood vessels. Then we’re going to code her procedure. Dr. Larry is harvesting part of the patient’s saphenous vein to use as a graft in heart bypass surgery. In ICD-9-CM, we can’t code the vein harvest as a separate procedure. It is included in the bypass procedure. However, in ICD-10-PCS, we can code both procedures according to guideline B3.9: “If an autograft is obtained from a different body part in order to complete the objective of the procedure, a separate procedure is coded.” So we know we are in the Medical and Surgical section of ICD-10-PCS, which gives us a first character of 0. We know we are dealing with a lower vein (the saphenous vein is located in the leg), which gives us a second character 6. Now we need to determine what root operation Dr. Larry is performing. She is cutting out a portion of the vein, which leads us to root operation, Extraction. That makes our third character B. Our code so far then is 06B. On to the table for 06B. In order to select the correct fourth character, we need to know which specific vein (greater or less saphenous) and which side (left or right). Dr. Larry documented greater saphenous of the left leg, which gives us a fourth character of Q. We also need to know which approached Dr. Larry used to harvest the vein:
  • Open
  • Percutaneous
  • Percutanous endoscopic
All three are possible choices for the fifth character. In this case, Dr. Larry documented a percutanous endoscopic approach. So our fifth character is 4. The table provides only one option for character 6 (the device), so we know our sixth character is Z. That leaves the seventh character. The table gives us two options:
  • Diagnostic
  • No qualifier
We know the procedure is not diagnostic. Dr. Larry is harvesting a vein, so we’ll use a seventh character Z, no qualifier. That makes our code: 06BQ4ZZ. Now, where did that vein go?

Ever have one of those nights when you just can’t sleep? Maybe you’re awake fretting about the transition to ICD-10. Or maybe you had one too many cups of coffee. Never fear, we have plenty of ICD-10-CM insomnia codes for you. In fact, the insomnia codes take up almost a full column in the Alphabetic Index. The American Academy of Sleep Medicine actually lists 11 types of insomnia. Well, now we know why ICD-10-CM includes so many insomnia codes. In order to code our insomnia, we need to know the cause. Is it stress-related insomnia? If so, we would code F51.02, adjustment insomnia. This type of insomnia usually comes and goes, and is related to stress. It’s also known as acute insomnia or short-term insomnia. So if you’re worried about your child’s first sleepover or freaked out about work, you probably have adjustment insomnia. Note that only a doctor can properly diagnose our insomnia issues, but it’s fun to speculate. Let’s see what else could be keeping us up all night. Perhaps we should have skipped that 2 a.m. coffee run to Starbucks and the venti espresso macchiato. That leads us to insomnia due to caffeine, but are we suffering from caffeine abuse, dependence, or use? Hmm, Starbucks isn’t a regular stop, so we’ll say caffeine use, and our code would be:
  • F15.982, other stimulant use, unspecified with stimulant-induced sleep disorder
Category F15 (other stimulant related disorders) includes amphetamine-related disorders and caffeine, so too much coffee or soda lands here. Note that use, abuse, and dependence have different codes, so the physician will need to document not only the substance (in our case caffeine), but also differentiate between use, abuse, and dependence. The same holds true for other stimulants, such as amphetamines, cocaine, opioids, and stimulants. Perhaps we really suffer from an anxiety disorder. That’s a depressing thought, but it could be why we’re wide awake in the middle of the night. That takes us to:
  • F51.05, insomnia due to other mental disorder
We also need to code the specific mental disorder causing the insomnia, so if we suffered from generalized anxiety disorder, we would also code:
  • F41.1, generalized anxiety disorder
Maybe our wakefulness is because we just got back from a trip to Ireland and we’re still on Irish time. In that case, we may actually be suffering from circadian rhythm disorder and our code would be:
  • G47.25, circadian rhythm sleep disorder, jet lag type
Oh, wait, that trip was just a dream. Guess we have to go back to the more mundane explanations. Better yet, let’s put in the DVD of Tree of Life and see if we can get some sleep instead.

Athenian philosopher Socrates famously drank poisonoud hemlock after being found guilty of corrupting the minds of the youth of Athens and of impiety for not believing in the gods of the state. According to Xenophon, Socrates claimed in his trial defense that he would be glad to circumvent the rigors of old age by being sentenced to death. Unfortunately for Hippocrates and the ancient Athenian coders, ICD-1 wasn’t even around when Socrates gulped his hemlock cocktail, so they couldn’t code his untimely death due to poisoning. Let’s do it for them with ICD-10-CM. ICD-10-CM’s Table of Drugs includes four categories of poisoning:
  • Accidental
  • Intentional self-harm
  • Assault
  • Undetermined
In Socrates’ case, he voluntarily drank the hemlock. When we check the Table of Drugs, we find T62.2X2 for hemlock poisoning, intentional self-harm. Being the experienced coders we are, we check the Alphabetic Index and learn we need a seventh character for our poisoning code. Since Socrates died (and thus couldn’t have a follow up), we’ll report an initial encounter. That give us:
  • T62.2X2A, toxic effect of other ingested (parts of) plant(s), intentional self-harm, initial encounter
What if the poisoning was accidental, as in the case of composer Johann Schobert. Schobert died after consuming poisonous mushrooms he believed were edible. The Table of Drugs directs us to T62.0X1A for noxious mushrooms, which is almost the same code we reported for Socrates. (Note that both are initial visits since both died.) The difference is the sixth character:
  • 1 for accidental poisoning (Schobert)
  • 2 for intentional self-harm (Socrates)
Grigori Rasputin, the Mad Monk of Russia, was poisoned by cyanide by a group of Russian nobles who objected to Rasputin’s influence over Czar Nicholas II and his wife Alexandra. The Table of Drugs includes several possibilities for cyanide poisoning, depending on how the cyanide is ingested:
  • Cyanide(s) (compounds) (potassium)(sodium) NEC
  • dust or gas (inhalation) NEC
  • fumigant
  • hydrogen
  • mercuric—see Mercury
  • pesticide(dust) (fumes)
The conspirators mixed potassium cyanide with wine and in tea cakes so we know what kind of cyanide. We also know Rasputin was the victim of an assault. He eventually died after being beaten and thrown in a river, so we’ll assume this is again an initial visit. That gives us:
  • T65.0X3A, toxic effect of cyanides, assault, initial encounter
The abbreviation NEC (not elsewhere classified) will look familiar. We have the same thing in ICD-9-CM. NEC means we have the specific information but don’t have a more specific code available. You’ll see NEC pop up periodically on the Table of Drugs. So be sure to check what’s in your cup so you don’t end up like Artaxerxes (III and IV).
Working on blood vessels in ICD-10-PCS

Dr. Cap I. Larry is back at work on some blood vessels at Stitch ‘Em Up Hospital. Let’s see what she’s up to today. For all of Dr. Larry’s procedures, we’re going to be coding from the Medical and Surgical section, so our first character will always be 0. Our second character will represent which blood vessels she’s working on:

2, Heart and great vessels

3, Upper arteries

4, Lower arteries

5, Upper veins

6, Lower veins

Not sure where that blood vessel lives? Check Appendix C, the Body Part Key in the ICD-10-PCS Manual. The procedure Dr. Larry performs will determine our third character, so let’s see what she’s documented in today’s first record. Dr. Larry placed two drug-eluting stents in a patient’s left anterior descending coronary artery. So we know we are coding a procedure on the coronary artery, which means our second character is 2. For coronary artery procedures, the ICD-10-PCS guidelines state: The coronary arteries are classified as a single body part that is further specified by number of sites treated and not by name or number of arteries. Separate body part values are used to specify the number of sites treated when the same procedure is performed on multiple sites in the coronary arteries. What is our root operation? We have two possibilities:
  • Dilation
  • Insertion
What is the intent of the procedure—to open up the vessels or to place a nonbiological appliance to assist in the physiological function. Dr. Larry documents the procedure is done to open narrowing of the artery, which makes our root operation Dilation (third character 7). Since we now have the first three characters (027) we know which table to use. The table includes choices for 1-4 sites in the coronary artery. Dr. Larry placed two stents, so we would use fourth character 2 (coronary artery, two sites). It doesn’t matter which coronary artery is involved per the guidelines. The fourth character is determined by the number of sites treated. Dr. Larry documented a percutaneous approach, so our fifth character is 3. And we know she used a drug eluting stent, so our sixth character is 4. Dr. Larry did not document any bifurcation, so our seventh character is Z. Put together, our code is:
  • 027134Z, dilation of coronary artery, two sites with drug-eluting intraluminal device, percutaneous approach
Dr. Larry’s second procedure involves draining excess fluid from a patient’s colic artery. The colic artery is a lower artery and we know we are coding a drainage. That leads us to the table for 049. In order to select the appropriate fourth character, we need to know which colic artery is involved:
  • 6, Right
  • 7, Left
  • 8, Middle
Dr. Larry’s procedure notes specify right colic artery. She also documented use of a drainage device and a percutaneous approach. So our code is: 049630Z, drainage of right colic artery with drainage device, percutaneous approach Our final patient of the day suffers from some really nasty spider veins, so Dr. Larry is performing microincisional phlebectomy. So what root operation is microincisional phlebectomy? Here’s where it helps to have clinical knowledge or good rapport with your clinical staff. Since we’re on good terms with Dr. Larry, we asked her to explain the procedure in layman’s terms. Phlebectomy involves making small incisions or needle punctures to extract the problematic veins with a phlebectomy hook. A hook is inserted into a microncision in the leg. A section of the vein is hooked and then removed through the incision. And that translates to which root operation? Maybe extirpation? Wait, that involves taking solid matter out of a body part. Scratch that. Maybe it’s excision. We are removing a portion of a body part, sort of. Wait, what about extraction? I think we’re on to something here. Extraction is defined as pulling or stripping out or off all or a portion of a body part by the use of force. Well, pulling a vein out with a hook certainly sounds like force to me. (It also sounds really painful.) Extraction it is. For extraction of lower leg veins, we don’t need to know the specific vessels involved, we just need the approach. Dr. Larry’s procedure notes supply that information percutaneous, which gives us:
  • 06DY3ZZ, Microincisional phlebectomy of spider veins, lower leg
And on that really painful note, we’re wrapping up for the day.
ICD-10 coding for that pesky plague

What do you know, bubonic plague is still hanging around. It seems like we should have eradicated it by now. Turns out, if you go to the desert southwest and play with dead animals you too can contract plague. And you can contract more than just bubonic plague. ICD-10-CM includes 13 conditions under plague (but only seven codes—some are doing double duty). Fortunately, none are end-of-the-world apocalyptic plague. So what do you need to know in order to code for plague? Really the only thing you need is the type of plague (and that means the provider must document it):
  • A20.0, bubonic plague
  • A20.1, cellulocutaneous plague
  • A20.2, pneumonic plague
  • A20.3, plague meningitis
  • A20.7, septicemic plague
  • A20.8, other forms of plague
  • A20.9, plague, unspecified
Other forms of plague include:
  • Abortive plague
  • Asymptomatic plague
  • Pestis minor
Category A20 (plague) also contains the following Includes note:
  • Includes: infection due to Yersinia pestis
Interestingly enough, a group of scientists recently decoded the genome for Yersinia pestis from medieval victims of the Black Death. How cool is that? Now if they could just clone a dinosaur.
Are you ready for some football injuries in ICD-10-CM?

Football season is underway in Anytown and we have some crazy players coming in to Fix ‘Em Up Clinic with some crazy-looking knee injuries. Quarterback Tom is in after suffering an unhappy triad of injuries:
  • Anterior cruciate ligament sprain
  • Medial collateral ligament sprain
  • Medial meniscus tear
Tom apparently wasn’t fast enough to get away from the defensive lineman who accidentally hit Tom’s knee with his helmet. What do we need to know in order to code Tom’s triad of trouble? We know ICD-10-CM is big on laterality, so we’ll need to know which knee Tom injured. What else? We already know which specific ligaments Tom injured—anterior cruiciate and medical collateral. For the torn medial meniscus, we need to know which type of tear Tom sustained:
  • Bucket-handle tear
  • Peripheral tear
  • Complex tear
  • Other tear
Other tear does not mean unspecified tear. It means that we don’t have a code for the specific type of tear Dr. Lombardi documented. ICD-10-CM does offer a code for unspecified tear, but we want to avoid those codes as much as possible. For all of these injuries, we also need to know the encounter so we can add the correct seventh character. When we read Dr. Lombardi’s documentation, we learn the following:
  • Tom is being seen for an initial visit for all three injuries
  • Injuries sustained to right knee
  • Complex tear of medial meniscus
  • Injuries suffered during a football game
  • Game played at high school field
With that information, we would report these codes:
  • S83.511A, sprain of anterior cruciate ligament of right knee, initial visit
  • S83.411A, sprain of medial collateral ligament of right knee, initial visit
  • S83.231A, complex tear of medial meniscus, current injury, right knee, initial visit
  • W21.81XA, striking against or struck by football helmet, initial visit
  • Y92.321, football field as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y93.61, activity, American tackle football
So much for Tom’s injuries and his season. Cornerback Deion suffered a pretty strange injury—a cleat puncture wound to the knee. Apparently one of the other team’s players lost a cleat and was left with the screw sticking out of his shoe. As Deion wrapped up the wide receiver, the other player accidentally stepped on Deion (he was losing his balance so we can’t blame him for putting his foot down). Sadly for Deion, that foot came down on his knee and the exposed screw found a place without padding. Result: puncture wound of the knee. Dr. Lombardi notes that no foreign body remained in the left knee. No blood vessels or other structures of the knee were injured and this is Deion’s first visit. We would code:
  • S81.032A, puncture wound without foreign body, left knee, initial visit
  • Y92.321, football field as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y93.61, activity, American tackle football
Steve, Anytown’s punter, didn’t make it out of the game unscathed either. One of the opposing team’s players tried to block Steve’s punt, missed the ball, and took out Steve’s knee and his kneecap. Dr. Lombardi documents the following:
  • Traumatic lateral patella dislocation
  • Initial visit
  • Right knee
  • No other ligament damage
  • Significant contusion to right thigh
That gives us the following codes:
  • S83.014A, lateral dislocation of right patella, initial visit
  • S70.11XA, contusion of right thigh, initial visit
  • Y92.321, football field as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y93.61, activity, American tackle football
We don’t know if the blocker’s helmet caused the injury, so we would not add W21.81XA. Is there a kicker not in the clinic?
Coding for undetermined and borderline diagnoses

Wouldn’t it be nice if the physician documented a definitive diagnosis for every patient at the time the patient left the office, clinic, or hospital? We know that will never happen. Sometimes, the physician just doesn’t know and instead of documenting a definitive diagnosis,  the physician instead uses words like:
  • Probable
  • Possible
  • Rule out
  • Suspected
Great, so what are we supposed to do with those? The answer depends largely on what type of records you code. According to the ICD-10-CM Official Guidelines for Coding and Reporting, outpatient  coders should not report codes for diagnoses that is not confirmed. Instead outpatient coders report the condition(s) to the highest degree of certainty for that encounter/visit, such as symptoms, signs, abnormal test results, or other reason for the visit. Inpatient coders, on the other hand, can code an uncertain as if it existed or was established. The bases for these guidelines are the diagnostic workup, arrangements for further workup or observation, and initial therapeutic approach that correspond most closely with the established diagnosis. That’s what we do now under ICD-9-CM, so we all know how this works. What happens though with a borderline diagnosis? The 2013 ICD-10-CM Official Guidelines for Coding and Reporting include a section devoted to reporting a borderline diagnosis. According to the guidelines:

If the provider documents a "borderline" diagnosis at the time of discharge, the diagnosis is coded as confirmed, unless the classification provides a specific entry (e.g., borderline diabetes). If a borderline condition has a specific index entry in ICD-10-CM, it should be coded as such. Since borderline conditions are not uncertain diagnoses, no distinction is made between the care setting (inpatient versus outpatient). Whenever the documentation is unclear regarding a borderline condition, coders are encouraged to query for clarification.

How nice. We all get to code it same way. That makes life simpler. So does having a written guideline. Now if we could just get them to clear up sepsis.
Reboot for ICD-10—Training and Operational Readiness Checklist for 2013

The transition to ICD-10 code set is expected to be one of the most substantial changes in medical coding history and providers and payers need to start preparing now. Undoubtedly, you still have plenty of questions to answer, including:
  • What education and training does your staff need?
  • How far along is your organization’s transition and where should you be?
  • How can you tell if your payers will be ready on time?
  • What pitfalls are you likely to encounter?
Two experienced ICD-10 specialists—Gloryanne Bryant, RHIA, RHIT, CCS, CDIP, CCDS, AHIMA-Approved ICD-10-CM/PCS Trainer, and Steven C. Benjamin PMP, Program Director for UnitedHealth Group—will  share their ICD-10 implementation experience during Reboot for ICD-10—Training and Operational Readiness Checklist for 2013. This HealthLeaders Media  90-minute webcast  begins at 1 p.m. Eastern October 22. You’ll not only get to hear Gloryanne and Steve’s ideas, you’ll also get to ask questions. So come prepared to pick their brains! Learn how to assess your organization's existing structure to easily determine the steps for transition. Our speakers will give you the knowledge to move forward with timely compliance and prioritize initiatives.
Time for healthcare organizations to work together

Hospitals and physician practices are used to being in competition with each other and maintaing a veil of secrecy over internal operations. Well, that’s not really limited to just healthcare, it happens with just about every type of business. With the looming implementation of ICD-10, it’s time to put down your sword and make sure you are as collaborative as possible, says Thea Campbell, MBA, RHIA, who leads health information at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. “It’s great if you are ready, but if the little hospital down the street isn’t ready, that’s a big problem,” Campbell told attendees at the AHIMA National Convention in Chicago.
Coding Clinic transitioning to ICD-10 Q&A

Got an ICD-10 question? Answers are coming soon. ICD-10 implementation is still almost two years away, but the American Hospital Association’s Coding Clinic will add an ICD-10 section starting in the fourth quarter of 2012. AHA is currently including an ICD-10 insert, but published the final insert in the third quarter Coding Clinic, RHIA, is the Director of Coding and Classification at the American Hospital Association told attendees at the AHIMA clinical community meeting September 29 in Chicago. “When we finally implement ICD-10, we will have an existing body of knowledge,” Leon-Chisen said. AHA will continue to include ICD-9 questions until the transition October 1, 2014, but will not translate the ICD-9 coding advice to ICD-10. A translation wouldn’t be appropriate because of the differences in the coding systems, Leon-Chisen said. In addition ICD-9 questions don’t always include information needed to assign ICD-10 codes. AHA is already receiving some interesting ICD-10 questions, so some coders are already using the new system, Leon-Chisen said. AHA is currently accepting ICD-10 questions, so if you need more information, send them a query.
Practice makes ICD-10 easier (but not perfect)

How tired are you of hearing the phrase “documentation, documentation, documentation” as you prepare for ICD-10? I have a new phrase that you’ll soon dread as well: “Practice, practice, practice.” Coders not only need to learn the new coding systems, they also need to practice using them before October 1, 2014, says Gloryanne Bryant, RHIA, RHIT, CCS, CCDS. “This is going to be interesting because it is going to take people away from the work they are doing now,” Bryant says. You’ll need to determine how much time you’re going to tell coders devote to practicing ICD-10 and also decide how you’re going to begin coding records in ICD-10. Are you going to have coders code in both systems concurrently? Will you have coders code in ICD-9 first, then go back and recode in ICD-10? Practicing will make coders better at ICD-10. After all, we’re still practicing in ICD-9 and APCs, Bryant says. Also think about how you’ll provide feedback to coders to let them know what they are getting right and what they need to improve. Don’t plan to get rid of your test environment after October 1, 2014, Bryant says. You’ll still be practicing after go-live.
Don't take after Chicken Little during ICD-10 transition

News flash: The sky is NOT falling. You don’t need to press the panic button when you think about the transition to ICD-10. It’s time to prepare, practice, and plan. The transition will be a huge endeavor, but we need to remember why we’re doing it, Gloryanne Bryant, BS, RHIA, RHIT, CCS, CDIP, CCDS, an HIM professional and leader for more than 30 years. “The reasons we’re moving to ICD-10 are getting lost. We’re doing this for the right reasons.” Those reasons include:
  • Better data collection
  • More accurate clinical picture of the patient’s health
