So now when the physicians say, “My patients are in the hospital longer because they’re sicker,” they can prove it. Don’t focus on the negatives, Bryant advises. Instead stress the positives, especially when you are working to educate staff members. When CMS first announced plans to move to ICD-10, many people looked at the increase in the number of codes and started planning their retirement parties for September 30, 2013. But it’s really not that bad. ICD-10 requires more specificity and that alone accounts for a larger percentage of the additional codes. For example, for a patient suffering from impacted cerumen (wax in the ear), you would report ICD-9 code 380.4. ICD-10-CM offers four codes:
  • H61.20, impacted cerumen, unspecified ear
  • H61.21, impacted cerumen, right ear
  • H61.22, impacted cerumen, left ear
  • H61.23, impacted cerumen, bilateral
The only difference is ICD-10-CM specifies which ear in involved. Chances are the providers are already documenting that information, we’re just not looking for it because right now, we don’t need to know. Other diseases will be more challenging because they involve more change. By now, you’ve probably heard about the major changes to coding diabetes. Those changes will require you to modify any templates or forms you have for each specialty or department that might see a diabetic patient. Sounds like a lot of work, doesn’t it? Yes and no. You’ll need to spend time comparing the information you’ll need to what you have and determine how to modify the forms. But once you do that for one department, say primary care, you can tweak the changes to make them applicable in other departments, says Thea Campbell, MBA, RHIA, who oversees HIM at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. You don’t need to reinvent the wheel every time and you don’t need to solve the same problem over and over. Fix it once, then adjust the changes. So keep calm, carry on with your transition plans, and don’t worry about something falling on your head.

We all know coder productivity will go down after the transition to ICD-10 and it may never rebound to current levels. The question is, how much will productivity decline? It could drop more than you expect if preliminary results of a pilot study presented during the AHIMA National Convention are any indication. Right now, inpatient coders complete an average of 24 charts each day, according to Susan Fenton, PhD, RHIA, assistant professor of health information management at Texas State University in San Marco. Fenton joined forces with UASI, an HIM consulting firm, and the University of Cincinnati Health, University Hospital to conduct a small study into coder productivity in ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-PCS. The study involved only six coders, so it is not a comprehensive study, Fenton said. Rather than have coders code the same records in ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-PCS, Fenton’s team selected 54 records, then divided the records in half. Coders coded 27 records in ICD-9-CM and 27 different records in ICD-10-PCS. The group selected cases that were as close as possible in complexity and type. Coders need an average of 25.51 minutes to code an inpatient record in ICD-9-CM, Fenton said. In ICD-10-PCS, that time jumps to 43.23 minutes, a 69% increase. That number came as a surprise to Fenton and Mary Stanfill, MBI, RHIA, CCS-P, CCS, FAHIMA, vice president of HIM consulting services for UASI. The study team found a huge range in the coders’ productivity. The six coders included took anywhere from an additional 10.6 minutes (31.6%) to 27.78 minutes (89.8%) on average. Because the team is still analyzing the results, they have not yet looked at the accuracy of the code assignment or analyzed how experience and education affect productivity. The study did highlight the importance of training. The difference between the well trained coders and the not-well-trained coders was significant, Stanfill said. “That tells me that training is worth it.”

The rugby players who come into the Fix ‘Em Up Clinic are a pretty tough group. They can shrug  off broken ribs, downplay dislocations, and boast about bruises. They are no match for gnats, though. Tina brought Tony into the clinic after he complained of fever and pain in his left thigh. He also had a red, inflamed area on his left thigh that had been growing. Dr. Grubber documents that Tony was bitten by an insect on the thigh while playing rugby last week. Apparently Tony was in no hurry to come into the clinic, even though the rash around the bite kept growing. After running some blood tests, Dr. Grubber diagnoses Tony with cellulitis. Fortunately for Tony, he’s not septic or suffering from any other illnesses, although he has plenty of past injuries documented in his chart. For this visit, however, we’re just coding for cellulitis. When we look up cellulitis in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index, we find plenty of choices. ICD-10-CM classifies cellulitis by the affected site. So for Tony, that’s left thigh. Scanning down the list of sites, we come to “thigh” which directs us to cellulitis, lower limb. Cellulitis lower limb lists L03.11-. That little dash on the end of the code tells us the code requires additional characters. Off to the Tabular Index, where we find: L03.11, Cellulitis of other parts of limb. Well we know lower left limb, which gives us ICD-10-CM code:
  • L03.116, cellulitis of left lower limb
Hank, another member of the rugby squad, also came in for an insect-related illness. Instead of being a snack for a gnat, Hank spent time entertaining some ticks. He presents with a circular, outwardly expanding rash on his right arm. Dr. Grubber diagnoses Lyme disease with no complications, and we’re off to the Alphabetic Index. We find only one code for Lyme disease: A69.20. The code doesn’t include a dash at the end, so it probably doesn’t need additional characters. Just to be safe (and because we never code from the Alphabetic Index), we’re off to check the listing in the Tabular Index. Under A69.2 (Lyme disease), we find the following choices:
  • A69.20, Lyme disease, unspecified
  • A69.21, meningitis due to Lyme disease
  • A69.22, other neurologic disorders in Lyme disease
  • A69.23, arthritis due to Lyme disease
  • A69.29, other conditions associated with Lyme disease
Dr. Grubber didn’t document any other conditions associated with Hank’s Lyme disease, so we’re stuck with A69.20, even though it is an unspecified code. Hank wasn’t the only rugby player to fall afoul of the ticks. After the team’s trip to Colorado, Jeff started feeling not so good. He ignored his fever, nausea, and lack of appetite, but the petechial rash and abdominal pain sent him running (okay, lurching) for the clinic. Dr. Grubber documents spotted fever. If we look up spotted fever in the Alphabetic Index, we are directed to Fever, spotted and a whole list of possibilities, depending on the cause of the spotted fever.
  • A77.0, spotted fever due to Rickettsia rickettsii
  • A77.1, spotted fever due to Rickettsia conorii
  • A77.2, spotted fever due to Rickettsia siberica
  • A77.3, spotted fever due to Rickettsia australis
  • A77.4, ehrlichiosis
  • A77.8, other spotted fevers
  • A77.9, spotted fever, unspecified
When we read the rest of Dr. Grubber’s note, we find that he specified Rocky Mountain spotted fever, which falls under:
  • A77.0, spotted fever due to Rickettsia rickettsii

Rocky Mountain spotted fever

Sao Paulo fever

 Fortunately, Dr. Grubber is predicting a complete recovery for all three patients, but warned them to be wary of insects in the future. That sounds like some good advice. Does anyone have any bug repellent?
Coding turf monster attacks in ICD-10-CM

Legendary Green Bay Packers coach Vince Lombardi once described the ideal linebacker as agile, hostile, and mobile. Sadly, some of our local linebackers are significantly less agile and somewhat immobile after their weekend quest for gridiron glory went awry. First into the Fix ‘Em Up Clinic this Monday is Jack, who claims to be the victim of the Turf Monster. It seems Jack tried to tackle a running back, but his foot got stuck in the artificial turf. He is complaining of pain, swelling, and limited joint movement at the base of one big toe. Dr. Rooney diagnoses Jack with turf toe of the right big toe, a condition that unfortunately does not appear in the ICD-10-CM index.  So we need to read through Dr. Rooney’s notes to see if she provided a more ICD-10-CM friendly diagnosis. In the body of Dr. Rooney’s note, we find the following documentation: “Hyperdorsiflexion injury of the first metatarsophalangeal, initial visit. Patient suffered injury while pushing off of foot to make a tackle on football field.” Excellent, that’s a diagnosis we can find in ICD-10-CM and in fact it leads us to:
  • S93.521A, sprain of metatarsophalangeal joint of right great toe, initial encounter
Like more ICD-10-CM injury codes, this one requires a seventh character to denote the encounter. Since Dr. Rooney documented initial visit, we add the seventh character A. When Jack comes in to see Dr. Rooney for follow-up (always assuming he is following doctor’s orders), we’ll use the same base code and just change the seventh character to D (subsequent visit) or S (sequela). Remember, though, that Dr. Rooney will need to document the exact injury again in any subsequent visits. We can’t take “follow up for turf toe” and come up with a code. We’ll need more detail in that visit note. If Jack comes back and sees a physician other than Dr. Rooney, we’re back to A for the seventh character. According to the ICD-10-CM Official Guidelines for Coding and Reporting, seventh character A is used while the patient is receiving active treatment for the condition. Examples of active treatment are:
  • Surgical treatment
  • ED encounter
  • Evaluation and treatment by a new physician
For Jack’s injury, we can also add external cause codes:
  • Y92.321A, football field as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y93.61, activity, American tackle football
The Turf Monster claimed a second victim with linebacker Chris, who planted his foot to make a cut in pursuit of the quarterback and felt something pop. Turns out that pop was his Achilles tendon rupturing. Dr. Rooney documents a complete traumatic rupture of the left Achilles tendon, initial visit. When we look up a traumatic rupture in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index, we are directed to see Strain. Note that under Rupture, ICD-10-CM does include numerous non-traumatic and traumatic injuries. A ruptured Achilles tendon is not among them, so we’re off to look under Strain. The listing under Strain is pretty small, just 12 entries. Unfortunately, none are for Achilles tendon. Instead, we are directed to see Injury, muscle, by site, strain. Under Injury, we finally find what we’re looking for: Achilles tendon strain (S86.01-). We also see another possibility, Other specified injury of Achilles tendon (S86.09). Dr. Rooney documented a complete rupture, not a strain. So which code do we report? Here’s where our knowledge and experience (and helpful clinical staff) come in handy. Tendon strains are divided into three grades:
  • Grade 1 (mild strain) involves a slight pull of the tendon and microscopic tendon tearing with no loss of strength or change in tendon length.
  • Grade 2 s is characterized by tearing of tendon fibers within the tendon or at the tendon bone junction. The tendon’s length increases and strength usually decreases.
  • Grade 3 is a complete rupture of the tendon.
That means Chris suffered a grade 3 Achilles tendon strain, which gives us:
  • S86.012A, strain of left Achilles tendon, initial encounter
And depending on our payer requirements and preferences, we could also add:
  • Y92.321A, football field as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y93.61, activity, American tackle football
The Turf Monster apparently had quite the appetite this weekend. Our final football victim, I mean visitor, Jamaal, came in with bruising, tenderness, and cramping in his right thigh. During the game, he jumped up to tip a pass and landed awkwardly. His foot planted with his knee partly flexed and didn’t move. Dr. Rooney examines Jamaal and diagnoses a partial tear of the right quadriceps muscle. She notes this is an initial visit. We already know that Tear directs us to Strain, which in turn directs us to Injury. So we’ll go straight to Injury this time and this code:
  • S76.111A, strain of right quadriceps muscle, fascia and tendon
  • Y92.321A, football field as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y93.61, activity, American tackle football
So our team’s injury report is looking kind of grim. Anyone want to suit up?

Outpatient coders currently report procedures using CPT codes. That won’t change after the switch to ICD-10. However, some facilities currently require outpatient coders to also report procedures using ICD-9-CM Volume 3 codes the same way inpatient coders currently report procedures. So will those outpatient coders have to learn to code in ICD-10-PCS the same way inpatient coders will? That will end up being an organization-by-organization decision. Can you budget for training outpatient coders on ICD-10-PCS? Can you find the time to train them? Is there any benefit of training them? The answer to that last question is yes, according to Donna Smith, RHIA, a senior consultant with 3M. “Don’t discount outpatient coders,” Smith says. After all, they understand CPT coding and coders who get CPT do better with ICD-10-PCS. Coders who use CPT codes are also a great resource, Smith says. They are used to looking for things that inpatient coders don’t have to look for now. Outpatient coders can help inpatient coders pull apart an operative report and break down the procedure. That in turn will help inpatient coders determine a root operation and build an ICD-10-PCS code.
CMS schedules National Provider Call on Preparing Physicians for ICD-10 Implementation

Getting physicians on board with the transition to ICD-10 won’t be easy, but CMS is trying to help. CMS will host a National Provider Call: Preparing Physicians for ICD-10 Implementation at 1:30 p.m. (Eastern) Thursday, October 25. During the call, Dr. Ginger Boyle will share her success and some practical advice about the SRHS transition to ICD-10. Boyle is a practicing family physician who has developed a coding education program for Spartanburg Regional Healthcare System (SRHS) and its family practice residency program. CMS subject matter experts will also present the latest information and updates from their areas, followed by a question and answer session. Agenda:
  • Transitioning to ICD-10: practical pointers for providers
  • Overview of ICD-10 implementation requirements
  • Plans for Local Coverage Determination (LCD) and National Coverage Determination (NCD) ICD-10 conversions
  • National implementation issues and plans
  • Question and answer session
Registration Information:  In order to receive call-in information, you must register for the call on the CMS Upcoming National Provider Calls registration website. Registration will close at 12pm on the day of the call or when available space has been filled; no exceptions will be made, so please register early. Presentation:  The presentation for this call will be posted prior to the call on the FFS National Provider Calls web page. In addition, a link to the slide presentation will be emailed to all registrants on the day of the call.

Anytown hosted a national ICD-10 conference this week and some of the Fix ‘Em Up Clinic’s coders attended the sessions to learn all about the new coding system. The rest of us got to meet some of the faculty right here in the clinic. They did a site visit for the wrong reasons. Our first esteemed patient, Kim, came in two hours before her presentation complaining of abdominal pain radiating to her back, nausea, and a fever. Dr. Carroll documented that Kim has a history of kidney infections and upon examination diagnosed another one. He documented that she is not pregnant and did not recently give birth. When we look up “infection, kidney” in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index, we find a variety of choices:

kidney (cortex) (hematogenous) N15.9

with calculus N20.0

with hydronephrosis N13.6

following ectopic gestation O08.89

pelvis and ureter (cystic) N28.85

puerperal (postpartum) O86.21

specified NEC N15.8

We know from Kim’s history that she was not pregnant recently, so we can eliminate some of the codes. Dr. Carroll also noted “no calculus and no cysts” so we can rule out a few more codes. Still, we need a little more information in order to select the correct code. When we reread Dr. Carroll’s note, we find the following diagnosis (naturally not where it should be in the documentation, but it is there):
  • Chronic pyelonephritis associated with stricture of ureter
That significantly narrows our choices to one:
  • N11.1, chronic obstructive pyelonephritis
Fortunately for Kim, she’ll be fine with antibiotics and made it back to the conference in time for her presentation. Getting to the lecture hall wasn’t a problem for Gloria. Her problem started when she got up to speak. According to her history, she came in complaining of heart palpitations, chest pain, tingling in her hands, difficulty breathing, and an upset stomach. She was convinced she was having a heart attack. Fortunately, she just suffered a panic attack. Gloria, however, was not comforted by Dr. Carroll’s diagnosis. She insisted she never panics. I’m going with Dr. Carroll on this one and reporting F41.0 (Panic disorder [episodic paroxysmal anxiety] without agoraphobia). Our final speaker, Pam, hobbled in after celebrating a little too much at the post-conference get-together. Pam tripped going down the stairs in the conference center and heard a snap, followed by excruciating pain. Well, followed by pain, the post-conference celebrations helped reduce the ouch factor. Dr. Carroll sends Pam for x-rays, which confirm a broken foot. In order to code Pam’s broken foot, we need to scour Dr. Carroll’s documentation for the following information:
  • Which bone or bones did Pam fracture?
  • Is the fracture open or closed?
  • Is the fracture displaced or non-displaced?
  • Which foot did Pam break?
  • Encounter type: initial, subsequent, sequela
By reading Dr. Carroll’s documentation, we learn this is an initial visit for a displaced, closed fractures of the cuneiform and cuboid bones of the right foot. Great, so we can code this, right? Not so fast. We’re ready to code the fracture of the cuboid bone:
  • S92.211A, displaced fracture of cuboid bone of right foot, initial visit
But when we look up a fracture of the cuneiform bone, we find three choices because the foot contains three cuneiform bones:
  • Lateral
  • Intermediate
  • Medial
Oh Dr. Carroll, we need some more information! And because Dr. Carroll quickly responds to our query, we find out that Pam actually broke two cuneiform bones—the lateral and the intermediate. That means we would report:
  • S92.221A, displaced fracture of lateral cuneiform of right foot, initial visit
  • S92.231A, displaced fracture of intermediate cuneiform of right foot, initial visit
By the way, if you look up “fracture, foot” in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index, it directs you to “fracture, tarsal” and the specific bone involved. Because we are excellent coders who have read the entire code book (actually we know to check the notes at the front of each chapter), we know we also need to include secondary codes from Chapter 20 (external causes of morbidity) to indicate the cause of Pam’s injuries. From Dr. Carroll’s notes, we know she fell down stairs at a convention center. That leads us to codes:
  • W10.8xxA, fall (on) (from) other stairs and steps
  • Y92.29, other specified public building as the place of occurrence of the external cause
And with that, the convention—and convention mishaps—are a wrap. I think I’ll stick to virtual events from now on.
So, Doctor, what were you REALLY doing in that procedure?

Inpatient coders will face a big learning curve when it comes to ICD-10-PCS. It’s a completely different system with a lot more detail than ICD-9-CM Volume 3. The biggest potential problem could be choosing the correct root operation. Without the right root operation, coders can’t get to the correct code. And physicians don’t need to document a specific root operation name. It’s up to the coder to figure it out. (Thanks, guideline A11.) Determining the root operation won’t always be easy because some root operations are very similar (excision and resection for example). So what to do? Maybe we should follow Taiwan’s plan and make physicians document the specific root operation by name (good luck with that). Donna Smith, RHIA, a senior consultant with 3M, offered a better solution during our conversation at the AHIMA National Conference. Are you ready? Here it is: Ask the physician to explain the procedure to the coders. Pull in one or two physicians from each specialty at your facility to talk to the coders. Make sure they’re nice, friendly docs who are willing to share information. Avoid the mean, grumpy docs. Ask the physician to walk through the operative notes for your organization’s most common procedures and explain to the coders what he or she is actually doing. What’s really going on in the operating room? Once the coders know the intent of the procedure, they’ll have an easier time determining the root operation. You can also do a little cross-training of the physicians. During the meeting, show the doc the ICD-10-PCS table for that particular procedure. That way, the physician can see what the coders need in the documentation. If you use an EHR, collaborate with the physicians from each specialty to create a template they can use for their most common procedures. Smith suggested having physicians from each specialty drive their own templates. After all, a vascular surgeon will perform different procedures than a neurosurgeon, so they’ll need to document different information. An added side bonus to this approach: you get clinicians and coders working together to improve documentation, which will make the transition easier for everyone.

Hurricane Sandy blasted the Mid-Atlantic region this week, causing plenty of destruction in its wake.  We could undoubtedly spend a lot of time coding for the injuries people suffered as a result of the hurricane/tropical storm—broken bones, contusions, lacerations, and so on. Instead of the actual injuries, let’s look at some of the codes for external causes in ICD-10-CM. You probably know these better as ICD-9-CM E codes. They are the codes that explain how and where the patient suffered an injury. ICD-10-CM contains a whole series of codes for cataclysmic storm (X37). All of these codes require a seventh character to denote the encounter type:
  • A, initial encounter
  • D, subsequent encounter
  • S, sequela
Many also require one or two placeholders (X) so the character for the encounter ends up in the correct place in the code.
  • X37.0, hurricane
  • X37.1, tornado
  • X37.2, blizzard (snow)(ice)
  • X37.3, dust storm
  • X37.4, tidalwave
  • X37.8, other cataclysmic storm
    • Cloudburst
    • Torrential rain
    • Excludes2: flood (X38)
  • X37.9, unspecified cataclysmic storm
    • Storm NOS
    • Excludes1: collapse of dam or man-made structure causing earth movement (X39.0)
Notice this series includes both an “other” and an “unspecified” option. Even though ICD-10-CM includes unspecified codes, you should avoid using them as much as possible. One of the main reasons for moving to ICD-10 is for increased specificity. An unspecified code doesn’t give you that additional level of detail. This series of codes also includes both types of Excludes notes.
  • An Excludes1 note means not coded here. Think of this as a pure excludes note. You should never report the excluded code with the code above the Excludes1 note.
  • An Excludes2 note means not included here. The condition excluded is not part of the condition under which it is listed, but a patient may have both conditions at the same time. So a patient could have suffered injuries as the result of both a flood and torrential rain. It’s okay to report both.
You might also see patients who have been exposed to fire as a result of the hurricane. More than 80 homes in Breezy Point, in New York City's Queens borough, burned during the storm. ICD-10-CM includes codes to denote exposure to both an uncontrolled and a controlled fire. For exposure to uncontrolled fire in building or structure, select the appropriate code from series X00. Note that X00 codes also require a seventh character to denote the encounter, so you will need a placeholder again. This series of codes also includes several different notes:
  • Includes: conflagration in building or structure
  • Code first any associated cataclysm
  • Excludes2:
    • Exposure to ignition or melting of nightwear (X05)
    • Exposure to ignition or melting of other clothing and apparel (X06-)
    • Exposure to other specified smoke, fire and flames (X08.-)
If the fire is uncontrolled, but not in a building or structure, choose a code from X01.

It’s All Saints Day (you know, the day after Halloween) and the waiting room at the Fix ‘Em Up Clinic is full of ghosties and ghoulies and long-legged beasties. I’m not sure if we have any things that go bump in the night, though. Ghost Henry gobbled an incredible number of Snickers bars for breakfast this morning. While Snickers are generally not considered the breakfast of champions, they were almost Henry’s last meal. Shortly after breakfast, Henry broke out in hives, started wheezing, and complained of tightness in his chest and a stomach ache. His mom brought him into Fix ‘Em Up, where Dr. Casper diagnoses anaphylactic shock due to a peanut allergy. So what do we code first—anaphylactic shock or the peanut allergy? You probably already know it’s the anaphylactic shock. That’s the reason for Henry’s visit today. Also, when you look up Allergy, peanut, in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index, the code listed is for status without reaction. If we were coding Henry’s medical history, we would note Z91.010 (allergy to peanuts). Since Henry is actually experiencing a reaction to his allergy, the anaphylactic shock, we would code:
  • T78.01XA, anaphylactic reaction due to peanuts, initial visit
Like many ICD-10-CM codes T78.01 requires a seventh character for the encounter type. Dr. Casper documented an initial visit, hence the seventh character A. Don’t forget your sixth character placeholder. T78.01A is not a valid code and will result in a denial. Witch Sue is also in for overindulging in chocolate after a night of Trick-or-Treating. She didn’t suffer an allegoric reaction like Henry, but she did end up with a really bad bellyache. Dr. Casper rules out an appendicitis and dyspepsia and diagnoses general abdominal pain due to overconsumption of candy. When we look up Pain, abdominal, in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index, we end up with a wide range of choices, including:
  • R10.0, acute abdomen
  • R10.1, pain localized to upper abdomen
  • R10.3, pain localized to other parts of lower abdomen
  • R10.8, other abdominal pain
  • R10.9, unspecified abdominal pain
Under R10.8, we find our choice based on the documentation of general abdominal pain:
  • R10.84, generalized abdominal pain
Gavin’s mom thought he would make a cute spider for Halloween, but Gavin’s coordination wasn’t up to the challenge of managing eight legs. One of the extra legs got in the way and sent him sprawling to the payment. At the same time, another leg caught him in the eye. He ended up with a broken wrist and abrasions to his hand from trying to break his fall and a scratched cornea. What does Dr. Casper need to document for use to code these injuries? For all three injuries, we need:
  • Laterality
  • Encounter
For the abrasions and the broken wrist, we need some additional specific details. Where specifically on the hand are Gavin’s abrasions? Is it the palm, the fingers (and if so, which one[s])? It is the back of his hand? Does Gavin have any open wounds or punctures to go with the abrasions? For the wrist fracture, we need to know: Open or closed? Displaced or non-displaced? Here’s what Dr. Casper documents: Initial visit with 11-year-old male with multiple abrasions to right palm, right index finger, and right middle finger. No foreign bodies in wounds. Patient also suffered open fracture of right wrist with displacement of cuneiform and semilunar bones. Patient also suffered left corneal abrasion. He was trick-or-treating and tripped over his costume. He fell on a level surface (sidewalk) and did not strike any objects other than the sidewalk. Based on that documentation, we would report codes:
  • S62.111B, displaced fracture of triquetrum [cuneiform] bone, right wrist, initial visit
  • S62.121B, displaced fracture of lunate [semilunar], right wrist, initial visit
  • S60.511A, abrasion of right hand, initial visit
  • S60.410A, abrasion of right index finger, initial visit
  • S60.412A, abrasion of right middle finger, initial visit
  • S05.02XA, injury of conjunctiva and corneal abrasion without foreign body, left eye, initial encounter
  • W01.0XXA, fall on same level from slipping, tripping and stumbling without subsequent striking against object, initial encounter
  • Y93.01, activity, walking, marching and hiking
Sadly, ICD-10-CM does not include a code specific to trick-or-treating. Maybe next year.  For now, I’m off to enjoy the leftover candy in the breakroom.
You'll never believe what that crazy coyote did this time

Wile E. Coyote may bill himself as a Super Genius, but based on his last visit to the ACME ED, I think that’s overstating things a bit. What landed Wile E. back in the ED, you ask? Another complicated, convoluted plan to snag a roadrunner lunch. In this, um, ingenious plan, Wile E. painted a tunnel opening on a hillside to lure his lunch into his clutches. The only problem was, the “meep, meep” he thought meant food actually signaled a really large truck moving at a high rate of speed through Wile E.’s shortcut. Things didn’t end well for Wile E. The ACME ambulance crew brought him in and (un)luckily for Wile E. (and for us), Dr. Fudd was on duty.  Dr. Fudd is not our top doc and he’s really bad at documentation. Let’s see what Dr. Fudd did document so we can figure out what additional information we need to code Wile E.’s injuries. First, Wile E. suffered multiple broken bones, which is not surprising since he was run over by a truck. For fractures we need to know:
  • Specific site (which bone and where on the bone)
  • Side (left or right)
  • Type of fracture (open or closed, displaced or non-displced)
  • Encounter (initial, subsequent, sequela)
In reviewing the documentation, we note that Dr. Fudd documented this is an initial visit. That will give us our seventh character extension for the codes that require one. Wile E.’s list of fractures includes:
  • Broken leg
  • Broken ankle
  • Multiple rib fractures
  • Multiple foot fractures
First things first, which side are the fractures on? Keep in mind they can be on different sides, or even on both sides (in which case, we would report two different codes—one for the left side and one for the right). Dr. Fudd documented that he sent Wile E. for x-rays for left-side fractures. Can we code from that documentation? No. We need Dr. Fudd to either specify that the fractures are on Wile E.’s left side or to document that he reviewed the radiology report of left-sided fractures. So we’ll have query. But before we do, let’s make a list of all of the specific information we need so we only need to send a single query. Are Wile E.’s fractures open or closed? Dr. Fudd only documented the ribs as closed fractures, nothing about the leg and foot. That’s something else to add to our query. The 2013 ICD-10-CM Official Guidelines for Coding and Reporting do give us a default on the question of open or closed as well as displaced or non-displaced. The guidelines state: A fracture not indicated as open or closed should be coded to closed. A fracture not indicated whether displaced or not displaced should be coded to displaced. However, ICD-10-CM does include specific seventh characters to denote types of open fractures. If we can obtain that information, we should because it will make the coding—and the medical record—more accurate. In response to our query, Dr. Fudd documents the following:
  • Broken leg—transverse right tibia, shaft, class I Gustilo, displaced
  • Broken ankle—right medial malleolus and trimalleolar, both with dislocation, class II Gustilo
  • Multiple broken ribs—right side, closed
  • Multiple foot fractures—third, fourth, and fifth metatarsal, right foot, closed, non-displaced,
The broken ribs are easy. We only have four choices—single or multiple, right or left. In this case, we would report:
  • S22.41XA, multiple fractures of ribs, right side, initial visit
On to the rest of the fractures. By the way, did you notice all of the fractures are on the right side not the left like the x-ray order? It seems Dr. Fudd wrote an incorrect initial x-ray order. Fortunately, the radiologist pointed out the error and Dr. Fudd amended the order. He just didn’t include it in the record. (The radiologist, however, did.) For the ankle and leg fractures, Dr. Fudd notes class I and class II Gustilo. If you don’t regularly work with traumatic fractures or orthopedics, you might not be familiar with the Gustilo-Anderson classification system. The Gustilo-Anderson classification identifies the severity of the soft tissue damage. If you aren’t familiar with it, make sure your physicians are. And make sure they know to document it. ICD-10-CM includes two different seventh characters for the initial visit of an open fracture:
  • B, initial encounter for open fracture type I or II
  • C, initial encounter for open fracture type IIIA, IIIB, or IIIC
For the open fractures, we would report:
  • S82.421B, displaced transverse fracture of shaft of right fibula, initial encounter for open fracture type I or II
 
  • S82.51XB, displaced fracture of medial malleolus of right tibia, initial encounter for open fracture type I or II
  • S82.851B, displaced trimalleolar fracture of right lower leg, initial encounter for open fracture type I or II
Now we’re down to the foot fractures. Wile E. broke three metatarsals, so we need these three codes:
  • S92.334A, nondisplaced fracture of third metatarsal bone, right foot, initial encounter
  • S92.344A, nondisplaced fracture of fourth metatarsal bone, right foot, initial encounter
  • S92.354A, nondisplaced fracture of fifth metatarsal bone, right foot, initial encounter
That’s all for Wile E.’s broken bones. What other injuries did he suffer? According to Dr. Fudd’s  (somewhat sketchy) documentation, Wile E.’s only other injury is a lacerated spleen. How big is the spleen laceration? The size of the laceration will determine which of these codes we report (with the appropriate seventh character to denote the encounter):
  • S36.030, Superficial (capsular) laceration of spleen
  • S36.031, Moderate laceration of spleen
  • S36.032, Major laceration of spleen
The ICD-10-CM Tabular Index includes these size guidelines to help determine severity of the laceration:
  • Superficial—less than 1 cm
  • Moderate—1 to 3 cm
  • Major—greater than 3 cm
Dr. Fudd documented a 2.3 cm lacteration, which gives us S36.031A. And with that, Wile E. hobbles out of the ED to hopefully order some takeout for dinner.
Have you done your ICD-10 coder assessments?

Do you know what you don’t know about ICD-10? Do you know where your knowledge gaps are? Unfortunately, the answer is probably no. More than half of the people who responded to our completely unscientific poll on JustCoding said their organizations haven’t performed any coder assessments in preparation for ICD-10. I was a little surprised by that, especially when I looked back at the timelines AHIMA and AAPC put out in 2010 and 2011. Those guidelines recommended coders complete anatomy and physiology (A&P) assessments by mid-2011 based on the October 1, 2013 implementation date. Move the implementation date forward one year to October 1, 2014, and you can also move those assessment target dates up a year. So coders should have completed assessments by mid-2012. It’s now November and 56% of respondents said their organizations had not yet conducted any coder assessments. What do you know now? How strong is your A&P knowledge? Granted, human anatomy hasn’t changed in a really long time, but when did you last actually review anatomy? Did you really know it or do you assume you do because you took A&P when you became a coder? If your organization hasn’t done a coder assessment, do one yourself. Identify which body systems you know well and which ones you know the least, recommends Gloryanne Bryant, BS, RHIA, RHIT, CCS, CDIP, CCDS, an HIM professional and leader for more than 30 years. Focus your training on your weakest areas, but don’t forget to review your stronger areas as well. Bryant also recommended determining how well you know the current coding guidelines. Most of them are going to stay the same in ICD-10. If you don’t know them now, start learning them. At the very least, review the guidelines. They change almost every year. Again, maybe not a lot, but you still need to stay on top of those changes. Until you know where your knowledge gaps are, you can’t create an education plan. That’s true for individual coders and for organizations as a whole. Without a solid foundation in A&P, medical terminology, and pathophysiology, you won’t succeed in ICD-9, let alone ICD-10.

Quite a few campers took advantage of the nice weather this weekend to make one last trip into the woods before winter. Unfortunately, some of them ended up in Fix ‘Em Up Clinic as a result of their adventures. So let’s see who our unhappy campers are and what injuries they suffered. First we have Rick, who flashed back to his scouting days and decided to start a fire with flint and steel. He would have been better off using matches. While striking the flint and steel together to create a spark, he actually created a sliver of flint, which ended up in his eye. Along the way, it sliced into his lower eyelid. Apparently our ICD-10 training hints are getting through to some of the Fix ‘Em Up physicians. Dr. Huckleberry documents a 0.5 cm laceration to the lower left eyelid and an ocular laceration ofthe left eyeball. Dr. Huckleberry documents that the flint chip is still in Rick’s eye and also documents this is an initial visit. So we have laterality and encounter for this patient.  For the laceration, we need to know whether Rick suffered a prolapse or loss of intraocular tissue. When we go back to Dr. Dingleberry’s notes, we see that Rick did not suffer a prolapse or tissue loss. That leads us to codes:
  • S01.112A, laceration without foreign body of left eyelid and periocular area, initial encounter
  • S05.32XA, ocular laceration without prolapse or loss of intraocular tissue, left eye, initial encounter
Two things to note with the ocular laceration code: the code is only five characters long, so we need to add a placeholder (X) so our seventh character for encounter ends up in the correct place. Also, we don’t actually need to know whether the foreign body is still in the eye in order to code the laceration. We can also add some codes from Chapter 20 (external causes of morbidity) as well, if our payer wants them. When we review Dr. Dingleberry’s notes, we learn that Rick’s injuries occurred :
  • At a campsite (Y92.833, campsite as the place of occurrence of the external cause)
  • During the building of a campfire (X03.4XXA, hit by object due to controlled fire, not in building or structure, initial encounter)
  • When he was struck by flint (W20.8XXA, other cause of strike by thrown, projected or falling object, initial encounter)
The camp fire also proved to be dangerous to fellow camper Chuck. Rick used porous rocks to build the stone circle around the fire and the rock exploded. Chuck found himself in the path of the flying debris and now has some lovely lacerations and burns to show for it. Dr. Huckleberry documents an initial visit for lacerations to the:
  • Right index finger
  • Right palm (multiple lacerations)
  • Right forearm (multiple lacerations)
  • Left cheek
  • Forehead
For these lacerations, we need to know if the exploding rock shards remained in the wound. Dr. Huckleberry helpfully documented that he found rock shards in all of the lacerations. We also need to know if the flying rocks damaged Chuck’s nails. (Dr. Huckleberry’s notes say no). That give us codes:
  • S61.220A, laceration with foreign body of right index finger without damage to nail, initial visit
  • S61.421A, laceration with foreign body of right hand, initial visit
  • S51.821A, laceration with foreign body of right forearm, initial visit
  • S01.422A, laceration with foreign body of left cheek and temporomandibular area, initial visit
  • S01.82XA, laceration with foreign body of other part of head, initial encounter
Remember, “other part of the head” does not mean an unspecified part of the head. There are unspecified codes if you really must use one, but query first for a more precise location. Also note the specificity in the finger laceration codes. ICD-10-CM includes separate codes for each finger for the left and right hands. In addition, the codes specify whether any foreign bodies remain in the lacerations. We’ve got Chuck’s cuts coded, now let’s see what else is in the documentation that we need to report. Dr. Huckleberry’s notes indicate that Chuck suffered second-degree burns to his right arm, so we report:
  • T22.211A, burn of second degree of right forearm, initial encounter
We are also instructed to use additional external cause code to identify the source, place and intent of the burn (X00-X19, X75-X77, X96-X98, Y92). We know that Chuck was struck by exploding rock fragments at a campsite and the injuries were accidental, so we can rule out codes in the X75-77 range (intentional self-harm) and the X96-98 range (assault). ICD-10-CM does not include a code for exploding campfire rocks. Our additional codes are:
  • W20.8XXA, other cause of strike by thrown, projected or falling object, initial encounter
  • X03.4XXA, hit by object due to controlled fire, not in building or structure, initial encounter
  • Y92.833, campsite as the place of occurrence of the external cause
Arthur, the third member of the camping expedition, missed all of the campfire fun. Arthur consumed too many adult beverages trying to, ahem, stay hydrated and instead need to head for the trees. Sadly, Arthur picked the wrong place to answer the call of nature. On his way to the perfect spot to relieve his bladder, he tore down a spider web and stumbled into some poison oak. The spider, completely unsympathetic to Arthur’s oncoming rash, decided to extract revenge for the web decimation by biting Arthur repeatedly. Dr. Huckleberry documented allergic contact dermatitis due to poison oak, which gives us:
  • L23.7, allergic contact dermatitis due to plants, except food
What about the spider bites? Arthur did not notice what kind of spider bit him (he was otherwise occupied at the time). However, he is exhibiting toxic effects from the bites. Since we don’t know what kind of spider was responsible, we can code:
  • T63.301, toxic effect of unspecified spider venom, accidental (unintentional)
In some cases, you can determine the type of spider involved, in part by geography. ICD-10-CM contains specific codes for bites by a:
  • Black widow spider
  • Tarantula
  • Brown recluse spider
  • Other spider
Each type of toxic effect includes subcategories for:
  • Accidental (unintentional)
  • Intentional self-harm
  • Assault
  • Undetermined
All of this reminds me why I avoid roughing it!
Real goals and benefits of ICD-10-PCS

You need enthusiasm and a desire to keeping learning to tackle the monumental task of learning ICD-10-PCS. In authoring an ICD-10 CM/PCS education program 10 hours per work I learn something new every day. The purpose of this blog is to share along the way with other coders. This week while preparing a presentation titled “ICD-10-PCS-An Introduction” my research took me to assembling a list of the goals and benefits of ICD-10 PCS. There are so many myths regarding this new coding system that I want to share these REAL GOALS AND BENEFITS. GOALS
  • Improve the accuracy and efficiency of procedure coding
  • Replace ICD-9-CM procedure codes with a more logical system
  • Improve communication with physicians by developing a code system that aligns more with the clinical aspects of various procedures
  • Allow coders to construct accurate codes with minimal effort
  BENEFITS:
  • Completeness
  • Expandability
  • Standardized terminology
  • Multiaxial
  • May reduce coder’s anxiety because it better captures procedural descriptions and details
  • Anatomically detailed clinical data
ICD-10-PCS guidelines go right down to our fingers and toes! ICD-10-PCS includes 31 root operations, but before you go there don’t forget to look at the Official Coding Guidelines for ICD-10-PCS. They are an extensive set of guidelines with instruction on how to use the root operations and cannot be overlooked.   For example, ICD-10-PCS coding guideline, Body Part Guideline: Fingers and Toes (B4.7), tell us:

If a body system does not contain a separate body part value for fingers, procedures performed on the fingers are coded to the body part value for the hand. If a body system does not contain a separate body part value for toes, procedure performed on the toes are coded to the body part value for the foot.

Example: Excision of finger muscle is coded to one of the hand muscle body part value in the Muscles body system.

Think positively about ICD-10 and consider all the goals and benefits to breathe new life into our profession. For me, choosing to embrace ICD-10 fully and teach it to others has been exciting and fun.
No need to scare the docs about ICD-10

How many of you are worried about getting physicians on board with the ICD-10 transition? We all know physicians are busy people. So how do you get them engaged in learning about the increased specificity (and additional documentation needed) in ICD-10? First of all, don’t tell them everything. They don’t need to know and more importantly, they don’t care. A cardiologist doesn’t need to know that the ED physician has to document the Glascow Coma Scale. “Unless you have a physician who wants to go into the weeds—and there are a lot of weeds in coding—only give them the information the need,” says , Melody W. Mulaik,  MSHS, CPC, CPC-H, RCC, PCS, FCS President and Co-Founder of Coding Strategies, Inc. and Coding Metrix, Inc. located in Atlanta, GA . Be prepared to tell them why it’s important—better data, better patient care. And avoid scaring them just because you can. “Not everything is a crisis,” Mulaik says. While you’re at, leave your gunslinger outfit at home. “Don’t go into the staff meeting with your guns blazing,” warns Scot Nemchik CCS, CIRCC, AHIMA-Approved ICD-10 Trainer, and vice president of coding compliance and education for IOD, Inc., in Green Bay, Wis. You’ll lose the hearts and minds of your audience in a hurry that way. Make this a collaborative effort. Ask the physicians for their input. Respect their time. Remember that they have a short attention span when it comes to coding. And if they’re already doing something right—like including laterality—make sure you tell that that too. A little praise could go a long way towards making your life easier.
Keep Calm and Carry On with ICD-10

Do you find yourself wondering how you will ever learn everything to be ready for the ICD-10-CM/PCS compliance deadline?  Does it feel overwhelming with how busy you are? The answer: Keep Calm and Carry On. During World War II this was a well- loved British motto. Keep Calm and Carry On was printed on large bright red and white poster and distributed for display. The daily bombings unnerved the general population and the government instructed them to Keep Calm and Carry On to get through the chaos and keep day to day life functional. Certainly ICD-10 is not comparable to World War II. Nonetheless, “Keep Calm and Carry On” seems to be good advice for the months ahead. Consider tackling ICD-10 CM by chapter. Focus on the new changes in each chapter: Chapter 1: Infectious and Parasitic Diseases (A00-B99)
  • Some category, subcategories, and terminology used have changed. For example, ICD-9-CM code 008-Intestinal infections due to other organism will be A08, Viral and other specified intestinal infections in ICD-10-CM.
  • Certain diseases have been rearranged. For example, a separate subchapter or block has been created for infections with predominantly sexual mode of transmission (A50-A64) and separate blocks have been created for viral hepatitis (B15-B19) and other viral diseases (B25-B34).
  • The term sepsis has replaced septicemia.
  • Streptococcal sore throat and its inclusion terms are reclassified in ICD-10 to Chapter 10: Diseases of the Respiratory System.
  • Many codes have been expanded to reflect manifestations of the disease with the use of fourth or fifth characters allowing the infectious disease and manifestation to be captured in one code instead of two.
  • New coding guideline I.C.1.c. (infections resistant to antibiotics) instructs coders to assign code Z16 for infection with drug resistance to microorganisms following the infection code.
Next week I will highlight the changes in ICD-10-CM Chapter 2 Neoplasm (C00-D49).

Over the river and through the woods to the Fix ‘Em Up Clinic we go. Not exactly where our patients want to spend Thanksgiving (and neither do we), but we’re here to coding their holiday mishaps. First is Sarah, who thought it was a good idea to text with her cousin Regina on the way to Grandmother’s house. Fortunately, she was driving slowly on a residential street when she hit a parked (unoccupied) car. Sarah sustained some minor injuries, including contusions to her chest from the airbag, a sprained wrist, and a broken nose. She also lost her cell phone privileges and her insurance company is going to want to talk about new rates. Dr. Gobbler sees Sarah and her documentation includes the following:

17-year-old female patient, see for initial visit following motor vehicle accident … Patient suffered contusions to right front wall of thorax caused by air bag … right radial carpal joint sprain, review of x-rays indicates closed hairline non-displaced fracture of distal pole of scaphoid bone … patient suffered closed nasal fracture.

Based on this documentation, we’re in good shape to code Sarah’s injuries. We know the:
  • Encounter
  • Laterality of the wrist sprain and fracture
  • Specific wrist bone fractured and location of the fracture (we have three choices for fractures of the scaphoid bone depending on the specific site of the fracture)
  • Specific joint sprained (we have four choices for a wrist sprain depending on which joint is injured)
  • Type of fracture (closed, non-displaced)
Our codes would be:
  • S62.014A, nondisplaced fracture of distal pole of navicular [scaphoid] bone of right wrist, initial visit
  • S63.521A, sprain of radiocarpal joint of right wrist, initial encounter
  • S20.211A, contusion of right front wall of thorax
  • S02.2XXA, fracture of nasal bones, initial visit
  • V53.5XXA, driver of pick-up truck or van injured in collision with car, pick-up truck, or van in traffic accident, initial encounter
  • W22.11XA, striking against or struck by the driver side automobile airbag, initial encounter
  • Y92.414, local residential or business street as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y93.C2, activity, hand held interactive electronic device
  ICD-10 only includes one code (S02.2) for a nasal fracture. However, that code requires a seventh character, which gives you six possible codes. Don’t forget to add two “X” placeholders to move the encounter to the seventh character place. Otherwise, your code is invalid. While most of us still put our bird in the oven on Thanksgiving, Dennis decided to try something different. He went for the deep fried turkey. Not such a good choice as it turns out. Dennis claims that when he attempted to put his Butterball turkey into the hot oil, the bird jumped out, splattering the aforementioned oil in its wake. As a result, Dennis suffered second degree burns to his arm, side of his neck, and side of his face. Dr. Gobbler documents the following:

36-year-old male patient presents with second degree burns to left forearm, left neck area, and left check …patient suffered third degree burns to left index and middle fingers … initial encounter ... patient accidentally burned by cooking oil while attempting to deep fry turkey outside on patio of single-family residence … patient suffered no additional injuries.

ICD-10-CM codes do not specify the size of the burn, just the degree. And some of the codes include multiple areas. So even though Dr. Gobbler documented burns on five sites, we only need the following three codes:
  • T23.242A, burn of second degree of multiple left fingers (nail), including thumb, initial encounter
  • T22.212A, burn of second degree of left forearm, initial encounter
  • T20.29XA, burn of second degree of multiple sites of head, face, and neck
The burn codes all feature the following note: Use additional external cause code to identify the source, place and intent of the burn (X00-X19, X75-X77, X96-X98, Y92) So we need to add:
  • X10.2XXA, contact with fats and cooking oils, initial encounter
  • Y92.018, other place in single-family (private) house as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y93.G3, activity, cooking and baking
Since Dennis’ burns were accidentally self-inflicted, we don’t need an assault code (X96-X98) or an intentional self-harm code (X75-X77). The bird did not get far however. Dennis’ wife found it “hiding” on the roof of the garage. She decided to dump Dennis at Fix ‘Em Up Clinic and head for a restaurant for dinner. That sounds like a good plan to me. Happy Thanksgiving!
Black (and blue) Friday at Fix ‘Em Up Clinic

Black Friday marks the beginning of the holiday shopping season—and the holiday injury season at Fix ‘Em Up Clinic. Patients started showing up shortly after the stores opened this morning with shopping related injuries. Heather came in complaining of a sore right wrist after being shoved to the during a midnight madness free-for-all at the local mall. Dr. Carroll documents a traumatic rupture of tendons in Heather’s wrist, contusions and abrasions to her hand, and contusions to her knees. Apparently Dr. Carroll enjoyed too much turkey on Thanksgiving because he forgot to document some important information. We need to know:
  • Encounter (initial, subsequent, sequela)
  • Laterality for the wrist and hand injuries—we can’t use Heather’s complaint to decide which side she injured. Dr. Carroll must include that information in his documentation
  • Specific ligament ruptured –collateral ligament, radiocarpal, ulnocarpal, or other. Other doesn’t not mean unspecified. ICD-10-CM does include a code for unspecified ligament, but we want to avoid unsing unspecified unless absolutely necessary.
  We do know the knee contusions are bilateral because Dr. Carroll documented knees. Let’s see what additional information Dr. Carroll can provide about Heather’s injuries. In response to our query, Dr. Carroll provides the following:

Initial encounter for traumatic rupture of radiocarpal and collateral ligaments of right wrist; contusions to right hand, abrasions on left palm; contusions on both knees.

Great, now we can report the following codes:
  • S63.311A, traumatic rupture of collateral ligament of right wrist, initial encounter
  • S63.321A, traumatic rupture of right radiocarpal ligament, initial encounter
  • S60.221A, contusion of right hand, initial encounter
  • S60.512A, abrasion of left hand, initial encounter
  • S80.01XA, contusion of right knee, initial encounter
  • S80.02XA, contusion of left knee, initial encounter
If Heather had suffered injuries to her fingers in addition to the abrasions and contusions to her hands, we would need to code those injuries separately by the specific finger injured. We can also report the following external causes codes if the payer wants them:
  • W03.XXXA, other fall on same level due to collision with another person
  • Y92.59, other trade areas as the place of occurrence of the external cause (the mall)
  • Y93.01, activity, walking, marching and hiking
Sadly, ICD-10-CM does not yet include a code for door-buster shopping, or any shopping for that matter. Our next patient Rex really wanted that jersey at the sporting goods store in the mall, but unfortunately for him, someone else wanted it more. Rex arrived at Fix ‘Em Up with some pretty nasty bruises as well as a broken leg. The other guy really didn’t fight fair it seems. Dr. Morang documents an initial visit for:
  • Contusions to the right periocular area
  • Closed, nondisplaced fracture of zygomatic arch (that explains the really nasty bruise on Rex’s face)
  • Laceration of the lower lip (no foreign body in wound)
  • Open displaced oblique fracture of shaft of right tibia (Gustilo class I)
Apparently Dr. Morang slept off the Thanksgiving turkey better than Dr. Carroll. With this documentation, we can code the following:
  • S82.231B, displaced oblique fracture of shaft of right tibia, initial encounter
  • S00.11XA, contusion of right eyelid and periocular area, initial encounter
  • S02.402, zygomatic fracture, unspecified, initial encounter
  • S01.511A, laceration without foreign body of lip, initial encounter
I think I’ll wait for Cyber Monday. It’s way too dangerous out there.
AMA continues to fight against ICD-10 implementation

When I first heard that the American Medical Association (AMA) is still fighting against ICD-10 implementation, I thought, “Seriously?” and rolled my eyes. In case you haven’t heard, the AMA’s House of Delegates again voted to oppose the implementation of ICD-10 during its 2012 Interim Meeting. This is the second time the House of Delegates has tried to stop ICD-10. Their first effort resulted in a one-year delay. I don’t think another delay is likely. Chris Stahlecker from CMS’ Administrative Simplification Group of the Office of eHealth Standards and Services summed up the problem of not switching to ICD-10 during a recent CMS National Provider Call: “We just can't continue to exist on the ICD-9 codes…we cannot advance our healthcare delivery system based off of code values that are becoming obsolete and very complicated to convey any meaningful information,” Stahlecker said. My friend Jennifer Avery, who is a regulatory specialist with HCPro, often complains about the lack of specificity in ICD-9 procedure codes. She’s fond of pointing out that coders report a central venous catheter insertion and a peripherally inserted central catheter with the same code (38.93). So how do you know what the physician actually did? The AMA claims the switch to ICd-10 presents a “bureaucratic and financial burden on physicians.” The AMA is probably right. The transition will require a considerable amount of resources—both personnel and financial. I get that physicians, practices, and hospitals have finite resources. My checkbook reminds me about finite resources every month. But we can’t keep putting of the switch. Each year we wait, the costs go up, which in turn puts an even bigger burden on physicians, hospitals, and practices. The AMA’s delegates may ask CMS to skip ICD-10 all together and move straight to ICD-11. That’s unlikely to happen. ICD-11 codes aren’t ready yet, so no one knows for sure what they will look like. The beta version of the codes is expected in 2015, according to the World Health Organization. That’s one year after the US will finally transition to ICD-10, so on the surface it might seem like a good idea to wait an extra year. Except it won’t be just one extra year. The codes probably won’t be ready for actual use for several years after beta testing begins. In its resolution, the AMA mentions October 17, 2017 as a possible date to begin using ICD-11. Given how long it’s taken to get ICD-10 codes ready for use in the US, 2017 seems very optimistic for ICD-11. Part of the problem is too many people used fear as a motivator when CMS announced the switch to ICD-10. It seems like everyone focused on the number of new codes without really looking at the actual codes. Yes, we’ll have a lot more codes in ICD-10, but physicians should already be documenting some of the information coders need. For example, laterality alone can quadruple code choices and it’s something physicians should already be reporting. If a physician treats a patient for macular keratitis, the physician should be documenting which eye. In ICD-9, it doesn’t matter—coders only have one code: 370.22. In ICD-10, coders will have four choices:
  • H16.111, Macular keratitis, right eye
  • H16.112, Macular keratitis, left eye
  • H16.113, Macular keratitis, bilateral
  • H16.119, Macular keratitis, unspecified eye
The only difference is laterality—specifically coding for the eye (or eyes) involved. Not every change is going to be that simple of course. Coding for diabetes and fractures will change significantly in ICD-10. Physicians will need to document some things they aren’t documenting now. Some of that will be new information, some of it will be information they should be documenting now. If physicians documented correctly and appropriately now, we wouldn’t need clinical documentation improvement specialists. The AMA also stands to lose a significant amount of money if CMS moves away from CPT coding and requires ICD-10-PCS codes for both inpatient and outpatient procedures. That idea has been tossed around quite a bit and in some ways makes sense. ICD-10-PCS would need some additional codes, for services such as E&M, but ICD-10-PCS has plenty of room to expand (unlike ICD-9). That potential financial hit probably also factors into the AMA’s opposition to ICD-10. We’re moving to ICD-10 for the right reasons: better data and better patient care. I hope the AMA remembers that and stops fighting implementation.
Learn differences for coding neoplasms in ICD-10-CM now

When coding for neoplasms in ICD-10-CM, coders will notice some differences in clinical documentation and sequencing. ICD-10-CM and ICD-9-CM coding for neoplams share some similarities, but ICD-10-CM provides greater detail. For example, ICD-10-CM will provide information about whether the neoplasm occurred in a right-sided or left-sided body part. Coders will still use the alphabetic index and tabular list for code assignment. The neoplasm table column for in situ will be next to the column for benign instead of being at the end of the columns. The biggest sequencing difference is relates to anemia associated with malignancy. ICD-10-CM differentiates whether anemia is due to:
  • Cancer
  • Treatment for the cancer
  • Both
This information will affect new sequencing requirements under ICD-10-CM and MS-DRG assignment.  When a patient is admitted or seen for management of anemia associated with the malignancy, coders will report the malignancy as the principal diagnosis followed by a code for the anemia, according to ICD-10-CM coding guidelines. In ICD-9-CM, coders would sequence the anemia code as the principal diagnosis followed by the appropriate code for the malignancy. The ICD-10-CM Official Guidelines for Coding and Reporting state:

Anemia associated with malignancy

When admission/encounter is for management of an anemia associated with the malignancy, and the treatment is only for anemia, the appropriate code for the malignancy is sequenced as the principal or first-listed diagnosis followed by the appropriate code for the anemia (such as code D63.0, Anemia in neoplastic disease).

Another change is that primary malignant neoplasms that overlapping sites are now coded separately. The ICD-10-CM Official Guidelines for Coding and Reporting state:

Primary malignant neoplasms overlapping site boundaries

A primary malignant neoplasm that overlaps two or more contiguous (next to each other) sites should be classified to the subcategory/code .8 ('overlapping lesion'), unless the combination is specifically indexed elsewhere. For multiple neoplasms of the same site that are not contiguous such as tumors in different quadrants of the same breast, codes for each site should be assigned.
Be very, very quiet--we’re hunting ICD-10-CM codes

Most of the odd ICD-10-CM codes, the ones that make us laugh or roll our eyes, live in Chapter 20 (External causes of mortality). Here you will find such gems as:
  • X32, exposure to sunlight (which does not include tanning beds)
  • X52, prolonged stay in weightless environment (I’d love to be weightless)
  • W61.43, pecked by turkey (apparently it didn’t want to be Thanksgiving dinner)
  • W56.41, bitten by shark (we’re going to need a bigger boat)
  • W49.01, hair causing external constriction (keep the scissors handy)
Not all of the circumstances described by external cause codes are laughing matters. You’ll also find codes such as:
  • V00.321, fall from snow-skis (not very funny if you’re the one falling and potentially very painful)
  • W40.0, explosion of blasting material (only amusing when animated characters are involved)
Some of the external cause codes include a remarkable amount of detail and in order to report the correct code, the provider needs to document that detail. Consider code series V30 (occupant of three-wheeled motor vehicle injured in collision with pedestrian or animal). Your code choices include:
  • V30.0, driver of three-wheeled motor vehicle injured in collision with pedestrian or animal in nontraffic accident
  • V30.1, passenger in three-wheeled motor vehicle injured in collision with pedestrian or animal in nontraffic accident
  • V30.2, person on outside of three-wheeled motor vehicle injured in collision with pedestrian or animal in nontraffic accident
  • V30.3, unspecified occupant of three-wheeled motor vehicle injured in collision with pedestrian or animal in nontraffic accident
  • V30.4, person boarding or alighting a three-wheeled motor vehicle injured in collision with pedestrian or animal
  • V30.5, driver of three-wheeled motor vehicle injured in collision with pedestrian or animal in traffic accident
  • V30.6, passenger in three-wheeled motor vehicle injured in collision with pedestrian or animal in traffic accident
  • V30.7, person on outside of three-wheeled motor vehicle injured in collision with pedestrian or animal in traffic accident
  • V30.9, unspecified occupant of three-wheeled motor vehicle injured in collision with pedestrian or animal in traffic accident
In order to choose the correct code, you need to know which person was involved (driver, passenger, or someone outside the vehicle) and whether the accident was traffic or non-traffic related. You also need to know the encounter type so you can add the appropriate seventh character (just don’t forget your placeholders). Some external cause codes include intent, such as:
  • W33.0, accidental rifle, shotgun and larger firearm discharge
  • W33.1, accidental rifle, shotgun and larger firearm malfunction
  • X73, intentional self-harm by rifle, shotgun and larger firearm discharge
  • X94.1, assault by hunting rifle
  • Y23.1, hunting rifle discharge, undetermined intent
ICD-10-CM does not yet include a code for shot by an angry, vengeful deer. But who knows? We have lots of room to expand ICD-10-CM. Until then, happy hunting (in your code book)!
ICD-10-PCS root operations: How much did the physician remove?

Penny arrived at the Stitch ‘Em Up Hospital with a benign growth on her thyroid gland (ICD-10-CM code D35). The growth isn’t causing any functional problems, so we don’t need to report any additional ICD-10-CM codes. Penny’s doctor, Dr. Morang,  wants to remove the growth to make sure it doesn’t cause problems in the future. When we code the procedure in ICD-10-PCS, we need to know several key pieces of information. First of all, we need to know what exactly Dr. Morang is removing:
  • Just the benign growth
  • Part of Penny’s thyroid
  • Penny’s full thyroid
That will determine which root operation we will use to build our code. If Dr. Morang is removing the growth only, we would use root operation Extirpation (taking or cutting out solid matter from a body part). If Dr. Morang is removing part of Penny’s thyroid, we would use root operation Excision (cutting out of off, without replacement, a portion of a body part). In this case, Dr. Morang plans to remove Penny’s entire thyroid, so we need to consider other root operations. Here’s where we need to look for a second piece of information: how is Dr. Morang removing Penny’s thyroid? Is he cutting it out? Ripping it out (let’s hope not, that sounds painful)? Using energy, force, or a destructive agent? Dr. Morang’s operative note states he excised the thyroid using a sharp instrument. So that eliminates several more root operations:
  • Destruction (physical eradication of all or a portion of a body part by the direct use of energy, force, or a destructive agent)
  • Extraction (pulling or stripping out or off all or a portion of a body part by the use of force)
That leaves us with Resection (cutting out or off, without replacement, all of a body part). Note that we’ll use Resection even though Dr. Morang documented Excision. Physicians do not need to use the root operation in their dictation. It’s up to the coder to determine the correct root operation based on the intent of the procedure. In this case, the intent is to remove the entire thyroid, so the root operation is Resection. We can start building our code based on what we know so far: Resection of the thyroid will fall under the Medical and Surgical section of ICD-10-PCS, so our first character is 0. The thyroid is part of the endocrine system, so our second character is G. Dr. Morang is performing a Resection, which makes our third character T. Now we can go to the ICD-10-PCS table for 0GT and see what else we need to know to complete the code. We already know he is removing the thyroid, which makes our fourth character K. If he was only removing one lobe of Penny’s thyroid, we would use either G (left lobe) or H (right lobe). For our fifth character, we need to know what kind of approach Dr. Morang used and the table offers only two choices:
  • Open (0)
  • Percutaneous endoscopic (4)
Dr. Morang documented an open procedure. This particular procedure only has two approaches, but other procedures can be performed using additional approaches. Make sure the physician documented how he or she performed the procedure. We still need two more characters to complete our code, but luckily we don’t need any additional information. The only choices for the sixth and seventh characters are Z (no device and no qualifier). That gives us a final ICD-10-PCS code of 0GTK0ZZ (resection of thyroid gland, open approach). Dr. Morang declared Penny’s surgery a success and sends her home. Since we have both a diagnosis code and a procedure code, we can send off the bill as well.
ICD-10-PCS: Multiple procedures with same root operation, different body part

The multiple procedure guidelines in ICD-10-PCS present possibilities for coder confusion. Several guidelines relate to the coding of multiple procedures, some under the heading of multiple procedures and others dispersed throughout the various root operation guidelines. One ICD-10-PCS multiple procedure guideline states coders can report multiple procedures when the same root operation is performed on different body parts as defined by distinct values of the body part character. Coders build an ICD-10-PCS code by using a ‘table’ format that will allow them to construct multiple codes from a single table. In some cases, coders can construct more than 200 possible codes from a single table. Within the various sections of ICD-10-PCS, each character of the seven-character alphanumeric code identifies ‘specific’ or ‘general’ values. In the Medical &Surgical section, if separate body part (character 4) values exist, then coders must report multiple codes. For example, if a physician performed an open total abdominal hysterectomy (removing both the uterus and the cervix), we would look at root operation Resection (cutting out or off, without replacement, all of a body part) in the alphabetic index. This leads us to table 0UT-. Character 4 contains ‘separate’ character values for the uterus (9) and the cervix (C). Therefore, in order to report the procedure we would need to report two codes:
  • 0UT90ZZ
  • 0UTC0ZZ
Also, if the physician removed tubes and ovaries, we would report additional codes for this procedure.
ICD-10-CM heads out to deer camp

It’s the second week of deer camp and all the hunters are at Fix ‘Em Up Clinic. Moe came into the clinic with some serious frostbite. Apparently, he fell asleep in the latrine at the camp and spent the night there. In order to code Moe’s frostbite, we first need to know whether the frostbite is superficial or includes tissue necrosis so we know which series of codes to look under:
  • T33, superficial frostbite
  • T34, frostbite with tissue necrosis
Under T33, you’ll notice this instructional note:
  • Includes: frostbite with partial thickness skin loss
So our physician documenting skin loss does not automatically mean we use a code from T34. The physician will need to document tissue necrosis. The next thing we need to know is the specific location or locations where the frostbite occurred. We also need to know the encounter so we can report the appropriate seventh character. Let’s look at Dr. Frost’s notes and see if we have enough information to code Moe’s frostbite: 39-year-old male seen for initial treatment of frostbite…three toes on right foot show frostbite with tissue necrosis…right ankle shows frostbite with some skin loss, but no necrosis…lower right leg superficial frostbite. Patient also has frostbite with tissue necrosis of left index, middle, and ring fingers and superficial frostbite of left hand. Based on this note we know we are coding for five areas of frostbite:
  • Toes of the right foot
  • Right ankle
  • Right lower leg
  • Index, middle, and ring fingers of left hand
  • Left hand
We also know the degree of frostbite at each site and the encounter, so we can code:
  • T34.831A, frostbite with tissue necrosis of right toe(s), initial encounter
  • T34.532A, frostbite with tissue necrosis of left finger(s), initial encounter
  • T33.811A, superficial frostbite of right ankle, initial encounter
  • T33.71A, superficial frostbite of right knee and lower leg, initial encounter
  • T33.522A, superficial frostbite of left hand, initial encounter
One thing to note about the frostbite codes: the codes for the fingers and toes do not require the physician to specify which or how many fingers and toes are involved. The codes currently read finger(s) and toe(s) with no further specificity. Moe’s friend Larry joined him at deer camp and at the Fix ‘Em Up Clinic. Larry, being the more dedicated hunter, was up in a tree stand and fell asleep. He then fell out of the tree stand and was impaled by a deer’s antlers. The unlucky deer apparently was checking out the tree where Larry placed his stand. Bambi sadly is a goner after suffering a crush injury to the skull (Larry being a big guy), but Larry survived with a puncture wound to the abdomen. In order to code Larry’s injury, we need to know:
  • Where specifically the puncture wound occurred—right or left side, upper or lower quadrant
  • Whether the puncture penetrated to the peritoneal cavity
  • Whether any piece of the antler remained in the wound
  • Encounter type—initial, subsequent, sequela
Dr. Frost documents the following: 41-year-old male patient seen for initial visit of penetrating injury to lower right quadrant of abdomen.,, piece of antler stuck in abdominal wall, no penetration into peritoneal cavity. That leads us to:
  • S31.143A, puncture wound of abdominal wall with foreign body, right lower quadrant without penetration into peritoneal cavity, initial encounter
Fortunately, Larry suffered no other injuries and is expected to recover. Our final deer camp refugee, Curly, came in complaining of pain he describes as "piercing needles in the skin." He also sports a rash with blisters along his right side and stated he experienced chills, stomachache, and diarrhea two days before the rash appears. Dr. Frost examines Curly and learns he had chickenpox as a child. Curly’s current condition relates back to that childhood malady. He is suffering from shingles, not a condition related to his stay at the deer camp. When we look up shingles in the ICD-10-CM alphabetic index, we are directed to see herpes, zoster. Sadly that is not the end of our diagnostic quest. The ICD-10-CM tabular list breaks herpes zoster down into seven subcategories:
  • B02.0, zoster encephalitis
  • B02.1, zoster meningitis
  • B02.2, zoster with other nervous system involvement
  • B02.3, zoster ocular disease
  • B02.7, disseminated zoster
  • B02.8, zoster with other complications
  • B02.9, zoster without complications
Hmm, we may need to ask Dr. Frost for some clarifying information. When we query, Dr. Frost states zoster without complications, so we code B02.9. So Moe, Larry, and Curly are on their way (hopefully not back to deer camp) and I feel a sudden need to avoid the woods. Bambi’s brothers might be out for revenge.

We’ve already discussed one of the multiple procedure guidelines in ICD-10-PCS, but we still have three more to go. And that’s not counting the guidelines that are not included in the multiple procedure section. Now let’s look at what happens when a provider performs procedures on multiple body sites in the same body part value during the same operative session. The medical and surgical section of ICD-10-PCS includes 31 body systems, including:
  • Central nervous system (second character 0)
  • Eye (8)
  • Bursae and ligaments (M)
  • Lower joints (S)
That’s not the complete list obviously, but it gives you an idea. Each body system is then further broken down into body parts and those parts vary by system. For example, under bursae and ligaments, you find:
  • Head and neck bursa and ligament (fourth character 0)
  • Shoulder bursa and ligament, right (1)
  • Shoulder bursa and ligament, left  (2)
  • Elbow bursa and ligament, right (3)
  • Elbow bursa and ligament, left (4)
  • Wrist bursa and ligament, right (5)
And so on. Again this isn’t an exhaustive list, bursea and ligaments contain 27 possible fourth characters. So if the physician performs a procedure on two different body parts, say the right wrist and the right elbow, the codes will be different because you have a different body part. The payer can clearly see your physician performed two distinct services. What happens when a surgeon repairs a torn left posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) and a left lateral collateral ligament (LCL) by open approach during the same operative session? Both ligaments are coded to the body part of knee bursa and ligament.
