Ralph immediately traveled to the Acme ED last night for initial treatment by Dr. Boom and is being seen today for a follow-up by Dr. Sam. We know that Ralph suffered a traumatic amputation. In order to code his accident we also need to know:
  • Was the amputation complete or total?
  • Which hand was involved?
  • Which specific fingers were involved?
Dr. Sam documents he is seeing Ralph for a follow-up visit for complete traumatic amputation of the right index finger and partial amputation of the right middle finger caused by exploding fireworks. That gives us codes:
  • S68.110A, complete traumatic metacarpophalangeal amputation of right index finger, initial encounter
  • S68.122A, partial traumatic metacarpophalangeal amputation of right middle finger, initial encounter
This is a follow-up treatment for Ralph’s injuries, so why are we calling it an initial visit? Because the ICD-10-CM Official Guidelines for Coding and Reporting tell us to add the seventh character of A when a patient is receiving active treatment including:
  • Surgical treatment
  • ED encounter
  • Treatment by a new physician
Dr. Boom saw Ralph in the ED, today Dr. Sam is treating him at the clinic. An initial visit with a doctor means you append A as the seventh character. And with that, we will close the clinic for the day and hope you all stayed safer during your holiday celebrations.

Everyone likes to think physicians are infallible (especially physicians), but accidents do happen, even during surgery. In ICD-9-CM, we can choose between two possible codes for a hemorrhage (998.11) or hematoma (998.12) that complicates a surgery. You’ll find them under Complications in the ICD-9-CM Alphabetic Index. Unfortunately, those codes don’t really tell us much. We know the hemorrhage or hematoma complicated the surgery, but we don’t know where it occurred. That will change in ICD-10-CM. ICD-10-CM contains numerous codes for hemorrhage or hematoma complicating surgery, based on location.  Also, you won’t find all of the complication codes grouped together. Instead, ICD-10-CM includes them in the section related to the body part. For example, the codes for an intraoperative hemorrhage of the ear are:
  • H95.21, intraoperative hemorrhage and hematoma of ear and mastoid process complicating a procedure on the ear and mastoid process
  • H95.22, intraoperative hemorrhage and hematoma of ear and mastoid process complicating other procedure
The codes for an intraoperative hemorrhage of the nervous system are:
  • G97.31, intraoperative hemorrhage and hematoma of a nervous system organ or structure complicating a nervous system procedure
  • G97.32, intraoperative hemorrhage and hematoma of a nervous system organ or structure complicating other procedure
You probably also noticed that the codes specify not only where the hemorrhage occurred, but also what kind of procedure the bleed complicated. So if the hemorrhage occurred in the right eye and it complicated an ophthalmic procedure, you would report H59.111. If a hemorrhage occurred in the left eye complicating another procedure, report H59.122. The eyes also pose a challenge because you need laterality as well. Was the bleed in the left eye, right eye, both eyes, or unspecified? You don’t need that detail for the ears though, just the eyes. Hopefully, your surgeons are not prone to accidental hemorrhages or hematomas and you won’t need to use these codes often. If you do, you can find them by looking under Complications in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index. Once you’ve found the term under Complication, move down to Intraoperative, and then to the specific system or site where the hemorrhage or hematoma occurred.
Don’t forget about other ICD-10-PCS sections

When we talk about root operations in ICD-10-PCS, we often focus on the 31 root operations in the Medical and Surgical section of the manual. After all, we’re going to use those codes the most and Medical and Surgical is by far the largest section of the manual. ICD-10-PCS includes more than just medical and surgical procedures. Some of the additional sections include:
  • Obstetrics
  • Placement
  • Imaging
  • Nuclear medicine
  • Radiation Oncology
Some of the sections are very small. For example, Osteopathic includes only one table (7W0) for Treatment (manual treatment to eliminate or alleviate somatic dysfunction and related disorders). Similarly, Chiropractic codes are limited to the root operation Manipulation (manual procedure that involves a directed thrust to move a joint past the physiological range of motion, without exceeding the anatomical limit). Some root operations appear in multiple the section of the manual. For example, the root operation Change (taking out or off a device from a body part and putting back an identical or similar device in or on the same body part without cutting or puncturing the skin or a mucous membrane) is used in both the Medical and Surgical and Placement sections. However, the third character in an ICD-10-PCS code represents different root operations depending on the section. In Medical and Surgical, the root operation character value 2 represents Change. In the Imaging section, a 2 represents a CT scan.

In late June, CMS and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) released the 2014 ICD-10-CM codes without the updated guidelines. Those guidelines are now available on the CDC website. Narrative changes in the guidelines appear in bold, while text that moved within the guidelines is underlined. The first notable text change is under the Punctuation subsection of the guidelines. The nonessential modifiers in the Alphabetic Index to Diseases apply to subterms following a main term except when a nonessential modifier and a subentry are mutually exclusive. In those cases, the subentry takes precedence. For example, in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index under the main term Enteritis, “acute” is a nonessential modifier and “chronic” is a subentry. Therefore, “acute” does not apply to the subentry “chronic”. The guidelines also point out that there is no national requirement that makes reporting External Causes codes mandatory. Some states or payers may require External Causes, but reporting these codes is otherwise optional. However, the guidelines recommend reporting these codes anyway because they provide valuable data. As a reminder, you should never use an External Causes code as the first listed code or principal diagnosis.
Spot the nuances in ICD-10-CM glaucoma coding

One of the big changes to coding glaucoma in ICD-10-CM is the addition of laterality to the codes. ICD-10-CM includes options for right, left, bilateral, and unspecified. ICD-10-CM also includes seventh characters to classify the stage of the glaucoma. Depending on the documentation, you will assign one of the following as the seventh character for all codes in the H40.10, H40.11, H40.12, H40.13, and H40.14 series:
  • 0, stage unspecified
  • 1, mild stage
  • 2, moderate stage
  • 3, severe stage
  • 4, indeterminate stage
Note that unspecified and indeterminate are two different things. You will only assign unspecified if the physician doesn’t actually specify a stage. In some cases, however, the physician can’t stage the glaucoma. When the physician states he or she is unable to determine a stage, the seventh character should be 4, indeterminate. This is actually a clinical finding, not missing documentation. If a patient presents with mild pigmentary glaucoma of the right eye, you would assign ICD-10-CM code H40.1311. If the physician diagnoses a patient with severe acute angle-closure glaucoma of the left eye, report H40.2123. What happens when a patient is diagnosed with glaucoma in both eyes? Do you automatically use the bilateral code? No. In order to report a bilateral glaucoma code, everything about the glaucoma must be exactly the same in both eyes—same type, same stage. If the patient has mild low-tension glaucoma in the left eye and moderate low-tension in the right eye, you need to report two different codes:
  • H40.1212 for the right eye
  • H40.1221 for the left eye
However, if the patient has moderate intermittent angle-closure of both the right and left eyes, you only need one code: H40.2332.
CMS hosting National Provider Call on ICD-10 basics

October 1, 2014, is a little more than 14 months away. Where do your ICD-10 implementation plans stand? Do you know what resources you’ll need for the transition or when you should providing training? AHIMA and CMS are teaming up for a National Provider Call to review the basics of ICD-10. CMS will host the call at 1:30 p.m. (Eastern) Thursday, August 22. AHIMA’s Sue Bowman will discuss the following topics during the call:
  • Benefits of ICD-10
  • Similarities and differences from ICD-9
  • Coding
    • Basics of finding a diagnosis code
    • Placeholder "x"
    • Unspecified codes
    • External cause of injury codes
    • Type of encounter
  • Training needs and timelines
  • Resources for coding and training
A CMS representative will provide an implementation update and the call will include a live question-and-answer session. To register, visit MLN Connects Upcoming Calls.

ICD-10-CM is all about specificity, right? The increased detail is one of the reasons the U.S. is (finally) moving to the new system. So true or false: you should never report a nonspecific code. Actually, it’s false. In some cases, coders can and should report Sign/symptom and “unspecified” codes. According to the ICD-10-CM guidelines, signs/symptoms or unspecified codes sometimes best reflect a patient encounter. That being said, you should always code to the highest level of specificity. Don’t just default to a nonspecific code so you can get the bill out the door. However, sometimes physicians can’t come up with a definitive diagnosis. They just can’t say what’s wrong with the patient. Maybe they are waiting for a lab test or a radiology report. Maybe the patient’s symptoms are so vague the physician can’t pick a single diagnosis. Or the conditions could be so similar the physician can’t choose. When the physician can’t assign a definitive diagnosis, coders should report codes for sign(s) and/or symptom(s). Remember though if you have a definitive diagnosis, you can’t code signs or symptoms that are integral to the diagnosis. A patient comes complaining of lower right quadrant abdominal pain. If the physician can’t determine the cause of the pain, report ICD-10-CM code R10.31. What happens if the physician documents the patient has an acute appendicitis with lower right quadrant pain and generalized peritonitis? You would report K35.2 for the appendicitis, but not R10.31. Abdominal pain is an integral symptom of appendicitis. ICD-10-CM also includes plenty of details about infectious diseases, including causative organisms (think botulism or salmonella) or types (such as pneumonia). If a physician diagnoses a patient with pneumonia, but doesn’t know the specific type, coders should assign an unspecified code (J18.9, pneumonia, unspecified organism). Report an unspecified code when it most accurately reflects what the provider knows about the patient’s condition at the time of that particular encounter. Do not select a specific code that is not supported by the medical record.

Apparently not everyone believes CMS’ claim that it will not move the ICD-10 implementation date again, based on our (completely unscientific) poll on JustCoding. We asked readers whether they thought CMS would move the date and gave them four choices:
  • Definitely will move it
  • Definitely won’t move it
  • Probably will move it
  • Probably won’t move it
That’s not the exact language from the poll, but that’s what the choices represented. I was a little surprised by the results—each choice received almost 25% of the votes. I was hoping that one choice would emerge as a clear winner, but no such luck. Personally, I don’t think CMS will move the date, but I’ve been wrong before. That leads to a second, equally important question: If CMS holds to October 1, 2014, will everyone be ready? Based on other surveys and talk at recent conferences, the answer to that question is probably no. The big healthcare organizations, such as the Kaiser Permanentes, Ascensions, and Cleveland Clinics of the healthcare world, probably will be ready. They have more resources available to create and carry out a transition plan. The scope of the transition is bigger for them, so they probably are not waiting until the last minute. Smaller healthcare organizations, such as one- or two-physician practices, critical access hospitals, and small standalone acute care facilities, may not be ready. Physicians seem resistant to the transition and the American Medical Association is lobbying hard to prevent it from happening. Some small organizations just don’t have the resources to plan and complete the transition far in advance. Almost 56% of the 1,200 practices that responded to a Medical Group Management Association (MGMA) survey indicated they had not yet begun ICD-10 implementation. MGMA released the survey in June. A little more than 38% of the respondents believe major health plans will not be ready October 1, 2014. Not all of the numbers are bad. More than 60% of respondents were extremely confident, confident or somewhat confident that their practice management vendor and electronic health records vendor would be ready for the transition. The majority of respondents do not plan to begin ICD-10 training for any of their staff before January 1, 2014. It’s interesting to note that 2.6% do not plan any education for clinical staff.

Summertime means beach time and unfortunately for some, Fix ‘Em Up Clinic time. First into the clinic today is Eric. After swimming in the ocean yesterday, Eric developed a pruritic, erythematous, papular rash on his trunk, axillae, and groin. Today, he experienced malaise, chills, and a sore throat. What could be wrong with Eric? His symptoms are vague and could point to a lot of different ailments. After further questioning by Dr. C. Shore, Eric revealed that he saw jellyfish in the area where he was swimming. He thinks he may have come into contact with one. Dr. Shore diagnosis the toxic effects of contact with a jellyfish. Not surprisingly, ICD-10-CM includes a code for that. Actually, it includes eight codes that each require a seventh character. You’ll find the codes in the T63.6 (toxic effect of contact with other venomous marine animals) series and you need to choose between:
  • Toxic effect of contact with Portuguese Man-o-war (T63.61)
  • Toxic effect of contact with other jellyfish (T63.62)
Eric is certain he was not stung by a Portuguese Man-o-war, so we know we’re in the T63.62 series. We still have four choices:
  • T63.621, toxic effect of contact with other jellyfish, accidental (unintentional)
  • T63.622, toxic effect of contact with other jellyfish, intentional self-harm
  • T63.623, toxic effect of contact with other jellyfish, assault
  • T63.624, toxic effect of contact with other jellyfish, undetermined
No one tried to assault Eric with a jellyfish, so T63.623 is out. Eric wasn’t trying to hurt himself, so we can eliminate T63.622. Based on Eric’s statement that he accidentally swam into the jellyfish, we’ll go with T63.621A. The seventh character denotes the encounter. This is Eric’s first visit for treatment, so we add A for initial encounter. Our next patient, 14-year-old Samantha, apparently thought a crab on the beach was dead, so she poked it—repeatedly. The crab was not pleased and tried to take off the offending digit. The crab was only partially successful, although it did succeed in sending Samantha screaming back to her mother. In order to code this encounter, we need to know:
  • Partial or complete amputation
  • Which hand
  • Which specific finger
  • Encounter type (initial, subsequent, sequela)
Dr. Shore documents an initial encounter for a partial amputation of the right index finger, which leads us to S68.120A (partial traumatic metacarpophalangeal amputation of right index finger, initial encounter). We can also add these External Causes codes for Samantha’s injury:
  • W56.81xA, bitten by other nonvenomous marine animals, initial encounter
  • Y92.832, beach as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y99.8, other external cause status (leisure activity)
ICD-10-CM does not include codes for poking a crab or examining a presumed dead animal and we don’t know what Samantha was supposed to be doing instead of annoying sleeping crabs. So we can’t add an activity code without more information. Today’s last patient also suffered a marine animal mishap, but this time, a seagull was indirectly to blame. Bob was out scavenging for seashells and sea glass for his artwork when he spotted a group of seagulls having clams for lunch. The gulls would take off, drop the clams on the rocks to break them, then swoop in and consume the exposed inner clam. Not all of the seagulls were on target and not all of the clams simply broke open. Bob had the misfortune of stepping on a sliver of clam shell, which sliced open the bottom of his bare foot. Of course, Bob was forced to flee the beach, picking up plenty of sand and other debris along the way, giving new meaning to suffering artist. We know Bob suffered a laceration to the bottom of his foot. Were his toes involved? If yes, we’ll need to add a code or codes for those injuries. Luckily for Bob, he only lacerated his foot. However, some of the sand remained in the cut and Dr. Shore had to remove it (Bob is not the strong, silent type). We also need to know which foot Bob injured and the encounter type. In Dr. Shore’s notes, he documented an initial visit for a 3 cm laceration of the left foot with foreign material. That gives us code S91.322A (laceration with foreign body, left foot, initial encounter). Be aware that the codes will vary by:
  • Location on the body
  • Laterality
  • Type of wound
  • With or without foreign body
We can also report some external cause codes for Bob, including:
  • W22.8xxA, striking against or struck by other objects, initial encounter
  • Y92.832, beach as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y93.01, activity, walking, marching and hiking
  • Y99.0, civilian activity done for income or pay
A quick word about the first and last codes on this list. When you look up stepping on an object in the Alphabetic Index, you are directed to W22.8. That’s the code we’ll use even though the definition doesn’t seem exactly correct. The Y99.0 code is open to debate a little, too. Bob said he was looking for material for his artwork. We would report Y99.0 if he sells his artwork because scavenging shells could be considered a work activity. If he creates art for art’s sake, we would use Y99.8 (other external cause status). Just remember the next time you’re at the beach: avoid the jellyfish, don’t poke the marine life, and stay away from seagulls.

Wile E. Coyote presented to the ACME ED this morning with more injuries suffered in his quest to catch the Roadrunner. You won’t believe what he tried this time. Wile E.’s plan involved dropping an anvil from a weather balloon onto the Roadrunner. Once airborne, Wile E. quickly spotted his potential prey and loosed the anvil. He apparently failed to consider that without the anvil’s weight, his balloon would rapidly rise. In the process, the string holding the balloon closed—and thus inflated—unfurled. If you’ve even seen what happens when a balloon loses its air, you know what happened next. Wile E. took a wild ride as the balloon deflated, then crashed to Earth when it finally ran out of air. To add insult to injury, the anvil he attempted to drop on the Roadrunner instead fell on him. Ouch. Now we get to code the poor coyote’s injuries. Wile E. suffered two distinct sets of injuries: one from the crash landing and one from the anvil falling on his head. We’ll deal with the crash-related injuries first. Dr. T. Byrd documents an initial visit for multiple injuries caused by a fall from a significant height, including two broken legs, torn knee ligaments, and a dislocated hip. For the leg fractures, we need to know:
  • Open or closed
  • Displaced or non-displaced
  • Specific location of the fracture for each leg
Dr. Byrd excels at documentation and provides the following information:
  • Closed comminuted displaced tib-fib fracture of the left leg
  • Type II open displaced medial condyle fracture of the right femur
  • Grade 3 sprains of ACL, MCL right knee
  • Obturator dislocation of right hip
We have everything we need to code for Wile E.’s injuries, although some of Dr. Byrd’s notes may need a little translation. A tib-fib fracture involves both the tibia and the fibula. A comminuted fracture means the bones are broken in multiple places. ICD-10-CM does include comminuted in the code descriptions for tibia and fibula fractures. We will need to code each fracture separately, even though Dr. Byrd included them on one line. A grade 3 sprain is usually called a complete tear. Don’t let that confuse you when you code the injury. When you look up Tear, ligament, in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index, it directs you to Sprain. We need to code the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) and the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) sprains individually. For Wile E.’s fall-related injuries, we would report:
  • S82.452A, displaced comminuted fracture of shaft of left fibula, initial encounter for a closed fracture
  • S82.252A, displaced comminuted fracture of shaft of left tibia, initial encounter for a closed fracture
  • S72.431B, displaced fracture of medial condyle of right femur, initial encounter for open fracture type I or II
  • S73.024A, obturator dislocation of right hip, initial encounter
  • S83.511A, sprain of anterior cruciate ligament of right knee, initial encounter
  • S83.521A, sprain of posterior cruciate ligament of right knee, initial encounter
All of these codes require a seventh character to denote the encounter and for all but one code, that seventh character is A (initial encounter). For fracture codes, the seventh character not only indicates the encounter, but also whether the fracture is open or closed. Since the right femur fracture is open, we use seventh character B. For open fractures, physicians must specify the type based on the Gustilo-Anderson classifications. However, if the physician does not identify the type of open fracture, default to B as your seventh character. Now that the fall is out of the way, we can look at the injuries caused by the falling anvil. Wile E.’s luck ran true in this case and the anvil landed on his head. Fortunately, Wile E. did not lose consciousness or suffer a traumatic brain injury. He did end up with a concussion, a closed non-displaced fracture of the frontal and parietal bones, and a 5-cm scalp laceration with stone slivers embedded. For this part of Wile E.’s injuries we would report:
  • S06.0X0A, concussion without loss of consciousness, initial encounter
  • S02.0XXA, fracture of vault of skull, initial encounter
  • S01.02XA, laceration with foreign body of scalp, initial encounter
Again, some things to note with these codes. Even though Wile E. suffered two skull fractures, ICD-10-CM classifies the frontal and parietal bones as the vault of the skull. So we only use one code. We also need placeholders for these codes. They all require a seventh character, but don’t have six other characters. In these cases, we use an X placeholder to make sure the seventh character ends up in the seventh spot in the code. Otherwise the code is invalid and we don’t get paid. Our patched-up coyote is ready to head back into the wild in pursuit of his dinner. But really, Wile E., it’s time to choose a different entrée.

First we saw the new ICD-10-PCS codes and guidelines in May, followed by the new ICD-10-CM codes in June and the ICD-10-CM guidelines in July. Now we have updated general equivalence mappings (GEMs) from CMS for both ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS. GEMs are a way to translate ICD-9 codes into ICD-10 codes and vice versa. The maps are a great tool and will get you to the correct code neighborhood, but they won’t always take you to the correct house. If you always had a one-to-one translation, moving to ICD-10 would be pointless. In some cases, one ICD-9-CM code maps directly to one ICD-10-CM code. For example, paratyphoid fever A maps from ICD-9-CM code 002.1 directly to ICD-10-CM code A01.1. More commonly, you’ll get a one-to-many match when you go from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM. For example, in ICD-9-CM, simple chronic conjunctivitis goes from one code (372.11) to four codes:
  • H10.421, simple chronic conjunctivitis, right eye
  • H10.422, simple chronic conjunctivitis, left eye
  • H10.423, simple chronic conjunctivitis, bilateral
  • H10.429, simple chronic conjunctivitis, unspecified eye
You cannot code directly from the GEMs, but they will point you in the right direction. Look at your common diagnoses by ICD-9-CM code, then plug those codes into the GEMs and see where the GEMs take you. You can use the GEMs to familiarize yourself with the ICD-10-CM codes (and the ICD-10-PCS codes for inpatient procedures). You can also see what the ICD-10-CM options are for diagnoses you commonly report. That can help you educate your physicians about any additional documentation they will need to provide for ICD-10.

It’s baby day at Fix ‘Em Up Clinic and Stitch ‘Em Up Hospital as we prepare to deliver new codes and guidelines for reporting pregnancy and delivery in ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS. Our first patient, Shannon, is a 31-year-old female, currently 40 weeks pregnant with her second child. She comes into the clinic because she is having contractions (and can’t wait to give birth). Dr. Stork admits Shannon to the maternity ward at Stitch ‘Em Up, where Shannon gives birth to a healthy baby girl. Since Shannon is apparently a pro at this baby business, we can happily report these two ICD-10-CM codes:
  • O80, encounter for full-term uncomplicated delivery
  • Z37.0, single live birth
All of the main pregnancy codes start with the letter O, not the number zero. It can be a little confusing if you forget that all ICD-10-CM codes begin with a letter. If you submit a code with a zero as the first character, the payer will kick it back as an invalid code. For the ICD-10-PCS procedure code, we have a nice, easy, one-line table in the Obstetrics section of the manual. Make sure you go to section 1, not 0 (Medical and Surgical). Our ICD-10-PCS code is 10E0XZZ. You only report this code for a manually assisted or vaginal delivery without instrumentation. Back at the Fix ‘Em Up Clinic, Dr. Stork sees Rachel, a 29-year-old patient who is 38 weeks pregnant with her first child. Rachel conceived her child through in-vitro fertilization. Dr. Stork informs the happy (and relieved) mother-to-be that she can expect to deliver a healthy baby boy within the next three weeks. Because Rachel conceived using in-vitro fertilization, she is considered a high-risk pregnancy, so we would report:
  • O09.813, supervision of pregnancy resulting from assisted reproductive technology, third trimester
  • Z3A.38, 38 weeks gestation of pregnancy
The Z3A- code is always an additional code only on the mother’s chart to indicate exact week of gestation. Also note that Dr. Stork did not document third trimester. She only documented 38 weeks pregnant. That’s okay. We can use the weeks to indicate the trimester. Not sure where trimesters begin and end? No worries. ICD-10-CM helpfully includes this breakdown at the beginning of the pregnancy section:
  • First trimester: less than 14 weeks, 0 days
  • Second trimester: 14 weeks, 0 days to less than 28 weeks, 0 days
  • Third trimester: 28 weeks, 0 days until delivery
Trimesters are counted from the first day of the last menstrual period. Our third patient, Melissa, is having a tougher time with her second pregnancy. Melissa is currently 33 weeks and four days into her second pregnancy. She is experiencing a constant headache and blurry vision. Dr. Stork examines Melissa and also finds her blood pressure is elevated. Dr. Stork diagnosis mild pre-eclampsia. We need to know if Melissa has pre-existing hypertension  because that will change our code. When we review Melissa’s record, we find a note from Dr. Stork stating Melissa has no pre-existing conditions that would affect her pregnancy, so we would report:
  • O14.03, mild to moderate pre-eclampsia, third trimester
  • Z3A.33, 33 weeks gestation of pregnancy
Our final patient for the day is Karin, a 29-year-old patient who is in the 22nd week of her first pregnancy—and she’s having twins! ICD-10-CM codes for maternal care for multiple gestations start at O30-. In order to code for Karin’s visit, we need to know whether the twins are sharing one placenta (monochorionic) or if they each have their own (dichorionic) and whether they are sharing an amniotic sac (monoamniotic) or are in separate amniotic sacs (diamniotic). In some cases the physician will not be able to tell. ICD-10-CM includes different series of codes if the physician doesn’t specify the number of placenta and amniotic sacs (O30.00-) and if the physician cannot determine the number (O30.09-). Make sure you read the documentation to determine which series of codes to use. Dr. Stork documents one placenta, but two amniotic sacs, so we would report:
  • O30.032, twin pregnancy, monochorionic/diamniotic, second trimester
  • Z3A.22, 22 weeks gestation of pregnancy
That’s all for our baby mamas for today. If you code a lot of pregnancies, be sure to read the guidelines for Chapter O in the ICD-10-CM Manual and take a look at the codes. ICD-10-CM includes specific codes for multiple pregnancies up to quadruplets, then adds a series for other specified multiple gestation (in case you treat Octomom).

CMS added additional ICD-10 MLN educational resources to its website and will be hosting an ICD-10 National Provider Call August 22. The new MLN educational resources include two fact sheets and a frequently asked questions booklet: “ICD-10-CM/PCS: The Next Generation of Coding” Fact Sheet, which includes information about the ICD-10-CM/PCS compliance date; ICD-10-CM/PCS; ICD-10-CM/PCS examples; structural differences between ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM/PCS; continued use of CPT codes; and use of external cause and unspecified codes in ICD-10-CM. “ICD-10-CM Classification Enhancements” Fact Sheet, which includes information about the ICD-10-CM/PCS compliance date; benefits of ICD-10-CM; similarities and differences between ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM; new features in ICD-10-CM; additional changes in ICD-10-CM; and use of external cause and unspecified codes in ICD-10-CM. “General Equivalence Mappings Frequently Asked Questions” Booklet, which includes background information and General Equivalence Mappings Frequently Asked Questions. The ICD-10 Basics National Provider Call beings at 1:30 p.m. (Eastern) on August 22 and the speakers will cover:
  • Benefits of ICD-10
  • Similarities and differences from ICD-9
  • Coding
    • Basics of finding a diagnosis code
    • Placeholder "x"
    • Unspecified codes
    • External cause of injury codes
    • Type of encounter
  • Training needs and timelines
  • Resources for coding and training
  • National implementation issues
Don’t stop at the Alphabetic Index

In ICD-9-CM, we know not to code solely from the Alphabetic Index. After all, the code could have additional digits or excludes notes or other coding directions (such as “code first” or “use an additional code”). Guess what—that won’t change in ICD-10-CM. We still have to look up the actual code in the Tabular List. ICD-10-CM codes can be up to seven characters in length. The Alphabetic Index rarely lists all seven. Sometimes ICD-10-CM is nice enough to let us know we need additional characters by putting a dash at the end of the code in the Alphabetic Index. For example, if you look up unilateral conductive deafness, the Alphabetic Index gives you code H90.1-. When you look up H90.1- in the Tabular List, you find two choices:
  • H90.11, conductive hearing loss, unilateral, right ear, with unrestricted hearing on the contralateral side
  • H90.12, conductive hearing loss, unilateral, left ear, with unrestricted hearing on the contralateral side
Coding life would be easy (well, easier) if ICD-10-CM did that for all of the codes that require additional characters. Alas, it does not. Look up gout, chronic, idiopathic, multiple sites in the Alphabetic Index. You see code M1A.09. That’s all. However, when you flip back to the Tabular List, you find out that you need a seventh character. Actually you need a sixth character placeholder and a seventh character to denote:
  • 0, without tophus (tophi)
  • 1, with tophus (tophi)
For chronic idiopathic gout of multiple sites without tophus, you would report code M1A09X0. Most of the codes without the dash actually require placeholders. You can have up to three X placeholders in a single code. You’ll usually find those in the External Causes section, such as:
  • W64.XXXA, exposure to other animate mechanical forces, initial encounter
  • W73.XXXD, other specified cause of accidental non-transport drowning and submersion, subsequent encounter
  • W85.XXXS, exposure to electric transmission lines, sequela
Don’t be fooled by the lack of a dash. Make sure you check the Tabular List to get the complete code.
Attack of the summer sports injuries

Ah, the dogs days of summer. An evil time when, according to the ancient Romans, the sea boils, dogs grow mad, and men contract, among other diseases, burning fevers, hysterics, and frenzies, whatever those are. Fortunately, no ancient Romans suffering from frenzies have come into the Fix ‘Em Up Clinic lately, but we have seen a rash of summer sports injuries. Todd spent the summer working on his golf game. He comes in to see Dr. Sunni Daze complaining of pain in his right elbow. Dr. Daze diagnoses golfer’s elbow and prescribes physical therapy and anti-inflammatory drugs. The ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index includes golfer’s elbow, but directs us to epicondylitis, medial. As a side note, you’ll also find tennis elbow in the Alphabetic Index with a note to see epicondylitis, lateral. We have three possible choices for Todd’s condition, but because the documentation specifies the right elbow, we would report:
  • M77.01, medial epicondylitis, right elbow
Our next patient, Bob, arrives still wearing his summer league baseball uniform. Bob tells Dr. Daze that he was rounding second base and trying for third when he heard a popping sound followed by “excruciating pain” in his left heel. After a thorough examination, Dr. Daze diagnoses a ruptured Achilles tendon. ICD-9-CM classifies an acute traumatic rupture or tear of a tendon as a sprain. ICD-10-CM classifies it as a strain. So off to strain, tendon, we go. Only to discover that we really need to look up Injury, muscle, by site, strain. But wait, we don’t have a muscle specified. Dr. Daze specified a rupture of the Achilles tendon. Now what? Fortunately, under Injury in the Alphabetic Index, we find an entry for Achilles tendon directing us to code series S86.01-. We know this is the left Achilles tendon and is an initial visit, which means we will report:
  • S86.012A, strain of left Achilles tendon, initial encounter
The Anytown Skateboard Park has sent plenty of business our way this summer and today is no exception. Steven was showing off what he thought were his mad skateboarding skills when a twig on the ramp took him down. Steven broke his fall by putting out both hands and also broke his wrist and suffered assorted other scrapes and bruises. Fortunately, he was wearing a helmet and thus avoided a concussion and any serious brain injury. What information do we need in order to code Steven’s broken wrist? In general, to code fractures in ICD-10-CM, we need to know:
  • Right or left
  • Open or closed
  • Displaced or non-displaced
  • Specific bone and where on the bone
Let’s see what Dr. Daze documented. Initial visit for 18-year-old male, fell from skateboard at park. Suffered abrasions to left palm, right palm, left knee. X-rays confirm Colles’ fracture of right arm, rules out other fractures. Steven suffered a Colles’ fracture, which is actually a fracture of the distal end of the radius. ICD-10-CM includes specific codes for Colles’ fractures, as well as Smith’s fractures and Barton’s fractures. Because Dr. Daze specified a Colles’ fracture, we only have three main choices:
  • S52.531, Colles' fracture of right radius
  • S52.532, Colles' fracture of left radius
  • S52.539, Colles' fracture of unspecified radius
We know Steven fractured his right radius and this is an initial visit, so our final code would be S52.531A (Colles' fracture of right radius, initial encounter). We also need to code Steven’s other injuries, and since Dr. Daze helpfully indicated laterality, we would code:
  • S60.511A, abrasion of right hand, initial encounter
  • S60.512A, abrasion of left hand, initial encounter
  • S80.212A, abrasion, left knee, initial encounter
In ICD-9-CM, we look up abrasions by going to injury, superficial, by site. In ICD-10-CM, we can just look up abrasion and find the entire list of abrasion codes. Because we know where Steven was and what he was doing when he was injured, we can also add some external causes codes:
  • V00.131A, fall from skateboard, initial encounter
  • Y93.51, activity, roller skating (inline) and skateboarding
  • Y92.830, public park as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y99.8, other external cause status
And with that, the staff at Fix ‘Em Up Clinic wishes you a safe and happy weekend!
Trek through the Table of Drugs in ICD-10-CM

Paracelsus, the father of toxicology (among other things), once wrote: “Everything is poison, there is poison in everything. Only the dose makes a thing not a poison.” Cheery thought, right? Fortunately, we can code for poisonings of all types in both ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM. The Table of Drugs in ICD-10-CM looks a little different from the one in ICD-9-CM, but it works the same way. In ICD-9-CM, we can choose a code to represent:
  • Poisoning
  • Accident
  • Therapeutic use
  • Suicide attempt
  • Assault
  • Undetermined
You find the drug, check the documentation, and match up what the cause with the correct column, then double check the code in the Tabular List. For example, if a patient accidentally took too much citric acid while trying a lemon and orange diet, we would report 989.89 (other substances, chiefly nonmedicinal as to source, other). In ICD-10-CM, we’ll follow the same steps: Determine what drug was involved, determine the intent, find the code in the table, and double-check it in the Tabular List. ICD-10-CM’s choices are a little different, but for the most part, represent the same intent as the ones in ICD-9-CM. In ICD-10-CM, our choices are:
  • Poisoning, accidental (unintentional)
  • Poisoning, intentional self-harm
  • Poisoning, assault
  • Poisoning, undetermined
  • Adverse effect
  • Underdosing
For our patient who overdosed on citric acid, the Table of Drugs directs us to T47.5X1 (poisoning by digestants, accidental [unintentional]). However, we can’t stop there. We still need to double-check our code in the Tabular List. When we do, we notice that all of the codes in the T47- series require a seventh character to identify the encounter:
  • A, initial
  • D, subsequent
  • S, sequela
If the physician saw the patient for an initial encounter for an accidental citric acid overdose, we would report T47.5X1A. The opposite of an overdose is an underdose, and ICD-10-CM adds a column to the Table of Drugs to represent underdosing. An underdose may be intentional (the patient doesn’t like the side effects or can’t afford the prescription) or it can be unintentional (the patient forgot to take the medication, possibly because of dementia). The Tabular List provides us with some additional guidelines to use for poisonings, and you’ll find them at the very beginning of the Poisoning section (T36). When a patient suffers an adverse event, code first the nature of the adverse effect. For example, a patient on acebutolol develops a first degree heart block. We would report:
  • I44.0, atrioventricular block, first degree
  • T44.7X5A, adverse effect of beta-adrenoreceptor antagonists, initial encounter
We also need to use additional code(s) to specify:
  • Manifestations of poisoning
  • Underdosing or failure in dosage during medical and surgical care (Y63.6, Y63.8-Y63.9)
  • Underdosing of medication regimen (Z91.12-, Z91.13-)
A paranoid schizophrenic patient comes in for initial care of hallucinations. Her schizophrenia became symptomatic again because she has not been taking her prescribed dose of haloperidol. She told the physician she does not like how it makes her feel, so she reduced the dosage. For this patient, we would report:
  • F20.0, paranoid schizophrenia
  • T43.4x6A, underdosing of butyrophenone and thiothixene neuroleptics, initial encounter
  • Z91.128, patient's intentional underdosing of medication regimen for other reason
We have one code for the condition (schizophrenia), one for the underdosing, and one for the reason for the underdosing.

Do you ever feel like everything is on YouTube? In some cases, it’s more than you want to see, but the video site can be extremely helpful for coders who want to watch procedures. For example, search for gallbladder removal and you’ll get more than 24,000 results. Some of the surgeries require a strong stomach, but they are a great help when it comes to determining what physicians actually do. YouTube is also a handy place to catch up on ICD-10 implementation. CMS has its own YouTube channel and just posted a new video covering:
  • Tips for a smooth transition to ICD-10 in physician offices
  • ICD-10 preparation strategies
  • Details about the partial code freeze prior to the ICD-10 transition
  • Information about the Medicare Severity Diagnosis Related Grouper (MS-DRG) Conversion Project
The video runs for just over 19 minutes. Just don't get caught watching cute puppy videos when you tell your boss YouTube is helping you do your job.
ICD-10-CM lists codes exempt from POA reporting

Inpatient coders are used to assigning a present-on-admission (POA) indicator in ICD-9-CM. They will need to continue to assign POA indicators in ICD-10-CM. The POA indicators remain the same, but ICD-10-CM includes a list of codes that are exempt from POA reporting. Many of them appear in the I69- and O09- series of codes. That makes sense since I69- codes are sequela from cerebral injuries and the O09 codes are used for supervision of pregnancy. Many of the Q codes (congenital malformations, deformations and chromosomal abnormalities) are also exempt from POA reporting. Coders will not need to report a POA indicator for many codes in the S chapter with a seventh character of D (subsequent encounter) and S (sequela). You can download the complete list of codes exempt from POA reporting from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention website.

Labor Day might mark the unofficial end of summer, but sadly, it's not the end of barbecue mishaps at the Fix 'Em Up Clinic. Matt, who last year survived flaming tomato napalm, decided to grill up some fresh corn on the cob as part of a post-Labor Day cookout. Thankfully, he avoided mishaps during food preparation, which put him well ahead of last year. Sadly, consuming the food did not go as smoothly as cooking the food. When Matt bit into the corn, the hot juice spurted into his eye, burning his cornea. Matt stood up so fast, he knocked over the picnic bench he was sitting on. The bench got its revenge by tripping Matt as he attempted to flee indoors to flush his burning eye with cold water. Instead, he tripped, flipped, and hit the concrete patio face first. Ouch. Dr. Tom A. Toe examined Matt and documented a burn to Matt's eye, a broken nose, contusion of the shin (from banging into the bench), and a mild concussion with no loss of consciousness (LOC). In order to code for Matt's eye injury, we need to know:
  • Which eye
  • Which specific part of the eye
  • Burn or corrosion
  • Encounter type
In his notes, Dr. Toe specified a corneal burn of the left eye and noted this was Matt's first visit.That gives us code T26.12XA (burn of cornea and conjunctival sac, left eye, initial encounter). Make sure you include the placeholder X so the seventh character A (initial encounter) ends up in the seventh position. Because Matt suffered a burn, we need to report additionalexternal cause code to identify the source, place, and intent of the burn (X00-X19, X75-X77,X96-X98, Y92). In Matt's case those codes are:
  • X10.1XXA, contact with hot foods, initial encounter
  • Y92.018, other place in single-family (private) house as the place of occurrence of the external cause
We don't need a code from X75-X77 or X96-X98 because Matt's injuries were not caused by an assault (unless the corn is really alive) or intentional self harm. We would use Y92.018 because we do not have a code to specify the patio of the house. That makes it an “other” place. Matt's other injuries are fairly simple to code. For a nasal fracture, we only have one choice, but we do need placeholders and a seventh character. In Matt's case, the code is:
  • S02.2XXA, fracture of nasal bones, initial encounter
For Matt's bruised shin, we need to know which leg. Dr. Toe documented right leg, so we would code:
  • S80.11XA, contusion of right lower leg, initial encounter
Matt's final injury is the concussion. Because Dr. Toe documented no LOC, we would report:
  • S06.0X0A, concussion without loss of consciousness
If Matt had lost consciousness, we would need to know the length of time he was unconscious in order to correctly code the injury. So Matt is all patched up and on his way home, hopefully to remove grilled vegetables from his menu.
If ICD-10 were a game, what game would it be?

With the ICD-10 compliance date looming, can we find some fun in it all?  We can play Coding “Jeopardy” as a fun learning tool, but if ICD-10 were a game, what game would it be? Some might liken it to the game of Risk: Risk is a strategic game played on a board depicting a political map of the Earth, divided into 42 territories which are grouped into six continents. The primary object of the game is world domination, or "to occupy every territory on the board and in so doing, eliminate all other players." Players control armies with which they attempt to capture territories from other players, with results determined by dice rolls. Risk mitigation should be a top strategic initiative in your ICD-10 implementation. Providers can help mitigate their risk by:
  • Using electronic health record (EHR) systems with the capacity to adapt to the changes inherent in ICD-10
  • Providing ample training to coders and physicians before ICD-10 comes into effect
  • Creating a detailed plan for transition in advance of 2014
Many Chief Financial Officers in the midst of budgeting and paying for the resources to implement ICD-10 might call it Penny Pitch. Estimated costs for the implementation are staggering. Providers will invest as much as $83,000 for a small practice, approximately $285,000 for a medium sized practice, and $2.7 million or more for large systems. For some of us who have invested years in the classification of clinical data ICD-10 is purely and simply Candyland. The richness of the specificity in clinical data is sweet and has yet to be realized.  The benefits will be bountiful in better profiling due to the specificity of data collected and improved clinical information for research.  The race to find King Kandy, the lost king of Candyland can be compared the race to meet the compliance deadline of October 1, 2014. Racing into the Land of ICD-10, where we’ll discover:
  • Improved ability to measure health care services
  • Updated medical terminology and classification of diseases
  •  Better data for making clinical decisions
CMS sets deadline for ICD-10 LCDs

CMS has been releasing ICD-10 National Coverage Determination (NCD) “omnibus” transmittals since September 2012, which gives providers some information about CMS’ coverage policies moving forward. NCDs are only part of the picture. What about the Local Coverage Determinations (LCD)? CMS released Transmittal R1293OTN and MLN Matters® MM8348 setting April 10, 2014, as the deadline for all LCDs and related articles to be published in the Medicare Coverage Database. MACs may decide to simply translate ICD-9 codes to ICD-10 and update the LCD with that new information. However, MACs can also revise more than just the ICD-10 code(s), so someone within each organization will need to compare the LCDs to determine whether they contain code updates or coverage changes. An NCD is a nationwide determination of whether Medicare will pay for an item or service. NCDs apply in all Medicare jurisdictions. FIs, carriers, and MACs develop and/or adopt LCDs when CMS has not issued an NCD or when the NCD needs to be further defined. LCDs are applicable only to the specific local carrier, FI, or MAC. They do not apply nationwide. So the policy in one region may differ from coverage policy in a different region. A local policy may consist of two separate, though closely related, documents: the LCD and an associated article. The LCD only contains reasonable and necessary language. The article includes any non-reasonable and necessary language a Medicare contractor wants to add. CMS issued Transmittal R96MSP directing its contractors to fully implement all ICD-10-related system changes no later than October 1, 2013, to allow for end-to-end testing. Remember, though, that CMS itself is not performing end-to-end testing with providers. However, you can and should take advantage of opportunities to conduct end-to-end testing with contractors and as many other payers as possible.
Only a famous death will do

Death smiles at us all. All a man can do is smile back. (Kudos if you know I appropriated that from the movie Gladiator.) History is full of weird circumstances and odd injuries that lead to death. Let’s look at some of history’s more (in)famous deaths and see how we would code the injuries that caused death in ICD-10-CM. Going way back to the 600s B.C., Athenian lawmaker Draco was smothered to death when happy citizens of Aegina showered him with gifts of cloaks. His cause of death was likely asphyxiation. You’ll find the codes for asphyxiation in the T71- series, which covers both mechanical suffocation and traumatic suffocation. Note that all of the codes under T71 require a seventh character to denote the encounter. T71 also includes an Excludes1 note, which means not coded here. You should never report the excluded code with the code above the Excludes1 note. Be sure to check the Excludes1 note before selecting a code from T71. In Draco’s case, we would look for a code in the T71.1- (asphyxiation due to mechanical threat to breathing) series since the weight of the cloaks smothered him. T71.1 includes codes for suffocation by:
  • Smothering under pillow
  • Plastic bag
  • Bed linens
  • Another person’s body
  • In furniture
  • By hanging
  • Other causes
For Draco, it’s other causes since gifts of cloaks aren’t covered. We also need to know if the asphyxiation was accidental, intentional self-harm, assault, or undetermined. I’m going with accidental, because I don’t think the citizens were trying to kill him, so our code is:
  • T71.191A, asphyxiation due to mechanical threat to breathing due to other causes, accidental, initial encounter
Sticking with ancient deaths (455 B.C. to be precise), we can review the tragedy of Aeschylus. According to legend, the playwright died after being hit on the head with a tortoise. Apparently a passing eagle mistook Aeschylus’ head for a rock suitable for shattering the shell of the reptile. Instead, the eagle’s falling dinner shattered Aeschylus’ skull. For a skull fracture, we need to know the exact bone(s) fractured so we can correctly choose from these codes:
  • S02.0, fracture of vault of skull
  • S02.1, fracture of base of skull
  • S02.2, fracture of nasal bones
  • S02.3, fracture of orbital floor
  • S02.4, fracture of malar, maxillary and zygoma bones
  • S02.5, fracture of tooth (traumatic)
  • S02.6, fracture of mandible
  • S02.8, fractures of other specified skull and facial bones
  • S02.9, fracture of unspecified skull and facial bones
Many of these codes also have subcategories to further specify the exact site of the fracture. All of these codes also require a seventh character to denote the encounter. For some of the codes, such as S02.0, you’ll need to add placeholder Xs, so the seventh character actually ends up in the seventh position. Aeschylus probably also suffered a traumatic brain injury from the falling tortoise. ICD-10-CM category S06 (intracranial injury) includes all kinds of brain injuries, such as:
  • Concussion
  • Traumatic cerebral edema
  • Diffuse traumatic brain injury
  • Focal traumatic brain injury
  • Epidural hemorrhage
  • Traumatic subdural hemorrhage
  • Other specified intracranial injuries
  • Unspecified intracranial injury
Again, you’ll need to know the exact nature of the injury and the encounter. Sadly, while ICD-10-CM does include numerous External Causes codes for being struck by a falling object, none of them specify a tortoise dropped by an eagle. Maybe next year. Our final fatality for the day comes from 162 B.C. when Eleazar Maccabeus was crushed to death at the Battle of Beth Zechariah by a war elephant that he believed to be carrying Seleucid King Antiochus V. Eleazar ran underneath the elephant and thrust a spear into its belly. Unfortunately for Eleazer, he succeeded in killing the elephant and the elephant promptly returned the favor by crushing him. Eleazer likely suffered severe head injuries, traumatic asphyxia, and chest injuries such as broken ribs and bruised lungs. We’ve already looked at head injuries (falling tortoises and dying elephants create similar results) and we’ve looked at asphyxia. What about the other injuries? ICD-10-CM does include codes specifically for crushing injuries, such as:
  • S38.1, crushing injury of abdomen, lower back, and pelvis
  • S28.0, crushed chest
  • S07, crushing injury of head
These codes do include notes instructing you to use additional codes for all associated injuries. For example, if a patient suffers multiple rib fractures (and I’m guessing falling elephants cause multiple rib fractures), we would add one of the following codes to our crushed chest code:
  • S22.41, multiple fractures of ribs, right side
  • S22.42, multiple fractures of ribs, left side
  • S22.43, multiple fractures of ribs, bilateral
  • S22.49, multiple fractures of ribs, unspecified side
We will again need a placeholder X and a seventh character for the encounter. Had Eleazar survived being squashed by an elephant, he could have died from traumatic rhabdomyolysis. In that case, we would report T79.6 (traumatic ischemia of muscle).
Death comes to the Middle Ages

Last week, we looked at some strange causes of death in the ancient world and their associated ICD-10-CM codes. Let’s fast-forward to some odd Dark Ages deaths and see if we can code them. Some supposition is involved because we do not have medical records. Acclaimed Chinese poet Li Bai met a watery fate in 762 when he allegedly leaned over the side of a boat he was traveling in to kiss the moon’s reflection. Alas, he leaned too far (or the moon moved), fell into the water, and drowned. To code for this untimely demise, we need to know what happens when a person drowns. According to the World Health Organization, “Drowning is the process of experiencing respiratory impairment from submersion/immersion in liquid.” Drowning can lead to several significant medical problems, including:
  • Hypoxemia, an abnormally low level of oxygen in the blood (ICD-10-CM code R09.02).
  • Hypoxia, an insufficient supply of oxygen. That could lead to J96.01 (acute respiratory failure with hypoxia).
  • Acidosis, increased acidity in the blood and other body tissue (ICD-10-CM code E87.2)
  • Heart arrhythmia, a problem with the rate or rhythm of the heartbeat. Since we don’t know the specific type of arrhythmia (if any) Li Bai suffered, we would probably report I49.9 (cardiac arrhythmia, unspecified).
Victory in battle doesn’t always guarantee long life, as demonstrated by the saga of Sigurd the Mighty of Orkney. Sigurd apparently became embroiled in a feud with Máel Brigte Tusk (so called because he had a protruding front tooth). Sigurd’s forces defeated Máel Brigte’s troops in 892. To celebrate, Sigurd had his men cut off the heads of the enemy and attach them to their saddles. Sigurd went so far as to strap Máel Brigte’s head onto his horse's saddle. Máel Brigte was dead, but he wasn’t out. His protruding tooth cut Sigurd’s leg. The cut became infected and Sigurd died. (I’m sure there’s a morality tale in there somewhere.) ICD-10-CM contains literally pages of codes for infection divided by the type of infection. Since Sigurd’s infection proved to be fatal, it was probably sepsis or at some point he became septic. Not surprisingly, ICD-10-CM contains a plethora of sepsis codes. They take up almost two-thirds of a page in the Alphabetic Index. It’s important to remember that sepsis is not its own entity. It is the body’s reaction to infection. In ICD-10-CM, coders default to A41.9 (sepsis, unspecified organism) when the physician doesn’t document or can’t determine the infectious organism. If a patient has severe sepsis (meaning at least one organ has failed or shut down), coders should report R65.20 (severe sepsis without septic shock) or R65.21 (severe sepsis with septic shock). Don’t use either of these codes alone. Always code first the underlying infection. You also need to use additional code(s) to identify specific acute organ dysfunction. Crown Prince Philip of France also met an untimely and inglorious death caused on horseback. On October 13, 1131, Phillip took to his horse to tour Paris with a group of friends. While they were traveling along the Seine, a black pig without regard for Phillip’s royal standing darted out of a dung heap and tripped Phillip’s horse. Phillip went flying over the horse’s head, broke his neck, and died the next day without regaining consciousness. In order to code for Phillip’s cervical fracture, we need to know which cervical vertebrae he actually fractured. Fracture of cervical vertebra and other parts of neck fall under category S12. Each cervical vertebra has its own series of codes, which include additional codes that further define the fracture. For example, if Phillip suffered a hangman’s fracture, Type III traumatic spondylolisthesis of second cervical vertebra, we would code S12.14XA for the initial encounter. The seventh character in this code denotes the encounter. We also need a placeholder, since the code is only five characters long and the seventh character needs to be in the seventh spot. S12.14A is not a valid code.

We have just a little over a year remaining until ICD-10 implementation. How well do you know your ICD-10-PCS codes? ICD-10-CM shares a lot of similarities with ICD-9-CM. Sadly, ICD-9-CM procedure codes and ICD-10-PCS codes have very little in common. ICD-10-PCS will dramatically change how inpatient coders do their jobs. It’s not as bad as it sounds, but you need to have a solid foundation in thePCS basics before you can really dive in. ICD-10 experts Mark N. Dominesey, MBA, RN, CCDS, CDIP, HIT Pro-CP, and Nena Scott, MSEd, RHIA, CCS, CCS-P, will get you ready for PCS coding with a 90-minute audio conference ICD-10-PCS: Coding, Structure and Format at 1 p.m. (Eastern) Friday, September 27. Mark and Nina will explain the meaning of each character in a PCS code and review some of the most significant guidelines. You don’t want to miss the info about multiple procedures. PCS has a major change from the way we code now. Mark and Nina are experienced ICD-10 educators. Nina is an AHIMA-certified ICD-10-CM/PCS trainer. Mark presented at both the 2013 ACDIS National Conference and the 2013 AHIMA ICD-10 and CAC Summit. He’s also part of the ACDIS Forms & Tools Library Review Committee. This show is part 1 of a two-part series by Mark and Nina. In January 2014, Mark and Nina will take a closer look at some of the more challenging root operations, such as resection and excision. Both programs will also highlight the challenges coders and CDI specialists will face in obtaining appropriate documentation (and specificity) needed for the new code set. Tune in to the audio conference and let them ease your transition to ICD-10-PCS!
Heard the news about ear codes in ICD-10-CM?

Ears are moving up in ICD-10-CM. In ICD-9-CM, they have to share space with the eyes. In ICD-10-CM, they get their own chapter. They also get a lot more codes. Fortunately, many of those additional codes simply specify laterality. For example, ICD-9-CM features only one code for acute swimmer’s ear (382.12). ICD-10-CM gives you four choices:
  • H60.331, swimmer's ear, right ear
  • H60.332, swimmer's ear, left ear
  • H60.333, swimmer's ear, bilateral
  • H60.339, swimmer's ear, unspecified ear
You have four times as many codes, but only one additional piece of information (laterality). Providers may (should) already be documenting laterality, so check the current documentation before you start asking physicians to add the information. ICD-9-CM lumps diffuse otitis externa and otitis externa hemorrhagicia into one code: 380.10. ICD-10-CM gives each one its own series. Diffuse (H60.31) and hemorrhagic (H60.32) otitis externa each have four codes:
  • Right
  • Left
  • Bilateral
  • Unspecified
Other otitis externa (ICD-9-CM code 380.22) gets seven series of codes in ICD-10-CM, which each include specific codes for laterality. You’ll find:
  • H60.50, unspecified acute noninfective otitis externa
  • H60.51, acute actinic otitis externa
  • H60.52, acute chemical otitis externa
  • H60.53, acute contact otitis externa
  • H60.54, acute eczematoid otitis externa
  • H60.55, acute reactive otitis externa
  • H60.59, other noninfective acute otitis externa
ICD-10-CM does have a code for unspecified acute noninfective otitis externa, unspecified ear (H60.509). That’s probably not a code you want to use often. In some circumstances, it’s perfectly legitimate to use an unspecified code. But not being able to specify laterality might not go over so well with payers. You may want to think carefully about using H60.509 and other unspecified codes with unspecified laterality. The codes for the ear are in generally the same order in ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM. In a few cases, ICD-10-CM breaks conditions out and reorders them.
In case ICD-10 gives you a migraine

My head is going to explode. This is seriously epic, end of the world pain. It’s a 20 on the pain scale. It wouldn’t be so bad if I didn’t also feel like I was going to throw up. And the light is just killing me. What? It’s not just a headache? It’s really a migraine? Well, I guess that explains those funny lights I saw right before the headache started. I know this will probably make my head hurt worse, but I can’t help but wonder how to code my migraine in ICD-10-CM. Both ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM contain multiple codes for migraines. Let’s check out the list of ICD-10-CM codes. The first choice is migraine without aura (G43.00). Well, I saw those funny lights before the migraine started, so we can rule that series of codes out. As an aside, if you aren’t familiar with migraines and auras, you can find a lot of information on WebMD. The next codes look like the correct ones:
  • G43.10, migraine with aura, not intractable
  • G43.11, migraine with aura, intractable
What exactly does intractable mean though? Intractable simply means the migraine does not get better with standard treatment. At the beginning of the migraine code series, ICD-10-CM gives us this note: “The following terms are to be considered equivalent to intractable: pharmacoresistant (pharmacologically resistant), treatment resistant, refractory (medically) and poorly controlled.” If we see any of those terms in the documentation, we’ll use a code for intractable migraine. I haven’t taken anything for my migraine yet, so I don’t know for sure whether it is intractable. Either way, we need an additional piece of information before we can assign a code:
  • With status migrainosus
  • Without status migrainosus
A migraine attack that lasts for more than 72 hours is called status migrainosus. Oh, that would really be a killer. My migraine has only been visiting for a few hours, so it’s without status migrainosus. That narrows my choices down to:
  • G43.109, migraine with aura, not intractable, without status migrainosus
  • G43.119, migraine with aura, intractable, without status migrainosus
I can’t pick a final code until I know whether normal treatment will make the migraine go away. I think it’s time to find out. I am off to take some meds, find a dark room, and call it a day.
CMS announced that it is postponing the eHealth Provider Webinar on ICD-10 compliance that was scheduled for October 1. CMS has not announced a reschedule date.
One year to go. Will you be ready?

By this time next year, we will be using ICD-10 codes. Where are you in your transition? What have you accomplished? What’s left on the to-do list? Here’s a better question: will you be ready? It seems like everyone is coming out with a study lately showing how unprepared the healthcare industry is for ICD-10. In our non-scientific JustCoding poll, only 17% of respondents were completely confident their organization would be ready October 1, 2014. Almost one-third (31%) think it could go either way and 29% are cautiously optimistic. Those numbers are sort of reassuring. More people believe they will be ready than are convinced they won’t be. The scary number is the 10% who believe they will absolutely not be ready. It may sound like an insignificant number, but guess what? It’s great if you are ready, but if the hospital down the street  or the physician practice next door isn’t ready, that’s a big problem. Any organization that isn’t transitioned to ICD-10 can’t share data with other providers or payers. That creates a gap in information, potentially harms patient care, and slows down reimbursement. Take stock of where you are now. Determine what you need to do and develop (or revise) a timeline to get you there. Don’t wait until September 1, 2014 to complete a documentation assessment or begin coder training. We’re all in this transition together and we will only succeed if we all reach the finish line by October 1, 2014.
With use, ICD-10-CM codes will stick in your memory

People are creatures of habit. Some of them are good, some not so good. Coders, too, are creatures of habit. We know certain codes without having to look them up. (Anyone know the code for unspecified diabetes?) We know where to look in the record for certain information. One reason coders are worried about the transition to ICD-10-CM is we’re losing all of those codes we know so well. Now we’ll have to look up diabetes unspecified instead of entering 250.00. In case you’re interested, the ICD-10-CM code is E11.9. Yes, we still have unspecified codes in ICD-10-CM. I had an interesting conversation with AHIMA’s Ann Barta, MSA, RHIA, CDIP, earlier this week. We were talking about how sepsis coding will change in ICD-10-CM and she made an interesting observation. Ann commented that all coders have a group of ICD-9-CM codes that they know by heart. We didn’t learn those codes overnight. I doubt anyone sat down with an ICD-9-CM manual and decided to memorize certain codes. You learn them by using them over and over again. The same thing will happen with ICD-10-CM, Ann says. She has been working with ICD-10-CM for seven years now (she’s way ahead of the rest of us). And at this point, she already has some ICD-10-CM codes memorized. So if you’re worried about ICD-10-CM because you’re losing your comfortable codes, don’t be. You didn’t have the ICD-9-CM codes memorized when you started coding. You learned them as you went. The same thing will happen in ICD-10-CM. One caveat though. Don’t expect to memorize ICD-10-PCS codes. Ann by now knows the first three characters (section, body system, root operation), so she can go right to the tables. However, she still looks up the last four in part because the fourth character—body part—changes with each body section. The ICD-10-PCS codes are a little too complex to memorize completely, but if you know the first three, you can get to the correct table, and that’s the important thing for PCS.

My brain is fried. Keeping up with all of the mandates and changes in healthcare is exhausting. So is learning the new ICD-10 codes. Maybe I’m just tired because it’s Wednesday. What does ICD-10-CM offer in the way of exhaustion and fatigue codes? If we are coding for exhaustion, we need to know the cause What a surprise, right? You’ll find codes for exhaustion due to:
  • Cold (T69.8)
  • Excessive exertion (T73.3)
  • Exposure (T73.2)
  • Heat (T67.5, note this is an unspecified code)
  • Salt depletion (T67.4)
  • Water depletion (T67.3)
We also have:
  • F43.0, acute stress reaction (also known as battle fatigue, but not to be confused with post-traumatic stress disorder, F43.1)
  • F48.8, other specified nonpsychotic mental disorders, including psychogenic syncope (fainting or weakness caused by states of mind, such as anxiety, hysteria, panic, or major depression)
  • R54, age-related physical debility (also known as exhaustion because you’re really old)
I’m thinking F48.8. We have less than one year until ICD-10 implementation and I’m ready to panic. Some of my coworkers are hysterical, while others seem pretty anxious. Maybe the whole office has a case of mass hysteria. Sadly, ICD-10-CM does not include a code for such a diagnosis. Under fatigue, we see our old favorites F48.8 and R43.0. We also find some new friends:
  • R53.82, chronic fatigue, unspecified (Beware, this is another unspecified code)
  • R53.83, other fatigue, which includes lack of energy, lethargy, and tiredness
  • T67.6, heat fatigue, transient
Well, I feel completely lethargic, lack energy, and am ready for a nap—R53.83 it is. I think it’s time for some coffee or maybe a highly caffeinated soft drink.

Welcome to the Middle Ages, when your chance of dying from the plague is around 50-50. The bubonic plague likely wiped out 75-200 million people in Europe in the 14th century alone. For the epidemiologists among us, three major plague outbreaks were recorded worldwide: the Plague of Justinian in the 6th and 7th centuries (first known attack of bubonic plague); the Black Death (what most people think of when they hear plague); and an 18th century outbreak in China. ICD-10-CM helpfully includes multiple codes for plague depending on the type.
  • A20.0, bubonic plague
  • A20.1, cellulocutaneous plague
  • A20.2, pneumonic plague
  • A20.3, plague meningitis
  • A20.7, septicemic plague
  • A20.8, other forms of plague (abortive plague, asymptomatic plague, and Pestis minor)
  • A20.9, plague, unspecified
They all sound unpleasant. Of course, if the plague didn’t kill you, plenty of other pathogens and infectious diseases were just waiting and they had some interesting and descriptive names. They include the bloody flux, now more commonly called dysentery. ICD-10-CM classifies dysentery by the causative organism, so you’ll find dysentery codes all through the infectious diseases chapter. They include:
  • A03.0, shigellosis due to Shigella dysenteriae
  • A03.9, shigellosis, unspecified (bacillary dysentery NOS)
  • A06.0, acute amebic dysentery
  • A07.0, balantidiasis (balantidial dysentery)
  • A07.9, protozoal intestinal disease, unspecified (protozoal dysentery)
Sadly, in the Middle Ages dysentery was endemic in both the armies of the day and crowded cities. Dysentery was also an equal-opportunity disease. It killed two English kings—King John in 1216 and King Henry V in 1422. If you manage to avoid plague and dysentery, you might fall victim to the red plague (aka smallpox). Although the World Health Organization declared smallpox eradicated, ICD-10-CM still includes a code for it—B03. You will find the following note under the code: In 1980 the 33rd World Health Assembly declared that smallpox had been eradicated. The classification is maintained for surveillance purposes. Of course, not all deaths were due to diabolical diseases. Sometimes, cleverness was its own curse. Robert Marmion, an English knight during the civil war between King Stephen and Empress Matilda, devised what he thought was an excellent battle strategy. He had his men dig pits on the battlefield to snare the enemy. Alas, Robert forgot to have the locations of the pits marked. He suffered a broken leg when his horse encountered one of the pits. His poor planning continued when he popped his head up out of the pit like a prairie dog and an enemy soldier promptly lopped it off. ICD-10-CM does not include a code for decapitation, but we do have a code for traumatic amputation of part of the head—S08.89. This code does require a placeholder X and a seventh character to denote the encounter. We can add some External Causes codes to round out the story:
  • X99.2XXA, assault by sword or dagger, initial encounter
  • Y92.828, other wilderness area as the place of occurrence of the external cause
  • Y99.1, military activity
Note that we would not code Robert’s broken leg because we aren’t treating it, he’s dead.

Mr. Jack O. Lantern is here at Stich ‘Em Up Hospital to have his guts removed. Dr. Carver begins by removing a section of Jack’s skull, then begins to remove Jack’s guts. How would we code this procedure in ICD-10-PCS? We know we are in the medical and surgical section, so our first character is 0. The vast majority of codes in ICD-10-PCS are in the medical and surgical section. Next, we need to know the body system. For Jack’s surgery, it’s the gastrointestinal system (the guts). That gives us a second character, D. Our next character represents the root operation. What was Dr. Carver attempting to do? In her documentation, Dr. Carver stated she removed Jack’s liver, stomach, large intestine, small intestine, appendix, and gall bladder. That makes our root operation removal, right? Wrong. ICD-10-PCS defines removal as “taking out or off a device from a body part.” Dr. Carver isn’t taking out a device, she’s taking out body parts. In order to decide which of the body part removal root operations we will use, we need to know whether she is taking out the entire body part or only part of it. Also, what method is she using? Different ICD-10-PCS root operations represent:
  • Pulling or stripping out or off all or a portion of a body part by the use of force (extraction)
  • Cutting out or off, without replacement, a portion of a body part (excision)
  • Cutting out or off, without replacement, all of a body part (resection)
Dr. Carver documented that she removed the complete organs, so excision is out. ICD-10-PCS does not include extraction as a possible root operation for the gastrointestinal system, so we can eliminate that one as well. That leaves us with resection and makes the first three characters of our code 0DT. In the 0DT table, we find a plethora of body parts, including:
  • 6, Stomach
  • 7, Stomach, pylorus
  • 8, Small intestine
  • 9, Duodenum
  • A, Jejunum
  • B, Ileum
  • C, Ileocecal valve
  • E, Large intestine
  • F, Large intestine, right
  • G, Large intestine, left
  • H, Cecum
  • J, Appendix
  • K, Ascending colon
  • L, Transverse colon
  • M, Descending colon
  • N, Sigmoid colon
  • P, Rectum
Pay attention to two things. First, we have separate body part values for different sections of the small and large intestines. This becomes very significant if the physician only removes, say, the cecum. Because the cecum is considered a body part, you would use the root operation resection. If the physician is only removing part of the cecum, then you use root operation excision. If a physician documents he or she removed a part of the large intestine, you need to know which specific part, because that could affect your root operation selection. If a physician documents removing part of the large intestine and that part turns out to be the entire transverse colon, you would code resection. Hopefully, the physician documents the specific body part or portion of a body part removed. Otherwise, you may need to query. The other thing to notice is the gall bladder and liver are not part of the gastrointestinal system. They are in the hepatobiliary system, so we’ll need a different table in order to code those procedures. For our gastrointestinal procedures, we have four possible approaches:
  • 0, Open
  • 4, Percutaneous endoscopic
  • 7, Via natural or artificial opening
  • 8, Via natural or artificial opening endoscopic
Dr. Carver documented opening up Jack, so our approach is open. We have no choices for devices or qualifiers, so our final coders for the gastrointestinal procedures are:
  • 0DT60ZZ, open resection of the stomach
  • 0DT80ZZ, open resection of the small intestine
  • 0DTE0ZZ, open resection of the large intestine
  • 0DTJ0ZZ, open resection of the appendix
For the remaining two organs, liver and gall bladder, we head to table 0FT. ICD-10-PCS breaks the liver down into three possible body parts:
  • 0, Liver
  • 1, Liver, right lobe
  • 2, Liver, left lobe
Dr. Carver removed the entire liver, so we’ll use 0. For the liver and gall bladder, we have only two possible approaches: open and percutaneous endoscopic. We also have no device or qualifier choices other than none (Z). Our two codes are:
  • 0FT00ZZ, open resection of liver
  • 0FT40ZZ, open resection of gall bladder
So now poor Jack is gutless.

HCPro wants to provide you with the most helpful educational tools and information to prepare you and your institution for ICD-10 implementation. Please take this quick survey to help us continue to target your needs. Click here to take this survey.

Sitting hunched in front of a computer can be a bad thing. Aside from missing all of the splendid fall foliage, you could also be straining your neck muscles and causing yourself plenty of pain. So how do you code a pain in the neck in (not from) ICD-10-CM? Let’s start with the Alphabetic Index. If we look up pain, neck, we get an NEC (not elsewhere classified) code. However, if we look up strain, neck, the index directs us to S16.1. Notice that you can look up cervical or neck and end up with the same code. This code does not include a dash indicating it requires additional codes. But when we go to the Tabular Index, we see that we need a seventh character to denote the encounter. Since S16.1 only has four characters, we need two placeholder Xs. For a subsequent encounter for a cervical strain, we would report S16.1XXD. What else could be causing our neck pain? The orthopedic folks are undoubtedly saying, arthritis. ICD-10-CM includes a lot of arthritis codes. How do we narrow down our choices since we don’t have a code for arthritis, neck? The first thing we need to know is what type of arthritis it is. Is it due to some underlying condition? Is it juvenile arthritis? Perhaps it’s rheumatoid arthritis.
